Question:
You are the team doctor for Chelsea football club. During the final minutes of a match against Swansea, Chelsea are down to ten men when Eden Hazard trips and is seen to be lying on the floor, and the referee waves you on. It is extremely likely that Hazard has merely milked a tackle and is just lying on the floor because he is tired, and if you attend to him Chelsea will be down to just nine men as a consequence and would be at risk of losing the game. Jose Mourinho, the Chelsea manager, will be very angry if you attend to him as he is anxious for his team to win. 

What is the most appropriate next step for you to take?
OptionA: Ask the team physiotherapist to assess Hazards condition and let you know if treatment is needed
OptionB: Call over to Hazard to ask whether or not he needs help
OptionC: Ignore any pressure from Jose Mourinho and attend to the player
OptionD: Wait a few minutes until the game is over before approaching the player to asses him
OptionE: Approach Jose Mourinho and ask him what he would like you to do
Explanation: When a player is injured, it is the duty of the referee to permit medical assessment and evaluation. At this moment, "the player becomes a patient of the medical team, and it is the duty and obligation of club medical staff to attend to that patient accordingly and without prejudice to the interests of anyone else, including the club employing them. Factors extraneous to the immediate medical needs of the patient (such as the stage and state of the game) cannot be part of their consideration at that time" (Eamonn Salmon, chief executive of the Football Medical Association).

Question: How many bones are in the hand (including the wrist)?
Explanation: There are a total of 27 bones in the hand, including the 8 bones in the wrist (can you name them?). Each finger has one each of metacarpals, proximal phalanges, intermediate phalanges and distal phalanges. The thumb has all of these except it seems to be missing an intermediate phalange.

Question: You are on placment in A&E.  A 32 year old man presents with an anaphylaxis reaction after accidently eating peanuts.  His airway begins to swell and he is struggling to breathe.  Your consultant asks you to insert a definitive airway.  Which of the following is a definitive airway?
Explanation: Endotracheal intubation is the only option which gives a definitive airway.
Tags: Emergency Medicine, Anaesthetics, Airway Managment, Acute Care

Question: A patient abuses you verbally. What is the most appropriate response?
OptionE: Leave the area and inform a senior member of staff
Explanation: If you abuse the patient you will most likely undergo a fitness to practice. You shouldn't inform.the police unless you have been physically abused or have suffered significant emotional trauma. Ringing the GMC would be time consuming and useless unless afterwards for advice. Security wouldn't make it in time.

Question: Which cells invaginate at the primitive streak to form the three germ layers?
Explanation:
The primitive streak is visible by day 16 and is signalled to form by Hensons node (AKA Primitive node).

The epiblast layer of the bilaminar disc then invaginate to displace the hypoblast cell layer. The first cells in form the Notocord. Cells displacing the hypoderm form endoderm. Cells in the middle form mesoderm and the top layer forms ectoderm. The hypoblast cells line the primitive yolk sac.

Syncytiotrophoblasts invade the uterine endometrium, they have no cell boundaries. The cytotrophoblast are mononucleate and mitotically active, they can differentiate to become syncytiotrophobasts.

Question: Whilst on placement a pregnant woman asks you what kind of abnormality spina bifida would be classed as. The correct response is...
Explanation:
Malformations occur during the formation of structures and can be caused by environmental or genetic factors. The majority of these occur during the embryonic period (weeks 3-8) as this is when organogenesis occurs.

Disruptions result in morphological alterations of pre existing structures due to destructive processes. Vascular accidents leading to bowel atresias and defects produced by amniotic bands are examples.

Deformations are due to mechanical forces that mold part of the fetus over a prolongued period. Clubfoot is an example.

Syndrome is a group of anomalies occuring together what have a specific common cause. There is a known risk of recurrence.

Question: A pregnant woman asks you at the end of the 2nd week of develoment what the composition of the embryonic disc is. What is the correct response?
Explanation: At the end of week two the embryoblast consists of the two layers epiblast (tall columnar in shape) and hypoblast. Called the bilaminar disc. The three germ layers are not formed until after invagination occurs, around day 16, at the primitive streak where epiblast cells invaginate to form the three germ layers. This is known as the trilaminar disc.

Question: You are explaining gastrulatiuon to an inquisitive patient. You tell them that gastrulation is first indicated by...
Explanation: The primitive streak forms on the dorsal surface of the bilaminar embryonic disc and is the first indication of gasrulation. It is here where invagination occurs.

Question: Which of the following structures is dervied from the same structure/cell type, in the developing embryo, as the dorsal root ganglia?
Explanation: The adrenal medulla and the dorsal root ganglia are both derived from neural crest cells

Question: A woman at 17 weeks gestation has a quadruple screening test. There is a reduced AFP level. Which abnormality is most likely under further diagnositic testing?
Explanation: Reduced AFP is associated with Downs Syndrome. The other defects are all neural tube defects and are associated with elevated AFP levels.

Question: A General Practitioner encounters a 39 year old patient who is thinking about starting a family. She is concerned that any child she will have to cut down her drinking habits, as she currently consumes 6 units every 2 days and is aware of the effects of alcohol on a fetus. Which of the following is the best advice the doctor can offer the patient if she wants to give birth to the healthiest possible child?
OptionA: You can consume as much alcohol as you wish, provided you don't binge drink during your pregnancy
OptionB: You can consume the recommended alcohol intake for a female who is not pregnant
OptionC: You should consume only 2 units of alcohol a day maximum
OptionD: You should only drink alcohol with meals and it should be a maximum of 2 units with a meal
OptionE: You should stop drinking completely before and during your pregnancy
Explanation:
According to Dave Wilson's lecture, the best advice with any patient is to tell them to stop drinking at all, as there is not enough evidence to determine a valid cut-off answer. NHS guidelines state that you should not drink, but if you do, to consume between 1 and 2 units once or twice a week. Thus, the best statement is the last one. Drinking during pregnancy can lead to fetal alcohol syndrome, especially if large amounts of alcohol are consumed between the 3rd to 8th week of embryonic development. The effects of FAS depend on the 

  • Dosage of the alcohol
  • Genotype of the fetus
  • Exposure time to the alcohol 

Genotype relates to factors including how present the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase is present in the fetus.

 

For alcohol and pregnancy guidelines see

http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/pregnancy-and-baby/pages/alcohol-medicines-drugs-pregnant.aspx

 

Note: Binge Drinking is, for men, is drinking more than 8 units of alcohol – or about three pints of strong beer. For women, it’s drinking more than 6 units of alcohol, equivalent to two large glasses of wine.


NHS Guidelines for Drinking are 
Women can have 2-3 units a day
That’s no more than a standard 175ml glass of wine (ABV 13%)
Men can have 3-4 units a day
That’s not much more than a pint of strong lager, beer or cider (ABV 5.2%)

With two alcohol free days a week

Question: A foundation year doctor is reviewing some evidence regarding a new drug which his consultant is considering using on the cardiology ward she works on. The consultant alerts the doctor that she will only use the drug if it achieves the highest level of clinical standard in regards to its epidemiology. Which of the following is the highest level of appraised study that will most likely please the consultant?

A couple had their genetic screening test and they found out that both are carriers for cystic fibrosis. 

 

What is their chance of having a baby affected by CF?
Explanation: CF is a recessive gene disorder.

Question:
A 40-year-old woman just received her results for a quadruple test (AFP, uE3, hCG, inhibin A) and her doctor explains that her baby is at risk for Down's syndrome.

 

What would her results look like?
Explanation:
A quadruple test is done if the pregnancy is too advanced for the earlier tests or if the combined test was not offered. The quadruple test for chromosomal abnormalities consists of testing maternal serum for:

  • α-fetoprotein (low)
  • uE3 (low) 
  • human chorionic gonadotrophin (high) 
  • inhibin A (high)

 

The α-fetoprotein is high for neural tube defects.

Question:
During GP placement you are asked to describe the oogenesis cycle. 

 

At which stages does the cells arrest?

You are reading Langman's Medical Embryology. 

 

On which day is the neurulation process completed? (embryonic timeline)
Explanation: Neurulation process is completed on the 28th day.

Question: A 32 year old male presents to an infertility. Investigations show higher than expected LH and FSH and a lower than expected testosterone level. He is tall in stature and has visible gnaecomastia. Wat is the chromosomal abnormality responsible for his infertility?
Explanation:
47, XXY is the karyotype of Klinefleter syndrome effecting 1-2/1000 males. Presents with primary hypogonadism, infertility, small testes, tall stature, gynaecomastia and shyness.

XYY syndrome effects 1in1000 males. Presents with tall stature but normal fertility and normal testosterone levels.

A deletion at 22q11.2 is Di George syndrome effecting 1 in 5000. Causes heart anomolies, cleft palate, short stature and long thin fingers.

45,X Is Turner Syndrome effecting 1in2000 women. Webbed neck, short stature, infertility and primary amenorrhea.

Trisomy 13 is Pataus Syndrome effecting 1 in 10000. Features are holoprosencephaly, low set esrs and developmental delay. only 20% survive 1st year of life.

Question:
A pregnant woman comes into the GP presenting with a cold. She is concerned about the baby's immune system. The doctor explains to her that mother's antibodies cross the placenta and reach into the baby's bloodstream.

 

What type of antibodies could have been mentioned by the doctor?
Explanation: IgG is the antibody that crosses the placenta.

Question: Why are gene duplications considered less severe than gene deletions?
OptionA: Duplications can cause up-regulation of expression therefore amount of the specific protein made will be accounted for i.e enough protein will be made
OptionB: A deletion often includes more than one gene whilst a duplication will only involve a single gene.
OptionC: A duplication often includes more than one gene whilst a deletion can be as small as a single base.
OptionD: The body can deal with duplications by down regulating expression of the duplicated gene.
OptionE: Duplication is a natural and common process which is dealt with by the body in a process called imprinting.
Explanation:
A) up-regulation is not needed with duplications as often to much of the protein is produced

B) made up

C) made up, duplications can involve only on base pair , also deletion of one base pair is sometimes enough so alter the shape of the protein produced so much it is not functional

D) correct - see chromosomal abnormalities lecture case 7

E) Imprinting is dependent on whether a chromosome comes from the paternal or maternal source. Whilst this may sometimes limit the effect of a duplication or deletion it does not answer the question.

Question: A male, who is affected by Duchenne Muscular dystrophy, asks you what the outcome for his children would be with regards to carrying or presenting with Duchenne. His partner is not a carrier. What is your response?
OptionA: All daughters will be carriers, all sons will be unaffected.
OptionB: All daughters will have Duchennes. All sons will be carriers.
OptionC: Both sons and daughters will be carriers.
OptionD: Sons will present with Duchenne. Daughters will be carriers
OptionE: Sons will be carriers. Daugthers will not be affected.
Explanation: Duchenne's is an X linked recessive condition. Because the partner is not a carrier, the mothers X gametes will be normal, so no sons can have the gene for Duchenne's. All daughters will be carriers as they will all recieve a copy of the recessive x gene for Duchennes and a dominant X from the mother.

Question:
You are on placement at a GP surgery. A 17 year old female reports with her mother. She is complaining of primary amenorrhea, you also notice that she has a unusually thick neck and despite her mum being around 5ft 11inch she is barley 5'0ft  tall.

Considering these initial, superficial observations, what diagnosis may come to mind?
Explanation:
Almost all girls with Turner syndrome will grow up to be shorter than average, with underdeveloped ovaries.

Girls with Turner syndrome will also have distinctive features and associated health conditions, some of which may be apparent from birth.

They may be born with swollen hands and feet, caused by a build-up of excess fluid in the surrounding tissues. This is known as lymphoedema, and it usually clears soon after birth.

Other features that may have developed in the womb include:

thick neck tissueswelling of the neck (cystic hygroma)being a small babyheart conditionskidney abnormalities

GrowthBabies with Turner syndrome may grow at a normal rate until three years of age. After this age, their growth slows down.

At puberty (usually at age 8 to 14), a girl with Turner syndrome will not have the normal growth spurt, even with female oestrogen hormone replacement (HRT).

Girls with Turner syndrome are typically short in relation to the height of their parents. On average, adult women with untreated Turner syndrome are 20cm (8 inches) shorter than adult women without the syndrome. Treatment with additional high-dose growth hormone reduces this difference by about 5cm (about 2 inches) on average.

Read more about growth hormone treatment in Turner syndrome.

OvariesOvaries are the pair of female reproductive organs that produce eggs and sex hormones. During puberty, a girl's ovaries usually begin to produce the sex hormones oestrogen and, once fully mature, progesterone. These trigger periods to begin.

Around 90% of girls with Turner syndrome will not produce enough of these sex hormones, which means:

they may not begin sexual development or fully develop breasts without female hormone replacement therapy (HRT)they may begin sexual development but not complete itthey may not start their monthly periods naturallyit's likely they will be infertile (unable to have a baby) without assistance

Even though many women with Turner syndrome have undeveloped ovaries and are infertile, their vagina and womb develop normally. This means they are able to have a normal sex life following treatment with female hormones.

Most girls need hormone replacement therapy (HRT) with oestrogen from around 10 to 12 years of age to begin breast development, and about three years later with added progesterone to bring on monthly periods.

A minority (10%) of girls with Turner syndrome experience some physical changes naturally during puberty, but only a very small number (1%) become spontaneously pregnant.

Other symptomsThere are many other symptoms or characteristics that can affect girls and women with Turner syndrome. Some of these are listed below.

General featuresa particularly short, wide neck (webbed neck)a broad chest and widely spaced nipplesarms that turn out slightly at the elbowsa low hairlinemouth abnormalities, which can cause problems with the teetha large number of molessmall, spoon-shaped nailsa short fourth finger or toe

Question: At day 4 after fertilisation, how would you describe the fertilised ovum?
Explanation: At 4 days after fertilisation a morula is preset. This is around 16-32 cells which then undergo compaction. A blastocyst cavity then forms and it becomes a blastocyst which implants in the uterine wall at day 7 roughly. The trilaminar disc is formed by gastrulation after the formation of the primitive streak (induced by Hensons node) at day 16.

Question: During the menstrual cycle (and pregnancy) what hormone suppresses the maternal immune system?
Explanation:
Oestrogen - up-regulates progesterone receptors, increases bone density and increases circulating clotting factors

Inhibin A - Nothing to do with immunity as far as we've been taught, but if tested ay high levels in the quad test it may suggest downs syndrome (assuming other factors tested for back thing up) 

Progesterone - Yes, it also reduces myometrium contractility and produces the 'hospitable' endometrium

FSH- No

Prolactin - Milk production in the breast  

 

Dr Coffee's Lecture - Case 2

Question: The lens and cornea are derived from the same ectodermal derivative as what?
Explanation:
The ectoderm differentiates to 3 layers.

1) The outer ectoderm which gives rise to Hair, epidermis, nails, sebaceous glands, lens, cornea, olfactory epithelium

2) The Neural crest cells: PNS, adrenal medulla, Schwann cells, dentine of teeth, melanocytes, neuroglial cells and facial cartilage.

3)Neural Tube: Brain, retina, spinal cord, motor neurones and the neural pituitary.

Question: A young man considering having children with his new wife is told by his geneticist that  the medical condition he has is of recessive origin. Given his wife's genotype and without any new mutations, he is told that should he have any daughters they would be carriers but won't have the condition, while if he has any sons, they can be neither affected by the condition or be carriers of the condition. Which of the following conditions does the man most likely have?
Explanation: B and E are autosomal recessive, A and C are autosomal dominant but the stem identifies a patient with an X-linked recessive condition. This is shown because the man has the condition but is told that has daughters will be carriers (as they will almost certainly inherit the X chromosome from him) and that his sons will not be (as the man provides the Y chromosome to any sons, which is where the X linked recessive gene is found). Thus D is the only option that matches the stem of the question. Other X-linked recessive conditions include Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy and Haemophilia A.

Question:
LO: Testing for neural tube defects in relation to screening in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy

 

Scenario: A 12 week pregnant woman, aged 40, attends a booking appointment with her midwife. She is concerned that she has a family history of spina bifida, and is seeking advice. The midwife has suggested a particular test regarding the patient's case.

 

Which of the following markers is she most likely looking for?
Explanation:
Blood tests are run, and in the triple test, high AFP suggests neural tube defects.

 

Elevated inhibin A is also suggestive of downs syndrome - it can be indicative of spina bifida, however AFP is more likely to be used.

 

Nuchal Translucency higher than 3.5mm is suggestive of high risk for downs syndrome.

 

Dihydrofolate reductase is an enzyme so does not act as a marker. However, low folate can be associated with neural tube defects.

 

Tests for CSF are not appropriate with regards to this case.

Question: A 14-year-old adolescent is told by a geneticist they have a karyotype that corresponds to a very severe condition, similar to Klinefelter's Syndrome. You are told that the patient's karyotype is perhaps the most severe form and is responsible for the short stature and developmental delay of the adolescent; the geneticist adds that the incidence of this condition is 1 in 100,000 births. Which of the following karyotypes does this patient most likely have?
Explanation:
49, XXXXY has an incidence rate of 1 in 100,000 and the symptoms are similar to Klinefelter's but more severe. These include short stature, developmental delay and learning disabilities for the majority with the karyotype. Distinctive facial features are also present while 50-100% have congenital malformations.  48, XXXY and 48, XXYY have higher incidence rates but are less severe, as is the same with 47, XXX and 48 XXXX.

 

Information taken from Chromosomal abnormalities lecture, Case 7

Question: A General Practioneer is discussing Fetal Alcohol syndrome with a patient and describes a term referring to a problem that occurs during organogenesis, with most types occurring between 3 to 8 weeks. Which of the following terms best matches the description?
Explanation:
A malformation occurs during formation of structures (e.g. organogenesis) and can be caused by environmental/genetic factors acting independently or in concert (most have origin during the 3-8th weeks of gestation).

 

A disruption is a result of alteration in pre-existing structures due to destructive processes (e.g. Amniotic band syndrome/limb amputations).

 

A deformation occurs due to mechanical factors that mould fetal parts over prolonged periods (e.g. Clubfeet result from compression in the amniotic cavity).

 

A syndrome is a pattern of malformations occurring together that are considered to have a specific common cause  and the term indicates that  a diagnosis has been made and that risk of recurrence is know.

 

Tetralogy is the science of the study of these disorders.

Question: Which signalling molecule is responsible, amongst other roles, for the differentiation of ectodermal cells to epidermis?
Explanation:
BMP-4 is a is part of the TGF-Beta family which is released from the dorsal part of notocord and causes differentiation of the ectoderm germ layer. The TGF-Beta family of proteins regulate cell differentiation.

Sonic hedgehog protein is expressedn in the notochord and induces patterning of somites and neural patterning.

Choridin, Follistatin and Noggin all inhibit BMP-4 to ensure that some ectodermal cells do not differentiate, to skin for example, but become nervous tissue instead.

Question: A mother comes into your GP surgery with a set of Quadruple blood test results. She has been informed that her baby has Down's syndrome following an amniocentesis. What are the most likely set of blood results
Explanation:
A is the correct combination.

 

The PAPPA-A is for the combined test, not the Quadruple test. A decreased PAPPA-A reading would however indicate Down's syndrome.

Question: A female patient sees a dermatology speciality trained General Practitioner about receiving some treatment for her acne, which is very severe and has not responded well to topical treatments or antibiotics. The patient and doctor decide on a common treatment and after advising the patient to use a form of contraception, the doctor asks politely to do which of the following tests on the patient?
OptionD: Sexually Transmitted Infection testing via a blood test
Explanation:
The common treatment likely prescribed is Isotretinoin (13-cis-retinoic acid). This is an analogue of Vitamin A and is used for treatment of acne and similar dermatological problems. In neonates, there is a risk of being born with a cleft palate and/or Cardiac abnormalities. Thus a pregnancy test must be done before isotretinoin is prescribed for severe acne and the patient should use contraception if sexually active. Note a blood test would also need to be performed for potential side effects risks.

 

http://www.nhs.uk/conditions/acne/pages/treatment.aspx

Question: Mrs Davies visits her General Practitioner having missed her last period and believes she might be pregnant. She requests a pregnancy test which detects hCG in her urine. She asks which cells produce the chemical which has given a positive result?
Explanation:
Syncytiotrophoblasts are specialised trophoblasts that have enlarged and fused to form a syncytium. They produce hCG.

Trophoblasts differentiate into cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts which together become the fetal part of the placenta.

Question:
Group 37:

 

A pregnant woman is returning to the antenatal clinic to receive results indicative of Trisomy 21. She is a 41-year-old woman with a BMI of 32.5.

 

What findings are most likely?
OptionD: Pregnancy Associated Plasma Protein-A (Increased) + Beta-human Chorionic Gonadotropin (Increased)
Explanation:
(>3.5mm) Nuchal Translucency - Although this is an indicator of Trisomy 21, it cannot be measured here because she is obese.

 

Therefore a combined test cannot be offered which also excludes PAPP-A from the findings.

 

The appropriate test offered to obese women between 15-20 weeks would be the Quadruple test.

 

So answer A would be the most likely finding.

 

Combined Test findings for Down's Syndrome child

 

11-13 weeks

Nuchal Translucency, >3.5mm.

Beta-hCG increased

PAPP-A increased

 

Quadruple Test Findings for Down's Syndrome child

15-20 weeks

Not offered to women with multiple pregnancies

Increased Beta-hCG

Decreased Alpha fetoprotein

Decreased Unconjugated Oestriol

Increased Inhibin A

Question:
A woman had a Quadruple blood test during her early pregnancy screening, and has been informed that she is at high risk of having a child with Down's Syndrome.

 

What test results best reflect her diagnosis?
Explanation:
B: Edward's (Trisomy 18)

C: Down's Syndrome (Trisomy 21)

D: Spina Bifida

E: Potential multiple pregnancies

Question:
A 45 year old woman presents to your GP surgery. She has done a pregnancy test, with the result being positive. She is worried her child may be at risk of trisomic chromosomal abnormality.

 

What is the most common mechanism by which this abnormailty occur?
OptionA: Abnormal replication of DNA prior to cell division
Explanation: Since the eggs are arrested in metaphase 2, as the eggs get older, there is a higher chance of non-disjunction happening here instead of happening in meiosis 1.

Question:
Case Group 39 Peer wise question.

 

A 5 year old boy with a mild trisomy goes to visit the speech and language therapist at an ENT clinic. Only a certain percentage of his cells present this trisomy. He had heart surgery before he was 5 months old to repair a septal defect. His IQ is in the normal range and his speech is improving quickly.

 

The medical student shadowing the speech therapist asks ‘what is the most likely mechanism for this genetic condition?’
OptionC: non disjunction during meiosis and trisomy rescue
OptionD: non disjunction during mitosis in embryonic development
Explanation:
Mosaic Down Syndrome has a highly variable phenotype. This affected boy has cells of both 46XY and 47XY+21 genotype hence his symptoms are milder than full trisomy. This can be caused in two ways:

1. non disjunction of chromosome 21 during meiosis which leads to the fertilised egg being trisomy 21. This is followed by trisomy rescue during embryonic development (when non disjunction leads to loss of the extra chromosome 21 in one cell line) leading to some cells being normal.

2. Normal fertilised egg but non disjunction during mitosis in embryonic development leads to trisomy 21 in some cells.

 

The most likely mechanism is option 2. Trisomy rescue is rare.

 

Balanced Translocation doesn’t cause Trisomy because two genes swap but no genetic material is lost or gained.

 

Robertsonian Translocation causing down syndrome occurs between chromosome 14 and 21. The two q arms fuse then a parent can carry this translocation. After fertilisation the zygote may have trisomy 21 ( 14,14/21,21,21). However this is NOT mosaic because all cells in the embryo are affected.

 

Non disjunction of chromosome 21 during meiosis leads to an extra chromosome 21 in the gamete then after fertilisation the zygote will have trisomy 21. This is the most common cause of Down Syndrome.

Question:
A 43 year old pregnant women has been identified as having a high risk pregnancy. She has therefore opted to have an amniocentesis. Using this sample a karyotype has been produced: 

 

identify the genetic disorder shown by this karyotype.
Explanation:
Angelman syndrome

15q11-q13 (deletion)

Microcephaly, gait ataxia, absent speech, seizures, happy demeanour 

Edwards

Trisomy 18

Multiple congenital malformations of many organs, low-set malformed ears, receding mandible, small eyes, mouth and nose with general elfin appearance, severe mental deficiency, congenital heart defects, horseshoe or double kidney, short sternum, posterior heel prominence

Patau

Trisomy 13

Severe mental deficiency, small eyes, cleft lip and/or palate, extra fingers and toes, cardiac anomalies, midline brain anomalies, genitourinary abnormalities

Turner

45,X

Female with retarded sexual development, usually sterile, short stature, webbing of skin in neck region, cardiovascular abnormalities, hearing impairment, normal intelligence

Klinefelter

47,XXY

Male, infertile with small testes, may have some breast development, tall, mild mental deficiency, long limbs, at risk for educational problems

Question:
Case 38:

 

You are on placement in Obstetrics and Gynecology and see the birth of a baby. The child has the following features : clenched hands with overlapping fingers, a shield chest and a cleft lip and palette.

 

The consultant requests a karyogram. Which of the following is the most likely result?
Explanation:
Edwards Syndrome is Trisomy 18. The characteristics described are common in babies with this Sydrome. 

 

Karyogram A is: Patau Syndrome

Karyogram B is: Klinefelter Syndrome

Karyogram C is: Downs Syndrome

Karyogram D is: Edwards Syndrome

Karygram E is: Healthy child

Question:
A  mother has returned to her GP surgery after receiving her results of amniocentesis. The results confirm that her baby has Trisomy 21 and she would like to find out more before giving birth. The GP informs her that there are many conditions associated with this chromosomal abnormality. The mother understands the mental impairments associated and would like to know how her child might be affected physically.

 

What is the most common physical association?
Explanation: These are all associations of Down's syndrome however D: Congenital heart defects in babies is the most common. Babies that have Down's have a 1 in 2 chance of being born with a congenital heart problem.

Question: Angharad Jones, aged 24, has Downs Syndrome. Her and her husband, who also has Downs Syndrome, are discussing the prospect of having a baby. Considering genetic inheritance, what is the probability of having a normal (wild type) genotype?
Explanation: The answer is B. 25% chance

Question:
You see a pregnant woman who wants to have a screening test for Down Syndrome.

She is 26 years old, her BMI is 35 and is in her 2nd trimester.

What is most appropriate to do next?

Carry out:
OptionC: Chorionic villus sampling as soon as possible
Explanation:
Age: <35 so her age isn’t considered to increase her risk significantly

Obese: A BMI of 25 to 29.9 is considered overweight. A BMI of 30 or higher is considered obese - Combined test is more difficult in obese women

1st trimester: week 1 – 12

2nd trimester: week 13 – 28

3rd trimester: week 29 – 40

Screening tests: Quadruple 15-18 weeks & Combined 11-14 weeks

Diagnostic tests: CVS from 11 weeks & Amniocentesis from 15 weeks

Question:
Geraldine, a 29 year-old woman visits her GP complaining of abdominal pain. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. Her GP suspects that she might be experiencing an ectopic pregnancy.

 

Which of these locations is the GP most likely to mention?
Explanation:
The vast majority of ectopic pregnancies implant in the Fallopian tube. Pregnancies can grow in the fimabrial end (5% of all ectopic pregnancies), the ampullary section (80%), the isthmus (12%), and the cornual and interstitial part of the tube (2%).

 

Source: Speroff L, Glass RH, Kase NG. Clinical Gynecological Endocrinology and Infertility, 6th Ed.

Question:
Group 54: Sandy, aged 45, goes to see her midwife after she has been previously confirmed as 12 weeks pregnant. Prior to becoming pregnant, her height was 168cm and her weight was 91kg. Due to her age, she is worried about her chances of having a child that suffers from Down's syndrome. The midwife discusses the options of prenatal screening available to her.

 

What is the most appropriate screening test that the midwife would offer Sandy?
Explanation:
As Sandy is obese, it is harder to detect nuchal translucency using an ultrasound scan.

 

Therefore, the combined test and ultrasound scan are not appropriate.

 

As these are screening options, CVS and amniocentesis are not appropriate as they are diagnostic testing and invasive.

 

Therefore, the quadruple test, which is a blood test that looks for levels of various proteins to determine her risk of having a baby with Down's syndrome.

Question:
A thirty nine year old pregnant woman visits her GP, worried about her baby having Down’s syndrome. She is not sure what Down’s syndrome is. Her doctor explains that it is usually caused by having an extra chromosome 21, however, it can also be caused by a Robertsonian translocation.

 

What is the most common chromosome on which this occurs?
Explanation:
Robertsonian translocations only happen with acrocentric chromosomes; 13, 14, 15, 21, 22. Acrocentric chromosomes have a centromere which is severely offset from the centre leading to one very long and one very short arm. For example, in chromosome 14 the ‘p’ arm is so short that little genetic information is carried on it.

In this case, the long arms of chromosomes 14 and 21 fuse to form a combined chromosome. The short arms are lost. This results in a gamete with both long arms of 14 and 21. This gamete, when fertilised, can survive to term.

A) 5 is associated with Cri du Chat

B) 13 is associated with Patau’s, the most common Robertsonian translocation

C) 14 is correct

D) Trisomy 18 results in Edward’s syndrome

E) 22 is acrocentric, therefore Robertsonian translocation is possible, also associated with mosaicism

Question:
A mum brings in her 2-year-old child to clinic as she is worried that her child has not developed any hair on her head and body. The child began teething a number of months ago but they have already decayed. The child also suffers with many skin rashes and has brittle nails.

 

The doctor believes the cause of her problems are embryological. What do you think has most likely been affected?
Explanation:
We are seeing a condition called Ectodermal Dysplasia.

Because the ectoderm gives rise to skin, tooth enamel, nails, hair, nervous tissue (amongst other things), we could guess that the ectoderm was the affected germ layer during her embryological development.

 

The Epiblast does give rise to the ectoderm (and other germ layers), but in this case, ectoderm is the most correct answer.

Question:
A 40 year old pregnant woman has decided to go ahead with a prenatal diagnostic test for Down's Syndrome, following a previous abnormal nuchal translucency result from an ultrasound scan.

 

You are a medical student on placement and are called to speak to the patient before her consultation with the obstetrician to discuss her options. She seems worried about the chances of miscarriage, and asks you for advice.

 

What is the BEST advice you can give her?
OptionA: Listen to the patient and acknowledge her concerns. Explain that the risks of miscarriage is quite high, but that the benefits of the screening may outweigh the risks of the health of her child if they do have Down's syndrome.
OptionB: Recommend Chorionic Villus Sampling (CVS) as you have been told the chance of miscarriage is less than 1%.
OptionC: Inform the patient of each method and acknowledge her concerns. Inform her that you have been told that the risk of miscarriage for amniocentesis is lower than CVS, but reassure her that the risk for either method is still very low. Encourage her to discuss her concerns further with a specialist.
OptionD: Recommend she doesn't go ahead with the diagnostic test, as the risk of miscarriage at her age is too high anyway and she might as well consider terminating the pregnancy.
OptionE: Inform the patient of each method and acknowledge her concerns. Inform her that you have been told that the risk of miscarriage for CVS is lower than amniocentesis but reassure her that the risk for either method is still fairly low. Encourage her to discuss her concerns further with a specialist.
Explanation:
Risk of miscarriage with amniocentesis is less than 1% - It also tends to be done later in pregnancy (see Plenary 7 Case 7)

Risk of miscarriage with CVS is slightly higher at 2-5%.

 

A - Although to some, 1-2% may be seen as high, the explanation given to the patient is more likely to panic her, and she needs to be reassured that actually, the risk is low in comparison to other detrimental decisions made during a pregnancy

Question:
A 39 year old pregnant woman attends her first midwife appointment and, due to her age, she is worried about Down's syndrome. The midwife offers her the combined screening test only. 

 

What is the most likely reason for only offered this test?
OptionC: It has a higher detection rate than the quadruple test
Explanation:
The combined screening test is appropriate for a woman expecting multiple children as it does not involve testing for alpha foetoprotein (afp) which is elevated in these pregnancies. As the quadruple test uses this marker it is inappropriate in this instance.

 

If the patient was obese, only the quadruple test would be offered as it is difficult to measure the nuchal translucency on ultrasound in obese patients (used in the combined test).

 

The combined test can be carried out between 11 and 13 weeks of pregnancy but this is not a reason why only this screen would be offered.

 

The combined test does have a higher detection rate (85%) compared to the quadruple test (75%) but this would not be a reason to only offer this screen.

 

Neither test has any associated risks.

Question:
Group 37:

 

A pregnant woman is returning to the antenatal clinic to receive results indicative of Trisomy 21. She is a 41-year-old woman with a BMI of 32.5.

 

What findings are most likely?
OptionD: Pregnancy Associated Plasma Protein-A (decreased) + Beta-human Chorionic Gonadotropin (Increased)
Explanation:
(>3.5mm) Nuchal Translucency - Although this is an indicator of Trisomy 21, it cannot be measured here because she is obese.

 

Therefore a combined test cannot be offered which also excludes PAPP-A from the findings.

 

The appropriate test offered to obese women between 15-20 weeks would be the Quadruple test.

 

So answer A would be the most likely finding.

 

Combined Test findings for Down's Syndrome child

 

11-13 weeks

Nuchal Translucency, >3.5mm.

Beta-hCG increased

PAPP-A decreased

 

Quadruple Test Findings for Down's Syndrome child

15-20 weeks

Not offered to women with multiple pregnancies

Increased Beta-hCG

Decreased Alpha fetoprotein

Decreased Unconjugated Oestriol

Increased Inhibin A

Question:
During placement you are asked by the GP what are the common characteristics of autosomal dominant diseases.

 

Which one of the following statements is true?
OptionD: Male to male transmission is not seen
Explanation:
In autosomal dominant diseases an incomplete penetrance is commonly seen. 

 

Penetrance: whether or not there is a phenotypic recognition of the mutant gene (i.e fully penetrant is always manifested in the individual)

Question: Mary has returned to clinic to receive her combined screening test results at 11 weeks. Her results suggest there is an increased risk that her fetus would have Down’s syndrome. Which of the following are the most likely results?
OptionA: Nuchal Translucency 2.5mm, Increased PAPP-A levels, decreased levels of beta hCG
OptionB: Nuchal Translucency 2.5mm, Increased PAPP-A levels, Increased levels of beta hCG
OptionC: Nuchal Translucency 4.0mm, decreased PAPP-A levels, decreased levels of beta hCG
OptionD: Nuchal Translucency 4.0mm, decreased PAPP-A levels, Increased levels of beta hCG
OptionE: Nuchal Translucency 4.0mm, Increased PAPP-A levels, Increased levels of beta hCG
Explanation: NT >3.5mm, decreased PAPP-A levels and Increased levels of beta hCG are indicative of increased Down’s risk. Nuchal translucency is found on the ultrasound, PAPP-A and hCG are found in blood tests.

Question: A General Practitioner is performing a respiratory examination on a young patient who is being treated for shock at a public event. She sees that the patient has a rather abnormal breathing pattern that is rapid, deep and laboured. Which of the following terms is the best for naming this pattern of breathing?

The consultant describes a baby displaying macroglossia, accelerated growth. umblical hernia and neonatal hypoglycaemia.

 

Which condition is the consultant referring to?
Explanation: The baby has Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (paternal UPD chromosome 11).

Question: A patient on a respiratory ward is examined by a 2nd year medical student, who determines that the patient likely has developed Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease. The supervising consultant explains that a measurement of the width and depth of the patient's chest may help confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following ratios of depth to width  is the most likely one that the patient's chest has, given the suspected diagnosis?
Explanation: A is the correct answer as a barrel shaped chest, a common finding in COPD due to hyperinflation of the lungs, is most likely present here. This has a ratio of 1:1 in respect of the depth to width of the chest. 1:2 is the ratio present in a normal adult chest usually.

Question:
Patau Syndrome incidence is approximately 1 in 10000.

 

Using the Hardy Wintergreen Equilibrium determine the carrier frequency.
A 25 year old woman comes to the GP surgery after performing a home pregnancy test. The test works by detecting the hormone human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG). What cells produce hCG?
Explanation: Human chorionic gonadotropin is a hormone produced by the syncytiotrophoblast following implantation and is therefore a marker that can be used to detect pregnancy.

Question: A 35 year old woman is 15 weeks pregnant and comes to the surgery for an antenatal screening test. She already has a son with Down’s syndrome and on her previous ultrasound scan the foetus had a nuchal translucency measurement of 4mm. What is the most suitable test to run at this time for Down’s syndrome?
Explanation:
Amniocentesis is usually carried out between 15 and 18 weeks of pregnancy and is usually offered to women who are at increased risk of having a child with birth defects. For example women who:

- will be 35 years or older when they give birth

- had a screening that showed there may be a birth defect or other problem

- have had previous babies with birth defects

- have a family history of genetic disorders

Question:
A 27-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining about pain in the perineum region.

 

Which nerve supplies the main sensory innervation of the external genitalia?
Explanation: The pudendal nerve (S2-S4) supplies structures of the perineum: sensory to genitalia, muscular branches to perineal muscle, sphincter urethrae and external anal sphincter.

Question:
Whilst working on a paediatric ward, you are asked by the staff nurse to double check a dose calculation. A premature baby weighing 3000g requires a 1mg/kg slow intravenous dose of antibiotic X. The ampoule contains 8mg in 2mL. 

 

What volume of solution is required?
Explanation:
3000g = 3kg

Per 3kg -> 3mg of X required

 

if you have 8mg in 2mL and we need 3mg:

3/8 x 2 = 0.75mL
Tags: Emergency Medicine, Case 7, Drug calculations, Case 8, Case 9

Question: A new syndrome has had widespread devastating effects on a population. As the leading epidemiologist records that the incidence rate of the disease is 1 in 400 people, the genetics team try to identify what fraction of the population are carriers of the gene that has triggered this syndrome. Which of the following is the best guess of the carrier frequency of the disease?
Explanation:
p2+2pq+q2=1

Square root of 1/400 is 1/20 which equals q in the Hardy Weinberg Equilibrium Equation. Therefore p equals 19/20, as p + q must equal 1.

 

Therefore 2pq=carrier frequency=2 x 1/20 x19/20=19/200=0.095

 

If you used 1 as p instead, you get 2x1/20=2/20=1/10=0.1

Question:
At her first fetal scan, a woman discovers that she is having twins. She is concerned about the risk of her children having genetic abnormalities. 

 

What screening test would the doctor most likely advise?
Explanation:
correct answer is B. This is because the presence of twins lowers the reliability of the test as AFP would be elevated. 

D+E are diagnostic tests not screening tests

Question: A 20 year old male comes in to the clinic with rectal bleeding. He is diagnosed with Familial Adenomatous Polyposis. He reveals his wife is pregnant (who is not affected) and asks you what the chances are that his unborn child could be affected with the same condition.
Explanation:
There is always a 50% chance of passage of a autosomal dominant condition onto the next generation.

Other characteristics of autosomal dominance are;

-incomplete penetrance

-male to male transition

-multiple generations affected

Question:
Breckwith-Weidemann syndrome causes hypoglycaemia, macrosomia, macroglossia and omphalocele among other things.

What is the difference between omphalocele and gastroschisis?
OptionA: in gastroschisis organ protrusion is covered by a membrane whilst in omphalocele organ protrusion is not covered by a membrane but is 'open'
OptionB: in omphalocele organ protrusion is covered by a membrane whilst in gastroschisis organ protrusion is not covered by a membrane but is 'open'
OptionC: Omphalocele opens anteriorly whilst gastroschisis opens laterally
OptionD: A different name for the same condition
Explanation:
Google some images it will explain much better than I could. Just remember gastroschisis = no membrane

 

 

I doubt there us any need to know this but;

Gastroschisis is caused by;

 •Hirschsprung’s disease •Oromandibularlimb hypogenesis •(sporadic)

 

Omphalocele caused by;

•Trisomy 13 •Trisomy 14 •Trisomy 15 •Trisomy 18 •Trisomy 21

Question: Ring chromosome 20 is associated with;
Explanation:
Ring chromosome 20 syndrome;

 

Recurrent seizures are the most recognizable feature of this syndrome and are most often the first sign of this syndrome. These syndromes are often ongoing and poorly responsive to anti-seizure medications. Most patients develop seizures the first few years of life, but the age of onset ranges from ages 1 to 17. Different types of seizure have been reported in this syndrome. The most common seizure type appears to be brief focal onset epileptic seizures with impairment of consciousness and awareness, known as complex partial seizures. Other features you may see in these complex partial seizures include staring, oral automatisms, unspecified automatic behavior, involuntary motor movements and/or head turning.

Furthermore, many patients have subtle nighttime behavioral changes, such as stretching, rubbing, and turning resembling a nighttime awakening. However, electroencephalography (EEG) studies during these events show abnormal electrical seizure activity, indicating that nocturnal behavioral events are actually subtle nocturnal seizures or non-convulsive status epilepticus. Many of these patients experience their seizures only during sleep. They can have seemingly bizarre features as they originate from the frontal lobe of the brain. Often, individuals with ring chromosome 20 syndrome are initially found to have complex partial seizures of frontal lobe origin, though imaging studies do not show a corresponding structural brain abnormality. In certain patients, these seizures may secondarily generalized.

Individuals from the ages of 0–17 years should be considered for ring 20 chromosome analysis if they have: predominantly complex partial seizures, medically refractory crytogenic epilepsy, Lennox-Gastaut-like features with no cause identified, frequent subtle nocturnal seizures, an EEG showing prolonged high voltage frontally dominant slowing intermixed with spikes or sharp waves, an EEG showing overlapping features of continuous slow spike and wave discharges in sleep (CSWS) and electrical status epilepticus in sleep (ESES), and/or subsequent cognitive impairment/learning difficulties/mild retardation.

Question: Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy is an example of mitochondrial disorder. Mitochondrial disorders are always past from ................. to offspring.
OptionB: Father - as only paternal mitochondria are passed to offspring
OptionC: Mother - Due to an X linked recessive disorder
OptionD: Mother - as only maternal mitochondria are passed to offspring
OptionE: Mother - due to an autosomal dominant condition
Explanation: Several recognised disorders are due to mutation in mitochondrial DNA. Only the maternal mitochondria are passed on. See lecture 1 case 7.

Question: How long does the process of capacitation 'conditioning' take?
Explanation:
Dr Dave Wilson's lecture - case 7

Capacitation has a necessity for HCO3 ions, it is initiation is due to progesterone activation of the Catspor Calcium channel, calcium dependent reactions increase cAMP causing release of enzymes that break down the wall of the acrosome.

   

medical-dictionary = A conditioning process whereby the glycoprotein coat and seminal proteins are removed from the acrosome of a sperm. After capacitation has occurred, perforations develop in the acrosome.

Question: Tay-Sachs is a autosomal recessive condition with a extremely low 1 year survival rate. If there are two parents who are both carriers but are not affected, how many of their 8 offspring would you assume were affected by the condition?
Explanation:
0.25 chance of each child being affected. 8 x 1/4 = 2

 

Tay Sachs is caused by a mutation in the HEX-A gene (chromosome 15) causing a deficiency in the hexosaminidase enzyme which controls levels of fatty build up in the brain.

Question: A young male comes in with hearing difficulty, heterochromia iridum (different colors of iris in two eyes) or heterochromia iridis (two different colors of iris in same eye or characteristic brilliant blue iris) hair hypopigmentation (white forelock). He has a autosomal condition which results in the K+ channels not migration to where they belong in the ear and therefore no endocochlear potential is produced. What is this condition?

A women is 8 weeks pregnant and wishes to undergo an abortion. She visits her local general practitioner to find out some more information about the process. Out of the following facts, which is most true, considering the patient is from the UK?
OptionA: An abortion in the UK is legal up to 28 weeks
OptionB: A normal medical abortion is the only option of abortion after 12 weeks
OptionC: The father of the fetus must give consent if the abortion is to occur
OptionD: The patient is in the acceptable range for an early surgical or medical abortion
OptionE: Two qualified doctors must agree that the abortion can take place
Explanation:
E is definitely correct; two doctors' signatures must be provided before an abortion can happen 

A would be correct at 24 weeks

C is incorrect as the father does not need to consent; only the mother and 2 doctors do 

For B and D, see the timeline

Question: A 44 year old woman at 8 weeks gestation comes to the doctor for her first prenatal visit. She has mild nausea and vomiting but no other complaints. Her obstetric history is significant for three full-term, normal vaginal deliveries of normal infants. She wishes to have chromosomal testing of the foetus and wants Chorionic villus sampling performed, as she did with her last pregnancy. Compared with amniocentesis, chorionic villus sampling may place the patient at greater risk for which of the following?
Explanation:
A: Down syndrome is genetic so determined before 8 weeks
B: Correct. The very rare but possible side effect of CVS is transverse digital deficiency (limb defect). It can cause disruption of normal blood flow to fetal cartilage and this risk decreases as pregnancy advances.
C: Neural tubes will already have been formed by this point
D: Abortion is a possible effect (0.5-2% of miscarriage) but this is in the first trimester
E: It is no more likely than in amniocentesis

Question: A 27 year old woman at 10 weeks gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal visit. She is concerned about her risk for Down Syndrome in her foetus because her first child has Down syndrome. She would like to be tested as soon as possible. Examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 10-week gestation. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test for this syndrome at this time?
Explanation:
A: Amniocentesis isn’t usually performed before 15 weeks. CVS is preferable at this point in the pregnancy
B: Correct. This is a diagnostic test, (performed from 9 weeks) which checks for Down Syndrome by taking a sample of the chorionic villus of the placenta and analyse the DNA using PCR or FISH, determining the karyotype.
C: Cordocentesis is a blood sample from the umbilical cord - this tests for blood conditions, but is not an appropriate test at this stage and does not check for Down Syndrome
D: AFP is measured at an earlier stage and is not diagnostic
E: Nuchal translucency is not diagnostic so would need following up with CVS (or amniocentesis).

Question:
A 42 year old woman presents to her local GP after performing a home pregnancy test with a positive result. Her last menstrual period was 14 weeks ago and she has a BMI of 29kg/m2. The GP recommends that she has a screening test for Down's syndrome. Betty expresses her concern about the accuracy of the test, having had a friend who had a false positive result.

 

Which screening test would be most appropriate?
Explanation:
Answer: E (Quadruple test)

Although the combined test is the most accurate, being obese, she would need to have the quadruple test as the nuchal translucency measurement is difficult to obtain.

Also, with her gestational age being 14 weeks, it may be too late for the combined test as the time frame for this is 11-14 weeks. 

CVS and amniocentesis are diagnostic tests so would not be appropriate. 

NIFTY is not available on the NHS currently.
Tags: Embryology, Prenatal Screening, Screening, Case 7, Group 31

Question: Which of the following is not a feature of fertilization?
Explanation: B begins before fertilization after the oocyte is released from the ovaries (although it is only completed during fertilization)

Question: Stacey takes a pregnancy test after she misses a period. The test is positive. Subsequently she visits her GP and he explains what stage of pregnancy she is at. What is most likely to be her current gestational age in weeks?
OptionE: the number of weeks since the last day of her last period
Explanation:
C: A woman is usually 5 weeks along her pregnancy before she notices that she has missed a period (http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/pregnancy-and-baby/Pages/pregnancy-weeks-4-5-6-7-8.aspx)

E: The gestational age is worked out as the number of weeks since the FIRST day of a woman's last period

Question:
During placement, a genetic counselor tells you there are two main types of chromosomal abnormalities: numerical and structural.

 

Which one of the following is a structural abnormality?
Explanation:
Cri du Chat syndrome - partial deletion of short arm of chromosome 5.

 

Symptoms: catlike cry, microcephaly, mental retardation and congenital heart problems

Question:
A 9 weeks pregnant woman was diagnosed with rubella infection. 

 

What is the risk of the foetus being congenitally affected?
Explanation:
Preconception: Minimal risk

 

0 - 12 weeks: 100% risk of foetus being congenitally affected (major abnormalities)

 

13 - 16 weeks: Deafness and retinopathy 15%

 

After 16 weeks: Normal development, slight risk of deafness and retinopathy

Question: A General practitioner encounters a 5 year old patient with the karyotype 47, XY, +21 and is attempting to explain to the patient's new guardian about the challenges resulting from such a karyotype. The new guardian, who is considering having her own children, asks whether she is at high risk of producing a child with a smilier karyotype to the one she has just adopted. Given the woman's age at 30, which of the following is the best estimate of the risk?
Explanation:
From a PCS Unit 3 lecture, the risk for Down's Syndrome, shown in the question by karyotype 47, XY,+21, is

20 years-1 in 1450

30 years-1 in 940 

40 years-1 in 85

49 years-1 in 25

However, NHS choices also list the options as 

20 years of age has a risk of one in 1,500
30 years of age has a risk of one in 800
35 years of age has a risk of one in 270
40 years of age has a risk of one in 100
45 years of age has a risk of one in 50 or greater

The point of the question is to picture the exponential curve; therefore D is the closest answer with both sets of data

Question: A general Practitioner is explaining to an anaemic patient the composition of blood. She outlines a test tube to show the patient density and composition-which of the following statements is most correct in describing a normal person's test tube of blood?
OptionA: Plasma at the bottom of the tube and taking up the majority of the test tube
OptionB: Plasma at the top of the tube and taking up the majority of the test tube
OptionC: Red blood cells at the bottom of the tube and taking up the majority of the test tube
OptionD: Red blood cell at the top of the tube and taking up the majority of the test tube
OptionE: White blood cells in the middle of the tube and taking up the majority of the test tube
Explanation:
Plasma makes up 2/3 of the volume of blood and is the least dense part, hence floats to the top.

WBCs take up the smallest/minimal part of volume in the middle of the tube.

RBCs are the most dense and take up 1/3 of the tube volume

Question:
A 31-year-old woman comes to A&E with a scalp laceration that requires stitches. Before the procedure the doctor administers a local anesthetic.

 

What is the MOA of a local anesthetic?
OptionB: LA binds to alpha-subunit of a sodium channel on the cytosolic side
OptionC: LA binds to alpha-subunit of a sodium channel on the extracellular side
OptionD: LA binds to beta-subunit of a sodium channel on the cytosolic side
OptionE: LA binds to beta-subunit of a sodium channel on the extracellular side
Explanation: LA bind to an alpha-subunit of a sodium channel on the cytosolic side; this forces the channel to remain in the inactive state.

Question:
During labor a pregnant woman asks for a spinal 'MINI' to numb the pain. 

 

Which drug is used to inject this patient?
Explanation: A spinal  requires injecting the opiod fentanyl into the sub-arachnoid space providing quick pain relief; however it wears off in approximately 1 hour.

Question: A young pregnant mother experiences a drop in blood pressure in the first couple of weeks of pregnancy. Which of the following hormones is mostly responsible for this drop?
Explanation: Peripheral vascular resistance in the female's body decreases in pregnancy in the first 24 weeks due to progesterone mediated smooth muscle relaxation. This gradually returns to normal as progesterone levels fall.

Question: A 42 year old pregant woman visits her GP, who informs her she has iron-deficiency anaemia, caused the inability of her bone marrow to store iron in a specific compound. Which compound is the doctor most likely referring to?
Explanation: This question tests information presented on slide 10 in the "Haematological aspects of pregancy" lecture in Case 8. Iron is stored as Ferritin in the liver and Haemosiderin in the bone marrow. Haemoglobin is and iron compound in the blood (Obviously) and Succinate and Fumarate are other iron compounds- I think..... Hope the q was useful

Question:
A 29-year-old man comes at the GP with shortness of breath, wheezing and ongoing cough. You are requested to perform a respiratory examination and during it you observe flapping tremor in the patients hands.

 

What is the most common cause of flapping tremor found during respiratory examinations?
Explanation: Flapping tremor: CO2 retention – often seen in patients with type 2 respiratory failure e.g. COPD

Question: A cardiologist outlines the definition of a term with 'de novo development of blood vessels from endothelial cells differentiating in situ'. Which of the following words is the best match to the definition given?
Explanation:
From case 8 plenary

Angiogenesis -formation of new blood vessels from sprouting of new capillaries from pre-existing vessels (importance of so-called ‘angiogenic diseases’)

Neovascularisation- the formation of functional microvascular networks with red blood cell perfusion.

Question:
A 43-year-old man comes at the GP with shortness of breath, dry cough, tachypnea and tiredness. You are requested to perform a respiratory examination and during it you hear fine crackles on inspiration.

 

What is the most common cause of fine crackles found during respiratory examinations?
Explanation:
Fine crackles are explosive high-pitched sounds that occur in each cycle in mid/late inspiration and are repeated in subsequent cycles. Each crackle occurs at a particular transpulmonary pressure and represents a reopening of a previously closed small airway.

 

Unlike coarse crackles, fine crackles do NOT change after coughing or deep breathing.

Question: Human colostrum is the liquid produced by the lactating breast prior to human milk. A young mother wonders why her General Practitioner has told her that this is good for her baby and dealing with potential infections. Which of the following is the most likely reason the doctor gives the mother for the reason why?
OptionA: The total fat content of colostrum is higher than that of human breast milk
OptionB: The total immunoglobulin content of colostrum is higher than that of human breast milk
OptionC: The total lactose content of colostrum is higher than that of human breast milk
OptionD: The total mineral content of colostrum is higher than that of human breast milk
OptionE: The total protein content of colostrum is higher than that of human breast milk

Question:
A 14 weeks pregnant woman goes to the GP to complain about an increase in frequency of micturition. 

 

What is the most likely reason of increased urination in this patient?
OptionE: Bladder wall is less elastic than normal
Explanation:
In 1st and 2nd trimester the increase urinary flow reflects increased renal function. 

 

In later weeks, as the fetus increases in size, there is likely to be increased pressure on the bladder.

Question: A young soldier is shot down in the battlefield and requires immediate blood transfusion to survive. You are only the only person with him and somehow have the equipment to make a transfusion. You are unaware of your blood type but know that the soldier wounded is a Universal Recipient. Which of the following is his most likely blood group, given this fact?
Explanation:
O - blood group is classified as universal donor.

AB + blood group is classified as universal donor.

Keep in mind that these terms are only generally true in the vast majority of donations.

Question: You want to give blood to a friend who has recently been involved in a car accident. You know that you have the only Blood type that your friend can receive. Which of the following blood group are you most likely to have?
Explanation: O- is the only blood type that can be given to a someone who is O-. This is because an immune reaction would occur in response to the Rhesus antigen if a positive blood group was given and if A, AB or B were given,  an immune reaction would also occur as someone with O blood has plasma antibodies for A and B.

Question: You are performing a microbiology investigation where you discover some epithelium on the tissue. It is simple cuboidal epithelium-which of the following organs is this tissue likely from?
Explanation:
Simple cuboidal epithelium is commonly seen in the kidneys, ovaries and respiratory bronchioles.

http://www.bio.davidson.edu/people/kabernd/BerndCV/Lab/EpithelialInfoWeb/Simple%20Cuboidal%20Epithelium.html

Question: A anatomy professor analyses a piece of tissue at a crime scene and discovers the presence of transitional epithelium-which of the following organs is this tissue likely from?
Explanation: Transitional epithelium is commonly seen in the bladder, the superior urethra, ureters and prostate glands.

Question: A young female becomes pregnant. In the normal menstrual cycle the corpus luteum degrades, but this process is impeded during pregnancy because of the presence of which hormone?
Explanation:
In normal human pregnancy, human chorionic gonadotropin (hcg) is produced early in pregnancy to maintain the corpus luteum.

Hcg levels rise rapidly during early pregnancy, and hcg is the hormone detected during a routine pregnancy test. It is originally produced after fertilization by the cells that eventually become the placenta. hcg plays a pivotal role in maintaining the corpus luteum in early pregnancy. This enhances progesterone secretion, which in turn alters the physiology of the uterus enhancing vascular in growth so that the growth of the fetus can be sustained.

Progesterone is produced by the corpus luteum, but is not the hormone that maintains the physiologic structure.

Question: On a cardiology ward, you are measuring a patient's blood pressure, which the consultant tells you should be a hypertension of grade 3. Which of the following blood pressure readings is the most likely that you come up with, given that you perform the Blood pressure measurement correctly?
Which of the following labels on this image is directed to the cotyledon?
Explanation:
1. Umbilical cord

2. Amnion

3. Chorionic plate

4. Intervillous space (maternal blood)

5. Basal plate

6. Cotyledon

7. Villus

Question: Recent research on the anatomy of the breast has questioned a certain anatomical feature of the breast that had been presumed to have an important role and whether it actually exists-in the diagram below, which number corresponds to the label of that feature?
Explanation:
1. Intercostal Space

2. Pectoralis Major

3. Lobules of Mammary Gland

4. Nipple

5. Areola

6. Lactiferous Sinus

7. Fat lobule

This was highlighted by Dr Helen McCarthy in her Case 8 lecture

Question: At her dating scan, she heard her midwife speak of her crown rump length measurement. She is confused as to what that is, how would you explain it to her?
OptionA: The measurement of the length of the fetus from the top of the head to the bottom of the feet
OptionB: The measurement of the length of the fetus from the top of the head to the bottom of the buttocks
OptionC: The measurement of the length of the fetus from eye level to the bottom of the feet
OptionD: The measurement of the length of the fetus from eye level to the bottom of the buttocks
OptionE: Crown Rump length is not measured at the dating scan, so explain that she misheard.
Explanation: Refer to anatomy pratical or alternatively this is a good website: radiopaedia.org/articles/crown-rump-length

Question: A 29-year-old lady is entering the labour with cervical dilation of 6cm and is crying out in pain; she is told that this is expected and normal. Which of the following lists of spinal cord levels should be sensing and transferring this pain at this stage of labour?
Explanation:
This is the first stage of labour, as indicated by cervical dilation of 6cm. Covered in Dr Lucy de Lloyd's lecture, the main levels affected are T10-L1; thus B is the best answer as it includes the complete range.

This pain is transmitted via slow unmyelinated C fibres that accompany sympathetic nerve endings. These include

-> paracervical ganglion
-> hypogastric plexus
-> lumbar sympathetic chain

The pain is crampy, visceral, and poorly localised
Adjacent pelvic structures are also affected - L2 to S1-but B is still the answer that includes the most correct spinal cord levels
Tags: Case 8, Acute Care, Anaesthetics, Emergency Medicine

Question:
Group 33. (case 8)

 

A 33 year old woman has spina bifida. She is at 36/40 and is filling out her birth plan and discussing analgesic options with her midwife. She has had a previous severe adverse reaction to an opiate alkaloid. What analgesic option is best in this scenario?
Explanation: As this lady has spina bifida, the two neuraxial options (an epidural or spinal) are not appropriate. Aspirin is an NSAID and these are not given during labour. Pethidine is an opiate, and she has previously reacted to an opiate, so entonox is the best option for her.

Question:
An Irish  midwife is explaining to a mother that she is in the first stage of labour, she has an uncanny interest for why pain changes during labour. E.g . speed of pain. 

 

She explains that different fibres are stimulates and at different spinal levels in different stages of labour. 

 

 

What is the most accurate description out of the following?
OptionC: Fast myelinated A delta fibres at T10-L1 and S2-S4
Explanation:
A C fibres are always unmyelinated 

B is correct

C This second is second stage of labour

D a delta fibres are always myelinated 

E C fibres are  unmyelinated but are not effected at S2-S4 in the first stage of labour.

Question: Group 43; Stacey's mom who's had it on, is now in labour and is about to have an epidural. Stacey's mom asks you what the needle will pass through. What do you say to her (outermost to innermost)?
OptionA: Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Supraspinous ligament, Interspinous ligament, Ligamentum flavum, Epidural space, Dura
OptionB: Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Supraspinous ligament, Interspinous ligament, Ligamentum flavum, Epidural space
OptionC: Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Interspinous ligament, Supraspinous ligament, Ligamentum flavum, Epidural space
OptionD: Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Supraspinous ligament, Ligamentum flavum, Interspinous ligament, Epidural space
OptionE: Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Interspinous ligament, Supraspinous ligament, Ligamentum flavum, Epidural space, Dura
Explanation: Answer B is the correct order, as Dura is not pierced unless the patient is receiving a spinal analgesia.

Question: A women in labour asks her midwife for aspirin as she is in pain. Her midwife states that she is unable to give her aspirin and instead offers paracetamol as a form of analgesia. What was her reasoning behind this?
OptionA: Aspirin is only used in cardiovascular conditions
OptionB: Prevents formations of prostaglandin E2 and F2 which cause uterine contraction, thus prolonging labour
OptionC: Aspirin will become present in the breast milk and can therefore cause harm to the baby
OptionD: Apsirin inhibits the action of bradykinin, preventing the closure of the ductus arteriosus in the neonate
OptionE: Indirectly increases gastrin causing acid reflux in the mother reducing her comfort during the rest of labour
Explanation: PGE-2 sensitises neurones to bradykinin, aspirin inhibits PGE-2 production and therefore stops the action of bradykinin preventing the closure of the ductus arteriosus as bradykinin has contractile effects on smooth muscle.

Question: A 42 year-old female comes into a GP Surgery. She discussed with the doctor that she has taken a pregnancy test 2 weeks ago & that she is pregnant. The doctor during his history taking discovers that she has had 2 previous children (1 born prematurely at 35 weeks, 1 full-term). What is the parity of this female in numbers?
Explanation:
The 5 numbers represent GTPAL (Gravidity, term, preterm, abortions & living children)

Gravidity = Number of total pregnancies

Term = Number of pregancies that were from 38-42 weeks (i.e. full-term)

Preterm = Number of pregnancies that reached 20 weeks but were before 37 weeks of gestation

Abortions = number of pregnancies that were terminated

Living children = number of children that survive birth
Tags: Clinical Skills, Embryology, Physiology, Professionalism, Group 34

Question: A 32 year old primigravida is speaking to her GP about her gestational diabetes. She is 30 weeks pregnant and concerned about how it could affect her and her infant’s health. The doctor explains the potential health risks to her, and asks you to explain the hormonal basis of the disease. Poor control of which hormone is the most likely cause of her diabetes?
Explanation:
hCG - poorly controlled hCG usually leads to termination of foetus, due to lack of progesterone. It isn’t involved in gestational diabetes
hPL - correct! - hPL is a diabetogenic which decreases sensitivity to insulin. It maintains the concentration gradient of glucose so that the foetus receives an adequate supply. - as a result, high levels of hPL can lead to increased blood sugar levels in the mother. Gestational Diabetes Mellitus is treated with dietary control or oral hypoglycaemic drugs. It can last after parturition, if poorly controlled.
LH - levels of LH are suppressed during pregnancy by high levels of progesterone and consistent levels of oestrogen. It isn’t involved in gestational diabetes.
Oxytocin - this hormone is not heavily involved during pregnancy until labour. It isn’t involved in gestational diabetes.
Relaxin - this hormone helps relax the pubic ligaments during labour and is associated with oxytocin’s action. It isn’t involved with gestational diabetes.

Question: Lucy, an expecting mother, is primagravida. She was diagnosed with HIV during antenatal checks several months ago. Her due date is soon approaching and she has come to you, her GP, with concerns about her birth plan. Given her current circumstances, when she asks, which mode of delivery do you recommend to her?
OptionB: A home delivery with a midwife present
OptionC: A natural birth on a consultant led unit
OptionE: A natural birth on a midwife - led unit
Explanation: Due to the increase risk to the baby during delivery, a planned caesarean would seem the most appropriate option in Lucy's case. This is because baby and mother material can be exchanged during vaginal birth, which should be avoided given Lucy's HIV positive status. Planning the caesarean ahead of time will also allow Lucy time to learn about the process and manage her care plan around this.

Question: Tricuspid Atresia is diagnosed in a child shortly after birth. The doctor explains to his parents that there are several heart defects involved in this condition, one of which allows blood to flow directly from the right atrium to the left atrium. Which of the following defect, which are all involved in Tricuspid Atresia, would be most likely to cause this?
Explanation:
Patency of the forman ovale as this is where the foramen ovale remains open after birth and would allow blood to flow directly from RA to LA.

Tricuspid atresia is a form of congenital heart disease whereby there is a complete absence of the tricuspid valve. Therefore, there is an absence of right atrioventricular connection -->leads to a hypoplastic/absent right ventricle. This defect is contracted during prenatal development, when the heart does not finish developing. It causes the heart to be unable to properly oxygenate the rest of the blood in the body. Because of this, the body does not have enough oxygen to live, so other defects must occur to maintain blood flow. Because of the lack of an A-V connection, an atrial septal defect (ASD) must be present to fill the left ventricle with blood. Also, since there is a lack of a right ventricle there must be a way to pump blood into the pulmonary arteries, and this is accomplished by a ventricular septal defect (VSD).

An atrial septal defect (ASD) and a ventricular septal defect (VSD) must both be present to maintain blood flow-from the right atrium, the blood must flow through the ASD to the left atrium to the left ventricle and through the VSD to the right ventricle to allow access to the lungs

 

Group 39

Question: During labour a 30year old woman starts to experience severe cramps so doctors make the decision to insert a catheter into her back to administer her anaesthetics with an opioid. What is the route of administration?
OptionA: Skin, subcutaneous tissue, interspinous ligament, supraspinous ligament, epidural space
OptionB: Skin, subcutaneous tissue, interspinous ligament, supraspinous ligament, epidural space, dura
OptionC: Skin, subcutaneous tissue, interspinous ligament, supraspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, epidural space
OptionD: Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, epidural space
OptionE: Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, epidural space, dura
Explanation:
￼

Epidurals are given via a catheter and do not pierce the dura whereas spinals do pierce the dura and are just single injections.

A 25 year old woman has come to the GP with signs of anaemia. 2 months ago she gave birth to her first baby. During the prolonged labour she asked for pain relief which has had adverse effects on her bone marrow causing her symptoms.
what type of pain relief was she most likely to have received.
