A young girl has come to the GP and just started her period. She feels tired and faint and she is worried about anaemia. The GP requested a blood test where vitamin B12 is found to be low. This may be caused by malabsorption of B12 in the body.

 

 

Where is vitamin B12 absorbed?

A 21 year old woman goes to her GP with suspected IBD.

 

What procedure could the GP perform in order to distinguish between IBS and IBD in primary care?
Explanation:
Faecal calprotectin is released into the intestine upon inflammation so may not need a colonoscopy to distinguish between IBS and IBD.

 

A colonoscopy would not be done in primary care.

A digital rectal examination would not give you enough information.

Faecal occult blood test is used for screening for bowel cancer.

X-ray would be useless.
Tags: Inflammatory Bowel Disease, Group 54, Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11

Question: A 42 year-old woman presenting with anaemia had a portion of her bowel removed because of an occluded artery supplying the specific area. On observation of her abdomen, you notice a temporary stoma bag containing a liquid-like substance. You also find out that she gets prophylactic vitamin B12 injections. Which artery do you think was most likely to have been occluded?
Explanation:
B12 is absorbed in the terminal ileum, she is receiving injections because this is the part of the bowel that has infarcted and therefore she has poor absorption of the vitamin.

 

The Ileocolic is the artery that supplies the terminal ileum, which is shown in the diagram below. This is the artery that has been occluded and caused the infarction of the bowel. The diagram also shows the other arteries.
Tags: Abdomen, Lower GI, Group 46, Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11

Question:
A 14 year old boy, Novak presents with post prandial bloating and diarrhoea, of which he has been complaining of for the past 10 weeks. The other boys in the year have been picking on him for his short stature and you notice a reduction in muscle bulk. Blood tests and a stool sample were arranged by his GP.

The results are as follows:

 

Hb – 102 (115-145g/l)

 

MCV – 65 (80-99fl)

 

Ferritin – 4.8 (18-160ug/l

 

Total immunoglobulin A – 290mg/dl (70-400mg/dl)

 

IgA tissue transglutaminase (tTG) 36 units (elevated)

 

What is the most probable diagnosis?
Explanation:
Total immunoglobulin A – 290mg/dl (70-400mg/dl) <- this value is typically normal

 

IgA tissue transglutaminase (tTG) 36 units (elevated) <- this measurement falls within the characteristic diagnostic criteria for coeliac disease.
Tags: Abdomen, Inflammatory Bowel Disease, Lower GI, Case 11, Group 60

Question:
Mrs Claus has been very busy over the Christmas period and has been living off a diet of mince pies and candy canes. She begins to feel tired and notices cracks around her mouth. She visits North Pole Surgery where Dr Frosty performs some blood tests.

Her results are as follows:

 

Hb - 101 (115-145 g/l)

MCV - 86 ( 90-99 fl)

Ferritin - 5 (18-160 µg/l)

Folate - 7 (4.5-11 ng/ml)

Cobalamin - 387 (170-500 nm/l)

 

What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
Explanation:
Iron-deficiency anaemia is the correct answer because

  • Low MCV (microcytic anaemia), low ferritin, and low Hb indicate iron-deficiency as the cause

 

  • Normal folate and B12 indicate that the problem is not due to absorptive problems in the gut.

 

Mincopious just sounds like mince pies.

Question:
A 25 year old woman presents with diarrhoea.

Past Medical History: Ileal resection due to Crohn's Disease

Inflammatory markers are normal.

What is the most likely cause of her diarrhoea?
Explanation: Bile acids are absorbed in the terminal ileum. If there has been ileal resection this leads to malabsorption which can cause diarrhoea. It is unlikely to be a flare up of Crohn's due to normal values of the inflammatory markers.
Tags: Inflammatory Bowel Disease, Lower GI, Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11

Question: A young patient who has recently recovered from Blepharitis is having their final check-up with the optometrist; they are told that because the condition can be recurrent, they need to see the optometrist at a set regular time interval. At present, they have no symptoms or other eye conditions; what time interval does the optometrist most likely tell their patient?
Explanation: For a normal person with no symptoms or eye conditions, they should see an optometrist every two years for a check-up. Blepharitis is a non sight-threateninig eye conditions that frequently causes itching, irritation and inflammation to the eyelids and is relatively common in patients over 50. As this patient is devoid of symptoms as of present, they will require the usually number of check-ups.

Question: A young woman has decided to have a later surgical abortion at 22 weeks. She is very distressed and put under general anaesthesia. As a supervising Foundation year doctor, the operating surgeon asks you for the substance that will 'stop the foetus' heart'; which of the following does the surgeon most likely mean?
Explanation: Potassium chloride, when given in high concentrations can be used in fetal intracardiac injections to stop the hear from functioning. The drug digoxin is more frequently used today as it is easier to inject compared to potassium chloride.

Question: A Welsh Student 19-year-old patient is diagnosed with dry eye by their optometrist and is advised to make certain lifestyle changes; which of the following did the optometrist most likely tell the patient?
OptionA: Take more regular breaks with visual tasks, such as computer use
OptionC: Avoid cold and wet environments, especially during winter
Explanation: Dry eye can be caused by environmental factors and a, d,e are all correct. However the most likely answer is A as increased computer use can decrease your blink ratio, which can lead to dry eye. Regular breaks may help increase your blink ratio, while supplements are occasionally recommended if nutritional imbalances are found in patients. Protection against windy and hot environments is also encouraged.

Question: You perform a colonoscopy on a 52-year old patient and find that he has Ulcerative colitis; you begin to explain to your supervising consultant which areas of the Gastrointestinal tract are affected. Which of these parts are you most likely to definitely say is affected?
Explanation: Ulcerative colitis is generally limited to the colon and thus that rules out A, B and C. According to our lecture on IBD, Dr Hawthorne explicitly stated that in almost every case of UC the rectum is affected; 1/4 is proctitis (limited to the rectum) 1/3 of cases is limited to the the rectum to the splenic flexure (essentially descending colon) and the reminder of cases tends to be extensive/pan colitis. Thus E is the better answer compared to D
Tags: Abdomen, Inflammatory Bowel Disease, Lower GI, Anatomy, Case 11

Question: A patient with ulcerative colitis is giving a detailed history, as a colonoscopy has found that his condition has been isolated to his rectum. Which of the following is the patient suffering from in terms of symptoms that will most likely confirm the colonoscopy findings?
OptionC: Passing of blood and mucus separate to stool
OptionE: Passing of only blood separate to the stool
Explanation: Passing of blood and mucus separate to the stool is a classic sign of proctitis; when UC is isolated to the rectum only. No diarrhoea is present usually in this form of UC; the pain is only usually severe in elongated cases and severe urgency is often a feature of all cases of UC.
Tags: Inflammatory Bowel Disease, Lower GI, Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11

Question: During surgery, the presence of teniae coli helps to distinguish the large bowel from the small intestine. Which single layer of the intestine forms the teniae coli?
Explanation: The longitudinal layer of muscularis propria of the colon forms three longitudinal muscle bands also known as teniae coli.

Question:
Ian, a  54 year old doctor has recently been diagnosed with familial polyposis coli by colonoscopy.  He attends a genetic counsellor to discuss implications for his family but has not had genetic testing yet.

He has two sisters, Elizabeth and Jenny, two sons Andrew and Patrick  and two non-identical twin daughters Berenice and Aniqa.  One of his sons has 3 children Ilyas, Emma and Emily and his other son has a daughter Shaimma.  His daughters do not have any children.

On average what would be the total number of his siblings, children and grandchildren who would affected by familial polyposis?
Explanation: FPP is usually an autosomal dominant condition.  This means that his siblings and children have a 1 in 2 chance of inheriting the condition.  His grandchildren would have a 1 in 4 chance of having the condition though this would change when their parents are tested becoming either 1 in 2 or nil depending on whether or not their own parents have inherited the FPP gene.  Therefore overall 1 out of 2 siblings , 2 out of 4 children and 1 out of 4 grandchildren would be expected to affected (on average) giving a total of 4
Tags: Abdomen, Lower GI, Group 49, Genetics, case 11

Question: As part of the process of producing a karyotype, cells need to be cultured for 3-4 days. This involves using a chemical to encourage mitosis, followed by a chemical to disrupt the mitotic spindles in  order to prevent completion of mitosis. What is used to encourage mitosis?
Explanation:
Phytohemagglutinin is used to encourage mitosis.

Colcemid is used to disrupt the mitotic spindles to prevent completion of mitosis.

 

Others and random or made up

Question: Analysis of chromosomes in human development and disease is accomplished through classical cytogenetic procedures including G banding which uses the Geimsa stain. Dark and light bands are produced. Which of the following is not a feature of light bands?
Explanation:
Dark band: 

- Condensed chromatin

- AT rich 

- Gene poor

 

Light band:

- Less condensed chromatin

- transcriptionally active 

- Gene rich 

- GC rich

Question: A 25 year old woman comes in to your GP practice complaining of pain in her left lower quadrant. She explains how she has been trying to get pregnant therefore, the first thing you do is a pregnancy test. This comes back positive for 2 weeks, however due to the pain this lady is experiencing you are slightly concerned that she may be having a miscarriage. What percentage of pregnancies end in miscarriage?
Explanation:
15% of pregnancies end in miscarriage

50-60% of 1st trimester miscarriages have chromosomal abnormalities 

 

60% of miscarriages are due to trisomies 

20% of miscarriages are due to Turner's syndrome 

15-20% of miscarriages are due to Triploidy which are also 1-2% of all human conceptions.

Question: You are an obstetric F1 working a night shift when one of your patients goes in to labour. A nurse mentions that there is a known chromosomal abnormality of the baby about to be delivered. You are unaware of exactly what this may be until the baby is born and you see that they have rocker-bottom feet, micrognathia and finger flexion. You instantly know this baby has which syndrome?
Explanation: 3 most common signs of Edward's syndrome which is trisomy 18.

Question: Which of the following syndromes is a result of a terminal deletion?
Explanation:
Terminal Deletions:

- 1p36 deletion - "1p36 deletion syndrome"

- 4p deletion - Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome

- 5p deletion - Cri du chat syndrome 

 

Interstitial deletions:

- 7q11 deletion - Williams syndrome

- 15q11-q13 - Prader WIlli/Angelman syndrome 

- 17p11.2 deletion - Smith-Magenis syndrome

- 17p13.3 deletion - Miller-Dieker syndrome 

- 22q11.2 - DiGeorge syndrome

Question: Which of the following will produce offspring with Prader Willi Syndrome?
OptionA: Mutation or deletion of UBE3A gene (15q11-13) inherited from the father
OptionB: Mutation or deletion of SNRPN gene (15q11-13) inherited by Maternal UPD
OptionC: Mutation or deletion of UBE3A gene (15q11-13) inherited from the mother
OptionD: Mutation or deletion of UBE3A gene (15q11-13) inherited by maternal UPD
OptionE: Mutation or deletion of UBE3A gene (15q11-13) inherited by paternal UPD
Explanation:
A - nothing

B - correct. The child inherits both chromosomes from the mother, so they will be missing the non-imprinted gene from that father so do not express the functioning gene. 

C - Angelman's syndrome 

D - Nothing

E - Angelman's syndrome

Question: Which of the following are the 3 main consequences of fertilisation?
OptionA:
1. Restoration of diploid number 

2. The cortical reaction

3. Sex determination
OptionB:
1. Restoration of diploid number

2. Sex determination

3. Induction of cleavage
OptionC:
1.Cortical reaction 

2. Induction of cleavage

2. Sex determination
OptionD:
1. Prevention of polyspermy 

2. Sex determination 

3. Induction of cleavage
OptionE:
1. Acrosome reaction

2. Cortical reaction

3. Restoration of diploid number
Explanation: as per answer :)

Question:
After gastrulation 3 separate germ layers (endoderm, mesoderm and ectoderm) have been formed. To allow embryonic development to continue the notochord plays a vital role. 

 

What is the main role of the notochord?
OptionA: Induces the formation of the neural crest  which develops into the neural tube
OptionB: Induces the formation of the neural groove from the endoderm
OptionC: Induces the formation of the neural groove from the ectoderm
OptionD: Induces the formation of the neural crest from the ectoderm
OptionE: Induces the formation of the neural crest which develops into the neural plate
Explanation:
The notochord is a flexible rod of mesoderm which signals the ectoderm to thicken into the neural plate.

It then stimulates the neural plate to fold upwards into the mesoderm forming the neural groove. 

The neural groove then comes together to form the neural tube which later develops into the CNS and the Brain

Question: What hormone does the egg release after ovulation to allow sperm to be able to locate it?
which hormone is responsible for the capacitation of sperm?
Which of the following is responsible for the acrosome reaction?
What phase is a secondary oocyte arrested in?
What prevents polyspermy?
which responsible is responsible for the maintenance of the corpus luteum?
what hormone does the Corpus Luteum secrete ?
After how long is hCG detected in maternal urine?
after how long is hCG detected in maternal circulation?
if hCG ranges are above normal for a pregnant individual what does this suggest?

The consultant gives you a family tree diagram.

 

 

What type of inheritance pattern do you recognise?
Explanation:
The tree diagram represents an autosomal recessive pattern.

 

Characteristics of autosomal recessive include:

  • Usually affects one generation
  • Common in consanguineous families
  • Parents both asymptomatic carriers
  • 25% chance of recurrence

Question:
During a combined screening test at 12 weeks of pregnacy you notice the mothers results suggest a high risk of down syndrome. 

 

Which of the results below may have been seen in this test?
Explanation:
Combined screening is done between 11 and 14 weeks. It involves a nuchal translucency scan and a blood test for HCG and PAPP. 

 

Quadruple testing is another screening technique for down syndrome completed at 15 - 18 weeks. Answer A would be suggestive of down syndrome in quadruple testing. This is used when mothers book late or if Nuchal Translucency could not be completed accurately e.g is mother is obese.

Question: Which of the following systems is the first to become functional in the embryo?
Explanation: The circulatory system is functional in a rudimental way after 4 weeks.

Question: A 17 year old white female at 20 weeks gestation presents with a 2 day history of painful vesicular lesions on her labia. This is the first time she has ever had this problem. Her last sexual contact was 10 days ago. She has also had low grade fever, malaise, headache and mild, diffuse abdominal pain. On examination she has vesicles and erythematous papules on the labia bilaterally. A few firm, tender inguinal nodes are also noted. Which of the following tests is most sensitive for confirming the diagnosis?
Explanation:
Likely to be Herpes. Pregnancy is a slight problem as the infection could be transmitted at birth via the birth canal if not before transplacentally. If transferred, the foetus is at a very high risk of complications such as neurologic disease, so important to treat. 

 

Both D and E are used as tests for Herpes, but PCR testing has 95% sensitivity, whereas Tzanck testing is much lower.

Question:
During a painful labour a 29-year-old woman is given a regional nerve block for the perineal pain. The consultant palpates the ischial spine and uses it as a landmark to administer the local anaesthetic.

 

What nerve is most likely to be blocked?
Explanation:
The pudendal nerve (S2-S4) is usually blocked in this procedure.

It leaves the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen, then re-enters via the lesser sciatic foramen.

Motor Functions: Innervates the skeletal muscles in the perineum, the external urethral sphincter, the external anal sphincter, levator ani.
Sensory Functions: Innervates the penis and the clitoris and most of the skin of the perineum.

Question: New strains of HIV are the result of errors in:
Explanation:
HIV is a retrovirus which refers to the enzyme reverse transcriptase (RNA dependent DNA polymerase). RT transcribes RNA to DNA during the process of viral nucleic acid synthesis. 

 

New strains are therefore the result of errors in transcription due to reverse transcriptase!

Question: A young doctor is performing a Digital Rectum examination and is told by the consultant that the patient she was examining had 'ricewater' stools-what condition is this most likely indicative of?
Explanation: Ricewater stools, meaning watery stools with mucus and cell debris, is indicative of cholera.

Question: You are analysing the genes of a collection of patients diagnosed with Lynch Syndrome and how the gene alterations and genders of a select few patients. Given the following options, who is at most risk of developing colorectal cancer?
Explanation:
The following lists the affects of gender and gene alteration, with the average age of onset in those patients of the specific genotype. The risk measured is RELATIVE 

MLH1 Male High risk; Average Age 43

MLH1 Female Medium Risk Average Age 43

MSH2 Male High risk Average Age 44

MSH2 Female Medium Risk Average Age 44

MSH6 Male Medium Risk Average Age 55

MSH6 Female Low Risk Average Age 57

PMS2 Male Low Risk Average Age 59

PMS2 Female Low Risk Average Age59

EPCAM Male High Risk Average Age 43

EPCAM Female High Risk Average Age 43

Question:
A 57 year old man comes to the physician because of progressive weakness and weight loss over the past 2 months. He says he has been noticing areas of his skin getting darker even though it is winter and he is never in the sun. He takes no medications and has no other medical conditions. Physical examination shows no abnormalities other than orthostatic hypotension and hyper-pigmentation of his skin. Lab studies show:

 

Na - 130 (135-145)

K - 6.5 (3.5-5)

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis:
Explanation: Patient is showing hyponeutremia and hyperkalemia. Along with other symptoms this is most consistent with Addison's disease which is primary failure of the adrenal cortex leading to low aldosterone and low cortisol.

Question: As a trainee General Practitioner, you see a newly pregnant woman about nutritional advice. She was planning on going on a multivitamin supplement for the duration of her pregnancy but you advise against this after asking about her diet. as high levels of a certain vitamin can be potentially harmful. Which of the following vitamins is the doctor most likely concerned about keeping low?
Explanation: High levels of Vitamin A can cause liver toxicity in fetuses. 15 x the recommended daily allowance is thought to be a particularly dangerous level.

Question: You are examining a female's uterus via vaginal examination; you comment that its anatomical position is 'normal'. Which of the following descriptions thus can best describe the uterus position?
OptionE: Retroflexed, Retroverted and Anterosuperior to the bladder
Explanation:
The exact anatomical location of the uterus varies with the degree of distension of the bladder. In the normal adult uterus, it can be described as anteverted with respect to the vagina, and anteflexed with respect to the cervix:

Anteverted: Rotated forward, towards the anterior surface of the body.

Anteflexed: Flexed, towards the anterior surface of the body.

Thus, the uterus normally lies immediately posterosuperior to the bladder, and anterior to the rectum.

Question: A female presents with some spider like blood distributions on her arms and chest. She has recently become pregnant. Thus, raised levels of which hormone are most likely responsible for these pigmentation changes?
Explanation: Spider angiomas or spider naevi are common in pregnant/COCP patients with raised oestrogen levels as this causes dilation of blood vessels. Spider angiomas may also be caused by failure of sphincteric muscles surrounding cutaneous arteries.

Question: You are present at the birth of a 2 week premature baby who you note on observation has a cleft lip, is very small with a small head and has 6 fingers on both hands. You are informed that the child has a chromosomal abnormality, which condition to do most suspect?
Explanation:
Palau Syndrome is trisomy 13 with its main clinical symptoms beings severe developmental delay, microcephaly (small head), holoprosencephaly (forebrain doesn't divide properly so cleft lip/palate and one eye are common) and polydactyl (many fingers).

 

The other syndromes all have slightly different features:

Down's Syndrome: Muscle hypotonia, Brushfield spots (in iris), up slanting palpebral fissures, flattened nose and single transverse palmar crease.

Edward's Syndrome: IUGR, seizures, cleft palate- it is very similar to Patau's however has a clenched first and rocker bottom feet not polydactyl.

Triple X Syndrome: No physical changes as only one X is active at a time.

Triploidy: Ofter miscarriage/stillbirth, hypotonia, IUGR, craniofacial dysmorphism etc.

Question: A couple come into your surgery to talk to you about their attempts at having a baby. You explain to them about the fertilisation process and describe to the man about what happens when sperm fertilise and egg. Which of the following is the most accurate chain of events that occur during sperm fertilisation of the egg?
OptionA: Fusion of cell membranes- zona reaction- sperm penetrates zona pellucida- sperm penetrates corona radiata- head and tail of sperm enter cytoplasm of oocyte
OptionB: Head and tail of sperm enter cytoplasm of oocyte- fusion of cell membranes- zona reaction- sperm penetrates zona pellucida- sperm penetrates corona radiata
OptionC: Sperm penetrates corona radiata- sperm penetrates zona pellucida- zona reaction- fusion of cell membranes- head and tail of sperm enter cytoplasm of oocyte
OptionD: Sperm penetrates zona pellucida- sperm penetrates corona radiata- zona reaction- fusion of cell membranes- head and tail of sperm enter cytoplasm of oocyte
OptionE: Zona reaction- sperm penetrates zona pellucida- sperm penetrates corona radiata- fusion of cell membranes- head and tail of sperm enter cytoplasm of oocyte
Explanation: Firstly the sperm penetrates the corona radiata, capacitated sperm pass easily through this layer, then the sperm penetrates the zona pellucida, this requires the acrosome reaction in which proteolytic enzymes digest the zona pellucida. Then the zona reaction occurs when the sperm touches the oocyte surface and so lysosomes are released from cortical granules- cortical reaction. Next there is fusion of the cell membranes via interns on the surface of the oocyte and their ligands on the sperm. Finally the head and the tail of the sperm can enter the oocyte and the head forms the male pronucleus.

Question: A man comes into your clinic with symptoms of excess salvation and overactive glands. You decide to carry out some nerve conduction studies. On doing this you will be testing the pre-ganglionic and post-ganglionic sympathetic nerves of the salivary glands, which is the best description of the neurotransmitters that will be present at each stage of the nerve?
Explanation:
Somatic: One fibre that is ACh

Autonomic: Parasympathetic: Preganglionic is ACh, postanglionic is ACH

                   Sympathetic: Preganglionic is ACh, postganglionic is NA

Question: On a health visit you see a mother who is currently breast feeding her child, the baby is now 3 months old and she has breastfed since birth. Which explaining to the mother the benefits of breastfeeding you use the term Galactokinesis, what is the best description of this term?
OptionD: Synthesis and secretion of milk from the alveoli
Explanation:
1) Mammogenesis: preparation of breasts

2) Lactogenesis: synthesis and secretion of milk from the alveoli

3) Galactokinesis: ejection of milk

4) Galatopoeisis: maintenance of lactation

Question: A woman who is 28 weeks pregnant is rushed into A and E with painless antepartum vaginal bleeding, there are no other obvious symptoms and at her recent scan the baby was developing normally within the uterus. Which condition are you most likely to suspect?
OptionA: Early labour and breaking of the waters
Explanation: In this case her painless vaginal bleeding is most suggestive of placenta prove, where the uterus and placenta connection is weakened and uterine arteries pulled in different directions. Placental rupture would cause painFUL vaginal bleeding, ectopic pregnancy is not likely as thereby had a recent normal scan, and hem moral bleeding would be more likely to cause rectal rather than vaginal bleeding. It is also very unlikely that at 28 weeks she would experience an early labour and this would not explain the vaginal bleeding.

Question: Immature CD8 T cells require 2 signals to activate them, what are these two signals?
OptionA:
B7 co-receptor on Dendritic Cell binding to CD28 T cell receptor

CXCR 3 receptor on the Dendritic Cell
OptionB:
CCR7 receptor on Dendritic Cell

Antigen presentation of the viral antigen
OptionC:
MHC and peptide on a Dendritic Cell
B7 co-receptor on Dendritic Cell binding to CD28 T cell receptor
OptionD:
MHC and peptide on a Dendritic Cell

CCR7 receptor on Dendritic Cell
OptionE:
Presentation of the whole viral antigen

CXCR 3 receptor on the Dendritic Cell
Explanation:
Any immature CD8 T cell require these two signals:

Firstly MHC and peptide on a Dendritic Cell
And then B7 co-receptor on Dendritic Cell binding to CD28 T cell receptor

Question: A young girl comes into your clinic with a viral rash, you know that Measles and Rubella have very similar symptoms and so need to distinguish between these two viruses. They are both from the Paramyxoviridae family but which one of the following is not a true difference between the two viruses?
OptionB: Measles causes a cough, koplik spots and muscle pain, Rubella causes fever, sore throat and conjunctivitis
OptionC: Measles has a 10 day incubation period, Rubella has a 14-21 day incubation period
OptionD: Measles has a human only reservoir, Rubella has a human and animal reservoir
OptionE: Measles is an ss(-)RNA virus, Rubella is an ss(+)RNA virus
Explanation: All the other statements are true except D- as both Measles and Rubella are human only viruses with no known animal reservoir.

Question: On the emergency ward there is a child who has type 1 diabetes mellitus that has gone into diabetic ketoacidosis. Firstly you replace her fluid loss with I/V saline solution, what are the next most important things to consider in her treatment?
OptionA: Replacing electrolytes, restoring acid-base balance and slow infusion of Insulin
OptionB: Replacing lost potassium stores, emptying her bladder of acidic urine, providing glucose drinks
OptionC: Slowing giving Insulin by I/V drip, replacing lost carbohydrate stores and taking swabs
OptionD: Taking swabs to identify whether ad infection is present, taking bloods, preventing any intake of food until stabilised
OptionE: Treating the underlying infection, keeping her still and flat, ensuring she has adequate carbohydrates
Explanation:
The most important steps in treating DKA is to:

- Replace fluid loss

- Replace electrolytes

- Restore acid-base balance

- Give a slow infusion of Insulin

All other steps mentioned above can come later on or in some cases are not required.

Question:
A 24 year old primigravida is pregnant with twins at 17 weeks gestation. She has been experiencing nausea and vomiting of moderate intensity that is always worse in the morning.

She has tried nonpharmacologic therapies with little success, and despite eating in small amounts and avoiding odours and foods that make her nauseous, she is still vomiting frequently and has lost a significant amount of weight in the last couple of weeks. Labs reveal a hypochloremic alkalosis. As a GP, what is the best advice to give this female, given the circumstances?
OptionA: Advise the patient to drink more water and avoid caffeine and spicy foods, and to avoid eating as frequently as she has been doing.
OptionC: Prescribe the patient an antiemetic and antihistamine and ask the patient to return if the nausea does not improve
OptionD: Prescribe the patient chlorpromazine and glucocorticoids and ask the patient to return if the nausea does not improve
OptionE: Urgent referral to hospital to receive IV treatment
Explanation: This scenarios seems like a classic case of Hyperemesis Gravidum, excessive vomiting during pregnancy that often persists past 16 weeks and in ones first pregnancy; Kate Middleton reportedly had it with her first child. Weight loss and dehydration are common symptoms but the classic lab finding of metabolic hypochloraemic alkalosis (low chloride ion level in the blood) is indicative of the condition if features match. Patients with this finding should be rushed to hospital immediately to receive IV treatment for dehydration and malnutrition. IV drugs and antiemetics may be given at hospital as well.

Question: A pregnant lady is having some hormone levels measured at the start of her second trimester. Which out of the following hormones would you expect to be elevated relative to a normal healthy woman who is not pregnant and of the same age?
Explanation: All the hormones bar prolactin show decreased levels in pregnancy. Prolactin is elevated as it is shown to have a role in fluid balance in the fetus. It is produced in the anterior pituitary and also has a role in milk secretion.

Question: A pregnant women approaching her 3rd trimester is complaining strongly of shortness of breath. The General practitioner explains this is most likely completely normal in pregnancy. Which of the following volume changes is most likely causing the dyspnoea in this patient?
Explanation:
In pregnancy as the abdomen grows, the diaphragm elevates about or so 4cm and the ribs are pushed up and out as though one is expiring.

This creates a decreased expiratory reserve volume , and although this is physiologically balanced out by an increased tidal volume this still gives the sensation of shortness of breath to some pregnant women.

Question: A medical student is exploring the function of haem synthesis in the human body and founds out that most cells can carry out haem synthesis. Which of the following cells or organs cannot carry out haem synthesis?
Explanation: Erythrocytes/Red blood cells cannot carry out haem synthesis as they lack mitochondria, which contains the vitally important enzymes of Ferrochelatase and ALA synthase. Haem synthesis does occur in RBC progenitor cells however.

Question: An Foundation Year doctor is examining a chest X-ray and is trying to determine what the darkest colour is supposed to be representative of. Which of the following is the most likely correct composition producing the darkest colour?
Explanation: The more dense the substance, the whiter it appears; this is a general rule to apply when looking at X-rays. Air/gas is the least dense out of the list so will appear really black and dark. Metal, as the most dense object on the list would likely appear as a very bright white.

Question: An anatomist is inspecting a new cadaver and is keen to locate some plicae circulares; which of the following locations is the best place for her to find such features?
Explanation: Plicae Circulares are found prominently in the small intestine but are much more extensive in the jejunum compare to the duodenum and ileum. Plicae circulares are out foldings of both the mucosa and submucosa

Question:
A farm labourer shovelling horse manure cuts his hand on a tool. 6 days later he finds that his jaw is very stiff and he has a bit of a temperature. He visits his GP and who reviews his immunisation history.

Which booster immunisation is he most likely to have missed as a child?
Explanation: He is likely to have missed his DTaP/IPV/Hib booster because this contains a tetanus toxin. This would have caused him to have developed immunity to Tetanus toxins. Tetanus is caused by an infection with the bacterium Clostridium tetani, which is commonly found in soil, dust and manure. The bacteria generally enter through a break in the skin such as a cut or puncture wound by a contaminated object. The bacteria can quickly multiply and release a toxin that affects the nerves, causing symptoms such as muscle stiffness and spasms.

Question:
After birth a number of changes happen in the babies circulatory system to adjust to being outside of the womb. The closure of the umbilical vein allows blood to begin to flow through the liver then into the Inferior vena cava.

 

Which of the fetal shunts will this close?
Explanation: Ductus venosus connects the umbilical vein directly to the Inferior vena cava so blood skips the liver. After birth the close of the umbilical vein leads to the contraction and closure of this shunt to form the ligamentum venosum.

Question: Which of the below is NOT a key haemotological change during normal pregnancy?
Explanation:
Physiological Anaemia occurs due to heamodilution of the blood ( great rise in plasma volume then blood cells volume)

Mild thrombocytopenia meaning low platelet count which can occur during pregnancy with no pathological effects. However can be a sign of worsening condition in preeclampsia. 

Increase in procoagulants in order to protect against excessive bleeding after delivery. 

 

Folate deficiency anaemia does not occur in normal pregnancies however if the mother is folate deficient there is an increased risk of neural tube defects. Hence mothers are recommended to take folate tablets,

Question: You encounter a psychiatric patient who has been having regular flashbacks of a traumatic incident from a number of years ago. This has been happening for over 2 months and you, as the psychiatric foundation year doctor, recommend that he has Cognitive Based and Therapy and another psychotherapy type intervention. Which out of the following do you most likely recommend?
Explanation:
The patient's main symptom and time length is consistent with PTSD and, along with CBT, EMDR can be used to address it.

 

Research has shown that EMDR is the most effective and rapid method for healing PTSD.

 

"The therapy uses bilateral stimulation, right/left eye movement, or tactile stimulation, which repeatly activates the opposite sides of the brain, releasing emotional experiences that are "trapped" in the nervous system. This assists the neurophysiological system, the basis of the mind/body connection, to free itself of blockages and reconnect itself."

 

This topic was mentioned in one of the Virtual Cases in Case 12

Question: Your friend across the street from you is acting rather odd. He believes that "MI5 are out" to get him, despite being a young student, with no criminal conviction or dangerous/suspicious activities to his name. Which of the following terms best describes the feature that your friend is displaying?
Explanation:
A delusion, as defined in psychiatry, is a false belief firmly maintained in spite of indisputable and obvious evidence to the contrary. .This 'belief' is not usually shared with other members of patient's culture/subculture.

 

A hallucination is a perception in the absence of external stimuli (for example, believing that you have heard a bomb when no sound is present).

 

An illusion is a misinterpretation of external stimuli (for example, mistaking a car sound for gunfire)

Question:
A 44-year-old man with a history of depression is suspended from his clerical job because his boss is unhappy with his slowness. His depression is currently in complete remission but he suffers from side effects from his medication, notably lethargy.

 

What statutory act protects him from his employer?
Explanation:
These protect individuals from discrimination in the following situations:

  • At work
  • In education
  • As a consumer
  • When using public services
  • When buying or renting property
  • As a member or guest of a private club or association

The Equality Act sets out the different ways in which it is unlawful to treat someone, such as direct and indirect discrimination, harassment, victimisation and failing to make a reasonable adjustment for a disabled person.

Question:
A 22-year-old engineering student has developed an addiction to a novel psychoactive substance, methoxetamine. He has started to inject it and knows that it is causing huge problems in his life but he doesn’t want to talk to his GP about it because he’s afraid that they will label him as a “dirty druggie”.

 

What type of behaviour is being described?
Explanation: Felt or Self-Stigma: Describes feelings such as shame that interfere with a person seeking help. It describes the fear or shame that an individual or group may have that they, and their condition, will be negatively viewed. It may result in people avoiding healthcare and not seeking help when needed and not following through with medical instructions because they believe they are not deserving of help.

Question: What is the key significance of the labelling theory of deviance?
OptionA: It demonstrates how powerfully one’s judgements and identity can be influenced by the perceptions and judgements of other people
OptionB: It shows how deviant behaviour is learned acivity
OptionC: It illustrates how marginalised people can have a difficult time identifying with societies norms
OptionD: It indicates how the impact of labels can be easily deflected through techniques of neutralisation
Explanation: The labelling theory states that a person becomes deviant, not because of the act itself, but from how people react to that act, and a person may accepts the label as a personal identity. Through this, the labelling theory demonstrates how powerfully one’s judgements and identity can be influenced by the perceptions and judgements of other people

Question:
A 29-year-old female reports that, for most days  over the past 2 years, she has felt "down" and occasionally "mildly depressed."

 

Over this period, she also describes herself feeling tired, being easily distracted, and often sleeping more than in the past.

 

The patient denies any manic or hypomanic periods, refutes any suggestion of suicidal thoughts and says that she did not have any periods of  worsening of her depressed mood beyond what she has described.

 

What is the minimum amount of time this patient must exhibit these symptoms in order to meet the diagnostic criteria for dysthymia?
Explanation:
To be diagnosed with dysthymia or chronic depressive disorder, the

o Patient must NOT have any major depressive episodes in a two-year period

o Must NOT have any episodes of hypomania 

o Retain persistent, subclinical and mild depressive symptoms for two years minimum 

o Retain generally normal function despite depressed mood.

Question:
Caffeine is an antagonist for which of the following regulatory molecules?

 

A patient has come into A&E with heart palpitations following drinking too much Red bull. The registrar you are shadowing explains to you that the palpitations is probably due to taking too much caffeine. For which of the following is caffeine an antagonist?
Explanation: Caffeine has various pharmacological actions, but the one that is most likely involved in its action as a stimulant is that caffeine acts as an adenosine antagonist. Adenosine is a regulatory molecule released by neurons and glia, and it accumulates as a consequence of neuronal activity and metabolism.There is evidence to suggest that the accumulation of adenosine is what is responsible for sleep drive--the need for sleep that occurs after prolonged wakefulness.

Question: You are looking at a neurone map of the brain and see that serotonergic fibres pass through almost the entire brain. Which of the following brain locations can one expect to find the greatest  abundance of 5-HT neurons?
Explanation:
5-HT neurons are confined in highest abundance in the Raphe Nuclei along with a mix of other neuron.

They have extensive projections so that virtually every neurone in the brain may be contacted by a serotonergic fibre.

Question: A young girl is exploring the effects of dopamine after her father is diagnosed with Parkinson's disease. She tells her dad's neurologist that some vitamin supplements may be needed as her dad's diet is not the best and she knows the importance of a particular vitamin in the synthesis of dopamine. Which specific vitamin is she most likely referring to?
Explanation: Vitamin BG/Pyridoxine is a cofactor required for the enzyme L-aromatic amino acid decarboxylase (AADC) which converts L-DOPA to dopamine.

Question:
John, a 32-year-old man presents to his General practitioner with his friend, convinced that the government is after him for his secrets. His friend believes it to be all nonsense, saying that John has not left the house the house in a a few weeks and has lost all motivation to work at his job.

At the interview John speaks very little and expresses little emotion, looking at the corner of the room? Which of the following is a positive symptom of the condition with which John is suffering from?
Explanation:
Delusions, the beliefs of a person in overwhelming evidence in a person's social/cultural group that these beliefs are false, is the only positive symptom here od schizophrenia. Basically, symptom that starts with an A is a negative symptom. These include

Avolition-lack of motivation

Anhedonia-Lack of feeling pleasure

 

Affective flattening-lack of emotional expression

Alogia-speech poverty

Asociality-socila disinterest

Question: Tyler, a 23 year old man, has been brought to the general practitioner by his mother as a result of a 4 week cascade of worsening symptoms. He has been feeling very low and has been waking up early in the morning. His friends have also noticed him feeling tired all the time and ruminating about not trying hard enough during his education, catastrophising how he will be stuck in the same job for the rest of his life. He eats little and seems to have trouble sleeping. Which of the following best describes a core symptom that Tyler has that is likely indicative of some form of depression?
Explanation:
Anhedonia, a lack of pleasurable feeling, is one of the 3 core symptoms of depression. The other two are low mood and anergia-feeling tired/lack of energy.

 

Note

Depression guidelines vary a lot. This question was created from the MSE tutorial Powerpoint of Case 12, so hopefully any depression symptoms questions will be based on this.

Question: A 18-year-old female visits her General practitioner complaining of a lack of dreams recently in her sleep. She has that she has been going to bed at quite irregular times; what stage of the normal sleep cycle is most commonly associated with dreaming?
Explanation: REM/Rapid eye movement sleep is most commonly associated with dreaming. The contents of this sleep stage include the re-emergence of alpha waves on the EEG, an increase in Noradrenaline and an increase in vital signs.

Question: Frank, a 23 year-old male, has been sleep deprived following a stressful bout of exams. A neurologist uses him in his research project to measure the time lengths in certain stages of the normal sleep cycle; he measures EEG levels when Frank had insomnia/sleep disruption and is now measuring them for the first time after his exams. The neurologist informed Frank that he had a normal night's sleep compared to the last time she measured his EEG activity. Which of the following findings did the neurologist most likely discover with the EEG trace compared to the previous one she measured?
OptionA: An increase in REM sleep time length
OptionB: An increase in stage 1 time length only
OptionC: An increase in stage 1 and 2 time length
OptionD: An increase in stage 3 and 4 time length
OptionE: An increase in stage 4 time length only
Explanation: In response to sleep restoration, stages 3 and 4 are restored almost immediately. This is discussed in the case 12 sleep lecture

Question: You examining a brain map as part of a neurology project and are trying to locate an area known as the primary auditory cortex. Which of the following brain lobes is this area located?
Explanation: The primary auditory cortex-areas 41 and 42 on the brain map-is found in the temporal lobe

Question: A mother is awaiting her child's first MMR vaccine at her local surgery; she is told that her child will have a booster injection after this initial timeframe. Which of the following option is the correct one is stating the correct times when a child should have their MMR vaccination injections?
OptionA: First Vaccination at 5 to 6 months, Booster at 12 to 13 months
OptionB: First vaccination at 12 to 13 months, Booster at 18-19 months
OptionC: First Vaccination at 12 to 13 months, Booster at 24 to 36 months
OptionD: First Vaccination at 12 to 13 months, Booster at 40 to 60 months
OptionE: First Vaccination at 12 to 13 months, Booster at 48 and 70 months
Explanation:
The first dose of vaccine is usually given between 12 and 13 months. It is usually given at the same time as the Hib/MenC vaccine - this stands for 'Haemophilus influenzae type b/meningitis C' and the pneumoccocal vaccine (given as separate injections).

A second dose is usually given at age 3 years and 4 months to 5 years at the same time as the DTaP/IPV injection. (DTaP stands for diphtheria (D), tetanus (T) and acellular pertussis (aP) (whooping cough). IPV stands for inactivated polio vaccine. Polio is short for poliomyelitis.)

Question:
Vitamin B6 is used in the manufacture the enzyme L aromatic amino acid de-carboxylase. A key enzyme in the pathways associated with mono-amine formation. 

 

Jack Daniels is an alcoholic, leading to him having a deficiency in Vitamin B6 and Folic acid.

Which mono-amine will be significantly decreased due to this?
Explanation:
AADC is a key enzyme involved in the synthesis of serotonin, dopamine and noradrenaline. 

It converts L-dopa to dopamine and 5-hydroxytryptophan to serotonin. 

(5-HT = serotonin and 5-HTP = 5-hydroxytryptophan)

Therefore without the enzyme there will be increased L-dopa, and 5-HTP and decreased 5-HT

Glutamate and GABA have a different synthesis mechanism.

Question: A young patient is being examined by a psychiatrist for their Mental State Examination. A diagnosis of schizophrenia is made, with one positive symptoms standing out; which of the following is most likely that positive symptom?
Explanation: You may encounter all these symptoms in someone diagnosed with schizophrenia; however C is particularly iconic in schizophrenia patients and is often the easiest symptom to elicit. D is also a possibility but acutely seen in organic causes (brain tumour for example) . E  and B are also positive symptoms but are quite general-they could relate to a whole range of condition. Avolition (lack of motivation) is a negative symptom.

Question: You encounter a patient who is having strong auditory hallucinations of a nature that you believe is diagnostic of schizophrenia. However, a key note that your supervising consultant tells you is that the patient is saying that they can directly talk with the voices that they hear, and get responses. What is the most likely differential diagnosis?
Explanation: This particular feature, of having voices that the patient can talk, is very indicative of an organic cause of hallucinations and is seen in a traumatic head injury. In schizophrenia, you do not usually find patient who can talk back to the voices and engage in conversation with them.  Brief psychotic disorder is just basically schizophrenia where symptoms disappear after one month since the emergence of symptoms.Epilepsy and alcohol withdrawal may mimic schizophrenia symptoms but are classed as organic causes of hallucinations.

Question: A 22-year-old pregnant lady is having some pregnancy nutrition advice and is advised to avoid certain foods, including ripened soft cheese and pate. Which specific condition is the doctor wanting the patient to avoid by getting her not to eat these foods?
Explanation: Listeriosis is an infection with a gram positive bacteria called listeria. Infection can lead to amnionitis, septicaemia and/or spontaneous abortion. It is a food borne bacteria and is commonly found in cold deli foods.

Question:
A 22 year old male has been diagnosed with Schizophrenia. He was prescribed a first line treatment but didn't respond well to it. He has now been given a new treatment plan and has the following side effects:

 

Weight gain

Increased blood pressure

Mild agranulocytosis (significantly reduced WBC count)

Frequent urination

 

What is the most likely drug that has been prescribed in the new drug plan?
Explanation:
Aripiprazole counteracts the side effects of clozapine

Risperidone is a first line drug treatment

Question:
A 25 year old woman has been admitted to her local Community Mental Health Team (CMHT). In her notes, the psychiatrist reads that the woman has been displaying “negative symptoms of schizophrenia”.

 

Which of the following is NOT a negative symptom?
Explanation:
A. abnormal perceptions. Abnormal perceptions, such as hallucinations, are a positive psychotic symptom of schizophrenia. Positive symptoms are symptoms where something is added to normality.

All of the other options (plus asociality) are negative symptoms, where something is taken away from normality e.g. alogia is poverty of speech.

Question:
Shaggy and Scooby come across a dank bag of reefa (Cannabis). Just before Scooby whiteys, they ask themselves with receptor does the active ingredient in cannabis bind to?

From the memoirs of Zac Morris.
OptionD: They would have got away with it, if it weren't for those meddling kids
Explanation: The active ingredient in Cannabis is delta-9-THC which binds to the CB1 receptor.

Question:
A 19 year old male comes into the psychiatry outpatients clinic, for a treatment review.

7 months ago, he started hearing voices scolding him. He also lost motivation to work and appeared unkempt.

He was given a diagnosis and was started on Risperidone and subsequently Olanzapine for 2 weeks, after the former did not work.

He has also refused to receive any talking therapies.

 

He tells you today at this consultation that he is still hearing voices.

What would be the recommended next step?
OptionB: Keep encouraging him to undergo talking therapy
Explanation:
Continue prescribing Olanzapine is the correct answer, because he has only been on it for 2 weeks.

We need to allow more time (6 weeks) for the drug to work.

If he had already been on it for 6 weeks, we would prescribe Clozapine because it is used in the case of treatment resistance to other medications, therefore D is not correct.

 

B is not correct because he has previously stated he does not want this.

C is incorrect because this is a SSRI antidepressant

E is a typical antipsychotic which can cause motor side effects

Question: A patient comes into your GP surgery. This individual has a history of psychotic breakdowns and have been prescribed chlorpromazine. The individual has been taking it for 2 years. They are experiencing facial ticks, gestures, tongue protrusions as well as pursing of the lips. Which pathway is this drug affecting to exhibit the aforementioned side effects?
Explanation:
A - This is a generic answer for all pathways that dopamine is involved in, and is not the best answer.

B - This pathway is involved with cognitive behaviour and negative symptoms. Therefore the drug will exacerbate negative symptoms which were not described in the text above.

C - This pathway is involved in the reward pathway and when blocked reduces pleasure.

D - Correct as this pathway is involved with extra-pyramidal motor movements. When blocked they present with the effects described in the question - such as tardive dyskinesia and actue dystonia (in short term cases) - this is not described in the text above.

E - This pathway is involved with the inhibition of prolactin release. Therefore when blocked there will be no inhibition of prolactin release and will cause hyperprolactinaemia leading to lactation. This is not described in the text above.

Question: You are seeing a 14-year-old male patient about symptoms that include anhedonia, low mood and tiredness all the time over the last 3 weeks, since a traumatic. The patient's father is anxious about his son and wants him to take antidepressants. As a responsible General practitioner, you advise against this. What is the strongest reason for advising against antidepressant medication for this patient?
OptionA: CBT is the best treatment on offer and would suit the patient better
OptionB: The side effects associated with antidepressants, such as sedation and constipation, outweigh the benefits
OptionC: The patient is just feeling sad and does not need medication
OptionD: There is an increased suicide tendency in children prescribed antidepressants
OptionE: It is illegal to prescribe antidepressants to under 18s
Explanation: The 2nd Neuropharmacology provides the basis for this answer; antidepressants should ideally not be prescribed to children as there is an increased suicidal tendency and self harm risk, particularly in the first 7-8 weeks after starting the medication. Other options, such as lifestyle changes and support network features should be first explored before medication is recommended.

Question: A 25 year old male has an appointment with his psychiatrist at the Community Mental Health Centre. He was diagnosed with Type 1 Bipolar Affective Disorder 2 years ago. After completing a mental state examination, the psychiatrist decides the patient is having a manic episode. What would be the best pharmacological treatment option?
Explanation:
Olanzpine is an antipsychotic

Citalopram is an antidepressant

Lithium and Valporate are mood stabilisng drugs used to treat Bipolar Affective Disorder

 

In manic episodes, an antipsychotic is given as treatment on top of the mood stabilising drugs.

Question: Mr Jones has been invited to a 'Cheese and wine' night with his friends from case based learning. He has been taking monoamine oxidase inhibitors for 6 years. Why might he encounter issues on such an evening?
OptionA: Build up of tryptophan causes loss of consciousness
OptionC: Excess tyramine leads to build up of catecholamines
OptionD: Excess tryptophan leads to build up of serotonin
OptionE: The interaction of alcohol and MAOIs causes loss of libido
Explanation:
Cheese and wine contain high levels of tyramine, which is usually broken down by MAO (monoamine oxidase) in the gut. When taking MAOIs, this process is prevented.This causes a build up of tyramine which is the precursor for adrenaline and noradrenaline. This can lead to systemic sympathetic activation, e.g. heart palpitations and high blood pressure.

 

D is correct but not relevant to this question. The rest are all made up

Question: A 28 year old male has been treated for depression for several years.  The Dr chose to change his medication to an alternative antidepressant as his symptoms were not improving.  He was given a list of dietry requirements which included not eating certain cheeses, meats and alcoholic drinks, such as port.  Which of the following drugs has he been mostly likely been prescribed?
Explanation:
The answer is D - Phenelzine. 

C and D are both MAOI's and have an interaction to tyramine which is found in the foods listed.  However, Moclobemide has less dietry interactions as it is a non-traditional MAOI (being both reversible and selective).  Consequently, Phenelzine is most correct.

Question:
A 21-year old woman is referred to her psychiatrist presenting with auditory hallucinations, delusional perceptions and thought broadcasting. Her mother also comments that she has become more socially withdrawn in recent months.

 

She is prescribed an anti-psychotic drug. She is told to return every week to monitor her blood count due to the risk of agranulocytosis. 

 

Which anti-psychotic drug is she most likely to have been prescribed?
Explanation:
Most drugs in the second generation of anti-psychotic drugs have risk of bone marrow suppression. However, clozapine has the greatest risk of agranulocytosis (1-2% of patients). Third generation drugs have no bone marrow suppression.

 

Citalopram is an anti-depressant.

Question: A patient has schizophrenia and believes that he is Leonardo Di Caprio and he is about to win an Oscar. Which symptom is the patient presenting with?
Explanation: The patient is suffering from a secondary delusion because it is self referential and related to his elevated emotional state. It is a delusion of grandiosity because he believes he is someone of social importance.

Question:
A 54 year old man comes to his GP complaining of not being able to sleep well the past few weeks.

 

The patient seems very tired and says that he has been quite stressed in work recently.

 

You think he is not getting enough slow wave sleep.

 

What features would you see on an EEG for normal slow wave, stages 3 and 4 sleep?
OptionD: Delta waves with K complexes and sleep spindles.
Explanation: C is correct. You should only see delta waves in slow wave sleep.

Question:
A 21 year old male, simon cosis, presents with low mood and paranoid delusions. His parents say that they have noticed he has become notionally detached from his friends and rarely leaves the house. They say they can here him talking to himself at night. 

What pathway is most likely to be responsible for his hallucinations and delusional thoughts.
Explanation:
mesolimbic is responsible for positive symptoms of schizophrenia 

mesocortical is responsible for negative symptoms of schizophrenia

Question: Stress is a well known risk factor for depression. Which hormone is released from the anterior pituitary gland as part of the stress release?

Michelle is a 21 year old woman who, for the last 6 months, has become paranoid that the government has been watching her through her webcam. Her housemates, Kelly and Beyoncé cook her dinner one evening and she thinks she smells toxic gas coming from the food, a plot by the government to posion her. Which of the following terms best describe her symptoms?
Explanation: Because the food is actually there, the poisonous smell is an illusion, the delusion is thinking that the government is out to kill her, and this is why it is a persecutory delusion. She is paranoid, but answer A is most accurate.

Question: What are the features of 2nd (atypical) generation antipsychotics?
OptionA: Block Dopamine D2 and D1 receptors equally, similar side effects as typical antipsychotics.
OptionB: Block D1 receptors more than D2. Fewer extra-pyramidal side effects than typical antipsychotics.
OptionC: Block D1 receptors more than D2 and 5HT-2A receptors. Fewer extra-pyramidal side effects than typical antipsychotics.
OptionD: Block D2 receptors more than D1 and 5HT-2A receptors. More extra-pyramidal side effects than typical antipsychotics.
OptionE: Block D2 receptors more than D1. Fewer extra-pyramidal side effects than typical antipsychotics.
Explanation: C. 2nd Generation Antipsychotics block D1 dopamine receptors more than D2 dopamine receptors as well as 5HT-2A (Serotonin 2A) receptors. The lessened blocking of the Dopamine 2A receptors reduces the extra-pyramidal side effects that are present in typical antipsychotics (E.g. Acute dystonia and tardive dyskinesia) whilst still being an effective treatment of the positive symptoms of schizophrenia. The serotonin receptor blockade helps to treat the negative symptoms.

Question: Which section of the Mental Health Act allows a nurse detain a patient for 6hrs?
Explanation:
5.2 - you can be held for 72hrs

 

All the other sections are not relevant

Question: A patient comes into your surgery. He previously came to the surgery due to an episode of mania 6 months ago, and is now exhibiting symptoms of anhedonia, low mood and lethargy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation: BPAD type 1 must include at least one episode of mania, with an episode of depression, hypomania or mixed affective state. BPAD type 2 must have an episode of hypomania, plus an episode of depression or another episode of hypomania, but with no episode of mania or mixed affective state.

Question:
A 21 year old male has come into the CMHT centre that you were doing placement on. He has stated he recently moved from Jamaica and has been depressed for 'a little while'. He also says he is experiencing hallucinations and that he can hear voices talking around him, making him paranoid about what they are saying about him. The doctor has diagnosed him with schizophrenia and puts together a care plan.

 

What is the most likely first line of treatment in the care plan?
Explanation:
The correct answer is Risperidone

Clozapine is a 2nd generation antipsychotic but is more likely to be used if the initial drug treatment doesn't work (2 other drugs don't work). It could be used but is very expensive so is not ideal and use may be discouraged initially

 

CBT may be given at a future point, but its unlikely the individual would attend without the use of an antipsychotic so would not be the first line treatment

 

Given the extrapyramidal motor effects of 1st generation anti-psychotics, this is unlikely to be the first treatment given thus rules out Haloperidol

 

ECT is not used as the first treatment, usually for drug-resistant and severe cases

Question:
Anjikita has been experiencing some phsychiatric issues. Her GP prescribed her an antipsychotic.

Her blood tests show that she has a low white blood cell count.

What drug has she most likely  been prescribed?
Explanation: Clozapine has been known to cause agranulocytosis, so it is recommended that patients on clozapine have their bloods tested regularly.

Question:
A 42 year old male is admitted to the emergency department with a severe headache. He has systolic blood pressure of 148 mmHg and is tachycardic. He has been under a lot of stress recently and has been feeling down for several months. The GP has prescribed him some medication which has been successful in lifting his mood. However, he has not been following dietary advice for his medication.

Which of the following drugs has he been prescribed in the past which has caused the symptoms he has presented with today?
Explanation:
This man is taking Monoamine oxidase inhibitor and hasn't been following his dietary advice. Monoamine oxidase is an enzyme used to break down tyrosine (found in foods such as cheese and soy foods). An increase in tyrosine levels in the blood causes vasoconstriction of blood vessels, hence the symptoms: headache, tachycardic and high diastolic BP.  

 

'cheese reaction'

Question: You encounter a patient with atrial fibrillation and are attempting to assess the aetiology of the condition via the patient's history; your supervising consultant tells you that the patient's AF should not be reversible. Which of the following is thus the most likely cause of the patient's AF?
Explanation: Only E is a non-reversible potential cause of AF; all others can be potentially reversed

Question: A 74-year-old woman with a history of atrial fibrillation controlled with warfarin, diagnosis of diabetes, seizure disorder and recent MRSA infection is admitted to the hospital. Shebegins therapy with another drug and is found to have a supratherapeutic International Normalized Ratio (INR). Which of the following drugs is likely contributing to this patient's elevated INR?
Explanation:
Warfarin is metabolized by the cytochrome P-450 pathway. Inhibitors of this pathway include valproic acid and result in a decrease the metabolism of warfarin and increase a patient's INR.

Warfarin is an oral anticoagulant that interferes with the production of clotting factors II, VII, IX, X and factors C and S via inhibition of Vitamin K epoxide reductase. This enzyme deficiency depletes the use of vitamin K needed for clotting factor synthesis. Monitoring of warfarin's effects is done using INR.

Question: A 25-year-old male with a previous history of schizophrenia, visits his GP. He presents with auditory hallucinations, lack of concentration, repetitive movements, delusions and thought interference. Which would be the most appropriate treatment option?
Explanation: The diagnosis is schizophrenia, which can be treated with antipsychotic drugs. Lack of concentration is a negative symptom, and therefore, an atypical antipsychotic would be the best option. Atypical antipsychotics are more effective in treating negative symptoms as well as positive. Whereas, typical antipsychotics only treat the positive symptoms of schizophrenia.

Question:
Mr Jones comes to visit you in the GP practice.

 

6 months ago, you diagnosed him with depression and prescribed fluoxetine and a course of CBT but he has still not managed to see anyone as the waiting list is very long

 

Today he complains that he is not feeling any better, his appetite has not returned and he is still not sleeping well

 

What is the most appropriate course of action for you to take?
OptionB: Remove his prescription for fluoxetine and try to get him moved up the waiting list for CBT
Explanation:
Depression that is resistant to SSRI's (eg: Fluoxetine) is best treated with SNRI's (eg: Venlafaxine)

 

Source: Virtual Case on Depression and Cancer

Question: The long term stress response gives rise to the release of glucose from the liver and immunosuppression. What area does aderenocorticotropic hormone target and what type of molecule is released from here?
Explanation:
The long term stress response is called the Hypothalamic pituitary adrenal axis.

Cortisol is a glucocorticoid and is released from the Zona fasiculata layer of the adrenal cortex

Question: You are measuring a patient's blood pressure and get the reading 182/113. What is the correct definition of the condition relating to someone with this Blood pressure?

An elderly lady presents with problems performing simple tasks such as buttoning blouses or holding the phone. She has wasting of the small muscles of the hand and partial clawing of the little and ring fingers. Which nerve is likely to be damaged?
Explanation: This represents "Ulnar claw" - caused by ulnar nerve palsy.

Question: A 42-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency room after being mauled by a bear on a hunting trip.  He has a blood pressure of 60/40, a heart rate of 122, and his skin is pale, cool to the touch, and moist, while you can see a pool of blood surrounding a patient. This patient is most likely experiencing all of the following EXCEPT
Explanation:
The clinical situation is consistent with a patient in hypovolemic shock.

Increased stroke volume is not a characteristic of hypovolemic shock.

 

Hypovolemic shock is characterized by increased systemic vascular resistance, decreased cardiac output, decreased stroke volume, decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, and decreased central venous pressure.
Tags: Acute Care, Group 62, Emergency Medicine, Case 13, Case 4

Question: A patient presents with dizziness and some chest pain. Based on the ECG, what is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
The ECG shows an irregulary irregular ventricular rate. A narrow QRS complex (<120ms).There is also an absence of P waves. This is typical of Atrial Fibrilation.

Atrial Flutter=Saw toothed flutter waves would be present

SVT with WPW would have broad QRS complexes (>120ms) as there is cell to cell propagation of the action potential in the ventricles, not the usual conduction via His-Purkinje system. Ventricular tachycardia would also have broad QRS complexes.

Question: A patient is admitted and diagnosed with a STEMI based on the clinical history, ECG and Cardio biomarkers measured. A cardiologist is trying to identify where the infarct is located and judges it to be in the anteroseptal compartment of the heart. Which of the following ECG findings best supports this judgement?
OptionA: ST elevation in leads V4 and V5
OptionB: ST elevation and Q waves in leads V1, V2 and V3
OptionC: ST elevation in leads II, II and aVF
OptionD: ST elevation in leads V1, V2, V3 ,V4, V5, V6, I and aVL
OptionE: ST elevation and Q waves in leads V1, V2, V3 ,V4, V5, V6, I and aVL
Explanation:
ST elevation and/or Q waves in leads V1, V2 and V3 is indicative of an infarction in anteroseptal compartment of the heart.

D and E are indicative of an infarction in the Anterolateral heart area

Question: Mrs Allen receives her results from her recent amniocentesis. The results indicate a healthy foetus, however upon assessing the cells of the mother with the use of a microscope some anomalies were found. Her cells contained two barr bodies, what is her genotype?
Explanation: Barr bodies are the inactive x chromosomes found on the periphery of the cell. One barr bodie indicates 2 X chromosomes ( normal female). A presence of two barr bodies means that they have 47 chromosomes. (XXX)

Question: A 68 year old man comes to see you in your surgery. He has recently been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation, and you are discussing treatment options. He says he doesn't what to take any pills for his AF, as it is infrequent and doesn't bother him much. However, because of his CHADSVASC score, you advise him ...
OptionA: To return to the surgery within 3 months
Explanation: His CHADS2VASC2 score is 1 because of his age, which means that he is at risk enough of a stroke to require treatment. Therefore he should take an anticoagulant, such as warfarin.

Question:
A 29-year-old army officer goes to the local cardiology clinic complaining of dizziness, fatigue, and dyspnoea. One month ago, the patient went on a mission trip in the forest of dean and has been hospitalised since due to an infection of some sorts.

On assessment, vital signs are temperature 36.9°C, blood pressure 100/65, heart rate 41, and respiratory rate 16 with an oxygen saturation of 99%.

A print of the EKG strip is shown . What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Third degree (complete) AV block; the atria and ventricles beat independently of each other because of disruption in the conduction pathway in the heart.

 

Normal conduction of electricity through the heart starts at the SA node, travels to the AV node, and then to the ventricles via the bundle of His and Purkinje system.

If there is some breach in the normal conductive pathway, other cells in the heart can set an alternative heart rate, albeit at a slower rate.

In this case, the patient’s symptoms can be attributed to bradycardia.

Given the patient’s exposure to wooded areas a potential cause of this patient’s block is Lyme disease.

Patients with suspected Lyme carditis require hospitalization for cardiac monitoring and treatment with intravenous antibiotics such as ceftriaxone.

Question:
A 21 year old male patient comes into your GP surgery with symptoms of blackout. An ECG is performed, showing shortened PR interval and a delta wave on the QRS.

 

What condition does this patient have?

Where is the aetiology located in the heart normally?
Explanation: WPW is caused by an accessory pathway in the Bundle of Kent, AVRT is also correct, but WPW is more correct.This causes the characteristic signs in the ECG.

Question:
A 65 year-old patient attended his GP surgery for his regular INR check. He is taking warfarin for his AF. He's recently been discharged from hospital after pneumonia.

 

You are very concerned about him since his INR has a value of 6 at this check up.

 

What's the most likely reason for this?
OptionB: He's forgotten to take his warfarin tablet today
Explanation:
Correct answer: Due to his pneumonia, he has most likely had a course of antibiotics. These could have affected the speed at which his liver metabolises the warfarin, resulting in a very high INR.

 

Eating too much spinach would raise Vitamin K in your system, which would decrease your INR.

 

Forgetting to take your warfarin would decrease your INR.

 

Taking two warfarin tablets once would increase your INR, but not as much as in this question.

 

The test results are probably correct.

Question: An 84 year old new female patient comes to your GP practice with palpitations, shortness of breath, and a BP of 180/110. Upon taking a history you find out she has atrial fibrillation. She also had a stroke 3 years ago, has type 2 diabetes and a BMI of 32. What is her CHADS-Vasc score?
Explanation:
She has hypertension (her blood pressure was more than 140/90, she's more than 75 years old, she has diabetes, had a stroke and she's female.

 

1+ 2+ 1+ 2+ 1 = 7

Question: An 81 year old female who has T2DM and asthma presents with persistent palpations, racing heart, dizziness and high BP. (170/102 mmHg). She has been diagnosed with Atrial Fibrillation by the senior cardiologist. What would be your first line of treatment?
Explanation: The first line of treatment is rate control, this would be either beta blockers or calcium channel blockers (class 2 or class 4) however as she is asthmatic she can not be given beta blockers (propanol) so must be given a calcium channel blocker (verapamil). Adenosine is used for atrial flutter so would not be first line of treatment. Amiodarone is a potassium channel blocker and digoxin may be used if the veramapil is not effective. However bear in mind that digoxin should not be used for active fit people (NICE guidelines).

Question:
A 45-year old, Caucasian woman comes into the cardiology clinic complaining of palpitations, dizziness and shortness of breath. You perform an ECG and see a characteristic saw-toothed baseline. She has a heart rate of 150bpm, her blood pressure is 140/65 mmHg, and she is a diabetic.

 

Based on these findings, what is the diagnosis and what would you recommend as the first-line treatment?
Explanation: Saw-toothed baseline in ECG is characteristic of atrial flutter. Catheter ablation is first-line treatment for this condition as it is >90% curative.

Question: A cardiologist is conducting an ECG and puts the patient on amiodarone for Atrial fibrillation. The patient is curious as to how this drug works. The cardiologist explains that this drug affects a certain phase of the action potential. Which phase of the action potential is affected?
Explanation: Phase 3. Potassium channel blocker which prolongs repolarisation phase. Hence phase 3.

Question: Mr McCoy comes in with his neighbour and has a tale to tell his GP about his hoarse voice, lethargy and fever. His main problem was breathlessness whilst hoovering. The GP performed a 12 lead ECG. What's the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Pericarditis is seen on an ECG with saddle-shaped ST elevation and PR depression.

 

(Horse puns attributed to Case 69)

Question: June is a 72 year old lady. She had a pulmonary embolism 5 years ago. She has a blood pressure reading of 130/85mmHg and blood glucose reading of 6mmol. What is her CHADS-VASc score?
Explanation:
1 point- female

2 point- thromboembolic history

1 point- age

normal blood pressure and not a diabetic

Question:
Dave Harris is a 60 year old man who has been suffering for the past 6 months with increasingly frequent episodes of 'a fluttering heart.' He attends his GP who performs an ECG after taking a history. The RR interval is irregular and not every P wave is conducted to a QRS complex. However, for every 3 P waves there is a QRS complex.

 

What is the most likely diagnosis made by the GP?

A 69 year old man called Mr Trump recently experienced palpitations whilst expressing his radical views. Upon leaving the stage Mr Trump fainted and was rushed to hospital, injuring three protesters who were trying to stop the ambulance reaching the hospital. He survived a cardiac arrest and after an ECG was shown to have a broad complex tachycardia.

 

What is the recommended option for Mr Trump?
Explanation: Although Mr Trump may not deserve medical help as doctors we are obliged to offer treatment. He had ventricular tachycardia and an ICD is the most appropriate option.

Question: A 53 year old black female presents in your surgery with a blood pressure of 150/90. She is a heavy drinker, smokes 10-20 pack years and is a headteacher at a Secondary School in Merthyr Tydfil. In addition to recommending lifestyle modifications what would be your first line of treatment?
Explanation:
The NICE guidelines state that as she is of African or Caribbean (regardless of age) descent she should be prescribed Calcium Channel Blockers (Amlodipine) as a first line of treatment and NOT ACE inhibitors (Ramipril).

 

http://pathways.nice.org.uk/pathways/hypertension#path=view%3A/pathways/hypertension/treatment-steps-for-hypertension.xml&content=view-node%3Anodes-step-1-calcium-channel-blocker

Question:
You are reviewing a 30 year old patient with Atrial Fibrillation and he describes the medication he is taking. 

You are curious about the drugs he lists, and asks the cardiologist more about them. 

She tells you that one of the drugs works by reducing depolarisation phase 0 of a myocyte action potential.

Which of the following drugs works in this way?
Explanation: Given the cardiologists description that the drug acts on phase 0 the drug used is most likely to be Class I of the Vaughan Williams Classification System (Sodium channel blocker). Therefore the answer is Flecainide.

Question:
Mr Smith a 27 year old,  comes into his GP surgery for a check up. A trainee nurse asks to practice performing an ECG on him. 

She spots an irregularity.

What does this ECG show?
Explanation:
PR interval <120ms
Delta wave – slurring slow rise of initial portion of the QRS
QRS prolongation >110ms
ST Segment and T wave discordant changes – i.e. in the opposite direction to the major component of the QRS complex
Pseudo-infarction pattern can be seen in up to 70% of patients – due to negatively deflected delta waves in the inferior / anterior leads (“pseudo-Q waves”), or as a prominent R wave in V1-3 (mimicking posterior infarction).

Question: A 65 year old diabetic patient presents to his GP with a CHAD-VASC score of 3 and is consequently put on Warfarin. What would be the therapeutic target for his INR value?
