Explanation: The patient is diabetic and is over 65 so is in the high risk category for thrombosis. He therefore needs to aim for an INR value of 2.5-3.5.

Question:
A 53-year-old man comes to the GP complaining about chest pain, palpitations, dyspnoea and paresthesias. On examination the GP observes a depressed tendon reflex and some muscle weakness. The doctor orders a full blood count, dipstick urine test and an ECG.

 

What is the most probable diagnosis based on the ECG?
Explanation:
The ECG shows changes corresponding with Hyperkalaemia (at a serum potassium level of 6.5-8.0 mEq/L). The changes T wave changes are best seen in lead V3.

  • Most prominent change T wave peaked appearance with a greater amplitude and width than normal
  • Flattening of P wave
  • Prolongation of PR and QRS intervals

Management:

  • Calcium gluconate (doesn’t alter K+ but helps stabilise myocardium),
  • insulin and dextrose infusion,
  • calcium resonium,
  • iv fluids

Question: You are assessing a 66-year-old caucasian male patient who is on warfarin, as well as cardiac medications including bisoprolol. His Blood pressure is 168/100 and he has alcoholic liver disease. You suspect he still abuses alcohol. He was diagnosed with Atrial fibrillation some years ago, after a stroke. You have had problems controlling his INR levels. What is the best estimate of his HAS BLED score ?
Explanation:
Hypertension: Defined as systolic over 160= Score 1/1 for this patient

Abnormal Renal Function=0/1

Abnormal Liver function=1/1 for this patient 

Stroke=1/1 for this patient

Bleeding=0/1 -no significant bleeding history according to the stem

Labile INR=1/1 for this patient; his INR levels are not well controlled according to the stem

Elderly=1/1 for this patient as over the age of 65 

Drugs and or/alcohol=2/2 for this patient as he is suspected of alcohol abuse and other medication 

Total score=7 out of 8 

As score of 3 or more this indicates increased one year bleed risk on anticoagulation; this is sufficient to justify caution or more regular review with the patient

Question: During an annual retinopathy screening Mr Jones who is type 1 diabetic presents with cotton wool spots, some clusters of irregular branched vessels within the retina and venous bleeding appearing as loops and dilatations. As the doctor you are sent these results and have to reach a diagnosis of the stage of retinopathy present in Mr Jones' eye. Which is the best diagnosis?
Explanation:
Background retinopathy includes dots (microaneurysms), blots (haemorrhages) and hard exudates

Complete Blindness- can not determine from this information and very unlikely

Normal- this is not a normal set of findings

Pre-proliferative retinopathy- as described in the question, cotton wool spots (ischemia), intraretinal microvascular abnormalities and venous changes

Proliferative retinopathy- here there are new vessels formed and haemorrhage from these can cause complete blindness

Question: A 6yo boy has just been diagnosed with Type 1 Diabetes, as part of the process you must explain to his parents what this disease means. They ask you how insulin is normally produced in the body, you begin by explaining that pre-proinsulin goes through which process?
OptionA: Pre-proinsulin goes to the ER where it becomes A+B peptides (insulin) then moves to the Golgi apparatus where it is cleaved into C-peptide and insulin.
OptionB: Pre-proinsulin goes to the ER where it becomes proinsulin then moves to the Golgi apparatus where it is cleaved into A-peptide and peptides B+C (insulin)
OptionC: Pre-proinsulin goes to the ER where it becomes proinsulin then moves to the Golgi apparatus where it is cleaved into C-peptide and peptides A+B (insulin)
OptionD: Pre-proinsulin goes to the Golgi apparatus where it becomes proinsulin then moves to the ER where it is cleaved into C-peptide and peptides A+B (insulin)
OptionE: Pre-proinsulin goes to the Golgi apparatus where it becomes C-peptide then moves to the ER where it is cleaved into proinsulin and peptides A+B (insulin)
Explanation: Ribosomes produce proteins for pre-proinsulin from mRNA, in the ER this pre-proinsulin is converted into pro-insulin which is made up of 3 peptides (A, B and C). In the golgi apparatus this is then cleaved to form c-peptide and insulin (peptide A+B together). C-peptide then goes to membrane G protein whereas the insulin is secreted into the blood, travels to the liver and acts on insulin receptors.

Question: A 6yo female presents to A and E with faecal retention, constipation and a severely distended abdomen. After much investigation she is diagnosed with Hirschsprung's disease, a condition usually diagnosed at birth but may not present until later in childhood. One of the nerve plexuses most severely effected in this child is her myenteric plexus, which two intestinal layers does this plexus sit between?
OptionA: Between the circular muscle layer and the mucosa
OptionB: Between the circular muscle layer and the muscularis mucosae
OptionC: Between the longitudinal and circular muscle layers
OptionD: Between the longitudinal muscle layer and the muscularis mucosae
OptionE: Between the muscularis mucosae and the mucosa
Explanation:
The myenteric (Auerbach's) plexus sits between the circular and longitudinal muscle layers

The submucosal (Meissner's) plexus sits between the longitudinal muscle layer and the muscularis mucosae

Both of these plexuses are affected in Hirschsprung leading to paralysis of the bowel hence lack of bowel movements.
Tags: Abdomen, Anatomy, Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11, Histology

Question: You are given an ECG as a junior doctor on A&E. The P wave appears to be tall and pointed. What does this mean? The patient has ...
Explanation: The P wave represents the summation of electrical activity in the right atrium and left atrium. The right atrium depolarises slightly ahead of the left. Therefore RA enlargement causes a tall, pointed P wave. See the ECG tutorial powerpoint, slide 25.

Question: An elderly lady is rushed to A&E after fainting in the street and fracturing her arm. One of the nurses hands you her routine ECG. What is it suggestive of?
Explanation: Remember the mnemonic 'WiLLiaM'. V6 looks like an M, and V1 could be a sort of W (well not really). The LL stands for left BBB. These are pathological Q waves, because of failure of conduction through the bundle branches, which means that propagations of the depolarisation has to occur from myocyte to myocyte, which is slower than by normal specialised conduction tissue. See ECG tutorial powerpoint, slide 30. If it was right BBB, the appropriate mnemonic would be 'MaRRoW'.

Question:
An 11 year-old boy is brought into A&E by his worried parents who say he complained of a funny feeling in his chest, then passed out. You record an ECG and this is what you get:

 

 

 

What condition is this suggestive of?
Explanation: This is suggestive of WPW. This looks like slurring of the upstroke of the QRS complex, known as delta waves, and there is a shortened PR interval. Delta waves occur because there is 'pre-excitation' of the ventricles due to the accessory pathway.
Tags: Acute Care, ECGs, Emergency Medicine, Group 68, Cardiology

Question: A young man presents to his GP with angular stomatitis and glossitis, he is diagnosed with vitamin B2 (riboflavin) deficiency. Which of the following if the main role of vitamin B2?
Explanation:
Vitamin A: carotenoids, vision and antioxidants deficiency causes night blindness, impaired immunity and haematopoiesis 

Vitamin B1 (thiamin): carbohydrate metabolism (coenzyme), nervous system function and synthesis of DNA- acute deficiency in wernicke-korsakoff syndrome

Vitamin B2 (riboflavin): energy metabolism (coenzyme), eye health

Vitamin B3 (niacin) : FA synthesis

Vitamin B5 (pantothenic acid): energy metabolism, RBC production and hormone production

Vitamin B6 (pyroxidine): protein and AA metabolism, brain function and releasing stored glucose

Vitamin B9 (folic acid): DNA synthesis, RBC formation

Vitamin B12 (cobalamin): energy production/food metabolism, DNS synthesis, brain and NS formation and RBC formation

Vitamin C: Collagen, carnitine and coagulation

Vitamin D: regulates calcium to phosphorus ratio, bone formation

Vitamin E: antioxidant

Vitamin K: blood clotting action

Question: A 33yo male with crohn's disease has trouble with persistent anaemia due to poor iron absorption, which part of his intestines are responsible for most of the iron absorption?
Explanation:
Duodenum: absorption of calcium (actively via TRPV channels) and iron (via H+ as ferritin or transferrin)

Jejunum: Sodium (co-trasport with glucose via SGLT or exchange with H+ due to alkaline pH) and potassium (paracellular)

Colon: Potassium absorption, mostly just water reabsorption and minerals.
Tags: Nutrition, Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11, Inflammatory Bowel Disease

Question: A 19 year old ballet dancer falls onto fractures her right radius. She asks how long she will have to wear a cast. You explain to her that the bone must go through several stages of healing. These are:
OptionB: Bleeding --> Fibroblast replication --> Periosteum differentiation --> Intramembranous ossification --> Remodelling
OptionC: Endochondral ossification --> Fibroblast replication --> Periosteum differentiation -->  Bleeding--> Remodelling
OptionD: Bleeding --> Fibroblast replication --> Periosteum differentiation --> Endochondral ossification --> Remodelling
OptionE: Bleeding --> Fibroblast replication --> Periosteum differentiation --> Remodelling --> Intramembranous ossification
Explanation: Intramembranous ossification occurs when flat bones develop from a fibrous membrane. Endochondral ossification is what occurs when bones heal or in the formation of long bones.

Question: A man walks into A&E complaining of agonising sharp pain in his right iliac fossa. The consultant leading the department that evening asks a young foundation year doctor which of the following is true about the fibres that transmit this type of pain?
OptionB: The fibres terminate mainly on neurons in laminae II of the Spinal cord
OptionC: The fibres also transmit colicky, dull pain
OptionD: The fibres do not carry non-noxious afferent transmissions
OptionE: The fibres conduct at rates of 12 to 30m/s
Explanation: The scenario describes the latter stage of appendicitis where the pain is primarily carried by A delta fibres. Only E is true; the fibres are myelinated, they can conduct non-noxious stimuli and they terminate mainly on neurone in laminas I and V,

Question: A medical student is teaching spine examination and is counting the number of Lumbar vertebrae in a gentleman. How many should a normal person have?
Explanation:
7 Cervical

12 Thoracic

5 Lumbar

5 Sacrum

4 Coccyx

Question: Which of the following colours is the lamina of this vertebrae?
Explanation:
Red-Transverse processes

White-verterbral body 

Orange-spinious process

Yellow-superior articular processes 

Purple-Lamina

Question: Mr. Jones is brought into hospital after he suddenly collapses at home, having felt light-headed, cold and clammy in the moments before. He said he did not feel palpitations, but felt breathless and had chest pain at the time of collapsing. His ECG shows dissociated p-waves. What is his most likely diagnosis & treatment option?
OptionE: 1st degree AV block; no treatment needed.
Explanation:
1st degree AV block = long PR interval on ECG & is usually asymptomatic.

2nd degree AV block = non-conducted p-waves.

3rd degree AV block = dissociated p-waves.

Question: Today, what is the leading cause of death in pregnancy?
Explanation:
Eclamsia happens as a complication of pre-eclamsia (High blood pressure and protein in the blood). It happens when the blood pressure is so high that the pregnant woman starts to develop headaches, blurred vision, stomach pain, then seizures, convulsions, death. However, less than 1% of women with preeclamsia will develop eclamsia. Eclamsia may occur for up to 20% of all pregnant women death.

Gestational diabetes is thought to be caused by the over-effectiveness of Human placental lactogen (HPL), a hormone that makes cells more resistant to Insulin, to make sure there is enough glucose in the blood for the baby/fetus. Even though it increases the chances of induced labour, cesarian section, still-birth, miscariage and premature birth; it does not seem to dramatically change the mortality of the pregnant women in the UK. 

Maternal sepsis: anaemia, being overweight and cesarian sections are risk factors for sepsis. The major cause of sepsis is E. Coli, but it can happen because of MRSA, HIV and Influenza. It can happened during Cesarian section, spontaneous abortion, prolongued labour, breaking water early. Chorionic villus sampling has more chances to create sepsis than amniocentesis. 

Cytomegallo virus infection may not cause any symptom (usually mononucleosis-like) on the pregnant women. However, there is a 10% chances of affecting the baby if the mother is infected. Today there is not treatment. 

deep vein thrombosis is at increased risk during pregnancy. It would, however, increase the risks of Pulmonary embolism more than MI. It is not the leading cause of death. 

http://www.cdc.gov/cmv/risk/preg-women.html

http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/gestational-diabetes/Pages/Complications.aspx

http://www.emedicinehealth.com/eclampsia/article_em.htm

http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Deep-vein-thrombosis/Pages/Introduction.aspx

http://journals.lww.com/anesthesia-analgesia/Fulltext/2013/10000/Maternal_Sepsis_Mortality_and_Morbidity_During.24.aspx

Question:
You are recording some test results for an orthopaedic patient which are :

 

Calcium 2.00 mmol/L (2.20-2.60mmol/L)

Phosphate 0.6 (0.8-1.5 mmol/L)

Alkaline Phopshatase  110 (39-117 U/L)

Which of the following conditions does this patient most likely have?

You were walking down the street when, suddenly, you see through the window of a 2 floor house somebody hanging himself. You call the police and the A and E who arrive immediately. As the doctor arrives, he recognises you as one of his student on Thursday placement day and invites you to follow up the patient back to Heath hospital. As doctors are going through ABCDE, you notice that the patient breathes, but is bradycardic and breathes very slowly. You also notice, a little bit awkwardly, that the patient has priapism (he is having an erection!). The doctors asks you what drug would help the patient getting his penis unerected again. Which of this is he likely to mention?
Explanation:
Diazepan injections are sometimes given to patient suffering from muscle spasm.

The patient must be in neurogenic shock (disruption of the autonomic system due to nerve compression). Pseudoephredine activates the blood vessel alpha receptors so that vasoconstiction can occur again, and blood can flow away from the penis. Priapism occurs if a patient has had an erection for more than 4 hours and it is a medical emergency.

Question: A patient arrives at A&E from a road traffic collision and is suspected of having a spinal injury. The consultant spinal surgeon determines the injury to be an incomplete spinal cord injury. What is the most important prognostic variable relating to neurologic recovery in this patient?
OptionA: Administration of spinal dose steroids within the quickest time possible
OptionE: The Severity of neurologic deficit in this patient
Explanation:
The severity of the neurologic deficit is the most important prognostic variable is the most important in these type of patients. Read this paper on pubmed if you want good evidence behind this 

"Factors associated with improved neurologic outcomes in patients with incomplete tetraplegia.
Pollard ME1, Apple DF."

Question: A 32 year old plumber comes into the A and E department presenting with low back pain, loss of sensation in the inner thigh and knee. On examination there is a loss of the knee extension reflex, on MRI scan a herniated disc is seen, which nerve root is most likely to be compressed?

Rhodri present at A&E following a boozy night out in the lash. Rhodri got into a disagreement and was subsequent stabbed in the back with a kitchen knife. The doctor on shift performs a neurological examination on Rhodri and finds he has ipsilateral loss of motor function and proprioception in his left leg and contralateral loss of pain and temperature in his right leg. Which of the following cord syndromes is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation: C - Pain and temperature is carried in the lateral spinothalamic tracts which dessicates in the spinal cord while motor is carried in the corticospinal tract and propriception in the dorsal column both of which dessicate in the brain.

Question: A 59 year old female complains of lower back pain; she has a history of rheumatoid arthritis for which she has been prescribed corticosteroids for 30 years. After taking a history and a full spinal examination with relevant neurological tests, you decide she has sciatica. She has no history of trauma but admits to taking a minor tumble the other day. What is the most likely cause of the cord compression causing her sciatica?
Explanation:
From 30 years of chronic corticosteroid use she most likely has steroid-induced osteoporosis. Here is a diagram illustrating how this could happen.

 

Also note how she is 50+ years of age so likely to have decreased oestrogen levels due to menopause. Therefore the most likely cause of the cord compression causing her sciatica is a fracture due to osteoporosis caused by this chronic steroid use. This means she's likely to have weaker bones that are more likely to fracture especially when taking a tumble.

Question:
A 40 year old female truck driver comes into your surgery. She has been experiencing lower back pain for 6 weeks and has said that the paracetamol she's been taking hasn't been working. The Dr prescribes her codeine for her lower back pain.

 

As the Year 2 student following the doctor, the doctor asks you for the mechanism of action behind the drug:
OptionA: Gi inhibition causing K+ efflux and lack of Ca2+ influx, therefore less vesicle mediated release of neurotransmitters.
OptionB: Gi activation causing K+ efflux and lack of Ca2+ influx due inhibition of Ca2+ voltage channels, therefore less vesicle mediated release of neurotransmitters.
OptionC: Gs activation causing cAMP, PKA, and phosphorylation of Na+ channels
OptionD: Gs inhibition causing cAMP, PKA and phosphorylation of Na+ channels
Explanation: Binds to Gi, an agonist, causing the effects stated above.

Question:
A 72-year old man comes into your GP surgery the day after a fall where he hit his forehead on a table. He is complaining of bilateral muscle weakness and numbness in his limbs, particularly in the neck and shoulders. Bladder and bowel function is normal.

 

What neurological disorder is he most likely to be suffering from?
Explanation:
The injury he suffered could cause hyperextension of the neck, leading to bruising within the spinal cord, causing damage to cell bodies near the centre of the cord. These are likely to be cervical and thoracic nerves, leading to more muscle weakness and numbness in the upper limbs.

 

As his bowel and bladder function is normal, it cannot be cauda equina syndrome.

Question:
Mr Norbert Smaug came into A&E with several symptoms:

 

- Rectal & urinal incontinence

- loss of sensation in his buttocks, perineum and inner thigh

- social dysfunction (he was blowing fire)

- loss of bulbocavernosus reflex

 

 

Which diagnosis is most likely given by Dr (Spine) Dragon?
OptionA: LMN lesion - intervertebral disc herniation of lumbar spine
OptionC: UMN lesion - Anterior spinal cord syndrome in the lumbar region
Explanation:
The above are characteristic symptoms of Cauda Equina Syndrome - especially saddle anaesthesia

Note: Cauda equina comprises lower motor neurones as they have already synapsed in the Ventral horn - thus presents with LMN lesion signs

Question: Mikela Griffiths is a 38 year old in remission from breast cancer for six months. During her treatment, she received corticosteroids and chemotherapy and anti-oestrogen therapy. She has a pathological fracture. All blood tests are normal. She goes for a DEXA scan and her bone density is 2.4 standard deviations below the mean. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
• DEXA scan measures a person's bone density
  • A score greater than -2.5 standard deviations from the mean indicates osteoporosis
  • A score between 0 and -2.5 standard deviations from the mean indicates osteopaenia
  • Long term use of steroids and anti-oestrogen treatment increases your risk for osteoporosis

Question:
A F1 junior doctor is stabbed in the back by Mr. Hunt. On assessment he appears to have lost motor function and proprioception on the left leg and is unable to feel temperature and pain on his right leg. 

what is the most probable diagnoses?
Explanation: Brown sequard presents with ipsilateral paralysis, proprioception and loss of contralateral pain and temp.

Question: John, a construction worker, has been off work for 12 weeks with chronic back pain. For how many more weeks can he be off work and still be eligible for statutory sick pay?
OptionC: He is no longer eligible for sick pay (he has already passed the threshold)
OptionD: Sick pay is unlimited, as long as the patient has a fit note from their GP.
Explanation: Statutory sick pay may be paid to an individual for up to 28 weeks (12+16=28). This may become complicated if the patient returns to work and then becomes sick again shortly afterwards. See Gov.uk for more information.

Question: Miss Cavenagh has been away from her job as a builder for 8 days due to severe lower back pain. She mentioned this to her boss over an email when it first started. She is quite happy sat in bed watching Netflix and chilling until this pain goes away. What is her next step?
OptionA: She needs to ask for a fit note immediately as she has been unfit for work for over 14 calendar days
OptionB: Wait until 2 weeks of sickness and then visit her GP for a fit note
OptionC: She needs to ask for a fit note immediately as she has been unfit for work for over 7 calendar days
OptionD: Take a painkiller and rest. Because her job is manual, her boss will understand her absence
OptionE: She needs to ask for a fit note after missing 7 working days
Explanation: After 7 calendar days of self certification, the patient is required to provide a fit note. Her GP will advise her on treatment and the steps needed to get back to work.

Question:
Pat, a 26 year old chap was stabbed in the neck during a heated argument with his wife, after she recently found out about his other love interest, Crystal. Pat is unable to pick up his cell phone with his left hand and is unaware that Crystal is holding his right hand.

What do his symptoms suggest?
Explanation: Contralateral loss of pain and temperature combined with ipsilateral loss of motor function implies Brown-Sequard syndrome.

Question: What type of scan is this and what pathology does it show?

Group 65 case 14. In clinic you see a patient who complains of difficultly walking. On examination you note that he has lost proprioception, vibration and 2 point discrimination in his legs. However, he still has full power. What is the most likely pathology?
Explanation:
E is correct as theses are the symptoms of posterior cord syndrome, which is rare.

Anterior cord syndrome is distinguished by:  Bilateral spastic paralysis, Loss of pain, temperature, light touch & pressure with some degree of sacral sparing, Preservation of proprioception, vibration and 2 point discrimination.

Brown-sequard syndrome is usually caused by a penetrating injury, with Ipsilateral paralysis and Dissociate anaesthesia - loss of ipsilateral touch & contralateral pain / temp.

Central cord syndrome results in bilateral spastic paralysis with some sacral sparring, upper limbs are more affected. 

There is no lateral cord Syndrome.

Question:
A 62-year-old patient with a long past medical history of heart problems becomes unstable in the intensive care unit. His monitor depicts the rhythm shown below.

 

Which of the following electrolyte disturbances has most likely led to his current arrhythmia?
Explanation:
The heart rhythm shown is consistent with Torsades de Points (TdP), which can be precipitated by hypomagnesaemia, hypocalcaemia OR hypokalaemia

.

TdP is polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with increasing and decreasing amplitude.

 

Conditions that predispose patients to TdP include hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, long QT interval.

Question:
A 72-year-old woman presents with worsening "nodules" on her body; with many on her left hand . She describes several years of intermittent, severe joint pain, which she ascribed to arthritis with "old age." A picture of her hand is shown here  

Which of the following interventions is best for long-term treatment of this condition?
Explanation:
The patient most likely has chronic tophaceous gout.

Allopurinol is the best long-term therapy for this condition.

 

Chronic tophaceous gout is a subtype of gout in which patients experience repeated attacks of gout or persistent hyperuricemia.

This develops over many years, resulting in the creation of  tophi, which are filled with urate crystals. Patients with chronic tophaceous gout can develop tophi in bones, cartilage, joints, bursae, and/or subcutaneously.

Question: Which of the following arrows is pointing at the ligamentum flavum?
Which of the following arrows is pointing at the supraspinous ligaments?

A 13 years old boy comes into A and E with Diabetic ketoacidosis. He is given Insulin and IV-fluid. After his pH comes back to normal, he becomes dizzy and faints. You perform an ECG which shows the following:

 

 

What is the most probable cause of this ECG abnormality?
Explanation:
In ketoacidosis, patient often present with high potassium levels in their blood. This comes from: the proton/potassium pump that pumps the excess H+ (as the patient is acidic) into the cell and potassium out of the cell, insulin usually activates NA+/K+ pumps which makes sure K+ present in the blood does not become too excessive and potassium follows water that goes out of the cell because of the glucose that is outside in the blood. This Means: High potassium in blood, low potassium in cell. The kidney try to excrete potassium but it is doing this at a low rate.  

When treated with insulin, Insulin directly activates the NA+/K+ pump and makes sugar and water and potassium (all following the other) go back inside the cell. This does not leave a lot of potassium in the blood. Further more, IV fluid dilutes the potassium and encourages urine production. This causes hypokaelemia. 

hypokaelemia can produce long QT syndrome in previously normal patient. Long QT syndrome can cause "Torsades de pointe" which is a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.

Question: After performing a lumbar puncture on an elderly patient, they complain greatly of a bad headache that emerged soon after the procedure. Which of the following pieces of advice is the one you should give to the patient?
OptionA: You likely have a raised Intracranial pressure; you need to go to theatre right now
OptionB: Do nothing; it will pass in an hour or so
OptionC: You need to sit up right; this will minimise the headache
OptionD: Lie flat; this will minimise the headache
OptionE: The pressure in your back is too high; we need to do another lumbar puncture to drain more CSF
Explanation: The patient most likely has a Low pressure post-LP dural headache. This is not an emergency and can often be relived by lying the patient down. It is caused by a Leak of CSF, resulting in a fall in CSF pressure that causes traction on meningeal blood vessels and cranial nerves. It is made worse sitting up but relieved by lying flat

Question: You are measuring the contents of a man's semen; what percentage do you expect to be composed of sperm?
Explanation: From Dave's Case 7 Lecture; less than 10% of semen is made up of sperm

Question: You examine a women in A&E with a history of one day history of lower abdominal pain and a missed period. You later hear that the patient has had uterine bleeding recently. Examination finds lower abdominal rebound tenderness in the patient. What is the best management plan to confirm the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
The most likely diagnosis given the patient's missed period, bleeding and sudden onset of pain is ectopic pregnancy; Beta hCG is generally done as a screening test but abdominal US is a used as a confirmatory test. 

http://almostadoctor.co.uk/content/systems/obstetrics-and-gynaecology/pregnancy-and-labour/ectopic-pregnancy

Question: A 24-year-old female with a history of pelvic inflammatory disease presents with uterine bleeding and unilateral pelvic pain. Her last menstrual period was 6 weeks ago. You suspect an ectopic pregnancy. Which of the following locations did the zygote most likely implant itself?
Explanation:
All bar D are options for an ectopic pregnancy implantation; however, 95% of ectopics have the zygote implant in the fallopian/uterine tubes.

 

Source: Dave Wilson's Lecture; Case 7

Question: Charlie is 17 and has just been diagnosed with type 1 diabetes. He is learning how to calculate the carbohydrate coverage dose of fast acting insulin for a meal. He knows that his insulin:CHO ratio is 1:12, which means that every unit of insulin disposes of 12g of carbs. For this lunch he will eat 66 grams of carbs. How many units of insulin will he need to cover his meal?
Explanation:
The insulin:CHO ratio is 1:12, which means that every unit of insulin disposes of 12g of carbs.

The units of insulin needed is calculated by dividing the amount of carbs in a meal with the amount of carbs each unit disposes of, so 66g ÷ 12g = 5.5 units

Question: A 21 year old primigravida comes into your clinic for her booking appointment. She is 10 weeks pregnant, and is aware that this test could show if she has any infections that may affect her unborn child. However, she was unaware that some genetic conditions could also be picked up, and asks which ones can be detected. Which of the following genetic conditions can be detected through a blood test at the booking appointment?
Explanation: Sickle cell anaemia can be detected through the microscopic imaging of the mother's red blood cells. Thalassaemia can also be detected in the blood test at booking appointment. The other options are genetic conditions which cannot be screened for prenatally using a blood test.

Question:
An 82 year old woman presents to her GP with a loss of coordination in her hands. Her husband is concerned that she keeps dropping things. She tells you that a few days ago she fell backwards over a washing basket.

 

You perform a basic neurological examination and find that her MRC power grade in her arms is a 4 and only a 2 in her hands. The examination for her lower limbs is normal.

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation: The answer is B, central cord syndrome. This is the most common kind of cord syndrome and is particularly seen in elderly people who fall and their head is thrown backwards. The hyperextension leads to narrowing and decreased blood supply to the middle of the spinal cord. The upper limbs are more affected than the lower limbs (due to the lamination of the spinal cord) and it is characterised by loss of motion and sensation in the arms and hands.

Question:
A 64-year-old man is diagnosed with Parkinson's disease. You prescribe 250mg of Levodopa to be taken orally twice a day with meals. He asks you how this medication could help his symptoms.

 

Levodopa (L-DOPA) is a drug that works by avoiding the rate limiting step in the catecholamine synthesis pathway.

 

What is the rate limiting step in the catecholamine synthesis pathway?
OptionA: Dietary tyrosine is actively transported across the blood brain barrier (BBB)
OptionB: Dopamine is converted to noradrenaline by the enzyme dopamine-β-hydroxylase (DBH)
OptionC: L-DOPA is converted to dopamine by the enzyme L-aromatic amino acid decarboxylase (AADC)
OptionD: Noradrenaline is converted to adrenaline by the enzyme phenylethanoldopamine-N-methyltransferase (PNMT)
OptionE: Tyrosine is converted to L-DOPA by the enzyme tyrosine hydrozylase
Explanation:
1. Dietary tyrosine is actively transported across the blood brain barrier (BBB) 

2. Tyrosine is converted to L-DOPA by the enzyme tyrosine hydrozylase

3. L-DOPA is converted to dopamine by the enzyme L-aromatic amino acid decarboxylase (AADC)

4. Dopamine is converted to noradrenaline by the enzyme dopamine-β-hydroxylase (DBH)

5. Noradrenaline is converted to adrenaline by the enzyme phenylethanoldopamine-N-methyltransferase (PNMT)

 

 (lecture 1 case 12)

Question: A 12-year-old boy weighing 40kg is admitted to hospital for an emergency appendectomy. He must be given cefotaxime sodium (Claforan) 180 mg/ kg IM before his operation. The drug stock is 0.5 g/ml. How many millilitres will you give?
Explanation:
180 ml/kg needed, child weighs 40kg.

40x180= 7200mg needed for this patient

 

Stock solution is 0.5 g/ml

0.5 g/ml = 500 mg/ml

Patient requires 7200 mg

7200/500 = 14.4 ml required

 

 

Alternatively:

Stock solution is 0.5 g/ml

Patient requires 7.2 g

7.2/0.5 = 14.4 ml required

 

 

 

Extra information regarding this question:

Cefotaxime is an antibiotic used to treat gonorrhoea, meningitis, and severe infections including infections of the kidney (pyelonephritis) and urinary system. Also used before an operation to prevent infection after surgery.

Question: In gastrulation, one of the parts formed is the ectoderm; which of the following organs comes from the ectoderm?
Explanation: The hair, CNS and loss of other organs including the mmamry glands, pituitary gland, tooth enamel and adrenal gland medulla -see Dave's Lecture for a full list

Question: In gastrulation, the ectoderm, mesoderm and endoderm are formed, which of these organs is derived from the mesoderm?
Explanation: The mesoderm derivatives include the cranium, Connective tissue of the head adrenal cortex and the primordial heart

Question: A neonate is diagnosed with amniotic band syndrome. Which of the following terms best defines what condition this is?
Explanation:
A disruption =results in alteration pre-existing structures - due to destructive processes

Amniotic band syndrome is the example given by Dave Wilson in his tetralogy lecture

Question: A young doctor is concerned about a mother's alcohol consumption in pregnancy in relation to malformations. Which of the following weeks is the most common for a malformation effect to take action in a fetus?
Explanation: Weeks 3 to 8 of gestation are the most common for a malformation to occur but Professor Wilson specifics that Week 8 is the most common due to the stages of organogensis that are taking place here.

Question: A geneticist is assessing the causes behind Robertsonian Translocation-which of the following types of chromosomes most commonly can undergo a Robertsonian Translocation?
Explanation: See Fry's Lecture on chromosomal abnormalities. Acrocentric chromosomes (usually 13,14,15,21 or 22) can form Robertsonian translocations because their p arms are very small

Question: Which of the following is a terminal deletion syndrome?
A female patient is diagnosed with hypothyroidism; which of the following symptoms is she most likely displaying as a result of her condition?
Explanation: All the symptoms, bar E, listed match that of hyperthyroidism as opposed to hypothyroidism. Weight loss is experienced in hyperthyroidism as opposed to weight gain in hypothyroidism as the hormones secreted by the thyroid stimulate an increase the basal metabolic rate. This causes O2 consumption, Respiratory Rate, body temperature and energy use.

Question: Fertilisation has three important consequences. It determines the sex of the future fetus and restores the diploid number of chromosomes: what is the other consequence?
Explanation:
The 3 most important consequences of fertilisation are 

Restration of diploid number of chromosomes

Cleavage induction 

Sex determination

Question:
Which of the following option best completes the sentence?

Freshly ejaculated sperm are not capable of fertilizing the oocyte/egg because these sperm are ...
Explanation: Freshly ejaculated sperm are not capable of fertilizing the oocyte because these sperm are incapacitated

Question: The consultant asks you what are the pharmaceutical approaches to treat osteoporosis. He tells you that there are Antiresorptive drugs (inhibit osteoclasts) and Anabolic agents (which promote bone synthesis). He asks you to name the drug who does both.

A 30 year old artist attends her local GP clinic. She states that she has noticed her mouth feeling tingly and her hands spasming lately. She is tearful during the consultation because the hand spasms are starting to interfere with her work. 

The GP goes through her medical record and finds that she has underdone a thyroidectomy in the last year. Lab tests are done on her and the results come back. Which of the following test results is most likely?
OptionA:
• decreased PTH (parathyroid hormone)
  • increased plasma calcium
  • increased plasma phosphate
Explanation:
The history is suggestive of hypoparathyroidism following thyroidectomy. 

Markers seen in hypoparathyroidism:

  • Decreased or absent PTH (therefore ruling out C and D)
  • Decreased plasma calcium as a result of decreased PTH (therefore ruling out A)
  • Increased plasma phosphate

Question: A 27-year-old G2P1 female is concerned that she may give birth to another child with Down syndrome. She states that she may not be able to take care of another child with this disorder. Which of the following tests can confirm the diagnosis of Down syndrome in utero?
Explanation: The only way to confirm a diagnosis is to extract cells that originate from the fetus and perform a chromosomal analysis. An amniocentesis can be performed to extract amniotic fluid, which has cells from the fetus in it.  Chorionic Villus Sampling can also be done

Question: You encounter a patient who is vegan and has been feeling rather tired and weak. You monitor her iron levels and find them extremely low. What is the recommended intake of iron for a normal healthy adult who is not pregnant or menstruating?
Explanation:
1 mg/day-Healthy adult 

2mg/day-mentsruating female

4-7mg/day -pregnant woman

Question: A pregnant woman is visiting her midwife about nutrition during pregnancy. The midwife warns the patient that she may need an iron supplement later on in pregnancy. At which point in her pregnancy will her iron demands likely be the highest?
Explanation:
1st Trimester=12 weeks or less

2nd Trimester=13 to 28 weeks

3rd Trimester=29 weeks plus

Question: You are reviewing a patient with a bone marrow dysfunction syndrome. Which of the following diagnoses has this patient most likely been given?
Explanation:
From case 8 haematological aspects of pregnancy

A and C are Bone Marrow Failure syndromes

B is a Bone Marrow suppression syndrome

E is a Bone Marrow infiltration syndrome

Question: You encounter a patient with a platelet count of 85 x109/L. She is pregnant in her 2nd trimester. What is the most likely cause of this finding?
Explanation:
From case 8 lecture

Causes 75% of all cases of thrombocytopenia at term.

Platelet count usually >70x109/l

The counts recover within 2 months of delivery and there is no association with maternal haemorrhage

Fetal platelet count normal  as is the mother platelet count before and after pregnancy

Question: You come to see a patient who is recovering from a spinal surgery due to cord compression. In order to test your understanding that the spinal cord does not occupy the whole spinal canal, the consultant asks you what spinal cord level is compressed by a T8 vertebra displacement.
Explanation: Important to know

Question:
A 53-year-old man came to the cardiology clinic for a routine check up regarding his AF. The cardiologist requests an ECG and observes that besides the AF the patient has developed a new arrhythmia called 'bi-germinal beats'. After reviewing the prescriptions he determines that this could be induced by one of the drugs given to treat atrial fibrillation.

 

Which drug is most likely to be?
Explanation: Both Digoxin & Adrenaline can cause 'bi-germinal beats'. However, only digoxin is used to treat AF. (Coffee's lecture)

Question: A 18-year-old man comes into A&E with acute left-sided chest pain and breathlessness which developed while he was playing hockey. A standing X-Ray is taken. What is the diagnosis?
Explanation:
Development of acute chest pain and breathlessness while playing sport, is indicative of pneumothorax.

This is confirmed on the chest x-ray where the edge of the lung can be seen outside the border of the heart within the left hemithorax.

 

Treatment of this condition requires a chest drain.

Question: Blood from blood transfusions is separated into constituent parts and stored at different temperatures. What temperature are erythrocytes stored at?

A 25 year old primigravida comes to one of her antenatal appointments complaining of light-headedness. You notice she is quite pale and after running some blood tests you suspect she may have anaemia. Her results show an increased mean corpuscular volume (MCV) and low levels of haemoglobin and intrinsic factor antibodies. Given that she has been supplementing folate throughout her pregnancy, what vitamin/mineral may be deficient, causing these symptoms?
Explanation: The lady is suffering from pernicious anaemia, as can be seen by her increased MCV. This macrocytic anaemia can be as the result of a B9 or B12 deficiency, leading to incomplete development of DNA in red blood cells. As the woman has been supplementing B9 throughout her pregnancy, its is most likely that a B12 deficiency is causing her symptoms, also indicated by the low intrinsic factor.
Tags: Anaemia, Blood, Blood Results, Group 89, Haematology

Question: You are told by your supervising haematologist to request a fresh frozen plasma that has the richest source of fibrinogen-which of the following is the best type of fresh frozen plasma that meets this criteria?
Explanation:
CPP -The richest source of fibrinogen

From case 8 good transfusion lecture

Question: Platelets are give in transfusion for treatment of haemorrhage in patients with thrombocytopenia or platelet function defects. How many donors are required if the transfusion is from whole blood?
Explanation:
4 if from whole blood

1 if from apheresis

Question: Someone with AO genotype will produce certain antibodies. Which of the following is most true about the type of antibodies that this patient will produce?
OptionC: They will produce Anti-B and Anti-A antibodies
OptionE: They will produce a high concentration of anti-A antibodies with a smaller but significant concentration of anti-B antibodies
Explanation: From case 8 lecture

Question: If a patient has blood group O, who can they receive blood off?
Organogenesis begins from week 3 gestation; which of the following organs first begins to develop in embryology?

A mother, who is G3P2, is 3 weeks gestation and visiting her GP due to the complications that she has suffered in past pregnancies. She has had one diagnosed child with spina bifida. Given this history, which of these is the most correct nutritional advice for the mother?
OptionA: She needs 400 micrograms of Vitamin B9 supplementation a day
OptionB: She needs 500 micrograms of B9 supplementation a day
OptionC: She should watch her calorie intake and make sure she is not more than 9kg heavier by the 3rd trimester
OptionD: She needs 5 micrograms of Vitamin D a day and 400 micrograms of Vitamin B9 supplementation
OptionE: She should avoid foods such as liver and pate as they are high in vitamin A
Explanation:
A and E are correct in MOST pregnancies

C is true if the mother is already overweight at the start of pregnancy (they should gain no more than 5kg to 9kg of weight)

D would be correct in MOST pregnancies if it was 10 microgarms

B is most correct as you require 500 micrograms of B9/Folic acid supplementation if you have a history of NTDs-such as spina bifida

See lecture for case 8 

Development, Disease and Nutritional programming

Question:
Before the start of a surgery, the anaesthesiologist tells the patient he would administer a general anaesthetic which has a depolarizing effect on the neuromuscular junction.

 

What is the most likely drug used in this situation?
Explanation:
Suxamethonium is a neuromuscular-blocking drug which has a depolarizing effect. It acts as an Ach competitive agonist which has a slow break down rate and causes fasciculation.

 

(Nerve lecture, Case 14)

Question: What does the 'Winking Owl' sign on a plain radiograph of the spine most commonly indicate?
Explanation: The 'missing/winking eye', corresponds to a missing pedicle, most commonly caused by bony metastases in the spine.  (Dr McCarthy's 2nd pathology lecture)

Question:
Gollum has suffered a lumbar disc herniation causing unilateral weakness in ankle dorsiflexion, hyporeflexia of the knee jerk reflex and loss of sensation over the medial malleolus.

 

At what level is the disc herniation most likely?
Explanation: The signs are indicative of compression of the L4 nerve root. (ASIA chart)

Question: Which of the following terms is defined as "de novo development of blood vessels from endothelial cells differentiating in situ"
Explanation:
From case 8 cardiac embryology lecture 

Vasculogenesis: de novo development of blood vessels from endothelial cells differentiating in situ

Angiogenesis: formation of new blood vessels from sprouting of new capillaries from pre-existing vessels (importance of so-called ‘angiogenic diseases’)

Question: Which of the following landmarks of this placenta and developing embryo at the end of 2months gestation is considered the 'maternal portion' of the placenta?
Explanation:
From case 8 lecture

The Maternal portion: the decidua basalis. On the fetal side, the placenta is bordered by the chorionic plate and on its maternal side, by the decidual basalis

Question: Why shouldn't aspirin be given to patients who are under the age of 16?
A primigravida 31 year old woman is 13 weeks pregnant. After a routine blood test she is found to be of blood group AB Rhesus Negative. What's the best way to manage this pregnancy?
OptionB: Inject the woman with Anti-D during the pregnancy
OptionD: Perform an interuterine blood transfusion for the foetus
OptionE: Perform a blood transfusion in the neonate
Explanation:
Rhesus negative mother produces anti-D antibodies in response to exposure to Rhesus positive RBC of the foetus. Anti-D antibodies are IgG and can cross the placenta. If a rhesus D negative pregnant woman has pre-existing anti-D from a previous untreated preganancy, these can affect the second pregnancy by haemolysing the foetus' RBC. This causes Haemolytic Disease of the newborn (HDN) or stillbirht. 

 

First line manangement plan to prevent  this is to inject anti-D at 28 weeks, 34 weeks and 72 hours after birth

The other management options may be necessary if the anti-D is not administered.

Question: Calcitonin is released by which of the following structures?
Explanation: Calcitonin (also known as thyrocalcitonin) is a hormone that is produced  primarily by the parafollicular cells (also known as C-cells) of the thyroid.

Question: You know that both blood for donated for transfusions and the blood of pregnant women are tested for some infectious agents. You ask the hematologists for what additional infectious agent is the blood for transfusions tested on a routine basis (i.e. non in special circumstances)?

You are reviewing a pregnant women who is not vaccinated for rubella. The doctor tells you that rubella is a vertically transmitted disease and that it can affect the baby while in the utereus. Which of the following infectious pathogens CAN'T be transmitted vertically?

In the A&E, you see an ECG of a 47-year-old female who is acutely unwell. You notice that her trace shows tall, "tented" T waves. 

 

Which type of electrolyte imbalance causes this?
Explanation: Hyperkalaemia causes tall "tented" T waves on an ECG while hypokalemia produces broad, flat T-waves and prominent U-waves.

Question: Early on in pregnancy, elevated progesterone levels are needed to maintain pregnancy and progesterone is produced in excess by the corpus luteum. In the normal menstrual cycle the corpus luteum involutes, but this process is impeded during pregnancy because of the presence of which hormone?
Explanation: In normal human pregnancy, human chorionic gonadotropin (hcg) is produced early in pregnancy to maintain the corpus luteum.

Question: Colostrum is human milk produced in the first week after birth. A mother produces around 40ml a day for her child but which of these facts is most true about the composition of colostrum compared to human milk?
OptionE: It contains a calcium content higher than both normal human milk and cows' milk

Question:
On placement, while observing a few blood results you notice that one of the patients has hypocalcaemia.

 

What symptoms would you expect to see in that patient?
Explanation:
Depressed nervous system function and deposition of excess calcium/phosphate is seen in hypercalcaemia.

 

Abdominal pain and depression are symptoms of primary hyperparathyroidism.

Question:
A 67-year-old female comes to the A&E after falling down the stairs. The X-ray shows a subtrochanteric fracture of the hip. Additionally, you suspect that she might have osteoporosis and order a DEXA scan which confirms your diagnosis. 

 

What is the 1st line of treatment for osteoporosis?
Explanation:
Alendronate is a bisphosphonate (1st line of treatment). Mechanism of action: inhibits osteoclast function and induces their apoptosis.

 

Raloxifene and Strontium ranelate are 2nd line treatment.

 

Teriparatide and PTH are 3rd line treatment.

 

(Bone lecture by Dr C Beynon)

Question:
During placement, the consultant give you a patients blood results and tells you to interpret them:

 

Calcium: 1.6 (2.2 - 2.6 mmol/L)

Phosphate:  8.5 (2.5 - 4.5 mg/dL) 

Alkaline Phosphate: 171 (44 -147 IU/L)

PTH: high

 

What is your diagnosis based on the results?
Which of the following is the amnion?
Explanation:
1. Umbilical cord

2. Amnion

3. Chorionic plate

4. Intervillous space (maternal blood)

5. Basal plate

6. Cotyledon

7. Villus

Question: Which of the following is labelling the chorionic plate?
Explanation:
1. Umbilical cord

2. Amnion

3. Chorionic plate

4. Intervillous space (maternal blood)

5. Basal plate

6. Cotyledon

7. Villus

Question:
Niamh is desperate for the GP to give her some relief from her painful piles. During the consultation, she asks the GP to explain why her haemorrhoids are painful but her friend's are asymptomatic. 

 

Which one of the following statements is the most relevant to Niamh?
OptionA: Internal haemorrhoids are painful as they are innervated by the ANS
OptionC: External haemorrhoids are innervated by the superior rectal nerve
OptionD: External haemorrhoids contain no noiciceptive nerve endings
OptionE: External haemorrhoids are innervated by the somatic, inferior rectal nerve
Explanation:
A, C and D are incorrect.

Internal haemorrhoids are innervated by the ANS and so have no noiciceptive nerve endings. They only respond to stretch receptors.

External haemorrhoids are innervated by the inferior rectal nerve. This is a somatic nerve which detects painful stimuli.

Question:
A 32 years old father comes with his 1 year old son for vaccination. He explains that his son reacted had an allergic reaction after his last vaccination, at 4 month old. The father does not remember which one of the vaccines his son was allergic too, but his thinks it might be Pneumococcal. You think about how this later vaccine is created to figure out how an allergy could have developed. 

What kind of vaccine is the Pneumococcal vaccine?
Explanation:
A conjugate vaccine is created when a polysaccharide from the membrane of a bacteria is attached to a carrier protein to be introduced, together, in the vaccine and illicit an immunological response. Very very rarely, people can explicit a reaction against the carrier protein, CRP, of the vaccine. This is the case for all Conjugate vaccine, Meningococcal, Pneumococcal, HIB B vaccine)

Toxoid vaccine is made out of unactivated toxoid sent by some bacteria, like diphteria and tetanus

Subunit vaccine show only part of the antigen, usually the epitope (e.g. Hepatitis B)

MMR and influenza is a life, attenuated vaccine, while polio vaccine is inactivated.

Question: Which dopamine receptor activates Adenylyl Cyclase?
Explanation:
D1 and 5 are Gs coupled receptors and therefore activate Adenylyl Cyclase, increasing the intracellular concentration of the second messenger cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP).

 

D2,3 and 4 are all Gi/Go coupled receptor and therefore inhibit Adenylyl Cyclase. They activate K+ channels and inhibit Ca2+ channels.

Question: Which of the following types of family is best defined as "a household unit including a step-parent as a consequence of separation, divorce and possibly remarriage"?
Explanation:
Nuclear Family: two adults and their own or adopted children, living together in a household and connected by mutual affection and support.

 

Extended Family: a larger kinship network of grandparents, aunts, and nieces etc. who ideally live with or near close relatives and have a close and continuous relationship with them.

 

Lone/one-parent family: a single parent who has/has not previously been in a relationship, and who is not co-habiting

 

Reconstituted family: a household unit including a step-parent as a consequence of separation, divorce and possibly remarriage. This type of family includes adults who already have dependent children.

 

E is made up

Question: Which of the following is defined as "A newly formed family in which the parents and children were once part of other families"?
Explanation:
Nuclear Family: two adults and their own or adopted children, living together in a household and connected by mutual affection and support.

 

Extended Family: a larger kinship network of grandparents, aunts, and nieces etc. who ideally live with or near close relatives and have a close and continuous relationship with them.

 

Lone/one-parent family: a single parent who has/has not previously been in a relationship, and who is not co-habiting

 

Reconstituted family: a household unit including a step-parent as a consequence of separation, divorce and possibly remarriage. This type of family includes adults who already have dependent children.

 

Blended family: A newly formed family in which the parents and children were once part of other families.

Question: What is the dopamine effect on the pituitary gland?
Explanation:
Dopamine is a Prolactin inhibiting hormone released by the hypothalamus and has it's effect on the anterior pituitary.

 

The target for Prolactin is the breast tissue.

Function: stimulates the breasts to produce milk.

 

This hormone is secreted in large amounts during pregnancy and breast feeding, but is present at all times in both men and women.

Question: What is the Somatostatin effect on the pituitary gland?
Explanation: Somatostatin inhibits GH secretion. Additionally, it also inhibits insulin and glucagon secretion.

Question:
An 83-year-old lady is brought into the A&E by her family. Her BMI is 38.5 and she looks sleepy and confused. The family tells you that she has been feeling increasingly lethargic and withdrawn. The GCS is 9. The patients past medical records show no signs of any on-going disease.

 

You request TSH, free T4 blood tests and while waiting for the results you come up with a list of differentials. What is the top diagnosis that matches with the patients symptoms?
Explanation:
The patient has classic signs of Myxoedema Coma (end stage of untreated or insufficiently treated hypothyroidism) 

 

Typical clinical picture:

  • Elderly obese female
  • Becoming increasingly withdrawn, lethargic, sleepy and confused
  • Slips into a coma

Myxoedema coma is a medical emergency that requires immediate attention.

 

Management:

  • Airway management
  • Thyroid hormone replacement
  • Glucocorticoid therapy

 (Anatomy and physiology of the endocrine system lecture - Pete Taylor)

Question: What is the most common cause of Hyperthyroidism?
Explanation: (Anatomy and physiology of endocrine system lecture)

Question: What is the most common cause of Hypothyroidism?
Explanation:
All are causes of Hypothyroidism.

 

Viral infection can sometimes give transient Hypothyroidism.

 

(Anatomy and physiology of endocrine system lecture)

Question:
A patient was diagnosed with mild hyperthyroidism while under the care of the palliative team.

 

What is the most appropriate management?
Explanation:
Palliative treatment of mild hyperthyroidism is accomplished using B-blockers (propranolol most commonly used)

 

Treatment of Graves diseases include use of antithyroid medications, radioactive iodine, or thyroidectomy.

 

Toxic multinodular goiter and solitary adenomas may be treated with radioiodine therapy.

 

Thryoiditis is usually self limited and therapy is rarely needed.

 

(Anatomy and physiology of endocrine system lecture)

Question:
A 47-year-old African American woman presents to her family physician for a routine examination.

Past medical history is of amyloidosis and non-rhythm-based cardiac abnormalities secondary to the amyloidosis.

Which of the following cardiac parameters would be expected in this patient?
Explanation: This patient has diastolic heart failure secondary to amyloidosis. Diastolic heart failure is characterized by a decrease in ventricular compliance with normal contractility (preserved ejection fraction).

Question: A man with cardiac failure presents with worsening oedema. The doctor prescribes spironolactone and asks you in what part of the nephrone does it exert its actions.
During your obstetrics placement you are assisting a birth. The doctors asks what is the most common presentation of the fetus?

A 74-year-old Caucasian male visits your office regularly for treatment of New York Heart association class IV congestive heart failure.

Which of the following medications would you add to this man's drug regimen in order to improve his overall survival
Explanation:
Spironolactone is the only agent shown here to decrease mortality in advanced heart failure.

The RALES trial showed that spironolactone improved morbidity and mortality in patients with class III and IV congestive heart failure (CHF). 

 

Digoxin and Furosemide are use to treat SYMPTOMS of HF; the three drug classes shown to reduce mortality and morbidity in heart failure patients are 

ACE inhibitors

Beta Blockers 

Sprionolactone

Question: In the normal physiological state, which of the following stimuli cause stretch-mediated receptors in the right atrium to release natriuretic peptides?
Explanation: An increase in venous return to the right atrium will stimulate stretch-mediated receptors at the junction between the atria and the IVC and SVC. These cause atrial myocytes to release a natriuretic peptide called ANP, which causes systemic vasodilation. This increases GFR, leading to an increased excretion of sodium and water, ultimately causing a decrease in blood volume and causing it to return to normal.

Question: You see a 50 year old patient who is complaining of severe breathlessness. He has a history of hypertension, smoking and a family history of heart failure at a a relatively young age. He has type II diabetes mellitus. On history taking, you observe that he struggles to get up and gets symptoms from walking very short distances. He does not seem breathless talking to you now. What NYHA functional class  of heart failure does this man have?
Explanation: The severity of his breathlessness suggests class III as he is breathless on minimal exercise. Class IV would be breathless at rest. Class I is normal-breathless only at marked exercise. Class IIa is breathless at moderate exercise. Class IIb is breathless at mild exercise

Question:
A type 2 diabetic patient came to surgery on 1st of January suffering from NYHA stage 2 Heart failure. You therefore prescribed to him DRUG X. However, he came back on February the 1st, unhappy with DRUG X you prescribed for him. This medication, he says, provokes a continuous cough. You therefore prescribed DRUG Y. On March the 1st, the same patient comes back to you for regular checking and a note comes up on your screen stating that it was recently discovered that he developed renal artery stenosis bilaterally as his atherosclerosis developed. You therefore ask him to stop DRUG Y and make sure he does not come back to DRUG X as both are contra-indicated for bilateral renal artery stenosis. You therefore decide to put him on DRUG Z to make sure he still received appropriate vasodilation therapy. 

What could DRUG X, DRUG Y and DRUG Z be?
OptionA:
DRUG X: lorsatan

DRUG Y: perindopril

DRUG Z: Isosorbide mononitrate + hydrolazine
OptionD:
DRUG X: perindopril
DRUG Y: losartan
DRUG Z: Isosorbide mononitrate + hydrolazine
Explanation:
ACE inhibitors (e.g. perindopril) is a standart treatment for all Heart failure, it decreases Angiotensin II (vasoconstrictor -> reducing GFR) secretion and increase bradykinin production ( vasodilator -> increasing GFR). However, high levels of bradykinin can cause a persistent cough in some patients. This is why this patient was then put on an Angiotensin II receptor antagonist (ARA) (e.g. losartan) which does not affect the levels of bradykinin. 

However both, ACEI and ARA are contraindicated in bilateral renal stenosis. Why? Because BRS patients have a reduced flow because of the narrowing of the renal artery and therefore really need the action of Angiotensin II on the efferent arterioles to make sure the pressure is sufficient for the blood to pass inside the Bowman's capsule. Supressing Angiotensin II's effect would actually decrease the GFR because not enough pressure. 

To make it more clear, normally Angiotensin II consticts both the afferent and efferent arterioles. However, in BRS patients, it acts increasingly more on the efferent to keep some pressure. 

Finally, Isosorbide mononitrate decrease the preload by vasodilating the veins, and hydralazine decrease the afterload by vasodilating the afterload. These drugs are usually given in combinations and they improve the symptoms and mortality rates of HR patients.

Question: Which of the the following is correct with regard to the cardiac cycle during the middle of diastole?
Explanation: Aortic pressure falls during diastole. All of the other options are incorrect.

Question: Which is the most important site for regulating arterial pressure?
Explanation: The carotid sinus is quantitatively the most important for regulating arterial pressure.

Question:
A 19-year-old male student is admitted after vomiting blood. He had been out "getting bevved with the lads" and had consumed a lot of alcohol. He had vomited on a few occasions and during the last occasion his friends noticed that there was a fair amount of blood in his vomit.
On examination he appeared intoxicated, had a pulse of 94 bpm and a blood pressure of 128/76 mmHg. There were no abnormalities upon abdominal examination.
Explanation: Due to the high pressures exerted on the oesophagus during repeated vomiting, mucosal tears can occur. Patients lose little blood and these tears resolve with minimal intervention.

Question:
A 51-year-old-man was brought into the A&E after fainting in the street.

 

How would macula densa respond to a decrease in blood pressure?
Explanation:
A decrease in blood pressure results in less NaCl present at the distal tubule, where the macula densa is located.

 

The macula densa senses this drop in salt concentration and responds through two mechanisms:

  • First, it triggers dilation of the renal afferent arteriole, decreasing afferent arteriole resistance and, thus, offsetting the decrease in glomerular hydrostatic pressure caused by the drop in blood pressure.
  • Second, macula densa cells release prostaglandins, which triggers granular juxtaglomerular cells to release renin into the bloodstream

Question: What is the main cause of heart failure?
Explanation:
The main causes of HF are:

  • Ischemic heart disease (35-40%)
  • Cardiomyopathy (30-35%)
  • Hypertension (15-20%)

Others causes include: arrhythmias and valvular heart disease

Question:
During a tutorial on action potentials, Tom and Emily were discussing the different inward and outward movements of ions during the different stages of an action potential. Tom asked Emily "Stage 2 (the plateau phase) of the cardiac action potential is mediated by the movement of which ions?"

What was Emily's answer?
Explanation:
Explanation: 

Phase 0 (the depolarisation phase) is mediated by fast Na channels opening and an influx of Na ions into the cell.

Phase 1 (initial repolarisation) is caused by those channels closing.

Phase 2 (plateau) is caused by K and Ca channels opening, with the calcium entering the cell being balanced by potassium leaving the cell.

Phase 3 (repolarisation) is caused by Ca channel closure, causing a net negative current as K+ ions continue to leave the cell.

For the other answers, the inward movement of sodium alone would represent a positive current (and so not a plateau).

The inward movement of potassium combined with the outward movement of sodium is the normal action of the sodium-potassium pump.

Question:
A type 1 diabetic patient comes to your surgery for a check up on his NYHO stage IIa heart failure. He states that he feels breathless sometimes, but it does not seem to impact too much on his life. He tells you that a week ago, while driving, he became hypoglycemic and felt lucky he had a bit of sugar with him to keep him going as he felt he started to feel drowsy. Else, he seems to keep up with his insulin injections and glucose monitoring. 

What should you encourage the patient to informe the DVLA about?
OptionA:
The DVLA should be notified about the patients diabetes and the patient's heart failure.

They will take his license as he has had an episode of hypoglycemia.
OptionB:
The DVLA should be notified about the patients diabetes and the patient's heart failure.
They will take his license because of his heart failure.
OptionC:
The DVLA should only be notified about the patients diabetes. 
They will take his license as he has had an episode of hypoglycemia.
OptionD:
The DVLA should only be notified about the patients heart failure. 

He should be able to keep his license.
OptionE:
The DVLA should be notified about the patients diabetes and the patient's heart failure.

He should be able to keep his license.
Explanation:
Diabetes needs to be notified about type 1 diabetes and Heart Failure. However: a person can keep his driving lycense if: 

 must have adequate awareness of
hypoglycaemia
 must not have had more than one
episode of hypoglycaemia requiring
the assistance of another person in
the preceding 12 months
 there should be appropriate blood
glucose monitoring. This has been
defined by the Secretary of State’s
Honorary Medical Advisory Panel
on Driving and Diabetes, as no
more than 2 hours before the start
of the first journey and every 2
hours while driving. More
frequent testing may be required if
for any reason there is a greater risk
of hypoglycaemia, for example after
physical activity or altered meal
routine
 must not be regarded as a likely
source of danger to the public
while driving
 the visual standards for acuity and
visual field must be met

Our patient here dealt with his hypoglyceamia alone so everything is fine. 

Heart failure patients can continue to drive if they are symptomatic, as long as there symptoms don't impair their driving skills.

Question:
You've been asked to perform a cardiovascular examination on a 55-year-old man. While assessing the JVP you notice an absence of the a wave which precedes the carotid arterial pulse.

 

Which of the following pathologies can cause this symptom?
Explanation:
AF is a cause of absence in the a wave.

 

Pulmonary hypertension, tricuspid stenosis and pulmonary stenosis cause a large a wave.

Tricuspid regurgitation causes an increase in v wave.

 

(Pre-reading JVP - tutorial)

Question:
A 59-year-old healthy male presents to his primary care physician for a check-up.  His blood pressure at the previous visit was 160/95. The patient did not wish to be on any medications and at the time attempted to manage his blood pressure with diet and exercise. On repeat measurement of blood pressure today, the reading is 163/92. The GP decides to prescribe a medication which the patient agrees to take.

 

The patient calls his physician 6 days later complaining of a persistent cough, but otherwise states that his BP was measured as 145/85 at a local pharmacy. Which of the following is a contraindication to this medication?
Explanation:
This patient's presentation is consistent with hypertension. Angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors) commonly present with cough in around 20% of patients and are contraindicated in bilateral renal artery stenosis.

ACE inhibitors are usually cautioned in black patients as they have been shown to be less effective. Black patients are noted to have higher risks of angioedema with ACE inhibitors.

http://www.gpnotebook.co.uk/simplepage.cfm?ID=-2140471276&linkID=322&cook=yes

Question: A 45-year-old Caucasian man with a three-year history of diabetes mellitus presents to your office for a routine check-up. He has no complaints. His medications include metformin, aspirin, and a multivitamin. He works in office and lives in a bungalow with his wife. He smokes half a pack of cigarettes per day and drinks three cans of beer on weekends. His diet includes mostly meat and large amounts of "junk food." On physical exam, his blood pressure is 158/96 mmHg, heart rate is 82 bpm. His BMI is 35.0 kg/m2. The remainder of his physical exam is unremarkable. Laboratory studies reveal an HbA1c of 7.8%. At his last check-up one month ago, his blood pressure was 152/94 mmHg. Which of the following interventions would be most effective for lowering his blood pressure?
Explanation:
Weight loss is the most beneficial lifestyle intervention for obese patients.Every 10 kg reduction in weight can decrease systolic blood pressure by 5-20 mmHg

As his BMI is over 30kg/m2, this would cause the biggest change to his BP. Obviously all the other answer could help the patient lose weight but E is the best answer.

Question: Mr Johnsonn lives on his own in a bungalow and tries to travel to his local shop regularly. He has started to experience breathlessness on his way. He has heart failure. Which heart failure classification is he?
Explanation: NHYA Class IIb- Breathlessness on mild exertion

Question:
A 75 year old male enters your surgery complaining of breathlessness, especially when he's playing polo with his chums. He's devastated about the effect this is having on his social life. You decide to do a cardiovascular examination and notice an elevated JVP of 9cm. He says he has been told this by another health professional. Trying not to panic, you take a moment to reflect on this finding. 

 

What is the least likely cause of his chronically raised JVP?
Explanation: Stress is unlikely to be the major cause.

Question:
A child comes into A&E with symptoms of confusion, irregular pulse, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea and vision changes (blind spots). You've just found out the child has eaten a foxglove plant.

 

What compound is causing his symptoms and by what mechanism?
OptionB:
Tetrodotoxin (TTX)

Inhibits the firing of action potentials by blocking the voltage gated sodium channels
OptionD:
Cyanide poisoning

Over activation of vagal innervation to the heart
Explanation: Digoxin inhibits the Na+/K+ ATPase transporter, causing Na+/Ca2+ exchanger, raise in intracellular Ca2+ causing increased inotropy and decreased chronotropy with increased vagal stimulation and associated symptoms.

Question: Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause hypokalaemia?

Explanation: See lectures for case 15

Question: A patient comes into your GP surgery having been diagnosed with left ventricular systolic dysfunction. She is prescribed ramipril to help relieve her symptoms, she asks you to briefly explain how this drug works.
OptionA: It inhibits the Na/K/2Cl symporter of the thick ascending limb of the loop of henle
OptionB: It blocks the catalytic activity of the enzyme that converts angiotensin 1 to angiotensin 2
OptionC: It is a cardioselective antagonist of B-1 adrenoreceptors therefore prevents the binding of adrenaline
OptionD: It inhibits the Na/K pump in myocytes to reduce chronotropy
OptionE: It irreversibly binds to the COX domain of PGHS
Explanation:
ramipril is an ACE inhibitor therefore B is the correct answer

A= loop diuretic

C=beta blocker

D=digoxin

E=aspirin

Question: Which of the following is true about Spironolactone?
OptionA: Spironalactone is not suitable for a patient with an eGFR>50ml
OptionB: Spironolactone can cause an anion gap metabolic acidosis
OptionD: Spironolactone is safe for patients with Addison's disease
Explanation:
Spironalactone is not suitable for anyone with renal impairment. The threshold for this is eGFR <30ml.

Spironolactone causes aNON-anion gap metabolic acidosis

Spironolactone can cause arrhythmias, due to it's possible side effect of hyperkalaemia

Spironolactone is NOT safe for patients with Addison's disease because of it's possible side effect of hyperkalaemia

Spironolactone can cause feminisation including gynaecomastia in men due to its androgen antagonist effects.
Tags: Pharmacology, Renal system, Cardiology, Group 84, Case 15

Question: A patient who suffered from an anterior myocardial infarction about a year ago presents to you in clinic. He complains of severe tiredness and breathlessness among other things. You observe his JVP which is raised, and has large a waves. What might be the cause of his symptoms?
Explanation: It is likely to be pulmonary hypertension, caused by mitral regurgitation which occurred because of the left ventricular remodelling which occurred following his anterior MI. This was a scenario based on the patient we saw in wrap up!
