Eosinophils are involved in degranulation, are raised is asthmatics and during allergic response

Question: Mr Peters has a normal glucose metabolism, he has an appointment with you at the GP surgery at 1:30pm, just after he's eaten a large bacon sandwich for his lunch. In Mr Peters blood at the moment incretins are being released to help exaggerate the response of insulin to his bacon sandwich. Which of these is a correct way in which incretins aim insulin action and reduce beta cell workload?
OptionA: They act on the CNS to decrease satiety therefore reducing the amount of food consumed after a meal and so reducing insulin and beta cell workload.
OptionB: They increase glucose independent insulin secretion to reduce the amount of glucose present and aid its conversion to glycogen for storage
OptionC: They increase the secretion of glucagon post-prandially from alpha cells, helping to even out the balance of insulin and glucagon for optimal absorption
OptionD: They regulate gastric emptying, smoothing out the flow of chyme out of the stomach so that there is not a massive peak in glucose levels and so reducing workload for beta cells
Explanation:
A- Incorrect- Satiety means 'the feeling of being satisfied' so a decreased satiety would increase appetite, they actually increase satiety.

 

B- Incorrect- they aid glucose-dependant insulin secretion, to my knowledge there is no such thing as 'glucose independent insulin secretion'

 

C- Incorrect- they DECREASE the amount of glucagon secreted from alpha cells after eating, this means that there is to a massive reduction in hepatic glucose so that a better balance between insulin and glucagon is maintained while glucose levels still remain high in the intestines. Otherwise glucagon would just increase glucose levels back up again as soon as insulin has reduced levels.

 

D- They regulate gastric emptying, smoothing out the flow of chyme out of the stomach so that there is not a massive peak in glucose levels and so reducing workload for beta cells- this is correct.

 

Incretins such as GLP1 are very important in helping the action of insulin and reducing beta cell workload. By evening out flow of chyme there is not such a large surge of glucose entering the intestines and therefore there is more time for beta cells to produce insulin and deal with the glucose peak.

Question: 10 yo Jackie has type 1 diabetes mellitus, at an appointment with her today you decide to explain to her why taking her insulin is so important and some of the risks if she doesn't monitor her blood glucose. One of those risks is Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA). DKA results in metabolic acidosis via an increase in the anion gap, which of the following ion changes with give and increased anion gap in metabolic acidosis?
Explanation:
The Anion gap is the charge difference resulting from: (Na+ + K+) - (HCO3- + Cl-)

 

A normal anion gap is 15

 

There are two methods of gaining Metabolic Acidosis:

  1. By changing the proportion of Cl- and HCO3- so that the anion gap stays the same however a shift in the ratio of these two ions results in metabolic acidosis
  2. Or by just reducing the amount of HCO3- and so increasing the anion gap

Method 1 is achieved by either H+Cl- gain (so an increase in Cl- and a decrease in HCO3- as it is used to 'neutralise' the H+) or a loss of HCO3- which is replaced by Cl- (hypercholaraemic acidosis). This is most common in diarrhoea: here fluid losses into the lumen contain much more Na+ than Cl- and therefore much more Na+ loss however the fluids relaxing them contain equal amounts of Na+ and Cl- therefore giving a rise in Cl- to replace lost negative ions (HCO3-) balancing out the anion gradient. 

 

Method 2 is achieved by H+A- gain, this is just acid gain that uses up HCO3- to 'neutralise' therefore a reduction in amount of HCO3- however no compensation by Cl- therefore the value of (HCO3- + CL-) decreases so that the anion gap increases. This is most often seen, as in the question, in T1DM DKA with a accumulating organic acids.

Question: You’re a GP and Mr Smith, who is 67, comes in to see you to about his hypertension. You prescribed him with Chlortalidone a couple of months ago in an attempt to lower his blood pressure of 165/101 mmHg. You measure his blood pressure today and it’s 160/103 mmHg. What would you consider doing now?
OptionA: Prescribe him Ramipril to take alongside the Chlortalidone
OptionB: Prescribe him Amlodipine to take alongside the Chlortalidone
OptionC: Organise a repeat prescription of Chlortalidone for Mr Smith
OptionD: Prescribe him Amlodipine and Atenolol (and advise him to stop taking Chlortalidone)
OptionE: Prescribe him Amlodipine instead and advise him to stop taking Chlortalidone
Explanation:
• When you prescribe someone antihypertensive medication you have to take into account their age and ethnicity
  • If they’re <55 years you give them an ACE inhibitor or an Angiotensin-II receptor antagonist
  • If they’re >55 years or black you give them either a calcium channel blocker or a diuretic
  • As Mr Smith is over 55 years – you prescribed him Chlortalidone as an initial attempt to combat the hypertension (which is a thiazide diuretic)
  • As his blood pressure hasn’t really changed since this intervention, you should try a different drug
  • Another option would be a calcium channel blocker (hence why E is CORRECT – as you are giving him Amlodipine which is a calcium channel blocker)
  • A is INCORRECT because you have skipped a step… You should try out a different drug by itself before you start combining different groups of drugs (you would consider combining an ACE inhibitor and a diuretic in step 2 – if trying out a separate drug in step 1 was unsuccessful)
  • B is INCORRECT for the same reasoning as above (you have skipped a step)
  • C is INCORRECT as Chlortalidone isn’t working so you would try out a different drug (his BP hasn’t lowered at all)
  • D is INCORRECT as you wouldn’t consider added a beta blocker until step 4… (When you have tried triple therapy and it’s still unsuccessful – ACE inhibitor + Diuretic + Calcium channel blocker)
  • E is CORRECT as you would try an alternate drug

 

  • Chlortalidone = thiazide diuretic
  • Ramipril = ACE inhibitor
  • Amlodipine = calcium channel blocker
  • Atenolol = beta blocker

Question: A 54 year old woman is evaluated by a neurologist because of a gait disorder. When the physician passively moves the patients right great toe upward or downward, the patient cannot accurately report the direction of motion, although her perception of light touch and painful sensation is unimpaired. This finding can be best explained by a lesion of which of the following structures?
Explanation: the sensation that is disturbed is proprioception in the right great toe. The sense of proprioception, discriminative touch & vibration travels in the dorsal white column (Fasciculus gracilis & Fasciculus cuneatus) of the ipsilateral (same) side.The F. Gracilis carries the axonal fibres from the sacral & lumbar segments of the spinal cord while the Fasciculus cuneatus carries the axonal fibres from the thoracic & cervical segments of the spinal cord.Note: Dorsal white column carries sensations from the ipsilateral (same) side while the spinothalamic tracts carries sensations from the contralateral (opposite) side.﻿

Question: What is the valency of IgM?
Explanation: IgM is a pentamer, therefore it has a higher avidity (the more binding sites = the greater the avidity). The normal structure of an immunoglobulin is comprised of two heavy chains and two light chains. The tips of the H and L chains, called the variable (V) regions, constitute the antigen-binding site. Because most antibodies have two antigen-binding sites, they are said to be bivalent. As IgM is made up of 5  immunoglobulins joined together by a joining (J) chain, and each immunoglobulin has 2 antigen-binding sites, we can say that the valency is 5x2=10.

Question: You are asking as series of questions to a patient with heart failure on their follow up appointment. You ask a person wether they get breathless when walking from one room to the other room in their house. The patient says that they are fine when they are sitting down but moving from one room to the next leaves them breathless. According to the New York heart association classing system for breathlessness what score would best represent the patients symptoms?
Explanation:
1= Breathless only on marked exercise  

2a=Breathless on moderate exercise

2b= Breathless on mild exercise 

3= Breathless on minimal exercise 

4= Breathless at rest

Question: A doctor is prescribing a 50 yr old woman the drug alendronate for the secondary prevention of osteoporosis. He asks you to describe its mechanism of action. You say it...
OptionA: inhibits osteoblast activity and therefore reduces bone breakdown.
OptionB: increases osteoblast activity and therefore reduces bone breakdown.
OptionC: inhibits osteoclast activity and therefore reduces bone break down
OptionD: increases osteoclast activity and therefore reduces bone breakdown.
OptionE: increases osteocyte activity and therefore reduces bone breakdown
Explanation:
Alendronate is a Bisphosphonate which works by reducing bone breakdown by inhibiting osteoclast function through inducing apoptosis of osteoclasts.

lecture= Normal bone health and bone disease- osteoporosis treatments

Question: May goes to her GP to talk about frequent episodes where she breathes quickly, her heart races and she gets pins and needles in her hands. She feels like she is dying during these episodes. She says she feels OK after the episodes. On questioning, May says she feels "fine" from day to day, except for these episodes. She admits that she feels slightly tense and nervous in large social gatherings. What is the most likely diagnosis for May?
Explanation:
May describes features of "hyperventilation syndrome" which are physical symptoms that present with Panic Disroder. It is prevalent in 5% of the population.

 

Generalised Anxiety Disorder would present with a more persitent anxiety and chronic history

Phobic Anxiety Disorder would present with a more intense fear

May does not show any signs of a depressive disorder

Question: What is the mechanism of action of diazepam?
OptionB: Binds to gamma subunit of GABA-A receptor to allow more Cl- influx causing hyperpolarisation
OptionD: Inhibit NA and 5-HT reuptake into pre synaptic neurons
OptionE: Glutamate agonist by binding to NR2B subunit of NMDA receptor to allow more influx of Na+ and Ca+
Explanation:
Diazepam is a benzodiazepine and is an anxiolytic, used to treat anxiety. 

 

MOA: Binds to gamma subunit of GABA-A receptor to allow more Cl- influx causing hyperpolarisation.

 

C- MOA for Atypical Antipsychotics like Clozapine

D- MOA for TCAs used to treat depression like Amitriptyline

 

A & E are made up MOAs as far as I know

Question:
A 41-year-old pregnant woman was advised by her doctor to take a screening test for Down syndrome. Since her BMI was 33 kg/m2 she was offered a quadruple test.

 

Which of the following results would suggest that the baby has Down syndrome?
Explanation:
Lab findings for Down syndrome

  • Elevated hCG + INH-A
  • Lower levels of MSAFP and unconjugated Oestriol

α-fetoprotein is high for neural tube defects

Question:
The peritoneal cavity is divided up into the greater and lesser sacs.

 

Within the greater sac, there are also supracolic and infracolic compartments.

 

Which of the following is not part of the supracolic compartment?
Explanation:
The greater sac is divided up by the transverse mesocolon.

 

The supracolic compartment lies above the transverse mesocolon and contains the stomach, liver and spleen.

The infracolic compartment lies below the transverse mesocolon and contains the small intestine, ascending and descending colon.

Question:
The foregut is supplied by the coeliac trunk

 

Which of the following is NOT a component of the foregut
Explanation:
The gut can be divided up into 3 parts embryologically...

The foregut, midgut and hindgut.

 

Components of the foregut include the:

  • Oesophagus 
  • Stomach
  • Proximal duodenum 
  • Liver
  • Gall bladder
  • Spleen 
  • Part of pancreas 

These are all supplied by the coeliac trunk 

 

I got this information from the Case 11 Anatomy Practical.

Question: Which of the following characteristics of an Axonotmesis is incorrect?
Explanation:
Axonotmesis:

Axon damage and demyelination 

The endoneurium is intact 

It is also the same as Sunderland 1st degree classification

Question: Proximal rental tubular acidosis (RTA) is associated with a defect in what transport mechanism?
Explanation:
A is incorrect because bicarbonate is never excreted, only reabsorbed.

B is correct because the in PCT bicarbonate is reabsorbed as shown in the picture, and this is the defect that causes proximal RTA. It commonly occurs in fanconi syndrome, which is when there is deficiency in the proximal tubule reabsorption mechanisms of all substances. 

C is incorrect as H+ excretion failure is the cause of distal RTA.

D is incorrect as H+ is never reabsorbed, only excreted.

E is incorrect because NH3 is excreted in the distal tubule to buffer H+, but it doesn't cause proximal RTA.

Question: Rhidian, a 21 year old black male has been diagnosed with diabetes, compared to the risk in the general population, how likely is he to develop depression?
Explanation: People living with diabetes are 2-3 times more likely to develop depression than the general population. Prevalence estimates vary but the proportionate increase is consistent across many studies.

Question: Lois, a 34 year old female was diagnosed with Schizophrenia 2 years ago. She was prescribed Clozapine. Since her daignosis, Lois has put on 25kg and is complaining of always feeling tired and having the frequent need to urinate. She has a BP of 150/90. Her psychotic symptoms are better but Lois blames the Clozapine for her weight gain and lethargy. Although Lois' positive Schizophrenic symptoms are better, she still struggles with negative symptoms, most notably, avolition. What is the most appropriate course of action in dealing with Lois' complaints?
Explanation: Lois may have metabolic syndrome. Since Lois has negative symptoms, most notably, lack of motivation, this could have lead to her eating unhealthy, exercising and smoking thus causing the constellation of conditions that usually make up metabolic syndrome( insulin resistance, obesity, HBP, Dylipidemia). Therefore screening and monitoring of required lifestyle changes is the first step in addressing Lois' problems.

Question: Martin, a 56 year old man, comes in for a consultation after his wife forced him to. She states that he has been very down lately. You perform a mental state examination (MSE), which of the following below is NOT a domain of an MSE?

You are the on-call doctor in A&E when you see a 25 year old patient, Rhodri Davies, who has come in with his mother. His mother tells you that Rhodri's behaviour has recently changed, as well as his intellectuality. You ask about Rhodri's past medical history, and his mother tells you that she had elected not to give Rhodri the MMR vaccine, and as a result, he was infected with measles roughly around 7 years ago. You decide to perform a GALS assessment on Rhodri and find that he has an unsteady gait and muscle twitching. Taking his previous medical history into account, what do you diagnose Rhodri with?
Explanation:
Rhodri has presented with a classical case of late infection due to the previous measles infection. Anyone who has suffered from the measles virus and recovered, there will be a defective virus leftover, which can later in life, result in slow degeneration of CNS known as subacute sclerosing panencephalitis.

 

SSPE is a rare complication of measles that results in symptoms such as:

  • Bizarre behaviour
  • Dementia (loss of mental, emotional, and social abilities)
  • Coma
  • Gradual behavioural changes
  • Myoclonic jerking (quick muscle jerking or spasms)
  • School problems
  • Seizures
  • Unsteady gait
  • Very tense muscles or muscles that lack tone, with weakness in both legs

SSPE tends to occur several years after an individual has measles, even though the person seems to have fully recovered from the illness. Males are more often affected than females. The disease generally occurs in children and adolescents. The condition is usually fatal.

Question:
A 42 year old ex- cocaine addict is brought into A and E with a BP of 99/56 with an initial complaint of being able to feel his heart racing. He looks pale and his BP is 99/56. You take a quick history and note than he is on olanzapine. While you took a brief history, an ecg was taken:

Which management option would be absolutely contraindicated here?
Explanation:
The ECG shows Torsades de Pointes. Although not clear from the ECG, the fact that he is on olanzapine might indicate a prolonged QT interval which has then gone on to cause TdP.

Amiodarone is a voltage gated K+ channel blocker and will prolong the QT interval even further and kill the patient quicker which is why it would be contraindicated here.

Question:
A 2-year-old boy was referred to a paediatrician due to his history of recurrent infections, mild developmental delay and cleft palate.

 

Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities is likely to be the cause of the boy's problems?
Explanation: DiGeorge syndrome – mild-mod dev delay/LD, cleft palate, heart defects, immune problems

Question: Which of the following gives rise to the urogenital system in an embryo?
Explanation:
Mesodermal derivatives:

 

  • cranium, connective tissue of head, dentine, muscles of head,
  • urogenital system and accessory glands
  • connective tissue and muscle of viscera
  • pericardium and peritoneum, primordial heart, blood and lymphatic cells

(Prof. Wilson lecture, case 7)

Question: Which of the following gives rise to the retina in an embryo?
Explanation:
Ectodermal derivatives:

  • Central Nervous System, retina, pineal body, posterior pituitary gland, cranial sensory ganglia and nerves
  • epidermis, hair, nails cutaneous and mammary glands
  • enamel of teeth, inner ear, lens

Question: Which of the following gives rise to the liver in an embryo?
Explanation:
Endodermal derivatives:

  • Epithelial parts of the trachea, bronchi, lungs
  • Epithelium of GIT, liver, pancreas, urinary bladder
  • Epithelial parts of the pharynx, thyroid, tympanic cavity, tonsils, parathyroid glands

Question: Which of the following induces neural patterning as well as patterning the somites?
Explanation:
Sonic Hedgehog protein (Shh) initially expressed in the notochord induces neural patterning as well as patterning the somites.

 

Wnt family of proteins appear to function as inducers of ectodermally and mesodermally derived tissues/organs.

 

The TGF-b family of proteins, including the BMPs regulate cell differentiation

 

N-cadherin & E-cadherin are cell adhesion molecules 

 

(Prof Wilson lecture, case 7)

Question: Which of the following is the best description of Sunderland Nerve Injury Class IV?
OptionB: Loss of axonal, endoneurium and perineurium continuity-no conduction takes places
OptionC: Loss of axonal and endoneurium continuity-no conduction takes places
OptionD: Loss of axonal continuity-no conduction takes places

Question: Which of these is the best description of a neurotmesis injury according to the Seddon Classification?
OptionA: Loss of axonal, endoneurium and perineurium continuity only-no conduction takes places
OptionB: Loss of axonal, endoneurium continuity but perineurium intact-no conduction takes places
OptionC: Loss of axonal continuity only, endoneurium and perineurium intact-no conduction takes places

Question: A man comes in to your surgery for an ECG. On inspection of ECG, you see that there is T wave inversion in lead aVR and lead V1, what does this most likely indicate?
Explanation:
T wave inversion is a normal finding in aVR and V1 

 

Early stages of a STEMI - would cause hyperacute T waves 

 

An upright T wave would indicate coronary artery disease

 

Left bundle branch block produces T-wave inversion in the lateral leads I, aVL and V5-6

 

Right bundle branch block produces T-wave inversion in the right precordial leads V1-3.

Question: An 85 year old lady presents to your GP practice with colonic symptoms, and you decide that she needs further investigation. What is the most suitable form of imaging?
Explanation:
D is the correct answer because colonoscopy is used in patients with colonic symptoms under 40, or if cancer or colitis is likely. Minimal prep CT is used in over 80's who have colonic symptoms.

CT pneumocolon is used if the patients has colonic symptoms and has previously had a failed colonoscopy, or extra-colonic cancer is likely.

Barium enemas are rarely used.

Ultrasound cannot view gas, so has limited use when the patient has colonic symptoms.
Tags: Radiology, Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11, Imaging, Lower GI

Question: Which one of the following is purely endocrine in function?
Explanation:
See plenary 4, case 10 on key principles in the anatomy and function of the endocrine system.

Purely endocrine glands/organs: Pituitary glands, thyroid gland, parathyroid gland, adrenal glands

Partially endocrine glands/organs: Hypothalamus, gonads, pancreas, thymus

The partial endocrine glands also have exocrine function ie. they secrete hormones, enzymes into ducts whereas, the completely endocrine glands secrete into the blood only

Question: Your two weeks overdue and you are advised to come into the hospital for an induction. You know some methods of induction from your prior research, but which one is most likely to be administered?
Explanation: Prostaglandin gels are the best method of induction.

Question: A patient, who was diagnosed with Crohn's disease a year ago, begins to notice her symptoms are worsening. At the same time, she notices red lumps on her shin. What are these called?
Explanation:
All the answers are complications of IBD.

 

Complications related to disease activity (so if the disease is flaring up these are flaring up):

  • Peripheral arthritis (D)
  • Skin lesions- erythema nodosum (C and correct answer, these are more common in Crohn's) and pyoderma gangrenosum (E, these are painful ulcers on the skin and are more common in UC)
  • Episcleritis (B)
  • Mouth lesions- apthous ulcers (A), angular chelitis and lip swelling. These are all more common in Crohn's

Complications unrelated to disease activity:

  • Central arthritis- ankylosing spondylitis and sacro-ilitis. These are associated with HLA-B27.
  • Type 2 arthropathy- type of arthritis affecting more that 5 small joints.
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis- affecting bile duct.
  • Anterior uveitis- inflammation of anterior uvea of eye, associated with HLA-B27.
Tags: Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11, Inflammatory Bowel Disease, Lower GI

Question:
You're a GP and one of your patients, Mrs Moseley, a 43 year old woman, comes in to see you for a routine check up regarding her medical condition. During the consultation, you notice she looks a little upset.

 

Naturally, you ask about her ideas, concerns and expectations... With this, she goes on to tell you that her older brother had recently been diagnosed with colorectal cancer, aged 47.

 

You begin to reflect on the lecture you received as a medical student on the genetics of the GI tract and you try to work out the relative risk (RR) of Mrs Moseley developing colorectal cancer.

 

What will this relative risk be?
Explanation:
• Family history and age are very important risk factors for CRC (colorectal cancer)
  • Some CRCs arise from an inherited predisposition (familial risk)
  • Most CRCs, however, are sporadic and occur in people without a strong family history
  • As her brother is a 1st-degree relative with CRC, the relative risk of Mrs Moseley developing CRC is 2.8

 

 

 

Note that her brother is 47.... According to Dr Frayling's lecture, if her brother (or any other first degree relative for that matter) had been below 45 - the relative risk for Mrs Moseley developing CRC would be even higher (3.7).

 

I got this information from the 'Genetics of the GI tract' by Dr Frayling (Case 11)
Tags: Cancer, Gastrointestinal tract, Genetics, Case 11, Lower GI

Question: A 36-year old pregnant woman had an Chorionic Villus Sampling which came back positive for Down's syndrome. Since the couple has one boy affected by this disease they decide to have a medical abortion. Considering the mother is 12 weeks pregnant which of the following can be used to terminate the pregnancy?
Explanation:
Medical abortion:

  • <9 weeks - Mifepristone only
  • 9-20 weeks - Mifepristone and Prostaglandins

Question: Which of the following below is not a feature of adrenarche?
OptionB: Adrenal cortex secretes increased levels of DHEA, DHEAS and cortisol
OptionC: Adrenal cortex secretes increased levels of DHEA, DHEAS without increased levels of cortisol
OptionD: Tends to occur later in boys then girls
OptionE: There is activation of the hypothalamaic- pituitary-adrenal axis

Question:
You are a junior doctor on an endocrinology rotation. The senior doctor asks you to interpret a lab report:

Lowered TSH, normal T4, raised T3

 

What is your differential diagnosis?

Katrina Jane comes in to the GP surgery with angular cheilitis and glossitis. You, being a such a good doctor have realized that Kat has a nutritional deficiency as she has admitted to eating poorly over the past few months. Which nutritional deficiency is most likely causing Katrina's angular cheilitis and glossitis?

Mandy is wide awake at 2 am the night before her 2nd year medical school exam. 

 

She is frustrated but remembers revising sleep control and thinks she can remember the areas in the brain which are maintaining her wakefulness. She knows one of these areas produces the neurotransmitter orexin. 

 

What area of the brain could she be thinking of?
Explanation:
Lateral Hypothalic area stregthens the awake state through production of orexins. 

 

The other areas that stimulate wakefulness are: 

locus coeruleus in the Pons produces Noradrenaline

raphe nuclei in the brainstem produces serotonin 

TMN ( The tuberomamillary nuclei) in the hypothalamus produces histamine. 

 

VLPO is the Ventrolateral Preoptic nuclei and inhibits the reticular activating system via GABA production. Stimulating Sleep.

Question: How many subunits does troponin have?
Explanation: Troponin I, C and T are the main subunits if the protein

Question:
Ruby, a 4 year old child and her mother go to see the GP as Ruby has been suffering from a cough, sore throat and a cold. The GP suspects that Ruby has Adenovirus. 

 

According to the Baltimore virus classification, what class does adenovirus belong to?
Explanation:
Adenovirus is a double stranded DNA virus which is class I

 

Class II - ssDNA

Class III - dsRNA

Class IV - (+)ssRNA

Class V - (-)ssRNA

Class VI - reverse transcribed RNA

Class VII - reverse transcribed DNA

 

Adenovirus is commonly seen in young children as a respiratory infection (common cold), but can be more severe and life threatening complications in patients with multi organ disease with weakened immune system

Question: Bob has recently started a new job in a lab at a hospital and his first job is to analyse a blood sample, which shows that the patient has a reverse transcribed DNA virus. Bob has forgotten what examples of viruses are in Class VII of the Baltimore Classification, and as his colleague, he asks you what is an example of a reverse transcribed DNA virus?
Explanation:
Influenza is a (-)ssRNA virus

HIV is a revers transcribed RNA virus

Rubella is a (+)ssRNA virus 

Adenovirus is a double stranded DNA virus

Hepatitis B is a reverse transcribed DNA virus and therefore is the correct answer

Question:
While reviewing pain relief options for labor Dr Smith mentions that Entonox in high doses can cause a vitamin inactivation. 

 

Which of the following is the vitamins is the one affected by Entonox?
Explanation:
Cobalamin - B12

Folic acid - B9

Niacin - B3

Riboflavin - B2

Thiamine - B1

Question:
While reviewing pain relief options for labor Dr Smithsonian mentions that one treatment can cause the baby to become sleepy. Additionally, due to the active metabolites that can last in the foetus bloodstream up to 60 hours, this sedated state can sometimes lead to seizures. 

 

Which of the following was the treatment option that Dr Smithsonian mentioned?
Explanation:
Pethidine:

  • IM injection
  • moderate analgesic
  • highest fetal plasma concentration 2-5 hours after maternal IM dose
  • active metabolite norpethidine: t1/2 20 hrs (60 hrs foetus)
  • sedative, convulsant (foetus) 
  • sedative, N + V (mother)

Question: Upon parietal cell activation, which of the following biochemical pathways takes place?
OptionA: Cholinergic receptors activate Gs, increasing PKC, increasing intracellular Ca2+
OptionB: Gastrin receptors activate Gs, increasing PKC, increasing intracellular Ca2+
OptionC: Histamine receptors activate Gs, decreasing PKC, decreasing intracellular Ca2+
Explanation:
Cholinergic receptors activate Gq, increasing PKC, increasing intracellular Ca2+

Gastric receptors activate Gq, increasing PKC, increasing intracellular Ca2+

Histamine receptors activate Gs, increasing PKC, increasing intracellular Ca2+

Prostaglandin receptors activate Gi, decreasing PKA

Somatostatin receptors activate Gi, decreasing PKA
Tags: Abdomen, Physiology, Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11, Case 3

Question: A patient is is admitted to the hospital and on doing an ECG it is found that the patient has prolonged QT intervals and quickly develops Torsade de Points. You take a look at the list of medications that the patient is on to see if any of his medications could have caused prolonged QT intervals. Which of the following class of drug is most likely to have caused this patient's prolonged QT intervals?
Explanation: Monoamine inhibitors cause the Cheese effect

Question: Which of the following molecules is responsible for regulating the Ryanodine channel in cardiac myocytes from the cytosolic domain?
Explanation:
Calbindin - Involved in calcium homeostasis and buffering in the blood.

Calmodulin - regulates plasma membrane (PMCA) channel (ATPase) which transports Calcium out of the cell 

Calstabin - correct answer. aka FKBP.

Calsequestrin - regulates SERCA on the inside of the SR. Inhibits opening of the ryanodine channel. When there is a calcium overload in the SR, there is more release of calcium as it binds to calsequestrin. 

Phospholamban - regulates SERCA channel and is inhibitory to calcium uptake into the SR

Question: What is the name of the specialised cell in the duodenum of the small intestine that secretes mucous to help neutralise the acidic chyme?
Explanation: Brunner's glands are only found in the submucosa of the duodenum. Along with Goblet cells, they secrete mucous into the small intestine lumen. Since mucous is alkaline in nature, it helps neutralise the acidic chyme arriving from the stomach. This creates a more suitable pH for small intestinal enzymes to work at
Tags: Microanatomy, Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11, Histology, Case 3

Question: What are the most abundant cells in the anterior pituitary gland?
Explanation:
40-50% of the anterior pituitary cells are somatotrophs

15-20% are corticotrophs

10-15% are gonadotrophs

10-15% are gonadotrophs

3-5% are thyrotrophs

Question:
A 65 year old man presents to his GP for a routine check up with a history of heart disease and high blood pressure. He complains that recently he has been experiencing episodes of dizziness followed by fainting. These episodes occur throughout the day and are interfering in the patient’s day to day life.
The GP performs an ECG (shown below).

 

 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG and taking into account the history of the patient?
Explanation:
From the patient’s history, we are able to identify that he has three risk factors of LBBB: old age, high blood pressure and heart disease. In this case the heart disease is the underlying cause of the LBBB. Also the patient experiences the only symptoms associated with LBBB: pre syncope and syncope.
The ECG shows: a w shaped wave in lead V1 and an m shaped wave in v6. (The mnemonic WiLLiaM and MaRRoW is helpful.)

Question: Which of the following best describes the role of N cells in the regulation of GI motility?
OptionB: Release motilin in the duodenum which increases sensitivity of smooth muscle to nervous activity
OptionC: Releases enteroglucan in the ileum in response to glucose and fat
OptionD: Releases neurotensin in the ileum in response to fat, decreases motility
OptionE: Rleases VIP which relaxes smooth muscle, increases motility
Explanation:
A - enteric neurones

B - M cells

C - L cells

D - correct

E - NANC neurones
Tags: Abdomen, Physiology, Biochemistry, Case 11, Lower GI

Question: A 35 year old woman presents to you with BP readings 150/100, 149/98 and 160/95 on three successive days. A routine metabolic profile is normal except for a low potassium level (2.8). She denies vomiting, diahorrea or taking any prescription medications. Which of the following types of hypertension is most likely present?
Explanation:
Hypokalemia and high BP

Sodium is normal (water may come back aswell to balance)

Normally no electrolyte abnormalities in essential hypertension so must be a secondary cause. 

Hyperaldosteronism causes low potassium

Question: Which of these is not a type of clinical instability of the spinal cord?
Explanation:
Clinical Instability 

The loss of the ability of the spine under physiological loads to maintain its pattern of displacement so that there is no initial or additional neurological deficit, no major deformity and no incapacitating pain

Types include Mechanical, Neurological, Static and Dynamic

Question: A 50 year old man consults the physician because he has been having transient periods of rapid heart beat accompanied by sweating, flushing, and a sense of impending doom. Physical examination is unrevealing, with no evidence of arrhythmia at the time of the exam. However, the man's wife is a nurse so the doctor asks her to take vital signs the next time one of the episodes occurs. The next episode shows a BP of 195/140 and a heart rate of 160bpm. She promptly takes her husband to A&E but by the time they arrive the spell is over. Urinary measurement of the following would be most likely diagnostic in this case?
Explanation:
Symptomatology of Pheochromocytoma caused by:

- tumour of the adrenal medulla

- secretes excessive amounts of adrenaline and noradrenaline - inducing vasocontriction induced hypertension and increased cardiac stimulation. 

 

Breakdown products of adrenaline and noradrenaline in the urine are Vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and Homovanillic acid (HVA) which can be measured.

Question: You are going through a list of the effects of AT1R activation. Which of the following is least likely to be on that list?
Explanation: Dr.Coffey's lecture on HF drugs:

Question: Which of the following is not one of the five factors of personality?
Explanation:
The 5 personality factors are: OCEAN

O- openness

C- CONCIENTIOUSNESS

E- extraversion

A- agreablness

N- neuroticism

Question:
Your grandma is quizzing you about her arrhythmia because she knows you have been studying them at uni and therefore must be an expert.

 

You explain it is related to the heart having slow and fast pathways of conduction . This can result in different conduction times which can allow impulses to reenter areas of the heart that they shouldn't creating something called circus movement tachycardia. This is what is causing her fast heart rate. 

 

She shows you her  ECG and the P waves are buried. 

 

What drug is she most likely to have taken to terminate this tachycardia in the short term?
Explanation:
She is likely to have AV nodal dependent reentry tachycardia ( AVNRT) also called Paraoxysmal SVT's. 

 

Adenosine is an AV nodal blocker which causes hyper-polarization via KAch channels. It is short acting hence the most correct answer. (Valsalva manoeuvre can also be successful) 

 

Flecainide may be used long term to control the arrhythmia (according to Dr Coffeys lecture). Kumar and Clark also mentions Amiodarone, diltiziam and radio frequency ablation.

Question: What the ECG characteristics of this condition?
OptionA: Deep S waves v1 and Tall R waves V6
OptionB: R wave greater than S wave in V1
Explanation:
Tombstoning occurs in STEMI

P Mitrale occurs in left atrial enlargement

P pulmonary in right atrial enlargement often due to pulmonary hypertension.

Question: Andrew Brown is a 34 year old a black African man, he has a blood pressure of 180/100 and is prescribed Nicardipine, a calcium channel blocker. Although his blood pressure was fairly well controlled, three months later, Andrew is diagnosed with heart failure. What is the most appropriate course of treatment for his hypertension now?
OptionA: Cease the Nicardipine and start him on Furosemide (Loop Diuretic)
OptionC: Cease with Nicardipine but add Spironolactone (K+ Sparing)
OptionD: Cease the Nicardipine and start him on Indapamide (Thiazide like)
OptionE: Continue with Nicardipine only as it will not have an effect on his heart failure.
Explanation:
NICE GUIDELINES

 

Offer step 1 antihypertensive treatment with a calcium-channel blocker (CCB) to people aged over 55 years and to black people of African or Caribbean family origin of any age. If a CCB is not suitable, for example because of oedema or intolerance, or if there is evidence of heart failure or a high risk of heart failure, offer a thiazide-like diuretic. [new 2011]

 

If diuretic treatment is to be initiated or changed, offer a thiazide-like diuretic, such as chlortalidone (12.5–25.0 mg once daily) or indapamide (1.5 mg modified-release or 2.5 mg once daily) in preference to a conventional thiazide diuretic such as bendroflumethiazide or hydrochlorothiazide. [new 2011]

Question:
Molly a pregnant 32-year-old notices her breasts increased in size since her dating scan. You explain that the increase in breast tissue is due to hypertrophy & proliferation of ducts and the alveoli.

 

Which of the following promotes ducts proliferation?
Explanation: (Breast anatomy lecture, case 8)

Question: What is the most important galactopoietic hormone (maintains lactation)?
Explanation:
Prolactin appears to be the single most important galactopoietic hormone.

 

Feedback inhibitor of lactation; FIL (whey protein) regulates milk secretion
Milk production slows when milk accumulates in the breast (more FIL is present) & speeds up when breast is emptier

Continuous suckling is essential for removal of milk from glands

 

(Breast anatomy lecture, case 8)

Question: What is the most abundant sugar found in human milk composition?
Explanation: (Breast anatomy lecture, case 8)

Question: Which of the following immunoglobulins are found in breast milk?
Explanation: (Breast anatomy lecture, case 8)

Question: What is the maximum APGAR score that you can get with a newborn healthy baby with no emergency circumstances?
Explanation: APGAR

Question: A mother comes in at the GP with her baby for a routine check-up. She ask you at what age is the baby supposed to say his first word. Your answer is ...
Explanation: (Child development lecture, case 9)

Question: Glucose is converted to glucose-6-phosphate by the enzyme hexokinase, except in the liver and pancreas where it is converted by the enzyme glucokinase. What can be said about the enzyme kinetics of these two enzymes?
OptionA: Hexokinase and glucokinase both have a low Km
OptionB: Hexokinase has a high Km and glucokinase has a low Km
OptionC: Hexokinase has a low Km and glucokinase has a high Km
OptionD: Hexokinase and glucokinase both have a high Km
Explanation:
Km is the measure of the affinity of the enzyme for its substrate. The lower the Km, the higher the affinity

Hexokinase has a low Km and is inhibited at lower levels of glucose than glucokinase would be.

Glucokinase functions as a glucose sensor, stimulating glycogen synthesis and insulin production when blood glucose is high.

Question: Which of the following infectious intestinal disease causing bacteria is gram positive?
Explanation: See case 11 microbiology of the GI tract lecture
Tags: Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11, Infection, Inflammatory Bowel Disease, Lower GI

Question: A woman comes to the GP asking about vaccination needed during pregnancy. You check the 'Green Book' and say that she will need ...
Explanation: (Immunisation lecture, case 9)

Question: A patient was diagnosed with West Nile virus. Knowing it's a double stranded RNA virus which TLR is involved in endosomal virus recognition?
Explanation:
Endosomal TLR: TLR3, TLR7, TLR8 & TLR9

 

Only TLR3 responds to dsRNA viruses.

 

(Immunology A plenary, case 9)

Question: A patient was diagnosed with herpes simplex virus. Knowing it's an unmethylated CpG-rich DNA virus which TLR is involved in endosomal virus recognition?
Explanation:
Endosomal TLR: TLR3, TLR7, TLR8 & TLR9

 

Only TLR9 is used for unmethylated CpG-rich DNA viruses.

 

(Immunology A plenary, case 9)

Question: Which of the following is the most common risk factor for describing the commonest cause of heart failure?
Explanation: According to Professor Fraser, the most common risk factor in heart failure worldwide is hypertension; particurlay prevalent in western civilisation and Africa. Coronary Arterial Disease and Diabetes mellitus type II were also key factors mentioned in Fraser's lecture

Question:
You are taking a history from a patient who has come in with shortness of breath. She has quite a significant social history and she starts telling you all about her family.

 

She tells you that she divorced from her husband two years ago and is now living with her boyfriend, his child from his previous relationship and her twins from her previous marriage.

 

What type of family has she described?
Explanation: This is a blended family - a newly formed family in which the parents and children were once part of other families but now aren't together due to separation, divorce or remarriage.

Question: Which of the following symptoms is most sensitive to diagnosing heart failure?

You are on placement in EU. A patient is rushed into resus with a suspected opioid overdose.

You know from your case 8 revision that there is a drug that can block the effects of opioids.

The doctor administers the drug intravenously and tells you later that the drug was a competitive antagonist at the μ (mu) opioid receptor. He asks you to name the drug used.
Explanation:
Naloxone/Narcan is a competitive antagonist at the μ opiate receptors in the nervous system. Case 8 lecture from Dr Lucy De Lloyd

 

Fentanyl is an opioid - a synthetic opiate drug which is a powerful painkiller and tranquillizer.

Buprenorphine - Is used to treat opioid addiction

Naltrexone - Is used in the management of alcohol dependence and opioid dependence.

Methadone - Is an opioid used to treat pain and as maintenance therapy or to help with detoxification in people with opioid dependence.

Question: You receive the results of a young man's thyroid test, the results show that he has low level of T3 and T4, but high levels of TSH, you suspect hypothyroidism. What is the most accurate description of the effects of T3?
OptionA: T3 is an end product of T4 metabolism, it increases B12 absorption and folate metabolism
OptionB: T3 is a precursor of thyroglobulin, it has negative feedback on TSH release
OptionC: T3 is less active than T4, it regulates calcitonin secretion and B12 absorption
OptionD: T3 is more active than T4, it regulates basal metabolic rate and calcitonin secretion
OptionE: T3 is the product of the Thyroid axis, it regulates basal metabolic rate and folate metabolism
Explanation: T3 is produced from thyroglobulin as an active hormone, it is also produced from T4 conversion to T3. The main role of T3 is to regulate basal metabolic rate and calcitonin secretion

Question: G3P0+2 is written in the notes of a woman on a ward round, as a junior doctor you read this and report which of the following back to the obstetrician?
OptionA: She has had 3 pregnancies with a miscarriage/termination and is currently expecting twins
OptionB: She has had 3 pregnancies with no miscarriages/terminations and is currently expecting twins
OptionC: She has had 3 pregnancies with 2 miscarriages/terminations and is now pregnant
OptionD: She has had 3 pregnancies with 3 miscarriages/terminations, one of which was a set of twins.
OptionE: She is having her 3rd pregnancy after 2 previous miscarriages/terminations, one of which was a set of twins
Explanation:
G gravity= the number of pregnancies the woman has had including current pregnancies

P parity= the number of times a woman has given birth to a foetus with gestational age 24 weeks +

+2= indicates the number of miscarriages/terminations that she has had

So if this woman is G3 she is on 3 pregnancies with none carried to full term, as 2 are miscarriages/terminations therefore she must currently be pregnant with her third child. 

 

Group 39

Question: What does the Hering–Breuer reflex do?
Explanation: Lung inflation inhibits inspiration to prevent overinflation in Hering Breur reflex caused by slowly adapting stretch receptors in bronchial walls

Question: How often do the epithelium of the small intestine turn over?
Explanation: There is constant turnover of epithelial cells in GI tract with the small intestine epithelium totally replacing itself approximately every 6 days

Question:
Mr Jones comes into A&E on Tuesday afternoon. The consultant asks for an ABG to be performed. These are the results:

 

pH: 7.30

PaCO2: 41

Base excess: -2.5
Tags: Acute Care, Blood Results, Renal system, Haematology

Question: Activation of which of the following receptors causes hyperpolarisation rather than depolarisation?
Explanation: Photoreceptors, unlike other receptor systems, lead to a hyperpolarisation of the cell and not depolarisation

Question: Where would you find the Pores of Kohn?
Explanation: They are alveolar pores, allowing pressure equalisation between alveoli

Question: John, a 34 year old street motorcycle racer was thrown off of his bike during a race. First responders are on the scene and suspect that their may spinal cord injury. Which of the following below is not usually indicative of spinal cord injury?
Explanation: Sympathetics lost during spinal cord injury so there will not be hypertension, instead the patient will be hypotensive.

Question: Which interleukin is responsible for proliferation and differentiation of naïve CD8 T cells?
Explanation: CD8 T cells can make their own IL-2 once activated by the dendritic cells. In some cases the stimulus from the dendritic cells is not enough and CD4 T cells bind to the DC thus start the production of IL-2 needed by the naïve CD8 T cells.

Question: Which interleukin is responsible for the recruitment of neutrophils?
Dopamine is involved in the pleasure and reward system. The mesolimbic pathway:
OptionA: Projects from the ventral tegemntal area to the nucleus accumbens
OptionB: Projects from the ventral tegmental area to the frontal cortex
OptionC: Projects from the substantia nigra to the striatum
OptionD: Projects from the raphe nucleus to the cortex
OptionE: Projects from the raphe nucleus to the hippocampus
Explanation:
B - mesocortical pathway

C - nigrostratial pathway

D - serotonin pathway

E - made up pathway

Question:
You are working as an F1 on the orthopaedic unit and meet a young man who is complaining of a tingly foot. You decide to do a full neurological examination on him to make sure there aren't any other masked pathologies.

During the examination, you notice that he struggles to flex his hip. Which myotome is most likely affected?
Explanation:
ASIA chart:

L2: Hip flexors

L3: Knee extensors

L4: Ankle dorsiflexors

L5: Long toe extensors

S1: Ankle plantar flexors

Question: What do the majority of patients with Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy display in symptoms?
Explanation: The majority of patients, 90% or so according to Dr Yousef have no symptoms.

Question:
You are on placement with the gastroenterologist and they are keen to test your knowledge.

 

He starts quizzing you on the patient he had treated last week. The patient he described was elderly and had been admitted to hospital following numerous doses of antibiotics which had been unsuccessful. Below is the patients colonoscopy:

 

What organism is likely to be the one causing this problem?
Explanation:
C.difficle is correct.

The image shows pseudomembranous colitis which is caused by C.difficile usually from excessive antibiotics.

Question: What is the problem in Paget's disease?
OptionA: Demineralisation of bone due to excessive osteoclast activity
OptionB: Weakening of bone due to accelerated bone turnover
OptionC: Demineralisation of bone due to Vitamin D deficinecy
OptionE: Demineralisation of bone due to osteocyte malfunction
Explanation: Paget's disease is accelerated turnover of bone. Overactivity of osteoclasts leads to resorption of bone which is replaced rapidly due to increased osteoblast activity. This eventually causes the bone to weaken and increases the risk of fractures.

Question:
There's been a report about several people on a cruise ship coming down with an acute fever response, abdominal pain and pruritus. The other travels explain that these symptoms are only localized to the group who consumed oysters for dinner and they describes the patients as having 'yellow-flu' disease.  

 

What is the most relevant diagnosis?
Explanation:
HAV is a ss+RNA virus.

 

Transmission: enteral through contaminated water or raw foods.

Clinical: frequently mild or an icteric, „yellow-flu / liver flu“, acute hepatitis, no persistence or chronic outcome.

Treatment: no antivirals, vaccine with inactivated HAV. Only symptoms are treated.

Question: Natalie, a 45 year old woman suffers from muscles spasms and tetany. Her doctors have confirmed that is due to her hypoparathyroidism. What is the most common cause of hypoparathyroidism?
Explanation: Often times, thyroid surgery can lead to damage to parathyroid glands thus cause hypoparathyroidism. This is the most common cause.

Question:
Linda, a 30 year old lady goes to see her GP as she has unexplained weight gain, menstrual irregularities, fatigue and low mood. 

The GP sends her for a blood test to asses her thyroid.

 

What results would you expect to see, and what would be the most likely cause of her symptoms?
OptionA: High T4 and high TSH, Hashimoto's Disease
OptionB: High T4 and Low TSH, Grave's disease
OptionC: Low T4 and High TSH, Grave's disease
OptionD: Low T4 and High TSH, Hashimoto's disease
Explanation:
The most common cause of hypothyroidism is Hashimoto's disease, where low levels of T4 and high levels of TSH are seen

In secondary hypothyroidism, low levels of both T4 and TSH are seen.

 

80% of hyperthyroidism is caused by Graves disease, and you would se high levels of T4 and low levels of TSH

Question: A 34 year old caucasian male with two recent episodes of exertional syncope is found to have a harsh systolic murmur on cardiac ausciltation and asymmetric interventricular septum hypertrophy on echocardiography. His father died suddenly at age 30. The patients symptoms are most likely explained by left ventricular outflow obstruction created by?
Explanation:
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is described

- Septum is dilated

- Mitral valve abnormalities and striking of the septum

Question: A 11 week pregnant woman with a BMI of 23 kg/m2 has arrived at her GP for Down Syndrome Screening. What type of test will she probably have, and what will the results be, assuming her child has Down Syndrome?
OptionC:
Quadruple test:

AFP decreased
uE3 decreased
beta-hCG raised
Inhibin A raised
OptionD:
Combined test:

AFP decreased

uE3 decreased

beta-hCG raised

Inhibin A raised
Explanation:
The woman will be given the combined test as it is more accurate, she is not obese and she is in her 11th week.

The results suggestive of a Down's foetus are:

NT>3.5 mm
beta- hCG raised
PAPP-A decreased
Tags: Chromosomes, Pregnancy, Prenatal Screening, Embryology, Case 7

Question: Which of the following is the gold standard imaging for renal artery imaging?

You are shadowing a GP who sees a 25yr old women. She has come in to discuss the side effects of her medication. She explains that ever since she has started taking Amitriptyline she has gained a lot of weight. The GP asks you to explain which receptor is blocked to cause the weight gain?
Aspirin, an irreversible NSAID and antiplatelet medication should not be given to under 16s due to the associated risk of developing Reye's Syndrome. How many stages of reye's syndrome are there?
Explanation: There are 5 stages of Reye's Syndrome with each one getting more severe till the last stage. Stage 5 can be fatal

Question: The Bainbridge reflex is dominant when which of the following is true?
Explanation:
The Bainbridge reflex overrides when there is increased blood volume, it causes an increased heart rate to increase renal perfusion and so to decrease blood volume. It also decreases ADH and increases ANP (increases GFR), also to result in decreased blood volume. 

 

It is the Baroreceptor reflex that responds to a fall in blood pressure by increasing heart rate, increasing cardiac contractility and vasoconstriction.

Question: Jack, has recently been diagnosed with a spinal infection. Which of the pathogens below is the most likely cause of the infection?
Explanation:
MAIN CAUSES:

   60% Staph aureus (and some staph epidermidis)

•  30% Enterobacter
•  Salmonella/ Klebsiella/ Pseudomonas
•  Strep Viridans
•  Mycobacteria
•  Fung

 

THIS IS FROM THE SPINE DRAGON LECTURE ON SPINAL METASTASES

Question:
A new diagnostic test is used to screen 100000 patients for bowel cancer.

The test was 'positive' in 900 patients. Of those, 600 were subsequently found to have bowel cancer, the other 300 after extensive investigation were pronounced disease free. There were additional 100 cases of bowel cancer not picked up by the study.

What is the tests approximate sensitivity?

Recently, Jack, a 60 year old man has been feeling pain in his back with some neurological deficits and a low grade fever. He is worried that it might be a spinal tumor. However, upon imaging and blood cultures, the consultant has confirmed that he has a spinal infection. Where in the vertebral column is a tumor and infection most likely to be present respectively?
Explanation:
70% of Tumors occur in thoracic vertebra 

50% Of Spinal infections occur in the Lumbar vertebra 

 

Spine dragon's metastases lecture

Question: The results of Mrs Baker's Left Ventricular pressure volume test are as follows, which of the following conditions does this suggest about her heart?
Explanation:
Diastolic Heart Failure is Correct, all the others are causes of/are Systolic Heart Failure. 

 

Overall the curve represents Inotropy by the top End Systolic Function curved line and Compliance by the curved bottom End Diastolic volume line. As Inotropy decreases (Systolic heart failure) the gradient of the top line will reduce so the curve will appear to squash downwards. As compliance decreases (Diastolic Heart Failure) the gradient of the bottom curved line will increase (move upwards) so the curve again will squash. 

 

For the same volume value on the Red Line (End Diastolic Volume line) there is increased pressure- this is because there is diastolic failure so the heart is not relaxing properly therefore has more pressure in diastole. Hence in Diastolic Heart failure there is a shift in gradient of the red End Diastolic Function line. Whereas the gradient of the End Systolic Line stays the same, there is just a shift down the curve. 

 

 

Systolic Dysfunction would present as:

With an altered gradient for the curved End Systolic Volume line.

Question: Sokolow's score can be used with an ECG to assess whether a patient has left ventricular hypertrophy. What two leads are used to determine this score?
Explanation:
Sokolow Score uses leads V2 and V5

To calculate

Add the number of small squares in V2 for the S wave

Add the number of small squares in V5 for the R wave

 If more than 35 then ECG evidence of LVH

Question: What does the Brain ct scan show?
Explanation: Indicated by the lens shaped lesion

Question: Cell death occurs when the neuron reaches a ‘point of no return’ following irreversible damage to the plasma membrane, nuclear DNA or mitochondria. Which of the following cells are in a post-mitotic state (unable to divide)?
Explanation:
Once neuronal cell death occurs it cannot usually be replaced in most parts of the brain and spinal cord.

 

Cancers never arise from post-mitotic cells, but only from mitotic cells.

Question: Jack, a 65 year old man with a history of stroke was brought into A&E complaining of severe headache. He was sent for an MRI and it was found that he had an occlusion in his posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), which of the following below is NOT a common presentation of PICA occlusion?
OptionC: Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature on face
Explanation: Alan Watson lecture on cellular responses to injury

Question:
The following results were obtained on a 56-year-old female who presents with tiredness:

 

Free T4 9.3 pmol/L (9.8-23.1)
TSH 49.31 mU/L (0.35-5.50)


Which of the following signs would you expect on physical examination?
Explanation:
Results are typical of hypothyroidism.

Hypothyroidism is associated with:
a relative bradycardia
slow relaxation of tendon jerks, and
a so-called "peaches and cream" appearance.

 

Thyroid bruit is typical of Graves' thyrotoxicosis. (hyperthyroidism)

Question:
A 26 year-old male comes to the A&E complaining of nausea/vomiting and a terrible headache which is worse in the morning. His past medical history shows that 4 weeks ago the patient was treated for meningitis. His CT shows as following:

 

 

Which diagnosis is most appropriate for his condition?
Explanation:
The patient shows evidence of Hydrocephalus (enlarged ventricles). Since he has a history of meningitis it is more likely to be a non-obstructive type.

 

The headache may be worse in the morning after waking up because the fluid in your brain doesn't drain so well while you're lying down and may have built up overnight. Sitting up for a while may improve your headache. However, as the condition progresses, the headaches may become continuous.

Question: Which cranial nerve is responsible for pain and temperature sensation on the face?
Explanation:
Pain and temperature sensation on the face is transmitted by the trigeminal (V) nerve.

 

Occlusion of the PICA causes ipsilateral loss of both sensations.

Question: Rupture of which vessels are likely to lead to a subdural haemorrhage?
Explanation: The superior cerebral veins run from the cortex and cross the meninges to reach the superior sagittal sinus. When these rupture, the blood may split the border between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater, creating a subdural haematoma. This bleeding may be slow but persistent, sometimes presenting several weeks after injury.

Question: Regrowth of axons in the CNS is blocked physically by glial scar formation, and chemically by release of inhibitory molecules from glial cells and macrophages. Which molecule is released by oligodendrocytes, blocking adult but not embryonic axonal regrowth?
Explanation:
A (CSPGs) is incorrect as this is an inhibitory molecule produced by astrocytes which blocks axonal regrowth.

B (Calpain) is incorrect as this is the protease enzyme which is activated, during axonal degeneration upon extra and intracellular Ca2+ entering the cytosol and breaking down the cytoskeleton

C (Capsase) is incorrect as this is another protease which orchestrates programmed cell death (apoptosis)

D (Galectin-1) is incorrect, this is a molecule secreted by invading macrophages during axonal regeneration, which promotes Schwann cell migration and axon growth.

E (NogoA) is correct, this inhibitory molecule produced by oligodendrocytes blocks adult axonal regrowth but not embryonic.

 

Alan Watson's Lecture, Cellular response to injury (Case 16)

Question: Which one of the following is most likely to cause a meningitic syndrome?
Explanation: Meningitic syndrome-a type of coma-tends to be vascular (SAH) in origin or infectious meningitis

Question:
Mr Smith, a 52-year-old man, visits his GP surgery to review his blood pressure since he has type II diabetes mellitus. It is 149/110 mmHg. Additionally, his heart rate is 80 bpm. Mr Smith, smokes 15 cigarettes a day, drinks three pints of beer most nights and has a diet high in saturated fat. He drives everywhere and doesn't participate in any sports activities. He seems anxious and concerned that he a heart attack is imminent in the near future.

 

What is the initial step in treating his hypertension?
Explanation:
NICE guidelines on hypertension: while it is important that this patient's blood pressure is reduced, it is necessary to prove that it is persistent. It is possible that it is artificially high on this occasion, perhaps due to his anxiety.

 

It is also necessary to attempt lifestyle changes, which reduces BP and overall improves health. Prescribing drugs unnecessary exposes the patients to side effects and drug interactions.

Question: Which of the following is a DNA virus?
Explanation: Only Hepatitis B virus is a DNA virus, whereas Hepatitis A, C, D & E are RNA virus

Question: You are the on-call doctor in A&E when you see a young man who has just been involved in a road traffic accident (RTA). An x-ray confirms that the patient has a cribriform plate fracture. You perform a cranial nerve examination on him and realise the patient is presenting with anosmia. Which cranial nerve has been damaged?
Explanation:
The correct answer is the olfactory (I) nerve.

Exits skull through: Cribriform plate

Type: Sensory

Function: Smells

Result of lesion: Anosmia

Question: You are a medical student shadowing an ophthalmologist on her ward rounds. You visit a 59 year old patient, Mr Peter Pettigrew, and the ophthalmologist tells you that he recently suffered from a subarachnoid haemorrhage due to a brain aneurysm which required immediate surgery. She continues to tell you that after his surgery, it was found that Mr Pettigrew showed signs of pathology with a certain cranial nerve. Upon look at the patient, you can confirm that the damaged cranial nerve is the...
Explanation:
The patient is showing clear signs of occulomotor (III) nerve damage.

Exits skull through: superior orbital fissure

Type: Motor

Function:

  • Innervates superior rectus (looking up), inferior rectus (looking down), medial rectus (adducting the eye) and inferior oblique muscles (extortion of the eye) - the adduction by the medial rectus muscle is the most important
  • Raises eyelid (innervation of levator palpebrae superioris)
  • Constricts pupil (innervation of pupillary constrictor muscle)
  • Accomodation (innervation of ciliary muscle)

Therefore, damage to the occulomotor nerve will result in:

  • Abduction of the eye (as loss of adduction due to medial rectus will result in lateral rectus taking over)
  • Loss of parallel gaze
  • Ptosis
  • Dilate pupil, loss of light reflex with CN II
  • Loss of near response
Tags: Neurology, Cranial Nerves, Eye, Case 16, Case 6

Question: You are a GP on a normal day of clinics when you are visited by a 35 year old lady, Mrs Allen. She tells you that a week ago she had a dental implant procedure, and since then has had problems with chewing her food properly. She also tells you that she can't feel anything when she touches her skin around her chin. You decide to perform a cranial examination on this patient, and when you ask the patient to open her mouth, you see a clear sign of pathology. What is the nerve most likely to have been affected in Mrs Allen?
Explanation:
Whilst B is also correct, D is the single best answer. 

 

The patient is presenting with damage to the Mandibular (V3) portion of the Trigeminal (V) nerve.

Name: Mandibular (V3) portion or Trigeminal Nerve (V)

Type: Mixed 

Function: 

  • General sensation of anterior 2/3 of the tongue, mandibular face and teeth.
  • Motor innervation to muscles of mastication (temporalis masseter, medial and lateral pterygoids) and anterior belly of digastric, mylohyioid, tensor tympani, and tensor palati.

Results of damage:

  • Loss of general sensation in skin over mandible, mandibular teeth, tongue and weakness in chewing.
  • Jaw deviation toward weak side (due to the unopposing action of the pterygoid muscle)
  • Some people may present with trigeminal neuralgia where there is intractable pain in the V2 (maxillary) or V3 (mandibular) territory.

Question:
A 42-year-old male is currently being looked after in a care home after being diagnosed with Wernicke's encephalopathy. He has had a long history of alcohol abuse.
Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is responsible for Wernicke's encephalopathy?
Explanation:
Wernicke's encephalopathy is associated with haemorrhage into the areas of the brain called the mamillary bodies and occurs in patients with thiamine deficiency.
It is a particular problem in patients chronically abusing alcohol as these subjects depend heavily on the alcohol for their calorific intake.

 

NICE: 

People who drink heavily over a long period of time often have low levels of thiamine ( vitamin B1). This can be because they have poor eating habits and may often vomit. It can also be because alcohol can damage the stomach lining, affecting its ability to absorb vitamins from food, or because it damages the liver where the thiamine is processed. Lack of thiamine can lead to a condition that affects the brain and nervous system called Wernicke's encephalopathy. Symptoms include uncontrollable eye movements (these can be side-to-side, up-and-down or rolling movements), problems with walking and coordination, confusion and memory loss. However, some people may not show all of these symptoms, which can sometimes make it difficult for doctors to recognise it.

If people with Wernicke's encephalopathy are given treatment early, their symptoms will improve and they may make a complete recovery. However, if treatment is not given, or is not given in time, their condition may become life-threatening and irreversible brain damage can occur, severely affecting short-term memory

Question:
A 62-year-old man is taking warfarin for recurrent deep vein thrombosis.
His INR is usually stable at 2.5. However, on one occasion he attends the clinic to find a marked reduction in the efficacy of his warfarin.
The doctor suspects he has consumed more vitamin K than usual.
Which food is rich in vitamin K?
Explanation:
Vitamin K is found in:
Green vegetables such as spinach, cabbage and broccoli
Liver, and
Eggs.


Warfarin works to reduce the availability of the vitamin K dependent clotting factors factors II, VII, IX and X. Normally, vitamin K is required as a cofactor in the production of these factors, forming an intermediate which is then recycled back to vitamin K in the liver. Warfarin inhibits the liver enzyme required for recycling the vitamin K.
When warfarin is started, it takes several days to reach a therapeutic INR level as it takes time to deplete the body's store of vitamin K. Warfarin works well in those patients consuming stable amounts of vitamin K in their diet. Any sudden dietary changes can affect the INR.

Question:
You are asked to see a 3-year-old boy with severe chronic malnutrition.
You are concerned about kwashiorkor.
What clinical feature is common in kwashiorkor?
Explanation: Kwashiorkor is the inadequate intake of protein only and is associated with oedema, abdominal swelling and fat accumulation in the liver. Marasmus involves inadequate consumption of both energy and protein. Affected patients look emaciated but have no oedema or abdominal swelling. The term 'protein-energy undernutrition' encompasses both of these clinical scenarios.

Question: A child enters your clinic, they are post pubertal and suffer from severe malnutrition. What endocrine disorder is most typical of a child like this?
Explanation:
During starvation or severe malnutrition the body systems have to make many adaptations to reduced food intake.
The effects on the endocrine system are as follows:
increased glucagon - this stimulates gluconeogenesis
increased aldosterone, epinephrine, norephinephrine and growth hormone
reduced insulin production
reduced free and total T3 - this contributes to the reduced metabolic rate
reduced free T4 (with prolonged starvation)
hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism can occur.
In women hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism causes infertility, menstrual disturbance, amenorrhoea, premature ovarian failure and osteoporosis. Men experience infertility, erectile dysfunction and osteoporosis

Question:
Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) has many important roles, including protecting and supporting the brain.

 

Which of these is the correct sequencing for CSF flow?
OptionA: Lateral ventricles > cerebral aqueduct > fourth ventricle > interventricular aqueduct > third ventricle > subarachnoid space
OptionB: Lateral ventricles > cerebral aqueduct > third ventricle > cerebral aqueduct > fourth ventricle > cerebral aqueduct > subarachnoid space
OptionC: Lateral ventricles > interventricular aqueduct > third ventricle > cerebral aqueduct > fourth ventricle > apertures > subarachnoid space
OptionD: Third ventricle > cerebral aqueduct > lateral ventricles > interventricular aqueduct > fourth ventricle > apertures > subarachnoid space
OptionE: Third ventricle > interventricular aqueduct > fourth ventricle > interventricular aqueduct > lateral ventricles > apertures > subarachnoid space
Explanation:
Answer: Lateral ventricles > interventricular aqueduct > third ventricle > cerebral aqueduct > fourth ventricle > apertures > subarachnoid space

 

The fluid flows through the interventricular foramen (of Monro) into the third ventricle, is augmented by fluid formed by the choroid plexus of this ventricle, and passes through the cerebral aqueduct (of Sylvius) to the fourth ventricle, which also possesses a choroid plexus. The CSF from all theses sources , as well as any formed in the central canal of the spinal cord, escapes from the fourth ventricle into the subarachnoid space through the median aperture (of Magendie) and lateral aperture (of Luschka).

Question: In the UK what is the most common cause of Addison's disease?
Explanation: According to geeky medics-C is the right answer and accounts for 70% of cases in the UK

Question:
A patient has presented at your practice with unusually tanned skin, and muscle weakness. They complain of feeling constantly exhausted and a persistently low mood, and express concern about a loss of weight. 

 

With a differential diagnosis in mind you decide to run a few investigations, which of the following test results are most likely to be observed.
Explanation: Addisons disease is characterised by low sodium, high potassium, low AM cortisol as this when cortisol is naturally at is peak in the day, high ACTH and low aldosterone.

Question: Which of the following areas of abnormal implantation will cause placenta praevia?
OptionC: Interstitial Implantation -the narrow region of the uterine tube
Explanation: Leads to placenta praevia

Question: What two components are present in every virus?
Explanation: Some viruses have a lipid coating (an envelope) which helps with evasion from the immune system and with entry into cells. Some RNA viruses have reverse transcriptase, which allows formation of DNA from RNA, e.g. HIV. However not all viruses have RNA, or reverse transcriptase.

Question:
A 71-year-old man presents with orthopnoea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea. He was diagnosed with decompensation of chronic heart failure.

 

Which of the following medications has been shown primarily to provide symptomatic relief rather than improving mortality?
Explanation:
NICE guidelines  recommend that the initial treatment for chronic cardiac failure include ACE inhibitor and beta-blocker, both of which have been proven to improve mortality in these patients.

 

Diuretics which have significant symptomatic effects, surprisingly have not been shown to have an effect on mortality.

Question: Which functional cortical area of the brain degenerates first in early Alzheimer's?
Explanation: The Retrosplenial cortex is involved in spatial awareness and navigation. In early Alzheimer's this area degenerates first i.e. people lose ability to navigate in own home.

Question: A patient comes in to your surgery to get the results forum a recent blood test. You tell her that her C Reactive protein is increased, you tell her that it increases in response to inflammation. She asks you what the role is of CRP in inflammation, what do you reply to her?
OptionC: it has no specific role it is just produced as a by product of inflammation
OptionD: It binds to pathogens to cause phagocytosis
Explanation: C reactive protein is produced in the liver in response to IL6 and it binds to a protein on the surface to dead or dying cells to activate complement.

Question: Thinking about the different neurological cell types, which of the following would be found lining the ventricular systems in the brain?
Explanation:
Astrocytes

  • blood-brain barrier and blood flow
  • extracellular K+
  • extracellular Glutamate
  • ATP-induced Ca2+ uptake
  • growth factors
  • neuronal migration
  • synapse formation (forming neural circuitry)
  • neurogenesis
  • glial scars
  • astrocytomas

Ependyma

  • Lining ventricular systems

Microglia

  • defence

Oligodendrocytes

  • myelination (concerned with the production of myelin in the central nervous system.)

Schwann cells

  • any of the cells in the peripheral nervous system that produce the myelin sheath around neuronal axons

Question: A patient comes in to see you who you diagnose with osteomyelitis, they also have sickle cell anemia. When you are taking the history they mention that they had a few days of diarrhoea and vomiting after eating some under cooked chicken recently. Which pathogen most likely caused this?
Explanation: one of the complications of salmonella in sickle cell patients is osteomyelitis.

Question: A 60 year old gentleman presents to A&E with dysphagia, vertigo and loss of sensation on the right side of his face. On examination, you find he also has an ataxic gait and an abnormal temperature sensation on the left side of his body. An infarct in which artery would cause this set of symptoms?
Explanation: Lateral medullary syndrome is caused by occlusion of the PICA (posterior inferior cerebellar artery). The area of the brain involved in LMS is the posterolateral part of the medulla oblongata. The usual symptoms of LMS include vertigo, dizziness, nystagmus, ataxia, nausea and vomiting, dysphagia, hoarseness, hiccups, impaired sensation over half of the face, impairment of pain and thermal sensation over the contralateral side of the trunk, limbs and ipsilateral face and Horner's syndrome.

Question: Which lobe of the brain would you expect to find the inferior horn of the lateral ventricles?
Explanation:
Anterior Horn --> frontal lobe

Posterior horn --> occipital lobe

Inferior horn --> temporal lobe

 

Cerebellum is not considered to be one of the lobes of the brain.

Question:
A 21-year old male was brought at the A&E due to a blow to the back of his head. He's been vomiting for the last 10 minutes and complaining about a terrible headache. You hear the consultant talking about Cushing's triad.

 

What symptoms are included in Cushing's triad?
Explanation:
Cushing's triad is a sign of raised ICP.

 

(Unconscious patient lecture, case 16)

Question:
A 78 year old female patient is seen on a ward round. After taking a quick history, it becomes apparent that she has recently had a stroke, and is recovering. She has been started on anti-coagulant therapy.

 

The doctor asks you to take a more detailed history and have a look through her notes to work out her CHADS-VASc and HAS-BLED scores. You find the following which may be relevant.

 

Consumed a lot of alcohol (28+ units/week) for the majority of her adult life, which has led to abnormal liver function

A blood glucose measurement taken yesterday was 4.8mmol/L

Has peripheral vascular disease

A blood pressure measurement from earlier today was 132/78, which seems to be similar to measurements throughout her notes

 

She is not on any medication which could affect your scoring. 

 

What scorings would you feedback to the doctor?
Explanation:
Her CHADS-VASc would be scored as 6

 

Her age would score 2 points as she is above 75 (65+ = 1 point)

A stroke/TIA scores another 2 points

Vascular disease scores 1 point

Sex category (female) scores 1 point

 

HAS-BLED would score 4 points as follows

Abnormal liver function scores 1 point (Another is available under the A for abnormal renal function)

Stroke is 1 point

Elderly scores 1 point

Drug/Alcohol history score 1 point each (so just 1 point for the alcohol)

 

Blood glucose is normal and Blood pressure needs to be above 160mmHg systolic to be classed as hypertension.

Question: Why are cardiac myocytes action potentials much longer than skeeltal muscle action potentials?
OptionA: Due to the L type calcium channels
OptionB: repolarising potassium current turns on very slowly
OptionC: depolarisation takes longer in the cardiac myocytes due to lack of fast sodium channels
OptionD: Slower conduction between myocytes due to tight junctions
Explanation: Cardiac action potentials last about twice as long as skeletal muscle action potentials because the depolarising potassium current turns on very slowly and with considerable delay.

Question: A 25 year old woman who is 9 weeks pregnant comes into surgery asking for an early medical abortion. She has a BMI of over 35. She asks for you to explain the abortion procedure she is mostly likely to have. You say?
OptionA: Two tablets will be given. A tablet of mifepristone, an oestrogen receptor agonist. Then a second tablet of prostaglandin.
OptionB: Two tablets will be given. A tablet of mifepristone, a progesterone receptor antagonist. Then a second tablet of prostaglandin.
OptionC: Two tablets will be given. A tablet of mifepristone, a progesterone receptor agonist. Then a second tablet of prostaglandin.
OptionD: Early medical abortion is not suitable because of her weight. She would have to have Vacuum aspiration. This is a procedure that uses gentle suction to remove the foetus from the womb.
OptionE: Two tablets will be given. A tablet of mifepristone, a hCG receptor antagonist. Then a second tablet of prostaglandin.
Explanation: She is mostly like to have an Early medical abortion. Two tablets will be given. A tablet of mifepristone, progesterone receptor antagonist causes endometrial degeneration & sensitizes uterine contractions to prostaglandins. Then a second tablet of prostaglandin.

Question:
A patient comes into your clinic complaining of palpatations, breathlessness and chest pain.
