He tells you that these symptoms only come on occasionally and he has had them for a few years, but recently they have become more frequent so now he is concerned about them.Whilst taking the history you find out he hashistory of angina, you decide to take an ECG from him.

.

After seeing his ECG and hearing his history what treatment would you start him on?
Explanation:
Rate control is offered as a first line for people with AF unless they have a reversible cause of their AF, have heart failure as the cause, new onset AF or if rate control hasn't been previously successful according to the NICE guidelines. As his AF is probably caused by ischeamic heart disease and it had been going on for a few years, rate control is probably offered first. 

A, B and C are rhythm control. Digoxin is usually a second line rate control treatment.

Question: What is F in this imaging picture?
Explanation: • A – ascending colon, • B – descending colon • C – rectum • D – sigmoid colon • E – caecum • F – diverticula • G - appendix

Question: During her pregnancy a 35yo woman is given an opioid injection as pain relief. What is the mechanism of action of opiates as pain relief medication?
OptionA: Opioid receptors are Gi coupled receptors and so close voltage gated sodium channels and cause potassium efflux, hyper polarising cells and so decreasing excitability.
OptionB: Opioid receptors are Gi coupled receptors and so close voltage gated sodium channels and cause potassium influx, hypo polarising cells and so decreasing excitability.
OptionC: Opioid receptors are Gq coupled receptors and so cause PIP2 production from PLC, closing potassium channels, hypo polarising cells and so increasing excitability.
OptionD: Opioid receptors are Gq coupled receptors and so cause PIP2 production from PLC, opening potassium channels, hyper polarising cells and so decreasing excitability.
OptionE: Opioid receptors are Gs coupled receptors and so open voltage gated sodium channels and cause potassium influx, hypo polarising cells and so increasing excitability.
Explanation: Opioid receptors are Gi coupled receptors and so close voltage gated sodium channels and cause potassium efflux, hyper polarising cells and so decreasing excitability. They can cause respiratory depression in the baby and so use of the drug Naloxone which blocks opioid receptors if often given after birth.

Question: You are the on-call doctor in A&E, when ambulance brings in a 47 year old patient, Thomas Bennet, after falling down marble stairs and banging his head 5 hours ago. The patient complains of an intractable headache and you can see his head is tilted and his breathing is deteriorating. You perform an MRI scan, confirming your suspicions of an intracranial haemorrhage, but you also notice a change in brain tissue. Given the results of the MRI scan and his symptoms, what cerebral herniation has occurred in Mr Bennet?
Explanation:
The answer is C. The MRI shows a downward displacement (aka coning) of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. This can lead to compression of the medulla, resulting in respiratory depression and eventually, cardiorespiratory arrest. The most common signs are intractable headache, head tilt, and neck stiffness due to tonsillar impaction. The level of consciousness may decrease and also give rise to flaccid paralysis.

 

A. Subfalcine herniation: this occurs when the cingualate gyrus is displaced under the falx and to the opposite side. It can result in the compression of the anterior cerebral artery.

B. Transtentorial (Uncal) herniation: this occurs when the uncinate process of the temporal lobe herniates into the anterior part of the opening of the tentorium cerebelli.

D. Central tentorial herniation: this occurs when there is symmetrical downward movement of the thalamic region through the opening of tentorium cerebelli.

E. Transcalvarial herniation: aka external herniation, this occurs when there is downward displacement of the brain through a defect in the skull such as a fracture site or following a craniectomy.

 

http://lifeinthefastlane.com/ccc/brain-herniation/ has a good diagram of the herniations and simple explanations!

Question: You are on placement at  a GP surgery where a diabetic clinic is currently being run. The GP asks "which glucose transporter is responsible for the uptake of non-insulin mediated glucose into brain neurones and the placenta?"
Explanation:
C - GLUT-3 is the correct answer.

 

GLUT-1 enables basal non-insulin stimulated glucose uptake into many cells.

GLUT-2 transports glucose into the beta cell of the pancreas and is also present in the renal tubes and hepatocytes.

GLUT-4 is the channel through which glucose is taken up into muscle and adipose tissue cells following stimulation of the insulin receptor.

Question: You are assisting a dietitian whilst on placement who begins to talk about the phases of glucose metabolism. What are the phases of glucose homeostasis and which of these phases involve ketone bodies being a major fuel of the brain?
OptionA:
Phases: I (Well-fed), II (Post-absorptive), III (Early gluconeogenic), IV (Prolonged)

Phases II, III and IV involve ketone bodies as a major fuel of the brain.
OptionB:
Phases: I (Well-fed), II (Post-absorptive), III (Early gluconeogenic), IV (Prolonged)
Phases III and IV involve ketone bodies as a major fuel of the brain.
OptionC:
Phases: I (Well-fed), II (Post-absorptive), III (Early gluconeogenic), IV (Prolonged)
Phase IV involves ketone bodies as a major fuel of the brain.
OptionD:
Phases: I (Chronic starvation), II (Early gluconeogenic), III (Post-absorptive), IV (Well-fed)

Phases I and II involve ketone bodies as a major fuel of the brain.
OptionE:
Phases: I (Chronic starvation), II (Early gluconeogenic), III (Post-absorptive), IV (Well-fed)

Phase I involves ketone bodies as a major fuel of the brain.
Explanation: Ketone bodies are one of the major brain fuels in phase III (early gluconeogenic) and phase IV (prolonged).

Question:
The pituitary gland is split into two lobes - the anterior lobe and the posterior lobe.

Oxytocin is one of the hormones secreted from the posterior lobe - what is the other?
Explanation: The posterior lobe only secretes oxytocin and vasopressin.

Question:
A woman visits her GP complaining of feeling dizzy and light-headed, particularly when moving from a seated to a standing position. The GP takes a detailed history and takes the patients blood pressure, which is found to be low. The GP reviews the patients medication and decides this may be contributing to the patients hypotension and so makes alterations to this.

Once the patient leaves, the GP asks you "what structure in the brainstem has a regulatory effect on the autonomic control of the heart and blood vessels?"
25yo Jimmy is one of the 25% of left handed people than has a dominant left hemisphere. Which functions is this hemisphere responsible for?
Explanation:
The left hemisphere if dominant is responsible for language and language dependant memory, the left hemisphere is dominant in right handed people and 25% left-handed people

 

A- Emotional aspects of pain are regulated by the spinoreticular tract which ends in the reticular formation, the core of the brainstem

 

B- Correct

 

C- Reflex response to auditory stimuli is in the inferior colliculi in the midbrain (part of the corpora quadrigemina) at the top of the lateral lemniscus of the via the tectospinal tract

 

D and E- these are both functions of the right hemisphere in people who are left hemisphere dominant

Question: What description best matches what type of enzymes CYP 450 enzymes are?
Explanation: CYP450 enzymes are on demand enzymes involved in phase 1 oxidative modification reactions in the liver. Phase 1 reactions are functionalisation metabolism reactions that active the drug

Question: What does CYP 2E1 metabolise in the liver phase 1 reactions?
Explanation:
CYP2E1-etahnol metabolisation 

CYP1A2-caffeine and theophylline 

CYP1A1-Theophylline

CYP3A4-half of all phase 1 metabolism

Question: Which one of the following is the toxic species generated in significant quantities following a toxic dose of paracetamol (toxic at 4g to 6g)?
Explanation:
NAPBQI is produced via CYP1A2 and CYP2E1 metabolism of paracetamol, which is the secondary pathway to the UDP glucorination and sulphation that takes place with UGT.

Glutathione is the phase II anti-oxidant that normally metabolises this product

Question:
A 28-year-old male with no significant past medical history is brought to the emergency room after a skiing accident. His friend reports that the patient tumbled into a tree and briefly lost consciousness. He then regained consciousness and appeared normal for the rest of the day, but became progressively more confused that evening. A CT scan of the patient is shown below after his friend rushes him to A&E

 

What is the immediate management plan for this patient?
OptionD: Prepare patient for an immediate ventricular shunt operation
OptionE: Prepare patient for an immediate surgical evacuation of the skull
Explanation:
The patient has an acute extradural hematoma causing depressed consciousness and requires urgent surgical evacuation.

 

Epidural hematomas appear as lens-shaped collections that are bounded by the cranial sutures. They are usually caused by blunt trauma. The classical presentation includes a post-traumatic loss of consciousness, followed by a lucid interval lasting up to 48 hours and finally rapid deterioration. However, only half of patients with epidural hematomas present with this sequence of symptoms. The cornerstone of treatment is urgent surgical evacuation.

Question: What type of brain herniation is 3 displaying?
Explanation:
Subfalcine herniation- the most common cerebral herniation pattern, is characterised by displacement of the brain (typically the cingulate gyrus) beneath the free edge of the falx cerebri due to raised intracranial pressure.

 

1-Uncal herniation

2-Central Tentorial 

4. Transcalvarial herniation 

5. Upward transtentorial herniation (“reverse coning”) 

6. Foraminal or tonsillar herniation (“coning”)

Question: Which of the following muscles is an extrinsic muscle of the back?
Explanation:
The extrinsic muscles of the back include the superficial and intermediate layers of muscles. The Serratus Posterior Inferior muscle is in the Intermediate layer of muscles, whereas all of the other muscles are deep muscles of the back. 

 

The function of the Intermediate muscles of the back is to aid movements of the thoracic cage. 

 

The deep muscles of the back are associated with movements of the vertebral column

Question: Which of the following inflammatory cytokines is responsible for increasing vascular permeability to allow immune cells to reach tissues?
Explanation:
◦ interferon gamma (IFNγ) – essential in activating cell-mediated immunity in viral infections

◦ TNF-alpha – increases vascular permeability to allow immune cells to reach tissues

◦ IL-1 – causes fever and activates lymphocytes

◦ IL-6 – causes fever, stimulates the liver to produce acute phase proteins such as CRP, activates lymphocytes and promotes antibody production

◦ IL-4, IL-5 + IL-13 – promote IgE production and eosinophilic reactions in patients with allergies

Question:
A 25yo female, Summer, presents to your local community hospital panicking that she has a brain injury because after 5 years of wearing contact lens she can now touch her cornea without blinking.

 

You explain to her that this is a normal consequence of her wearing contact lens.

 

To explain how the reflex normally works you draw her a diagram. As she's a very intelligent patient you include all the nuclei/ganglion through which nerve signals pass from the cornea to the occularis occult muscle causing you to blink. 

 

Which of the following if the correct order of transmission for your diagram?
OptionA: Cornea (CNV1) -- Semilunar Ganglion -- Spinal Nucleus of CNV -- Facial Motor Nuclei CNVI -- Oculars Occult Muscle
OptionB: Cornea (CNV1) -- Semilunar Ganglion -- Spinal Nucleus of CNV -- Facial Motor Nuclei CNVII -- Oculars Occult Muscle
OptionC: Cornea (CNV1) -- Semilunar Ganglion -- Spinal Nucleus of CNVII -- Facial Motor Nuclei CNV -- Oculars Occult Muscle
OptionD: Cornea (CNV1) -- Spinal Nucleus of CNV -- Facial Motor Nuclei CNVII -- Semilunar Ganglion -- Oculars Occult Muscle
OptionE: Cornea (CNV1) -- Spinal Nucleus of CNVII -- Facial Motor Nuclei CNV -- Semilunar Ganglion -- Oculars Occult Muscle
Explanation:
The corneal reflex is a simple reflex arc including the cranial nerves V and VII

 

Once your cornea is touched its sensed by the CNV1 ophthalmic branch then goes down this nerve to the semilunar ganglion and then to the spinal nucleus of CNV. Here it synapses with interneurones of the spinal nucleus and passes into both the ipsilateral and contralateral sides to synapse at the facial motor CNVII ganglion. These motor tracts are the temporal branch of the facial motor nerve and innervate the oculars occuli causing you to blink. 

 

Option A is incorrect as Facial Motor Nuclei as we know is CNVII not CN VI (abducens)

Option C has the facial motor and trigeminal nucleus with the wrong cranial nerves (CNV is trigeminal not facial) 

Option D has the semilunar ganglion at the end of the pathway however it is at the beginning and actually outside the CNS hence 'ganglion'

Option E again has the semilunar nucleus at the end of the pathway but also has trigeminal and facial the wrong way round (CN V vs. CN VII)

Question: A 58 year old man presents to A+E. He presents with bilateral spastic paralysis, loss of pain, temperature, light touch and pressure sensations but has some sacral sparing. He has preserved proprioception, vibration and fine touch sensations. After looking at his notes you find out that he has had uncontrolled hypertension for the last 4 years. What spinal cord syndrome does this man most likely have?
Explanation:
Anterior cord Syndrome is usually vascular in origin and is caused by damage to the anterior spinal artery, this may be due to a thrombus occluding the artery or due to an aortic dissection which is seen in people with severe hypertension. 

Damage or occlusion of the anterior spinal artery effects both the anterior and lateral corticospinal and spinothalamic tracts on both sides hence the bilateral presentation, but preserves the dorsal columns on both sides hence the preserved proprioception, vibration and fine touch sensations.

Cortiospinal- Bilateral spastic paralysis

Spinothalamic- loss of pain, temperature, light touch and pressure sensations

Question: A patient with a pulmonary embolism is likely to experience some great changes in respiratory function to the specific part of the lungs affected. What is the most likely V/Q value for this patient in the part of the lungs affected by this pathology?
Explanation:
V/Q refers to ventilation divided by perfusion. As the perfusion will be reduced to O in regions affected in the lungs, the V will remain constant and thus anything divided by 0 is infinite 

The air ventilated will essentially be Physiological dead space and no gas exchange occurs

Question: You are a junior doctor on call. You are called in to see a 46-year-old patient who had brain surgery to remove a tumour a few months ago. He has no other significant history, systemic symptoms or known disease. According to the nurse he has had a rapid decline in neurological function. He has become forgetful, has seizures and has had a personality change. On examination you find he has startle myoclonus (when you clap your hands he jerks in an exaggerated manner). You are given a copy of recent MRI for this patient. What do you suspect?
Explanation:
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is an encephalopathy that results in a rapidly progressive dementia and other non-specific neurological features.

 

CJD is thought to be mediated via infectious prions, a type of protein, which manifest in cows. Prions are considered infectious in the sense that they can alter the structure of neighbouring proteins.

 

CJD can be spread through the use of contaminated instruments in surgery.

 

The MRI shows the typical cortical ribboning pattern seen in CJD.

 

http://radiopaedia.org/articles/creutzfeldt-jakob-disease

Question:
You are called to see a patient who has fallen through a glass window. In A&E you are asked to perform a GCS.

 

The patient presents with:

Eyes open to shouting

Blood pressure low

Patient can talk to you, but does not understand where he is (he gives his name and DOB when requested, but can't tell you where he is)

Upon pinching the trapezius he brings his hand above his clavicle
Explanation: https://www.google.co.uk/url?sa=i&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=images&cd=&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=0ahUKEwj1uvnn-KHMAhXMBsAKHUW1DoAQjRwIBw&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.tryingmypatients.co.uk%2F2012%2F05%2Fincreased-level-of-consciousness.html&psig=AFQjCNFy-_wtgWPlLl__QE5Nj-vSfh8lcQ&ust=1461404142281682

Question: Marie-Louise, a 7 and 1/2 month pregnant lady with gestational diabetes and pre-eclampsia into your surgery with photophobia, neck stiffness, headache and fever. She is working in a cheese-farm and is worried as she missed a day of work. What organism is she particularly at risk of, given her history?
Explanation:
Listeria monocytogenes can come from cheese.

http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Listeriosis/Pages/Introduction.aspx

Question:
A 10 year old presents to A&E with sudden onset seizures. You diagnose the patient with epilepsy.

What is the most common cause of epilepsy worldwide?

Timothy, 65 comes in to A&E. He has a 50 year pack history, he has right sided hemiparesis above the waist and seems to have receptive aphasia. Considering this is early presentation, where on the MRI should you look first?
Explanation:
Timothy shows signs of Middle Cerebral Artery Infarction

The first place you should look for damage on the MRI (according to the lecturer) is the Insula

Question: What is the most common cause of epilepsy worldwide?
Explanation: Cysticercosis is the most common cause of epilepsy worldwide due to its high prevalence the developing world.

Question: You are the on-call doctor in A&E when you see a 30 year old man, Idil Abdi, who is accompanied by a friend who acts as his Somali interpreter. You take a history where you find out that Idil recently migrated to the UK from Somalia after seeking asylum. His friend tells you that Idil has been suffering from seizures for the last few weeks and occasional headaches as well. He has no other medical conditions. You suspect this man has epilepsy, and given his background, you narrow down your main diagnosis to...
Explanation:
The correct answer is A. 

 

Cysticercosis is the most common parasitic disease of the CNS. It is caused by larval cysts of the tapeworm Taenia solium. These larval cysts infect brain, muscle, or other tissue, and are a major cause of adult onset seizures in most low-income countries. A person gets cysticercosis by swallowing eggs found in the faeces of a person who has an intestinal tapeworm. People living in the same household with someone who has a tapeworm have a much higher risk of getting cysticercosis than people who don’t.

 

Case 16; Lecture: Infections of the CNS by Clinton Mitchell

Question:
Jack, a 25 year male is carried against his will to A&E complaining of severe headache, neck stiffness,fever and increased sensitivity to light over the past few weeks. He is referred for a lumbar puncture to collect CSF for testing. His results are back and shown below:

 

Glucose: 60mg/dL (Norm 45-100 mg/dL)

Neutrophils: <20%

Lymphocytes: >50%

Protein: 70mg/dL (Norm 15-50 mg/dL)

 

 His CSF is cloudy and viscous in appearance and during the lumbar puncture, a very high opening pressure of 45 cm H20 is observed. 

 

Jack has meningitis. Judging from his results, what is the most likely culprit of his infection?
Explanation: His results are indicative of fungal meningits, which is chronic, hence his experience of these symptoms over the past few weeks.

Question:
A 28-year-old woman who is 25 weeks pregnant comes into the GP surgery to discuss her birth planning options. Both her and her GP agree that the best way for her to deliver her child is through an elective Caesarean section.

 

Which of the following options is most likely to be the reason for this decision?
OptionA: She is incredibly anxious about giving birth naturally so would prefer to have a Caesarean section.
OptionD: She has had one Caesarean section before.
Explanation:
A - this is not a valid reason for an elective C-section, if this was the case then she should be referred to a mental health specialist about her anxiety.

B - Number of miscarriages does not have a bearing on how a natural birth will take its course.

C - correct answer as the placenta is obstructing the internal os so this is very dangerous for both the mother and baby.

D - women who have had one C-section before should be allowed to try a natural birth if they wish.

E - women who are HIV positive should be allowed to try a natural birth if they wish.

Question: A 24-year-old man is admitted following the sudden onset of an occipital headache. On examination GCS is 15/15, neurological examination is unremarkable but neck stiffness is noted. A subarachnoid haemorrhage is suspected but the CT scan is normal. How long after CT should a patient have a lumbar puncture done, if Subarachnoid haemorrhage is suspected?
OptionE: Lumbar puncture should not be performed if Subarachnoid haemorrhage is suspected
Explanation: A lumbar puncture should not be done until 12 hours after the onset of the headache to allow time for xathochromia to develop.

Question:
You are a GP in Cardiff and Dania, a 23 years old patient with no important medical history comes in

"As I landed at Stansted aiport, coming back from my awesome trip in South Africa, my head already started to hurt" she says. 

"It came down a bit after I took some aspirin and I manage to get some sleep, but the next morning, the pain came back...it hurts here" (she shows you the base of her skull). I also think I've developed fever. Yesterday, I was still able to do things with the pain, I kind of did with it. But today, as I woke up, I noticed that I see double"

Do you have any other symptoms? you ask

"Well, my neck hurts when I bend my head forward and I seem to be more sensitive to bright lights"

...

What most probably infected Dania?
Explanation: Her meningitis developed over days, so she does not seem to suffer from acute meningitis. This excludes Listeria, neisseria and streptococcus pneumonia. Otherwise, she seems to be in a good health, so she is not immuno-compromised. This makes a fungus infection very unlikely. Tuberculosis seem like a better option. It is a subacute bacterial meningitis that often affects the meninges at the base of the skull. Because of its location, it often involves the cranial nerves. In fact, according to wikipedia, 15-40% of people infected by tuberculosis have cranial deficit and the abducens nerve is the most commonly affected by it. The abducens nerve enables abduction of the eye, therefore, people with abducens nerve palsy have their eye turning medially, which makes them have double-vision.

Question: You examine a 56 year old male who after taking a history and undergoing nerve conduction studies, confirm he has Guillain-Barré syndrome. During his history he told you a few weeks before he recently had cooked chicken for the first time, however admits to not having cooked it properly.  Given the history, what is the most likely  micro-organism to have caused this?
Explanation:
Campylobacter is the most common risk factor for Guillain-Barre and is spread via undercooked poultry. 

Influenza virus, Epstein-Barr virus, cytomegalavirus are all possible causes of Guillain-Barre syndrome, however campylobacter is the most likely cause given the history. 

 

Guillain-Barre syndrome= an acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy. Takes places 1-2 weeks post infection of campylobacteria.

Symptoms often start in your feet and hands before spreading to your arms and then your legs. Initially, you may have:

  • pain, tingling and numbness
  • progressive muscle weakness
  • co-ordination problems and unsteadiness (you may be unable to walk unaided).

 

Nerve conduction studies can be done to confirm this. 

 

CASE 11 LECTURE= MICROBIOLOGY OF THE GI TRACT

Question:
A 32-year-old woman is 26 weeks pregnant and has come into the GP surgery to find out more about the Health Visiting Programme. The GP explains that there are 4 levels of service in the Health Visiting Programme. He then goes on to describe one of these 4 levels. His description is as follows,

 

"Families can access timely, expert advice from a health visitor when they need it on specific issues such as postnatal depression, weaning or sleepless children".

 

Which of the 4 levels of service is the GP referring to here?
Explanation:
Community - Health visitors have a broad knowledge of community needs and resources available and work to develop these and make sure families know about them.

 

Universal - Health visitor teams ensure that every new mother and child have access to a health visitor, receive development checks and receive good information about healthy start issues such as parenting and immunisations.

 

Universal Plus - Correct answer.

 

Universal Partnership Plus - Health visitors provide ongoing support, playing a key role in bringing together relevant local services, to help families with continuing complex needs, for example, where a child has a long-term condition.

Question: A 45 year old man comes in with symptoms of diarrhoea, abdominal bloating, anorexia, nausea. Stool microscopy lab results come back and reveals trophozoites and iodine staining reveals cysts. Which microorganism is likely to have caused this?
Explanation:
This is the presentation of an infection by the intestinal protozoa Giardia lamblia.

 

MICROBIOLOGY OF THE GI TRACT LECTURE= CASE 11

Question:
A 25 year old rabbi presents to his GP complaining of fresh blood in his stools and diarrhoea. He has recently noticed that there is mucous present too and is worried that this might indicate something sinister. The GP requests a colonoscopy to be performed and this is the image collected:

The GP forms a diagnosis and then proceeds to explain potential complications of this condition to the patient. Which of the following is unlikely to be a complication mentioned by the GP?
Explanation:
Case 11, Plenary 4- IBD notes.

 

Jewish people are more likely to suffer from IBD. Fresh blood and mucous in stools along with diarrhoea are symptoms of Ulcerative Colitis. The colonoscopy image confirms this and shows superficial inflammation and a reddened mucosa which is suggestive of UC rather than Crohn's (in CD: cobblestone appearance which involves transmural inflammation).

 

All of the above are predominantly complications of UC apart from C (fistulae). Fistulae is more commonly seen with Crohn's disease instead.
Tags: Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11, Inflammatory Bowel Disease

Question: You a measuring the symphysis fundus height of a fetus in a mother. Which of the following values would you expect for a healthy fetus at 24 weeks gestation?
Explanation: Post 20 weeks gestation, the Symphysis fundus height should match the gestational age of the fetus, with a possibility of 2cm either up or down.

Question: A child presents to the GP with profound hearing loss, a forelock of white hair and pigmentation anomalies on the skin. What syndrome are they likely to have?
Explanation:
Waardenburg syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition characterised by varying degrees of deafness, minor defects in structures arising from the neural crest, and pigmentation anomalies. 

Deafness is caused due to the failure of cells that control potassium ion secretion to migrate the stria vascularis during development, leading to deafness

Question: Which of the numbers shown is directed at the chorion plate?
Explanation:
1-Umbilical Cord 

2-Amnion

3-Chorion Plate

4-Intervillous Space

5-Basal Plate

6-Cotyledon 

7-Villus

Question: What is the arrow for 7 pointing at?
Explanation: 1. Intercostal Space 2. Pectoralis Major 3. Lobules of Mammary Gland 4. Nipple 5. Areola 6. Lactiferous Sinus 7. Fat lobule

Question: Which of the following viruses is associated with haemorrhagic fever?
Explanation:
Dengue fever is a viral infection which can progress to viral haemorrhagic fever 

It is transmitted by the Aedes aegyti mosquito
incubation period of 7 days
It is a form of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) known as dengue haemorrhagic fever (DHF) may develop. Around 20-30% of these patients go on to develop dengue shock syndrome (DSS)

Question: Your supervising consultant quizzes you on a patient; they have acute renal failure, microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia and thrombocytopenia. Of the possible causes, the consultant tells you it is linked to a strain of E.coli. Which strain of E.coli classically causes the triad of features above?
Explanation:
Haemolytic uraemic syndrome is generally seen in young children and produces a triad of:

• Acute renal failure

• Microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia

• Thrombocytopenia

In occurs in 10% of VTEC infections and can be identified via culture on specialised agar.

Question: You encounter a patient suffering with strong diarrhoea, producing race water stools and effortless vomiting. What is the general antibiotic management for this patient?
Explanation: The pattern is typical of a vibrio cholera infection. The bacteria is gram negative ands the infection is toxic mediated. Usually, treatment is aggressive rehydration therapy and antibiotics are not usually given.

Question: What is the most common cause of gastroenteritis in children?
Explanation: Main risk is severe dehydration in gastroenteritis in children. The most common cause is rotavirus; this infection is typically accompanied by fever and vomiting for the first 2 days. The diarrhoea may last up to a week and the main treatment is rehydration

Question: A young doctor has ordered a modified ziehl meelson staining for a patient's stool sample. What is this technique commonly used to detect?
Explanation: Modified Ziehl Neelsen stain is specific for the intestinal sporozoa cryptosporidium

Question: A 24 year old man sadly had a cardiac arrest and died whilst playing in a football match. On autopsy you find out the cause behing his sudden cardiac death, which is most likely to have caused it?
Explanation: Hypertrophic cardiac myopathy is the leading cause of SCD in young people

Question: What is the physiological response of the eye to bright light?
OptionA: Muscarinic (parasympathetic) stimulation > Contraction of the circular sphincter muscle > Miosis
OptionB: Muscarinic (parasympathetic) stimulation > Contraction of the radial muscle > Miosis
OptionC: Adrenergic (sympathetic) stimulation > Contraction of the radial muscle > Mydriasis
OptionD: Adrenergic (sympathetic) stimulation > Contraction of the circular sphincter muscle > Mydriasis
OptionE: Muscarinic (parasympathetic) stimulation > Contraction of the ciliary muscle > Spherical lens
Explanation:
The correct answer is A.

 

The purpose of the pupils is to adjust the amount of light that hits the photoreceptors of the retina. Pupil size is controlled very well by 2 sets of muscles in the iris:

1) Radial muscle

2) Circular sphincter muscle

 

In bright light, there is muscarinic (parasympathetic) stimulation of the occulomotor nerve (CN III), which causes the circular sphincter muscle to contract. This constricts the pupil, resulting in pin-point pupils, known as miosis.

 

In low light, there is a1 adrenergic (sympathetic) stimulation, which causes the radial muscle to contract, causing the pupil to dilate. Therefore, radial contraction leads to mydriasis.

 

Answers B, C, and D are all completely wrong, however E is the correct mechanism for accomodation of the lens which allows focus on nearby objects.

Question:
A 45-year-old woman comes into the GP surgery presenting with symptoms of fatigue, weakness and weight gain. The GP carries out blood tests and thyroid function tests. The thyroid function tests showed evidence of hypothyroidism. The GP then explains the results to the patient and explains what is causing her hypothyroidism.

 

What is most likely the cause of her hypothyroidism?
Explanation: These are all common causes of hypothyroidism, however Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause.

Question: You are looking at a vertbra that had two transverse foramina and a bifid spinous process. What type of vertebra is it?
Explanation: Cerival vertebrae C3-6 are the typical cervical vertbrae and have a bifid spinous process and vertbral foramina for the vertbrae arteries.

Question: You are a doctor working in A&E, a patient comes in with bilateral spastic paralysis, loss of light touch and pain. He is still able to feel proprioception, vibration and 2 point discrimination. Which syndrome does he most likely  have?
Explanation: This is a classical presentation of anterior cord syndrome, which is usually vascular in origin

Question: Which chromosome is the gene that causes sickle cell anaemia located on?
Explanation:
Chromosome 4-Hungtington's Disease-AD

Chromosome 7-Cystic Fibrosis-AR

Chromosome 11-SCA-AR

Question: which of the following statements is true about necrosis?
OptionA: Loss of membrane stability causes cell contents to break down and disperse
OptionB: Cell breaks up into membrane bound apoptitic vesicles
OptionC: Occurs due to a loss of tropic factors
Explanation: In necrosis the cell ruptures leading to a inflammatory reaction in the tissue which can lead to further damage. Loss of membrane stability causes the cell contents to break down and disperse.

Question:
A 69-year-old type II diabetic gentleman presents to hospital with increasing left flank pain. Lab results reveal an increase in his serum creatinine from his normal level.

An arterial blood gas is drawn revealing:

  • pH 7.30 (7.35-7.45)
  • HCO3- 20mmol/L (22-28mmol/L)
  • PaCO2 4.7kPa (4.7-6.0kPa)
  • PaO2 9.3kPa at normal air (9.3-13.3kPa)

 What medication should be immediately stopped to prevent worsening of his acidosis?
Explanation:
This patient is suffering from nephrolithiasis (calculi in the kidneys) with worsening kidney function.

 

 

The use of metformin is predisposing this patient to the development of lactic metabolic acidosis as indicated by the low bicarbonate levels and slightly acidic pH, and thus, metformin medication must be stopped immediately.

Metformin is a biguanide oral hypoglycemic that works by decreasing gluconeogenesis in the liver.

It is widely regarded in the UK as the first-line oral diabetic agent, with first line treatment itself being often lifestyle management for type II diabetics.

Its major side effect is the development of lactic acidosis, which is important in the setting of acute kidney injury. All patients with worsening kidney function must be taken off of metformin and transitioned to another agent.
Tags: Case 9, Group 55, Acute Care, Pharmacology, Diabetes

Question:
A 29-year old male presents to the emergency department after being stabbed in the back with a kitchen knife. On completing a full neurological exam it is found that he cannot feel pain or temperature sensation on his right side. He has weakness and loss of light touch sensation on his left side.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation: Brown-Séquard syndrome is a rare spinal disorder that results from an injury to one side of the spinal cord resulting in hemisection of the cord. The damage to the corticospinal tract, spinothalamic tract and dorsal columns, results in ipsilateral upper motor neurone signs, contralateral spinothalamic signs, and ipsilateral dorsal column signs respectively.

Question: You are studying a person's genetic make up and can see that two chromosomes have become involved in a robertsonian translocation. From the following chromosome options, which of the following chromosomes is most likely to be involved in this type of translocation?
Explanation: Robertsonian Translocations tends to involve acrocentric chromosomes-those with a short p arm that can be easily lost with little consequence. The acrocentricr chromosomes are usually 13, 14, 15, 21, 22 and the y chromosome.

Question: Miss Eugeine, a pregnant 30yo woman presents to your clinic for her 20 week checkup and ultrasounds scan. On palpation of the pregnant abdomen you expect the fundus of the uterus to we at approximately which height?
Explanation:
At 20 weeks you would expect the symphysis fundus height to be about 20cm, approximately equivalent to the height of the umbilicus. 

 

At 12 weeks you would expect it to be 12cm- about that of the pubic symphysis (however relation of weeks to cm if more accurate from 16 weeks to 36 weeks antenatally)

 

At 36 weeks you would expect the fundus to be at about 26cm, the Xiphoid area.

 

Level T12 is equivalent to where the coeliac artery is and would be at around 14-16 weeks

 

Level L1 is equivalent to the superior mesenteric artery and would be at around 10-12 weeks

Question: You are a medical student on placement in the gastroenterology ward in UHW, the consultant is giving you and your peers a small tutorial regarding the physiology and pathology of the GI tract. She begins to talk to you about the migrating myoelectric complex. She tells you that an increase in activity of this complex is mainly associated with a condition. Which condition is the consultant referring to?
Explanation:
The migrating myoelectric complex is a propulsive movement initiated during fasting, beginning in the stomach and moving undigested material from the stomach and small intestine into the colon. It is essentially a peristaltic wave to clear the GI tract out. It repeats every 90-120 minutes during fasting (this is basically what causes the loud grumbling sounds when you're nearing the end of an exam and could really do with a Kasturi curry). It correlates with a high circulating level of motulin, a hormone of the small intestine. Movement prevents the back-flow of bacteria from the colon into the ileum and its subsequent overgrowth in the distal ileum.

 

The MMC happens in between meals and is stopped once a meal has been eaten.

 

An increase in the activity of the MMC is mainly associated with Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS), whereas a decrease in the MMC is associated with diabetic gastroparesis.

Question:
A 57 year old gentleman is brought to the A&E department by his wife complaining of severe chest pain. His clothes are damp and he looks quite pale. An ECG is performed, shown below.

 

Looking at his ECG, which artery is most likely to be the problem?
Explanation:
This patient is having an MI. 

II, III and aVF show ST elevation indicating that this is an inferior MI.

Inferior aspect of the heart is mainly supplied by the right coronary artery.

Question: What is the only part of the pancreas that is intraperitoneal?
Explanation:
The tail of the pancreas 

The left end of the pancreas that lies within close proximity to the hilum of the spleen.

It is contained within the splenorenal liagament with the splenic vessels.

This is the only part of the pancreas that is intraperitoneal.

Question: What is the age limit for someone being diagnosed with MODY?
Explanation: Maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY) is characterised by the development of type 2 diabetes mellitus in patients < 25 years old. It is typically inherited as an autosomal dominant condition. Over six different genetic mutations have so far been identified as leading to MODY.

Question: What is the most common subtype of MODY?
In the intrinsic part of the coagulation cascade, what coagulation factor begins the process that ultimately leads to the activation of thrombin?
Explanation:
The intrinsic pathway is the slower pathway and is activated when blood comes into contact with the injured vessel wall. All the elements needed to begin this part of the cascade are present in the blood normally. Factor XII is activated at the start of this process.

 

The extrinsic pathway, which is faster is activated when blood is exposed to the products of damaged tissue. This process begins via tissue factor, which is membrane and not found in the blood. This activated Factor VII that begins the extrinsic pathway.

Question: Which of the following sentences correctly describes the action of phosphoprotein phosphatase in the presence of Fructose 6 phosphate and insulin in the liver?
OptionE: Activates PKA that activates Protein Bisphosphatase and deactivates phosphofructokinase 2
Explanation:
A is correct and C is sort of correct but not as correct 

 

What happens is this 

  • In the presence of insulin and Fructose 6 phosphate in the liver, Phosphoprotein phosphatase is activated. 
  • This enzyme deactivates Protein Bisphosphatase (this converts Fru-2,6-BP to Fru 6P) and activates Phosphofructokinase 2
  • PFK-2 converts Fru-6P to Fru-2,6-BP
  • Fru-2,6-BP stimulates glycolysis to increase and gluconeogenesis to decrease
  • This lowers blood glucose

Question:
Mr Lewis is a 59-year-old gentlemen recently diagnosed with type II diabetes. His past medical history showed that he was diagnosed with stable angina and that the patient's twin brother died a few years ago of myocardial infarction. Due to the high risk profile Mr Lewis was prescribed aspirin.

 

What is the mode of action of this drug?
Explanation:
Aspirin:

o Inhibits COX irreversibly.
o Low dose very effective (>95%) inhibits platelets thromboxane A2 synthesis and reduces risk of thrombosis

o Mainly cardiovascular usage

 

Aspirin is not prescribed to children under 16 year old because it causes Reye's disease.

Question: Mr Andrews come into the surgery asking why taking aspirin increases the risk of stomach ulcers. You're answer is ....
OptionA: Because aspirin is weakly selective to COX-1 domain which inhibits the mucosal protective action of prostaglandins.
OptionB: Because aspirin is weakly selective to COX-2 domain which inhibits the mucosal protective action of prostaglandins.
OptionC: Because aspirin is weakly selective to COX-3 domain which inhibits the mucosal protective action of prostaglandins.
OptionD: Because aspirin is weakly selective to COX-4 domain which inhibits the mucosal protective action of prostaglandins.
OptionE: Because aspirin is weakly selective to COX-5 domain which inhibits the mucosal protective action of prostaglandins.
Explanation:
Aspirin is weakly selective for COX-1

 

COX-1 acts mostly on the stomach, intestine, kidney & platelets.

 

COX-2 acts mostly on inflammatory sites, macrophages, synovocytes.

Question: Which drug is an insulin secretagogue?
Explanation:
Insulin secretagogues:

- Sulphonylureas

- Meglitinides

 

Insulin sensitisers:

- Metformin

- Thiazolidinedions 

 

Inhibitors of glucose absorption from the GI tract:

- Acarbose

 

Incretin-based therapies

- DPP-4 inhibitors

Question:
A 63-year-old woman suffers a distal left anterior cerebral artery stroke. She presents to you with motor function loss affecting a certain part of the body.

 

Which part of the body is most likely affected?
Explanation:
The part of the brain that controls the motor function of the legs is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery.

The portion of the brain controlling motor function of the rest of the body is supplied by the middle cerebral artery.

The only possible answers are D and E.

Since the tracts cross in the brainstem, the left side of the brain controls the right side of the body.

An exception to this rule is the motor function of the face, since the tracts do not cross. The left motor function of the face comes from the left hemisphere.

Question:
A 35 year-old man was rushed to the A&E because he suddenly complained of a headache, loss of visual field and drowsiness. The patient had an immediate CT which shows stroke.

 

 

Which artery is occluded?
Explanation:
The CT shows evidence of a bilateral thalamic stroke. This region is supplied by the deep branches of PCA.

 

(Radiology lecture, case 16)

Question: Which of the following does glucagon decrease?
Which of the following drugs acts as a dipeptidyl peptidase-IV inhibitor?
Explanation: Saxagliptin, a type of glisten drug, acts to inhibit DP-4 that causes an increase in incretins (GLP-1, GIP) that increases insulin secretion and decreases glucagon secretion. This lowers plasma glucose. Common ADRs include headaches and nausea while the most potential serious ADR is an increased risk of pancreatic cancer.

Question: In hospital, a young man starts to become cold, sweaty and clammy and collapse to the ground. You see that there pupils are dilated and he says that he cannot feel you touching him. You know he is diabetic and that he has is on insulin. He begins to become confused, agitated and aggressive but is still talking, shouting abuse at you. Which of the following is the best initial management of this patient?
Explanation: Look at the moderate section-as this patient is becoming aggressive, injecting the glucagon makes most sense e

Question: Which of the following reactions  causes fibrin monomers to have 'side to side' joining with each other following the coagulation cascade?
OptionC: Occurs spontaneously without the aid of thrombin
OptionE: Factor X and Factor V activation of fibrinogen
Explanation:
A- Thrombin does cleave fibrinopeptide a from fibrinogen to form protofibril monomer but this has only weak non covalent hydrogen bonding and no cross links

B-Correct-thrombin also cleaves firbrinopeptide b from fibrinogen to allow the fibrin clot to strengthen via side to side bonds 

D-XIIIa acts on the fibrin polymer already formed to form the cross linked mesh in the fibrin polymer. This defers from B as it does not cleave any firbinopeptides

Question: In terms of memory, which part of the brain is most responsible for procedural memory (memory of skills and habits)
Explanation:
Amygdala-Emotional responses associative memory (Implicit/Non-declarative memory)

Basal Ganglia- Motor Sequence learning 

Hippocampus -Episodic Memory (Explicit/Declarative memory)

Neocortex-Priming and Remote memory 

Striatum-Procedural memory (Implicit/Non-declarative memory)

Question: A 59-year-old woman was diagnosed with type II diabetes and was prescribed Metformin. After explaining the common side effects she asks you about the serious adverse reaction. You say the drug increases the risk of ....
Explanation:
Common side effects for Metformin: GI disturbance (diarrhoea)

Severe side effect: lactic acidosis

 

(Dr Coffee's pdf, case 17)

Question: Which of the following muscles from the posterior compartment of the leg is a superficial muscle as opposed to a deep muscle?
Explanation:
Deep muscles

Popliteus 

Flexor Digitorum longus 

Flexor Hallucis longus 

Tibialis Posterior
