Question: What are the main forms of undigestible carbohydrates?
Explanation:
Carbohydrates that are not absorbed into the small intestine are fermented by large intestinal microflora.

NSP (non-starch polysaccharides), resistant starch and oligosaccharides are the main forms of undigestible carbohydrates.

 

Andrew Shore PSC 2 lecture on Nutrition

Not fun sorry!

Question: Kevin and his children are on a cruise holiday enjoying the sun. Over the next couple of days many people of the cruise ship become ill with diarrhoea and vomiting and a fever. What is the most likely cause? And why?
OptionC: Norovirus - immunity only lasts 6 months so can be re-infected
Explanation: Noroviris - main reason its so infectious is due to the tiny infectious dose - only 10 particles can cause an infection

Question: which type of virus doesn't need to make mRNA before it can make a protein?
Explanation: d= this type of virus already has its  RNA in the correct form for translation, no need to convert to mRNA

Question: who hates virology?

Mrs Jones is 15 weeks pregnant with twins. She has rung up her midwife to ask why her best friend (who is also pregnant) has just had the quadruple test but she has not. What would the midwife have told her?
OptionA: She can only have the quadruple test at 16-20 weeks duration
OptionB: We cannot tell if serum marker abnormailites are due to one twin or both so there is no point in performing the test
OptionC: She would have already had the quadruple test done at 10-14 weeks
OptionD: With multiple pregnancies biochemical markers are too low to be detected so there is no point in performing the test
OptionE: She has no risk factors for developing any foetal abnormalities so was not booked in to have any further tests but she can opt to have the test if she wishes
Explanation:
A - can only have the quadruple test at 15-20 weeks

B - correct

C - she would have already had the COMBINED test done at 10 - 14 weeks

D - usually too high

E - not offered to multiple pregnancies and only for single pregnancies who present late and miss the combined test

Question: Which of these is NOT a sign/symptom of addison's?
Explanation:
You would have weight LOSS in addison's. 

 

Hyperpidmentation due to ACTH loss of negative feedback on pituitary --> increased ACTH. ACTH shares a precursor with MSH, called POMC. More POMC is needed for the increased ACTH so more POMC is produced, hence production of MSH also increases. This results in melanin overproduction and hence hyperpigmentation.

Question: TRH stimulates the release of TSH and what other pituitary hormone?
Explanation: No real explanation at our level. See anatomy and physiology of endrocrine system lecture

Question: Myofibrils are made from three kinds of proteins, contractile, regulatory and structural. In relaxed muscle, myosin-binding site on actin is blocking by tropomyosin. These tropomyosin strands are help in place by which molecule?
Explanation:
Myofibrils are made from 3 kinds of proteins:

  1. Contractile proteins - generating force during contraction
  2. Regulatory proteins - help switch contraction process on and off, and;
  3. Structural proteins - keep thick and thin filaments in proper alignment, give myofibril elasticity and extensibility, and link myofibrils to sarcolemma and ECM.

The 2 contractile proteins are ACTIN (thin filament) and MYOSIN (thick filament)

 

Myosin functions as the motor protein, it pushes and pulls various certain structures to achieve movement. It's tail points towards the M line, the centre of the sarcomere. And the myosin heads resemble two golf clubs twisted together.

 

Actin is anchored to the Z discs. Individual actin molecules join to form an actin filament twisted into a helix. On each actin molecule is a myosin-binding site, where the myosin head attaches. Smaller amounts of 2 regulatory proteins - tropomyosin and troponin - are also part of the thin filament.

 

In relaxed muscle, the myosin-binding site is blocked by tropomyosin acting on actin. Tropomyosin strands held in place by T-troponin molecule.

 

  1. At the onset of contraction, an action potential passes through the T-tubules causing Ca2+ to enter the cardiomyocte through L-type voltage gated Ca2+ channels in the sarcolemma.
  2. This Ca2+ then activates the Ryanodine receptors on the SR, causing it to release Ca2+ (Ca2+-induced-Ca2+-release - CICR) into the cytosol. There, Ca2+ binds to C-troponin, causing a conformational change, with a dissociation of I-troponin from actin, allowing tropomyosin to move from the myosin-binding site. 

 

Once the binding sites are free, the contraction cycle begins.

 

As the contraction ends, intracellular calcium returns to the SR via the SERCA calcium channels. (Note, I made up the last two options - not sure if they exist!)

Question: A 55 year old women presents to the doctors with a broken wrist, bone pain and is lactose intolerant. After some blood tests showing normal Ca and raised ALP the doctor explains to her that she has increased bone resorption causing a remodelling disorder. What is this disorder called?
Explanation:
A - osteomalacia is due to reduced vitamin D (which she would have as she is lactose intolerant) but it causes the softening of bone due to reduced mineral content. Bone resorption isn't effected and Ca levels would be decreased (ALP normal or increased)

B - even though it is a remodelling disorder due to increased bone resorption, this is not the answer because osteoporosis causes reduced bone mass and strength with normal Ca and ALP levels

C - bone resorption is increased causing thicker bones and increased fractures. Ca normal and ALP increased

D - correct. Chronic remodelling disorder of bone causing abnormal bone architecture. 

E - osteomalacia in children

Question: In normal conditions how is O2 diffusion from alveolar air into pulmonary capillary blood limited?
Explanation: Experimental studies have demonstrated that in healthy individuals the partial pressure of oxygen in blood largely equilibrates with the partial pressure of oxygen in the alveolar space (Alveolar Oxygen) roughly one-third of the way through its course through the pulmonary capillaries. In other words, the partial pressure gradient of oxygen across the alveolar membrane is eliminated early on as blood moves through the pulmonary capillaries. Given these features, it is clear that oxygen gas exchange is perfusion-limited in a normal, healthy lung.

Question: During foetal life, a temporary blood vessel shunts blood from passing through the pulmonary trunk to the lungs. Instead, this blood passes into the aorta. This vessel usually closes soon after birth, leaving a remnant. What is the name of this blood vessel, and remnant respectively?
Explanation:
The correct answer is ductus arteriosus and ligamentum arteriosum.

 

1. Closure of ductus arteriosus: occurs by muscle wall contraction almost immediately after birth. Caused by bradykinin released from the lungs at the first inhalation. It takes 1-3 months for total obliteration, forming the ligamentum arteriosum.

 

2. Closure of the umbilical arteries: occurs by wall contraction caused by thermal/mechanical stimuli and change in O2 tension. Happens a few minutes after birth. Takes 2-3 months for total lumen obliteration, forming the medial umbilical ligaments.

 

 

3. Closure of foramen ovale: occurs due to the increased pressure in the left atrium and decreased pressure in the right atrium. First breath is important for this to occur. Crying by the baby creates a shunt right to left (cyanotic periods of the newborn). Becomes the fossa ovalis.

 

 

4. Closure of umbilical vein and ductus venosus: occurs shortly after closure of the umbilical arteries. Thus, the blood may enter the newborn for some time after birth. Once obliterated it forms the ligamentum teres hepatis and ligamentum venosum respectfully.

Question: Which of the following products of the complement pathway is involved with inflammation and phagocyte recruitment?
Explanation: Via c3 convertase, C3a and c5 a are activated that cause inflammation and phagocyte recruitment

Question: Ivor has a form of inflammatory bowel disease. He is concerned about other parts of the body which may be affected by his condition. Which of the following is NOT an extra-intestinal manifestation of inflammatory bowel disease?
Explanation:
SSPE = Sub-Acute Sclerosing Pan-Encephalitis, a complication of measles caused by re-activation of the virus after the primary infection has been cleared

 

The rest are all extra-intestinal manifestations of IBD, see Dr Hawthorne's lecture

Question:
Yograj presents to a+e with abdominal pain.

 

He tells you that at first the pain was diffuse and described it as aching

 

However, he informs you that now the pain is more sharp and localized to an area in the lower right area of his abdomen

 

What is the innervation of the peritoneum layers?
Explanation:
In this example, Yograj had appendicitis.

 

At first the inflammation just affected the visceral peritoneum which is innervated by C nociceptive fibres hence the aching, more diffuse pain

Later the inflammation affected the parietal peritoneum as well, which is innervated by A delta fibres hence the sharper, more localised pain (McBurney's point 1/3 of the way between the ASIS and the umbilicus)

Question:
You receive two different reports from two different patients who have just had colonoscopies. However, the printer is playing up and has missed off the appearance of these two patients' colons. Can you fill in the gaps?

 

Patient 1 - Appearance _________ Diagnosis: Crohn's disease

Patient 2 - Appearance _________ Diagosis: Ulcerative colitis
OptionE:
1: Small sacs bulges out of lumen into wall
2: Pseudopolyps
Explanation:
Cobblestoning = Crohn's

Pseudopolyps = UC

Small sacs bulges out of lumen into wall = Diverticular disease

Polpys may be benign or malignant

Question:
Sally receives a visit from the health visitor. She gave birth 9 months previously and has just stopped breast feeding her child. She is still getting small milk secretions from her breast however, and asks the health visitor to explain the physiology behind milk production.

Which of the following terms describes the maintenance of milk secretion?
Explanation:
A - preparation of the breast for lactation

B - synthesis and secretion of milk from the alveoli

C - made up!

D - ejection of milk from the nipple 

E - correct answer - the maintenance of lactation throughout milk uptake by child

Question: Harry has recenty found out that one year ago he accidentally impregnated a Cardiff met student on a drunken night out. 3 months ago, said Cardiff met student gave birth to a healthy baby boy. As part of his revision, Harry decides to take his newly discovered child to his 3 month vaccination appointment. Which of the following vaccines is the fruit of Harry's loins most likely to receive?
Explanation:
The standard vaccinations given at 3 months are:

  • 5-in-1 (DTaP, IPV and Hib)
  • Rotavirus Oral Vaccine
  • Meningitis C Vaccine

Meningitis B is given at 2,4 and 12/13 months

MMR vaccine is given at 12/13 and 40+ months

Pneumococcal conjugate vacine is given at 2,4 and 12/13 months

Hepatitis A vaccine is not part of the standard childhood immunisation programme (given to travelers visiting high risk areas)
Tags: Case 9, Public Health, Vaccination, Virology, Immunology

Question: Which of these is NOT a cause of high anion gap metabolic acidosis?
Explanation:
Diarrhoea results in excessive HCO3 loss. This is compensated for by the kidney, by increasing chloride reabsorption. Result is a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

 

Metformin can lead to lactic acidosis, the others all increase the amount of organic acid in the body. This results a depletion of the body's HCO3 stores to remove the H+. The negative ion eg -COO-, compensates for the loss in the negative charge but is not included in the anion gap calculation hence the anion gap increases.

Question: A 19 year old student, under stress from her exams, hears a voice calling her name as she begins to drop off to sleep. There is no one else around. Which phenomenon is being described?
Explanation:
Hypnogogic-as you go to sleep

Hypnopompic-as you wake up

Question: Whilst on placement, you visit a 19 year old female who is 32 weeks pregnant. She is excitied for the birth and tells you about how she plans to bottle feed her baby. You inform her that 'Breast is Best' (that breast feeding is the best option for her baby), however, the midwife tells you to avoid using this phrase, why?
OptionA: Actually, bottle feeding using formula milk is better for the baby
OptionB: Breastmilk contains less calories than formula milk
OptionC: It suggests that bottle feeding is still a good option
OptionE: The mother is excitied for the birth and discussing feeding is not important at this time
Explanation:
The correct answer is C. By quoting 'Breast is Best', you imply that bottle feeding with formula milk is 'Second best' and still a good option. The other answers are all false.

The NHS suggests that all mothers should breastfeed for 6 months post birth, however any amount of breastfeeding has a positive effect. 

A type of question like this (I think) may sneak in under sociology etc.

Question:
A student presents to you with diarrhea and abdominal pain. He also complains of fever and chills with a headache and some pain in muscles.

 

The patient was taking advantage of the few hours of welsh sunshine and had a barbeque and a few beers in bute park with his mates the other day.
Explanation: With the history of BBQ, you're thinking uncooked meat and hence salmonella or campylobacter. The fever, chills, headche and myalgia are more suggestive of salmonella than campylobacter. See SIMA GI symposium slides

Question: What type of waves dominate on an EEG in REM sleep?
Which of these is FALSE about the Jejunum in comparison to Ileum?
Explanation: Not much explanation - sorry! Everything apart from C is correct. There is no fat in the mesentery of the jejunum

Question: Artificial drugs don't do a good job of inducing natural sleep patterns. What stage of sleep do they decrease the length of mainly?
Explanation: From the case 12 sleep lecture-example of drugs include morphine, barbiturates and benzodiazepines

Question: To prevent naive CD8+ T cells becoming sensitised to the body's own proteins, co-stimulation is required to activate them. This involves two separate signals acting upon the naive T-cell telling it to become a cytotoxic T cell. The first signal is binding of MHC class 1 on the Dendritic cell to the T cell receptor. What is the second signal?
OptionA: CD28 on the Dendritic cell binds to CD40 on the naive T-cell
OptionB: CD40L on a T helper cell binds to CD40 on the naive T-cell
OptionC: B7 on the Dendritic cell binds to CD40 on the naive T-cell
OptionD: CD28 on the Dendritic cell binds to B7 on the naive T-cell
OptionE: B7 on the Dendritic cell binds to CD28 on the naive T-cell
Explanation:
The two signals required to stimulate a naive CD8+ T cell to differentiate into a cytotoxic T cell are:

  • MHC class 1 on the dendritic cell (containing peptides from the pathogen) binding to the T-cell receptor
  • B7 on the dendritic cell binding to CD28 on the T-cell

The same is true for CD4+ T cells except its MHC-2 not MHC-1

 

CD40L and CD40 are involved in B-cell activation by follicular helper cells

Question: Which of the following options in adolescence occurs first?
OptionD: Gonadarche and Growth axis activation-occurs first at the same time
OptionE: Adrenarche and Growth axis activation- occurs first at the same time
Explanation:
Adrenarche

occurs at 6-9years for females, 7-10 years for males

 

Gonadarche

Occurs at 8-14 years for females, 9-15 years for males 

 

GAS

Occurs at 12 years roughly for females

Occurs at 14 years roughly for males

Question: In adolescence, due to synaptic pruning, there are changes in brain white and grey matter. Which of the following is true about what happens to white and grey matter post puberty?
OptionB: Grey matter loss overall; White matter increases linearly
OptionC: White matter loss overall; Grey matter increases linearly
OptionD: Grey matter gain is shown at different rates in some regions; White matter increases linearly
OptionE: White matter gains shown at different rates in some regions; Grey matter increases linearly
Explanation:
Total grey matter volume exhibits pre-pubertal increase followed by post-pubertal loss

There is region-specific, non-linear pattern of development (inverted U-shape pattern in certain regions) with some parts showing very matter progression at certain stages and regression at others. However, post pubertal overall shows a decrease in grey matter

 

White matter increases  in a steady, linear pattern

Question: A Mental State Examination assess's 8 different factors in the patient presenting with a possible mental illness. Appearance/behaviour, speech, mood, affect, thoughts, perceptions, cognition and insight. When assessing a patient's THOUGHT's a doctor may writes down in their notes 'Knight's Move'. What would they be referring to?
OptionB: No association between one part of sentence and the next
OptionC: Patient is unable to inhibit them self from giving an answer they’ve already provided
OptionD: Accelerated flow and logical connection between thoughts but goal of thought not maintained
OptionE: One topic seems to veer off in a loosely associated way to the next and is sometimes hard to follow
Explanation:
a)Neologism.

b)CORRECT. Knights move thinking or derailment is where there is no association between one part of sentence and the next. The end result is word salad.

c)Preservation. Eg. Where do you live? Fairwater. How old are you? Fairwater. What day is it? Fairwater..tuesday.
d)Flight of ideas.

e) Loosened associations.

Question: You are a junior doctor on the obs and gynae ward in UHW. A baby has just been born who, according to the senior doctor, has transposition of the great vessels. Until the baby can be taken to theatre, what drug do you have in mind to keep the ductus arteriosus pen and maintain foetal circulation?
Explanation:
See case 8 anatomy practical handbook.

In birth, three things cause the closure of ductus arteriosus: increase oxygen saturation, bradykinin (so this answer is incorrect as we want to maintain the shunt not close it) and decrease prostaglandin. 

In transposition of the great vessels the right ventricle is tasked with the role of the left ventricle and oxygenating the systemic circulation. It can only maintain the required CO for a small length of time. 

You give prostaglandin to maintain the ductus arteriosus until an arterial switch operation can be performed.
Tags: Anatomy, Embryology, Emergency Medicine, Case 7, Case 8

Question: What age would you begin to give testosterone treatment for a male you believe has delayed puberty?
Explanation: At 14, you would commence testosterone therapy either orally or IM. You would do this until the testicular volume=8mls

Question: A 22 year old pregnant woman asks her midwife about the benefits of breast feeding. The midwife is very excited to promote breast feeding. Which of the following is the least likely benefit she will give?
OptionA: Helps increase the rate that gestational weight is lost.
OptionB: Increases insulin resistance and decreases childhood obesity
OptionC: Decreases child hospital admissions for lower respiratory tract infections and meningitis
OptionD: Decreases risk of breast cancer for the mother
Explanation: B- breast feeding actually has an opposite effect in that it increases glucose tolerance. On that note, starting an infant on cow's milk early may decrease the amount of insulin produced, leading to an increase in T1 diabetes. This is due to an induced immune response to bovine serum albumin which is similar in structure to beta cells of the pancreas, resulting in autoimmune destruction of the beta cells.

Question: Mr Porcupine a 56 year old man walks into the GP complaining about his stressful job, the long hours he has to push through, how tired he is and how much he wishes someone would understand him. He keeps complaining not realising he has 8minutes for this session.  You are about to doze off but have to keep awake when he finally starts explaining how he develops fast, intermittent irregular palpitations lasting for a few hours at a time for a week now. The ECG shows no visible p waves. The GP turns to you and you try to keep calm knowing he's going to ask you a question any second. And yes he did. "So, which drug would be  appropriate for rate control?" Knowing this from the top of your head, you say:
Explanation:
Flecainide and Amiodarone - for rhythm control in AF

Dabigatran - is a NOAC

Verapamil -  Reducing ventricular rate in atrial flutter and atrial fibrillation- rate control

Atropine - muscarinic receptor antagonist that is used to inhibit the effects of excessive vagal activation on the hear - anticholinergic effects of atropine can produce tachycardia

Question:
Peter is a 21 year old male that was brought to the clinic by his girlfriend. He looked unkempt and had a downward gaze, and seemed to have a low, monotonous speech. His girlfriend Georgia, says that he had been very down since the loss of his mother a year ago, who committed suicide after her marriage to an abusive husband. She was also suffering from depression before she died. 

As the medical student on site you think that Peter may have depression. 

What does not happen to the brain in depression?
OptionB: The left prefrontal cortex becomes more active
Explanation:
B does NOT happen in depression. The left prefrontal cortex is responsible for producing positive emotions, and in depressive people the activity of the left prefrontal cortex is reduced. 

 

A,C,D,E all occur with depression.

Question:
You are the on-call doctor at A&E, when you see Linda McCartney, a 56 year old lady who describes experiencing the sudden onset of palpitations whilst cleaning at 10:30am that morning. She stated that the palpitations came on without warning and had not gone away after she ceased cleaning to lie down – they were ‘regular and extremely fast’. There were no associated symptoms of shortness of breath, dizziness or chest pain. Five hours later, upon her presentation to the Emergency Department, the rapid heart rate is still continuing. You perform some tests, and confirm that Linda has AVNRT.

 

You think back to the pathophysiology behind this form of supraventricular tachyarrhythima, which of the following is correct in regards to AVNRT?
OptionA: It involves a functional reentry circuit within the AVN, involving a slow (α) pathway and a fast (β) pathway
OptionB: It involves a functional reentry circuit within the AVN, involving a slow (α) pathway and a fast (γ) pathway
OptionC: It involves an anatomical reentry circuit with the AVN, involving a slow (α) pathway and a fast (β) pathway
OptionD: It involves an anatomical reentry circuit within the AVN, involving a slow (α) pathway and a fast (γ) pathway
OptionE: It involves an anatomical reentry circuit within the AVN, involving a slow (β) pathway and a fast (α) pathway
Explanation:
The correct answer is A.

 

AVNRT is typically paroxysmal and may occur spontaneously in patients or upon provocation with exertion, coffee, tea or alcohol. It is more common in women than men (~75% of cases occurring in women) and may occur in young and healthy patients as well as those suffering chronic heart disease. Patients will typically complain of the sudden onset of rapid, regular palpitations. The patient may experience a brief fall in blood pressure causing presyncope or occasionally syncope.

 

An ECG for AVNRT will be rapid, but have normal QRS complexes, followed immediately by P waves (this is because the atria are excited in a retrograde manner, and the reentrant circuit is show). The amplitude of the QRS complex increases on alternate beats. 

 

 

AVNRT involves a functional reentry circuit in or around the AV node, in which there are 2 pathways:

  1. Slow pathway (α): slow conducting and short refractory
  2. Fast pathway (β): fast conduction and long refractory

To briefly explain how a functional reentry circuit occurs:

 

In normal sinus rhythm, an impulse entering and passing through the AV node will pass through a fast (β) pathway and a slow (α) pathway. As the fast pathway is rapidly conduction, the impulse travelling through it will exit the AVN to the ventricles, and will also move around to the distal part of the slow pathway meeting its impulse, and they will both cancel each other out.

 

However, in AVNRT, as the fast pathway is still in the absolute refractory period (remember ARP is longer in the fast pathway than slow), an ectopic impulse arrives in the AVN and can pass through the slow pathway because it's refractory is over, but cannot pass through the fast pathway. By the time this impulse in the slow pathway reaches the end of the AVN, the refractory period of the fast pathway is over, and so it can enter the fast pathway distally and the impulse can go round and round in an AVN reentry circuit.

Question: You are a consultant cardiologist in Morriston hospital. A patient has come to see you for a follow up appointment to review their medication and progress after a recent myocardial infarction with ST elevation. They are a biochemistry lecturer and want to know all about the drugs they have been put on, particularly about Clopidogrel which they have not heard of before. How would you explain this drugs mechanism of action to your patient?
OptionA: It is an anti-platelet drug that inhibits the action of thrombin on platelets
OptionB: It is an anticoagulant that inhibits production of factor Xa.
OptionC: It is an anti-platelet drug that inhibits the production of factor Xa.
OptionD: It is an anti-platelet drug that prevents initiated platelets activating other platelets and starting a chain reaction.
OptionE: It is an anticoagulant that inhibits the production of fibrin.
Explanation:
D is the correct answer - Platelets become activated when their intracellular Ca2+ rises, usually they are effluxing Ca2+. Platelets are initiated by collagen, thromboxane or TXA2, They then release ADP. ADP acts in an autocrine and paracrine fashion, activating platelets by binding to a GPCR receptor on their surface and causing a chain of reactions that halt Ca2+ efflux. Aspirin inhibits TXA2 action on platelets, Clopidogrel, and Prasugrel inhibit ADP binding to GPCR receptors. All these drugs are anti-platelet agents, Clopidogrel/Prasugrel and Aspirin work well together and are often prescribed together. 

 

A. Although thrombin does influence platelet aggregation, it is primarily part of the coagulation cascade and is not influenced by Clopidogrel or any other anti platelet drug.

 

B. Clopidogrel is an anti-platelet drug, not an anticoagulant and does not inhibit production of factor Xa which is part of the coagulation cascade.

 

C. Clopidogrel is an anti-platelet drug, but it does not act on factor Xa production which is in the coagulation cascade.

 

E. Fibrin is part of the coagulation cascade and not affected by anti-platelet drugs such as Clopidogrel.

 

Apologies if there is a lot of detail here, the main difference to note is the one between anti-platelet agents and anticoagulants.

Question:
Pembrokeshire's favourite organ baker, Emily Lloyd, is creating yet another masterpiece. Unfortunately, she drops a rolling pin on her toe (ouch!). Emily proceeds to give her foot a good ol' rub to minimise the pain, and soon makes a full recovery. 

Which pain pathway is responsible for:

a) The initial pain felt when the pin drops on her toe and

b) The pathway which works to minimise the pain?
Explanation:
A delta fibres are responsible for the sharp pain which is felt when the pin drops on her toe. 

The rubbing helps relieve the pain by activating A beta fibres. These inhibit the A delta fibres and is called the Gate Theroy of Pain (remember Beta makes it Better).

C fibres are slow unmyelinated fibres which are responsible for dull/secondary pain (eg the pain in the minutes following the injury).

Question:
Whilst on placement, you visit a 48 year old female patient called Trudi and start talking to them. After a brief history, you discover that she finds things sound considerably louder than normal in her left ear. She has not noticed any difference in her right ear. 

The junior doctor asks you what may be the problem in this patient.
Explanation: The SBA in this case is a lesion to a CN 7, which innervates the stapedius muscle. This muscle stabalises the stapes bone and dampens vibrations from loud noises. Paralysis to this muscle means things sound louder in the affected ear. It is also the smallest muscle in the body!

Question:
On conducting a colonoscopy, the colorectal surgeon observes increased vascularisation, a sand-paper like mucosal texture and diffuse inflammation extending past the left colic flexure.

What is his most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
The visual appearance described is characteristic of Ulcerative Colitis.

U.C has different names accrding to its extension through the colon.

It always begins in the rectum (proctitis) and extends proximally:

If it includes the rectum and sigmoid this is proctosigmoiditis

If it goes up to (but does not go past) the left colic flexure, this is left sided U.C

If it does extend past the left colic flexure, this is Extensive U.C.

If the whole colon is involved, this is pancolitis

Not-so-fun-fact: 10 % of patients present with pancolitis
Tags: Abdomen, Case 11, Inflammatory Bowel Disease, Lower GI

Question: Rebecca, 24, has come into A&E with suspected meningitis. She has a fever and her neck feels stiff. You decide to take a lumbar puncture and find the following. Polymorphs - normal, lymphocytes - raised, protein - slightly raised, glucose - normal and opening pressure of 50cm H2O. Which of the following pathogens is most likely to have caused the infection?
Explanation: Candida albicans is a fungal infection, which is identified as having raised lymphocytes, normal glucose, normal or slighly raised protein and a high opening pressure.

Question: Sally is two months pregnant and visits her GP complaining of light headedness and the sensation of fainting upon standing. The GP reassures her that orthostatic hypotension is common in the first trimester. Which of the following would the GP advise Sally to do, to reduce this symptom?
OptionA: Relax her hands and leg muscles before standing
OptionB: Stand for long periods of time so the feeling becomes second nature
OptionE: Lie on her back instead of her side
Explanation:
All the options except D are the opposite of what the GP would advise. He would suggest:

Clenching hands and leg muscles

Dont stand for long periods

Dont take hot bathes - this will cause vasodilation if the arteries - increased blood pooling in the peripheries 

Avoid lying on your back - lie on the side

Eat every few hours to maintain energy

Question: What types of white blood cell is shown below?
Explanation: Stain purple with multiple granules is the way to tell

Question: Where is the inspiratory centre found in the brain?
Explanation:
A-Expiratory centre

B- Made up 

D-Pneumotaxic centre 

E-Apenustic centre
Tags: Physiology, Anatomy, Respiratory Medicine, Case 16, Case 5

Question: Deficiency in which of the following components of the compliment system may lead to Hereditary angioedema?
Explanation:
C1 inhibitor inhibits C1 activation but also coagulation factors: C1-inhibitor therefore leads to Hereditary angioedema but the clinical symptoms of this are more related to dysregulated coagulation factors than complement. 

 

Deficiency in regulators at the C3/C5 stage, especially factor H leads to an increased risk of developing Age related Macular Degeneration (AMD) and atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome (aHUS)

 

The main regulator of the terminal pathway is CD59, which prevents the formation of the membrane attack complex. Deficiency in gene making the CD59 and DAF results paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinurea.

Question: What is the correct definition of the ST segment on an ECG trace?
OptionA: Start of S wave to Start of T wave
OptionB: Start of S wave to End of T wave
OptionC: End of S wave to Start of T wave
OptionD: End of S wave to End of T wave
OptionE: End of R wave to End of T wave
Explanation:
C is correct 

 

The other segment we need to know is the PR segment which is the end of the P wave to the start of the Q wave

Question: Which of the following measurements tends to be the smallest on an ECG trace of a normal healthy person?
Epigenetic mechanisms are the molecular basis for foetal programming. Which of the following is not a epigenetic mechanism?
Explanation:
EPIGENETICS-->'Molecular factors and processes around DNA that are mitotically stable and regulate genome activity independent of DNA sequence.' (Change in phenotype without a change in genotype So there is no change in the sequence of DNA.

Therefore D is incorrect.

 

From; Development, disease and nutritional programming lecture in case 8

Question: At what level does the oesophagus pierce the diaphragm?

A couple comes in to the GP surgery because of their 5 year old son's hyperactivity and inattentiveness which they have noticed more so since he has started school. The GP suggests the son may have ADHD. The mother looks worried as she believes it is something that she may have done throughout her pregnancy. 

 

What at is the most likely cause out of the following options for ADHD?
OptionB: mother's high cortisol levels due to stress
Explanation:
Smoking causes of the son's behaviour which is characteristic of ADHD. Smoking also leads to still birth, sudden infant death syndrome, asthma, learning difficulties and defects such as cleft lip. 

 

Wales has the highest smoking rates in the Uk at 33%

Question: You are the on-call A&E doctor, when you get a call from a GP who is worried about his patient, Dan Thomas, and you tell him to send the patient over. Once Dan arrives, you establish that he is a 53 year old man with a history of hypertension. He presents with palpitations, fatigue, mild dyspnoea and presyncope. You perform an ECG on Dan and below are his scan results, what do you diagnose?
Explanation:
The answer is B, Atrial Flutter with 2:1 block.

 

Atrial flutter is a type of supraventricular tachycardia caused by a re-entry circuit within the right atrium. The length of the re-entry circuit corresponds to the size of the right atrium, resulting in a fairly predictable atrial rate of around 300 bpm (range 200-400). 

 

Ventricular rate is determined by the AV conduction ratio (“degree of AV block”). The commonest AV ratio is 2:1, resulting in a ventricular rate of ~150 bpm. Higher-degree AV blocks can occur — usually due to medications or underlying heart disease — resulting in lower rates of ventricular conduction, e.g. 3:1 (~100 bpm) or 4:1 (~75 bpm) block.

 

Recognising what type of block this is from an ECG scan is by looking at how many flutter waves there are between each QRS/beat. As you can see in the above picture, there are 3, so this would be atrial flutter with a 3:1. Whereas in the ECG scan for Dan, there are 2 flutter waves between each QRS, therefore his was atrial flutter with 2:1 block.

 

Other points to make about the ECG for atrial flutter:

  • Narrow complex tachycardia
  • Regular atrial activity at ~300 bpm
  • Flutter waves (“saw-tooth” pattern) best seen in leads II, III, aVF — may be more easily spotted by turning the ECG upside down!
  • Flutter waves in V1 may resemble P waves
  • Loss of the isoelectric baseline

The most common form of typical atrial flutter is the anticlockwise reentry (90%), where the impulse runs anticlockwise around the atrium (usually the right) which stimulates the AV node every time it passes it. 

 

 

Clockwise reentry is uncommon.

Question: Mr Haversian attends clinic for his yearly checkup to test his bone mass. This is used to assess the progression of his osteoporosis. When analysing the results you use the T-score to assess his condition. Which of the following best describes the T-score?
OptionA: A comparison between the patient's bone mass and that of a healthy 20yo
OptionB: A comparison between the patient's bone mass and that of a healthy 30yo
OptionC: A comparison between the patient's bone mass and that of a healthy person their age
OptionD: A comparison between the patient's bone mass and that of an average osteoporosis patient age 20yo
OptionE: A comparison between the patient's bone mass and that of an average osteoporosis patient their age
Explanation:
T Score is a comparison between the patient's bone mass and that of a healthy 30yo

Whereas Z score is a comparison between the patient's bone mass and that of a healthy person their age

Question:
An anaemic patient in hospital is awaiting a blood transfusion (transfusion will come from a family member) and would like to know more about the process. The doctor mentions that he will have red blood cells transfused to raise the oxygen carrying capacity of his haemoglobin. He then also mentions that this patient will need an additional special requirement to his transfusion.

 

Which if the following is a requirement for this particular patient?
Explanation:
You irradiate blood if there is a risk of transfusion associated graft versus host disease

 

A and B - routine and normal for red blood cells anyway 

C - correct > Some patients are at particular risk of TA-GvHD.

 

These include: • Patients receiving transfusions from family members, tissue type matched donors or granulocyte (a type of white blood cell) donors • Patients with an inherited immune system disorder • Patients who have developed an immune system disorder, such as Hodgkin’s disease; or due to treatment with certain drugs; or because of a bone marrow/stem cell transplant

 

D - only indicated in patients who have a severe allergpic reaction to RBCs and need plasma completely washed from RBCs - just something to note, we don't need to know this I don't think. 

 

E - obviously not.

Question:
Whilst shadowing a consultant in A+E you are called to see Graham, a 72 year old type 2 diabetic, who has come in with severe shortness of breath. Upon taking a drug history, you establish that he is currently taking Aspirin, Glibenclamide, Metformin, Ramipril and Simvastatin. Concerned about his shortness of breath, the consultant orders and ABG. The results of Graham's ABG are:

  • pH - 7.26 (7.35-7.45)
  • PaCO2 - 4.2 kPa (4.6-6.0)
  • HCO3- - 18.4mmol/L (22-26)

Which drug is most likely to be responsible for Graham's shortness of breath?
Explanation:
Graham is suffering from lactic acidosis, a type of metabolic acidosis that can occur as a rare (but serious) side effect of treatment with Metformin. This is established by the ABG picture:

  • Low pH = Acidosis
  • Low Bicarb. = Metabolic acidosis
  • Low CO2 = Respiratory compensation (resulting in shortness of breath due to hyperventilation)

Therefore the correct answer is C

 

None of the other drugs have metabolic acidosis listed as a side-effect in the current edition of the BNF.

 

I will also add as an extra piece of information that he shouldn't be on Ramipril since he is over 55 years old. I threw that one in there as a bit of a distractor.

 

GOOD LUCK WITH REVISION EVERYONE

Question: You are a junior doctor on-call who had to assist in an emergency Caeserian section. After delivery, you were asked to examine the placenta by the gynaecologist as per procedure. On examination, you found some missing placental cotyledon. What is the consequence of this?
Explanation:
The condition of missing placental cotyledon is called placenta accreta. This happens when the placenta invades and become inseparable from the uterine wall. The consequence of this condition is obstetric haemorrhage/blood loss which could lead to hysterectomy or even death due to massive blood loss. 

 

A: I made this up. 

B: Placenta Increta= Normal/appropriate placental attachment to uterine wall

 

p/s: There's a question on this in the Anatomy booklet of Case 8.

Question: You are on placement in an STI clinic and you see a patient who has been diagnosed with a chlamydia. What treatment of you most likely offer them?
Explanation:
To treat chlamydia use use either azithromycin or doxycyline.

Aciclovir is an anti viral so not very useful against chlamydia.

Question: You see a patient in a STI clinic who has been prescribed aciclovir for his STI. Which STI has he got most likely?

Aciclovir is used in herpes. It doesn't cure it but it can help to lessen the symptoms and slow the gorwth and spread of herpes in the body.

It is an anitviral so wouldn't help in chalmydia, gonhorrea or syphillis

Question: Bupropion can be prescribed for depression and acts as an atypical antidepressant. Which neurotransmitter uptake is it though to inhibit?
Explanation:
In this class of antidepressants we still do not fully understand how they exert their anti-depressive functions.

Bupropion (an aminoketone) inhibits both NA and DA uptake but not 5-HT.

Its efficacy has been attributed to inhibition of DA reuptake similar to that of cocaine but does not cause the latter's sense of euphoria.

Question: A patients comes in to see you in a GP surgery and thinks she might be pregnant. You give her a pregnancy test and while you waiting for the result to appear, she is asking you lots of questions about female reproductive physiology. One of her questions is why doesn't it matter that you lose the lining of your uterus every month. You explain that you only shed one layer, one layer is always there. Which layer do you shed during menstruation?
Explanation: The stratum basalis is there throughout the menstrual cycle. During the profliferative phase of the menstrual cycle it proliferates to form the stratum functionalis, this is then shed during menstruation if there is no pregnancy.

Question: Which of the venous sinuses are the arrows are pointing to?
Explanation:
It's the Straight Sinus 

 

The venous sinuses and deep veins include the superior sagittal sinus, the inferior sagittal sinus which drains into the straight sinus; and the internal cerebral veins and the Great vein of Galen which also drain into the straight sinus.

 

(Radiological Neuroanatomy Lecture, Case 16)

Question:
A 49 year old male patient presents to you with a  worry that he will develop colorectal cancer. He has a strong family history of colorectal cancer and has recently discovered blood in his stool. He also has experienced some unintended weight loss over the past few weeks. 

 

After a past medical history and an examination of the colon via colonoscopy you diagnosis the patient with Attenuated FAP.

 

What is the main molecular change responsible for the development of cancer in this individual?
OptionA: Loss of the APC gene through mutation resulting in unregulated expression of B-catenin and therefore cell proliferation leading from adenoma to adenocarcinoma.
OptionB: Loss of the APC gene leading to dysfunction of DNA repair and the accumulation of DNA damage leading to tumour genesis.
OptionC: Loss of the MSH-2 and MLH-1 genes resulting in faulty DNA repair and the development of adenocarcinoma through the accumulation of mutations.
OptionD: Mutation of the VHL gene promoting tumourogenesis.
Explanation:
In both FAP and attenuated FAP the APC gene is mutated and consequently B-catenin is unregulated. B-catenin is a gene responsible for cellular division and its dysregulation has been associated with many diseases including FAP and colorectal cancer. Those with FAP are almost certainly likely to develop Colorectal Cancer. 

 

The average diagnosis of colorectal cancer due to attenuated FAP is around 50. FAP related colorectal cancer is diagnosed earlier. 

 

The mutation or loss of MSH-2 and MLH-1 is seen in lynch syndrome which results in a predisposition to cancer of the colon, ovaries and the development of desmoid tumours. The EPCAM gene is the regulator of the MSH-2 and MLH-1 gene, loss of this gene also predisposes to lynch syndrome. 

 

Interestingly attenuated FAP is due to mutation of the APC gene at a different loci to FAP and therefore the accumulation of polyps and mutations takes longer hence why it is known as attenuated.
Tags: Gastrointestinal tract, Cancer, Genetics, Case 11, Inflammatory Bowel Disease

Question: Drugs such as Phenelzine can be used in the management of someone with depression. What is the desired target of this particular drug?
Explanation: This is a MAOi and is supposed to target MAO-A receptor. They target both however in practice-MAO B is involved in parkinson's management.
Tags: Pharmacology, Psychiatry, Case 12, Mental Health, Neurology

Question: A patient has been on heparin for a little while now and his doctor is wondering about his degree of anticoagulation. How would the doctor check this?
Explanation:
A: INR is for warfarin

C: Anti-Xa is for low molecular weight heparin, but this can be estimated from dosage

D: NOACs don't have protocols for measuring plasma levels or screening tests so no checks are done regularly

E: like B - estimate for low molecular weight heparin

 

See case 13, Dr Coffey, Anti-Arrhythmic Drugs lecture

Question:
Yograj arrives at a+e. He states "I was playing guitar when all of a sudden my head started to ache, since then my neck has stared to stiffen and I have vomited twice". His mother says Yograj became unresponsive for brief periods of time on the drive over to the hospital. 

What is Yograj most likely suffering from and what medication would you administer?
Explanation:
This is a Subarachnoid haemorrhage:

 

Symptoms - Sudden onset headache is seen, patient describes it as "worst headache of my life". Nausea, vomiting, photophobia (light makes headache worse), neck stiffness, brief loss of consciousness are also common 

 

Management – bed rest, IV fluids, analgesics, Nimodipine.

Nimodipine is a calcium channel blocker which prevents vasospasm (arterial spasms leading to constriction and thus ischemia) used to treat Subarachnoid haemorrhages.

 

Further Manage refer to neurosurgeon for angiogram, embolisation (blocks the abnormal vessels), and clipping of aneurysm.
This is a very severe injury – assume it is a subarachnoid haemorrhage until proven otherwise.

Question:
In A&E a patient has died of sudden cardiac death. In his notes its says was suffering with moderate depression. He was relatively resistant to pharmacological treatment. 

 

His ECG before his death is shown below:

 

What drug was he most likely to have been taking?
Explanation:
The ECG shows torsades de pointes. This is a cardiotoxic side effect of TCA drugs. Hence this is not a first line treatment for depression and is only really used when patients are resistent to SSRI's and MOAI's. Imipramine, Dosulepin and amytripylinpine are the main TCA's used in the UK.

 

 

Fluoxetine - is a SSRI with the main side effects being GI disturbances and anxiety

Haloperidol - can cause torsades de pointes but it is an antipsychotic rather anti depressent. 

Phenelzine  -  is an MOAI and the main side effect here is cheese reaction 

Venlafine -  is another SSRI

Question: Herbert, a 82 year old gentleman, attends the GP clinic complaining of back pain. He is currently being treated for cancer. The GP is worried that the cancer has spread to his spine. In the case of Herbert, where is the most likely site of the primary tumour?
Explanation:
In this case, D is correct.

From Mr McCarthy's lecture, Breast is the most common site of a primary tumour that spreads to the spine, followed by lung.

Although men can develop breast cancer, it is far less likely than lung cancer. Therefore, on balance, Herbert is more likely to have lung cancer.

Question:
A 18 year old male comes into the GP clinic complaining of epigastric discomfort, vomiting and diarrhoea and a general feeling of being unwell. The patient explains that his symptoms began after a 'cheeky' nandos with the boys, he remarks that he thought the chicken was too pink. 

 

You decide to take a stool sample and send it to the labs in order to work out what organism is causing this discomfort and whether you need to prescribe any antibiotics. 

 

The results are as follows: Gram -ve rod spiral shaped bacterium. 

 

What organism is likely to have caused the discomfort?
Explanation:
Campylobacter jejuni is a common cause of food poisoning especially when the chicken is under cooked. Campylobacter jejuni is detected through stool sample culturing and is a gram -ve spiral shaped bacteria. This pathogen is usually self limiting. 

 

C.difficle infection of the lower GI would result in pseudomembranous colitis  after treatment for another infection by a broad spectrum antibiotic such as amoxicillin. 

 

Bifidobacterium is an anaerobic y shaped gram +ve bacterium that is considered part of the good gut flora. 

 

Norovirus is the most common cause of D and V due to food poisoning and is diagnosed through RT-PCR not stool sample or ELISA (unlike Rotavirus). Norovirus is self limiting. 

 

Shigella is a gram -ve rod bacteria but is not likely to be the causative agent based on the history.
Tags: Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11, Infection, Inflammatory Bowel Disease, Lower GI

Question: As 'The face of YOLO', Mabli was trying out some new dancefloor moves to use in front of the cameras. Unfortunately, she is a little overambitious with some of the moves and felt something 'give' in her back. She self diagnoses a herniated disc. Which of the following herniations is most likely?
Explanation:
The majority of spinal disc herniation cases occur in lumbar region (95% in L4-L5 or L5-S1). The second most common site is the cervical region (C5-C6, C6-C7). The thoracic region accounts for only 0.15% to 4.0% of cases. Herniations usually occur posterolaterally, where the anulus fibrosus is relatively thin and is not reinforced by the posterior or anterior longitudinal ligaments.

Always remember the lumbar vertebrae have to take the weight of all those above them, meaning there is more pressure on the disc. It's also the reason the lumbar vertebral bodies are bigger than the throracic and cervical vertebrae.

Question:
A patient presents to his GP with persistent headache and "funny feelings in his chest". 

 

On examination, the patient is hypertensive, looks abnormally pale and appears clammy to touch.

 

What is your most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
The patient is presenting with the 5 classic symptoms of Pheochromocytoma: Pain (headache), perspiration, palpitation, pressure (hypertension) and pallor.

 

This is due to a tumour of the adrenal medulla, resulting in adrenaline oversecretion.

 

Treatment is agressive alpha and beta blocker treatment prior to surgical removal of the tumour

Question: Which of the following side effects of antipsychotic medication is an oculogyric crisis an example of?
Explanation:
EPSE of antipsychotics 

o Parkinsonism

o Acute dystonia (e.g. torticollis, oculogyric crisis)=Dystonic reaction consists of sustained, often painful muscular spasms, producing twisting abnormal postures

o Akathisia (severe restlessness)

o Tardive dyskinesia (late onset of choreoathetoid movements, abnormal, involuntary, may occur in 40% of patients, may be irreversible, most common is chewing and pouting of jaw)

Question: Which one of these mechanisms is not a physiological mechanism that reduces nociception?
OptionA: Periaqueductal grey area in the midbrain has descending inhibitory control
Explanation:
Normal physiological mechanisms to inhibit pain include:

  • Input form the periaqueductal grey (PAG) in the midbrain has descending inhibitory control
  • PAG control causes 5-HT and enkephalins release in the dorsal horn which inhibit action potential transmission from painful stimulus from 1st to 2nd order neuron 
  • GABA is released from local interneurons to the dorsal horn which inhibits transmitter relaease from 1st order neurons
  • Noradrenaline is released from the locus coeruleus has an inhibitory effect in the dorsal horn

 

Glutmate & Substance P are neurotransmitters released in the dorsal horn during pain transmission.

Question: Why do newer atypicals such as risperidone and olanzapine cause fewer Extra pyramidal side effects then typicals such as haloperidol?
OptionA: They target the D1 receptors more than the D2 receptors
OptionB: They target the D2 receptors more than the D1 receptors
OptionC: They target the D1 and D2 receptors equally
OptionD: They target 5-HT2A receptors more than dopamine receptors
OptionE: They target NMDA Hypofunction more than dopamine receptors
Explanation:
Newer atypical anti-psychotics have a higher affinity for the 5-HT2A receptors than D2 and explain the reduction in extrapyramidal side effects.

 

E is also highlighted in the lecture but is less true of atypicals currently prescribed one the UK. There have been mixed trials for these ones.

Question: A mother present prsents to her GP at 14 weeks for her quadruple test. Which biochemical marker will not be tested?
Explanation:
Combined screening tests: PAPP-A and free beta hCG

Quadruple screening tests: free beta hCG, Inhbin A, AFP and uE3
Tags: Child development, Prenatal Screening, Biochemistry, Public Health

Question:
Its a very sad day. Yograj has just heard news his father (Yograj senior) has become ill whilst on a business trip to Africa. His symptoms included perspiration, priapism, dilated pupils and a head ache. As time goes by his symptoms worsen, he begins to hallucinate and is randomly aggressive. 40 days later Yograj senior dies. 

Following his death an autopsy is carried out, Negri bodies are seen.

What is the most likely cause of Yograj seniors death?
Explanation:
Lyssavirus is an RNA virus causing Rabies.

Rabies includes symptoms such as perspiration, priapism, dilated pupils, head ache, hallucinations, random aggression and Hyper salivation.

Negri bodies are seen on biopsies. 

Often caused by animal bites in Africa and Asia.

Question: Hefina was diagnosed with breast cancer 2 years ago. Her tumour was removed and she received chemotherapy treatment. She presented a year ago with back pain that was present even at night. An MRI showed the cancer had metastasised to the thoracic spine. She presents to A&E with weakness in her upper limbs and paresthesia in her fingers. Her blood pressure is 115/78, oxygen saturation 98% and has a heart rate of 78bpm. What is least likely to be in your management plan for this patient?
Explanation:
Hefina has Metastatic Spinal Cord Compression. It has a prognosis of 6 months survival. 

 

Let's analyse the information given in the question:

  • Breast cancer is the most common primary tumour to metastasise to the bone (21%)
  • Breast cancer is relatively chemosensitive. Other chemosensitive tumours include: Non Hodgkins Lymphoma, Hogdkins Lymphoma, Neuroblastoma and Prostate Cancer. 
  • Breast cancer metastatises to the thoracic spine  via the azygous veins
  • Back pain is the commonest symptom of Metastatic Bone Cancer (95%), typically it is bad at night
  • Because of the likelihood of the mets being in the thoracic spine the patient's compression of the spinal cord will show upper limb neurological deficits like motor weakness and parasthesia
  • Spinal cord compression may also present as Cauda Equina Syndrome, radiating pain or lower motor limb weakness
  • This person is normotensive, has a normal oxygen saturation and a normal heart rate- Hefina does not seem to be in shock

Management of metastatic spinal cord compression

  • MRI
  • Spinal surgery indicated if the patient has demonstrated: increased neurological deficit, spinal instability, paralysis, intractable pain or a growing tumour
  • After surgery, the management plan is for the patient to be nursed flat and to be logrolled
  • The patient is also encouraged to sit up for 3 to 4 hours at a time, if stable obs, the patient should remain upright
  • Corticosteroids should be prescribed to the patient to reduce oedema from surgery. The dose should be increased as neurological deficits decrease. 

 

*The mons pubis reflex (female version of bulbouscavernosus) would only be necessary if Hefina was in spinal shock- this is the first reflex to return after cord shutdown.

Question: Holly, a 65yo woman, arrives at A and E with an ECG taken on the way in the ambulance. The ECG shows broad QRS complexes with evidence of a single foci in the ventricles. Which diagnosis is most likely?
Explanation:
Broad QRS complexes with evidence of a single foci in the ventricles is most suggestive of Monomorphic Ventricular Tachycardia. This is usually due to a stable re-entry pathway due to injury such as a scar from a previous MI that allows impulses to reach the ventricles causing mini electrical circuits. 

 

In General Broad Complex Tachycardia's have a broad QRS complex and should be assumed to be VT unless proven otherwise. Other causes include accessory pathways, especially antidromic ones (impulses go down the accessory pathway and up via the normal bundle to the AVN). 

 

Monomorphic VT presents as follows:

 

 

Polymorphic VT presents as follows:

- It is due to multiple ectopic foci and usually presents as a waveform such as that for TdP. TdP is associated with long QT syndrome which can be triggered by a  number of causes including anaesthetics, antihistamines, TCAs and antibiotics. One of the common iatrogenic causes of LQTS is amiodarone as this K+ channel blocking drug prolongs the effective refractory period and so prolongs QT interval- it can lead to TdP in those who already have LQTS. 

Ventricular Fibrillation presents as follows:

- It is a lethal state where ventricle contraction rate can reach 500bpm and so no blood is delivered to the body. It required immediate defibrillation. - - Defibrillation differs from cardioversion as it is one high energy shock that is given at a random time within the cardiac cycle rather than the cardioversion shock delivered at the peak of the QRS complex.

Question:
Barry has been suffering from auditory hallucinations with voices telling him that the shop assistant in tesco is trying to murder him and that he should move to China. 

Barry was then diagnosed with schizophrenia, and started taking medication. He finds that the voices start to speak to him less frequently but his sister tells you that his mood had since deteriorated, and he is reluctant to even get out of bed, which was not a problem before taking medication. 

 

Which medication and it's mechanism of action is likely to cause this situtation?
OptionA: He was prescribed Chlorpromazine which is an antagonist for D1 and D2 receptors.
OptionB: He was prescribed Citalopram which inhibits 5-HT Re-uptake Transporters
OptionC: He was prescribed Lorazepam which is a GABA Receptor agonist
OptionD: He was prescribed Haloperidol which is a high affinity D2 antagonist
OptionE: He was prescribed Clozapine which is a D2 and 5-HT antagonist
Explanation:
It is most likely to be Chlorpromazine because it has affinity for both D1 and D2 receptors. 

 

D2 receptors are in the mesolimbic system, which is hyperfunctional in psychotic diseases; and are associated with positive symptoms, therefore antagonists will improve positive symptoms 

 

D1 receptors are in the mesocortical system, which is hypofunctional in psychotic diseases; and are associated with negative symptoms, antagonists might causes symptoms to worsen 

 

Therefore haloperidol is preferred because it has a high affinity to D2 receptors.

Question:
A woman on the maternity ward has just given birth to a baby boy. 

 

The pregnancy was quite traumatic and during labour, the baby started to become distressed. As a result, the midwife had to use forceps to help deliver the baby.

 

From the use of forceps during labour, a perineal tear was acquired. The tear involves the skin, perineal muscles and anal sphincter.

 

What degree of perineal tear is this?
Explanation:
This is a third degree perineal tear as it involves the skin, muscle and anal sphincter. A fourth degree tear would also involve the anal epithelium.

 

 

There is no 5th degree.

Question:
Yograj was at the yoghurt factory. He tasted a delightful mint yoghurt, but "what's this!?" he cried, and he pulled out a cashew nut from the minty, yoghurty concoction in his mouth. "I'm allergic to nuts!" he cried into the air, "I'm going to die, I forgot my epipen!". P.S Btw, don't panic, Yograj was fine in the end.

Question: You walk into the Heath library and put your bags down on a spare seat (its very early in the morning) and head off for a quick wee. You return and realise that the love of your life has sat down in the seat next to you. You're unprepared for this and you get very anxious and you're unsure as to whether you're going to projectile vomit or shit yourself, or both at the same time. Luckily, you just go into a broad complex tachycardia and collapse. You wake in the hospital where you are told you were administered adenosine. How does this drug work?
OptionA: prevents the formation of CAMP by adenylyl cyclase and thus the formation of PKA which causes Ca2+ channels to open, and also phosphorylates phospholamban on the Ca2+ ATPase pump on the sarcoplasmic reticulum
OptionB: K+ channel antagonist, which prolongs hyperpolarisation, increasing the length of the a.p
OptionC: Na+ channel antagonist above the AVN. Binds to resting/active Na+ channels= lengthening of phase 4 on the a.p through the AVN
OptionD: Antagonist of the A1 receptor. This causes a decrease in Adenosyl Cyclase and thus a decrease in cAMP. This results in Ca2+ being let into the cell and K+ efflux= hyperpolarisation
OptionE: acts on opioid receptors in the heart causing K+ efflux and therefore, hyperpolarisation.
Explanation:
A- MOA of Beta blockers.

B- class III drug e.g amidarone

C- Flecainide

D- correct

E- Didn't think there were Opioid receptors in the heart, but I googled it because you never know with medicine, and there are. Called Zetta appaz. Very interesting. Anyway its wrong

 

Just to finish off my little story:

The love of your life didn't notice you collapsed and got rushed into hospital.

You remain single forever and buy a cat.

The end.

Question:
Mr Jones has been having abdominal pain in the left iliac region and passing out bloody stools frequently for a few months. After a few tests and examinations were done, you are able to deduce the following: 

- the primary tumour invades into the subserosa 

- there is metastasis of 2 nearby lymph nodes 

- no metastasis of other organs 

 

What is Mr Jone's colorectal cancer TNM classification?
You prescribe a patient a co-trimoxazole antibiotic. They ask you how this affects the bacteria and how it treats the infection?
Explanation: Co-trimoxazoles work by inhibiting folate synthesis. Folate is an important building block for amino acids and nucleotide synthesis. Bacteris cannot take folate up from the environment, they have to synthesis it themselves.

Question: A patient comes in to a&e with appendicitis. They describe how they had generalised abdominal pain to start with and now they have pain the is very localised to the right iliac fossa. Which fibre transmits this pain?
Explanation: Sharp, well localised pain is transmitted through a delta fibres. Initial dull diffuse pain is transmitted through c fibres.

Question: Whilst on a break in placement you decide to indulge in some quality time watching 'Pingu' on your phone. In this episode, Pingu is made to eat leafy greens by his dad, who presumebly says 'They are rich in Vitamin K'. You are well aware that vitamin K is required for a number of clotting factors, but which of the following is not Vitamin K dependent?
Explanation:
The correct answer is Clotting factor V or 5, which is not Vitamin K dependent. All the others are dependent, and can be remembered by thinking 1972 (10,9,7,2).

If anyone does want to watch the episode in question, it is the first episode here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0syrKzXfKuI

Question: Whilst on placement, you visit a 64 year old gentleman who has recently experienced a very serious adverse drug reaction to dabigatran (a Novel oral anticoagulant). To who should the ADR be ultimately reported to?
Explanation:
This question is admittedly sneaky as a number of answers are correct

A - You would report to the consultant (who hopefully should know anyway) but then ultimately he/someone has to report it to Yellow Card scheme

B - There is no need to report to the GMC

C - The local health board may be informed, but there is no requirement by law

D - The SHOT scheme regards Serious Hazards of Transfusion, so would not be notified in this case

 

The correct answer is E

 

The Yellow Card Scheme is the UK system for collecting information on suspected ADRs to medicines. The scheme allows the safety of the medicines and vaccines that are on the market to be monitored.

 

The sort of ADRs that should be reported are:

- ADRs that have caused death or a serious illness

- Any ADR, however minor, if associated with a new medicine or one that is under continued monitoring (highlighted in the British National Formulary (BNF) with a black upside down triangle)

- Any ADR, however minor, if associated with a child (under 18 years of age) or in pregnancy

 

You can submit ADR information online, or via Yellow Cards in the back of the BNF

Question: Ectopics are one of the most common causes of palpitations and can be caused by catecholamines. Which of the following phases of the cardiac action pacemaker potential is affected that leads to ectopisc?

Gaby, 21 goes to her GP complaining of hip pain. She thinks she's overdone it with the pigeon pose in her Bikram yoga class. The GP asks about her diet. She's a vegan (reasons include: healthiness, compassion, sustainability and instagram). On examination of the hip, the joint is tender to touch.  

Gaby has her bloods taken: FBC, Thyroid function test, Bone profile. The key observations are:

  • PTH- high
  • Ca- low
  • PO4- low

 

Gaby is then sent for an x ray:

 

 

What is her most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Gaby's vegan diet has lead her to have vitamin D deficiency. 

 

Vitamin D deficiency can lead to insufficient calcium and phosphate absorption. This means new osteoid cannot be mineralised, causing bones to be softer and more pliable thus more prone to deformation. It is called osteomalacia in adults and Rickets in children. Osteomalacia may lead to osteoporosis. 

 

Typical bloods of osteomalacia patient:

  • Low PO4 and Ca
  • High/normal ALP
  • High/normal PTH

On x-ray:

  • diffuse demineralization: osteoporotic-like pattern
  • may show a characteristic smudgy "erased" or "fuzzy" type of demineralization
  • insufficiency fractures
  • pseudofractures (looser zones)

Causes of vitamin D deficiency:

  • Reduced sunlight
  • Inadequate diet
  • Malabsorption
  • Medication- rifampicin, phenytoin
  • Abnormal Vit D Metabolism- liver or renal disease
  • Hypophosphataemia

Treatment:

  • Oral D2/D3 e.g. calcichew
  • Stop being a vegan and eat oily fish & eggs

 

B- osteopaenia would be determined by DEXA scan

C- osteoporosis would be determined by DEXA scan

D- Primary hyperparathyroidism would have:

  • High/normal Ca
  • Low/normal PO4
  • High/normal ALP
  • High PTH

E- Primary hypoparathyroidism- PTH is high so cannot be hypo

 

If you want to nail the pigeon pose:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0_zPqA65Nok

Question: An 11 weeks pregnant woman has come to see you to discuss her result from the combined test for Down's syndrome. Her result is high risk and she wants to have a diagnostic test to confirm whether her baby has Down's syndrome. You tell her that she can either have chorionic villus sampling (CVS) or amniocentesis. What is an advantage to CVS over amniocentesis for this patient?
Explanation:
B- CVS can be performed from 11 weeks, so in this patient's case - immediately. This is an advantage as it gives the patient more time to make any decisions following the procedure and results.

A, C & E - All advantages of amniocentesis over CVS

D - I don't know whether this is true but it should bear no relevance to the patient's decision

Question: A pregnant woman comes in to talk about her pain relief options during labour. She wants some pharmacological pain relief but is worried about the effect on the neonate and she is scared of needles. Which of the following options would be the best pain relief to recommend?

Explanation: A is the answer, synacthen test is the ACTH stimulation test.
