Explanation: All others decrease in size with age

Question: Which of the following features of Alzheimer's disease tends to occur first in the progression of the disease?

Whilst revising ECGs, you come across an ECG that shows a prolonged QT interval. This patient could have Long QT syndrome.

 

You are thinking about the channel that could be involved in this syndrome.

 

Which channel is most likely?
Explanation:
According to Jeffs lecture, long QT syndrome is linked to 3 channels:

K v7.1 (slowly activating potassium channel) --> (Iks) Long Qt syndrome 1

K v11.1 (rapidly activating potassium channel) --> (Ikr) Long QT syndrome 2

Na v 1.5 (fast sodium channel in ventricular action potential) --> (Ina) Long QT syndrome 3

Question: Which of the following channels is responsible for maintaing the ventricular myocyte resting potential at -90mV?
Explanation:
IK1 is the inward direct rectifier potassium current that becomes active in phase 3 but is mainly active in phase 4 to maintain the resting potential of the ventricular myocyte.

From TJA case 13 lecture

Question:
27 year old Sally visits the GP for the latest set of vaccines for her newborn baby. She mentions that she can't remember the last time she had a vaccine and asks the GP when is she due her next one. The GP replies "not until you're 65 for the pneumococcal vaccination".

Which of the following is NOT an indication for getting the pneumococcal vaccine earlier than 65 years old?
Explanation:
Public health plenary case 9

The above are all indications for an early pneumococcal vaccination except asthma which is an indication for an influenza vaccination.

Question: What major effect does beta adrenergic stimulation have on the ventricular myocyte action potential channels?
Explanation:
From TJA's lecture

His slides explain it better but basically beta adrenergic stimulation acts to decrease the length of the action potential but mainly stimulating IKS and IK1 channels.

IKS is mainly active towards the end of phase 2 and phase 3 of the action potential and is responsible for repolarisation (along with IKR BUT this isn't stimulated by beta adrenergic stimulation)

IK1 helps maintain the resting potential of phase 4 and is active also in phase 3 (this is known as the inward rectifier current but TJA outlines it as outward in phase 3-probably too much detail to know why)

ICa-L channels are the long acting inward calcium channel that are also stimulated by beta adrenergic stimulation BUT less so than IK1 and IKS.

 

Thus beta stimulation shortens the action potential by increasing rate of repolarisation/decreasing time in diastole.

Question:
Primary haemostasis occurs at the initial damage to blood vessels. Platelet adhesion is initiated when glycoprotein (GP1b) receptors on the platelet membrane bind to _________ attached to collagen, in the exposed subendothelial matrix. 

 

Fill in the gap.
Explanation:
The correct answer is B, von Willebrand Factor (vWF).

 

Three steps of primary haemostasis (3 A's): adhesion, activation and aggregation

 

During primary haemostasis, the initial damage to blood vessels causes the circularly arranged smooth muscle in their walls to contract immediately. This is known as the vascular spasm, and it reduces the blood flow whilst haemostatic mechanisms take place.

 

Platelet adhesion is initiated when glycoprotein (GP1b) receptors on the platelet membranes bind to von Willebrand Factor (vWF) attached to collagen, in the exposed subenothelial matrix. This initial tethering promotes binding of platelet integrin α2β2 and glycoprotein receptors directly to collagen. 

 

The glycoprotein receptor binding initiates activation which causes the platelets to change shape, put out pseudopodia and make thromboxane A2 (TXA2) via COX. The TXA2 releases mediators from platelet dense granules, including serotonin and ADP. TXA2 and serotonin cause vasoconstriction, whilst ADP activates more platelets via P2Y receptors. 

 

Fibrinogen receptors are activated and phospholipid is exposed on the surface, plasma fibrinogen then sticks to activated platelets via these receptors, so that they aggregate forming a soft platelet plug. This is fragile and is stabilised with fibrin during clotting. 

 

 

Sorry it's not the clearest of pictures, but it's the only one I found with good detail!

Question:
On collecting their daughter from prep school one fine, sunny, breezy day, Ollie and Ines noticed that as the children played and ran around in such a confined space, many of them regularly bumped into each other. They spontaneously looked deep into each others eyes and wondered why this was the case.

 

Which one of these is the most likely to be the reason for the children regularly bumping into each other?
OptionA: Ollie and Ines' child was stupid and therefore couldn't help but bump into people
OptionB: Lack of development of the Pre-Frontal Cortex in the brain in children
OptionC: Lack of development of the Pre-Motor Cortex in the brain in children
OptionD: Lack of development of the Visual Cortex in the brain in children
OptionE: Lack of development of the Motor Cortex in children
Explanation:
Answer is:

(Assuming that their child was in fact the nerdiest child in the class- this rules out A)

 

B) Lack of development of the Pre-Frontal Cortex in the brain in children

 

The Pre-Frontal Cortex is essential for PLANNING and EXECUTING actions. 

It is one of the LAST areas to develop in the human brain, which explains why smaller children are unable to plan where they run/ walk enough in advance to avoid collision. 

In General, Motor & sensory systems mature earlier; higher order association areas (frontal, parietal, temporal corticies), which integrate those primary functions, mature later

(Taken from Neuroanatomy Lecture Case 12, and Adolescent Neurological Lecture Case 12)

 

Side note: watch out for small children walking into your path on pavements, and pity them for their inferior Pre-Frontal Cortexes

Question:
Yograj is over the moon because he finds out his sister is 12 weeks pregnant! He exclaims 'I am going to be an uncle at last!' to anyone who will listen. But bad luck runs in the family, and his sister unfortunately lost a baby in a previous pregnancy at 8 weeks gestation, which broke Yograj's little heart. Yograj excitedly attends the 12 week dating scan with his sister and saw the nurse in the antenatal clinic writing in the notes. When the nurse popped out he sneakily looked at what she'd written, as he is an inquisitive fellow.

 

What did he see his sisters gravidity and parity written as?
Explanation:
Gravidity is the number of times a woman has been pregnant, including the current pregnancy, so she is G2, which rules out answers a and c.

 

Parity is the number of pregnancies beyond 20 weeks gestation, whether viable or not, so her parity is 0, as her previous pregnancy did not reach this point, so B is wrong and D is correct.

 

If this pregnancy lasts beyond 20 weeks then she will be G2P1.

If she has this baby then becomes pregnant again, she will be G3P1

If we pretend that her previous pregnancy had made it to beyond 20 weeks, then she would currently be G2P1.

If she already had a 2 year old child, a miscarriage/termination at 8 weeks and is currently pregnant, then she would be G3P1.

 

Remember the number of foetuses delivered doesn't determine the parity/gravidity.

One pregnancy=one birth i.e. a woman who is not currently pregnant, but has delivered twins after 20 weeks is classified as G1P1.

Question: Which artery of the Circle of Wilis is the most common cause of an intracranial aneurysm?
Explanation: A: Anterior Communicating Artery

Question:
The initial phase (extrinsic pathway) of coagulation, is initiated by the exposure of ______ in the subendothelial matrix (collagen), which binds to factor ___ in plasma.This complex then activates factor X → Xa (and IX → IXa in the intrinsic pathway). When tethered to platelets via phospholipid, factor Xa then converts ______ to _______.

 

Fill in the gaps.
Explanation:
Fibrin monomers are cleaved from fibrinogen by the protease thrombin, a key component in clotting. Activation of thrombin involves sequential conversion of proenzymes to active enzymes (e.g. factor X → factor Xa) in a coagulation cascade.

 

EXTRINSIC PATHWAY: 

  • This is initiated by the exposure of tissue factor (TF; thromboplastin) in the subendothelial matrix (collagen), which binds to factor VIIa in plasma, to form a TF:VIIa complex.

 

COMMON PATHWAY: 

  • The Tf:VIIa complex activates factor X → Xa (and factor IX → IXa in the intrinsic pathway).
  • When tethered to platelets via phospholipid, factor Xa converts prothrombin (II) to thrombin (IIa).

 

This initial phase of coagulation aka extrinsic pathway produces comparatively little thrombin. However, it initiates the amplification phase (intrinsic pathway), because thrombin activates factors XI, VIII, V and more platelets. 

 

(Note that Ca2+ is required for activation of factors X, XIII and prothrombin (II) - Ca2+ chelators e.g. citrate/EDTA can therefore be used to prevent clotting in stored blood)

Question: Beta adrenergic stimulation can cause Po to increase in the RyR2 receptor by causing a regulatory molecule to dissociate-which molecule is this?
Explanation: Calstabin is another name for FKBP

Question: You are in tesco express on cathays terrace buying essential revision snacks and you suddenly hear a gasp and a splash. You look around the corner of the biscuit aisle and see a pregnant woman standing in a puddle. She looks terrified (probably at the sight of you in stained hoody/unwashed hair/crisps and hobnobs in hand), so having just revised case 8 you go to help. She is adamant the baby is about to pop out any second and doesn't want to have to tell everyone her baby was born in tesco. You first reassure her that it could be worse as your mate helped deliver a baby in lidl last week, and also say that the baby won't come out until her cervix is fully dilated at 10cm, and that this on average takes...... to occur? She is dubious until she sees a red lanyard hanging out your pocket (you take it everywhere just incase), at which point she relaxes and calls a taxi to the heath.
Explanation:
Full dilation (10cm) takes an average time of 15 hours. This could be much quicker if a woman as had a previous vaginal delivery.

After the waters have broken (marking the start of labour) contractions will begin at 20-30 minute intervals which dilate the cervix and encourage the baby to move into the birth canal.

Active labour is defined as when the cervix is 4cm dilated.

 

Stages of labour:

1-cervical dilation --> from waters breaking to 10cm

2-expulsion --> can take from a few mins to a few hours, from point of full dilation to when the baby is delivered

3-afterbirth --> usually 30 mins after the baby is delivered, further contractions expel the afterbirth. These contractions help to seal the blood vessels ruptured by separation of the placenta from the uterus wall. Mother can be given IM injection of syntocinon to speed up delivery of afterbirth and prevent post part haemorrhage.

Question: Which hepatitis virus is a DNA virus?
Explanation: Hepatitis B is the only DNA virus the others are all RNA viruses

Question: Neuropeptide signalling is involved in appetite control which of the hormones below stimulate the release of Agouti Related Protein (AGRP) from the Arcuate Nucleus?
Explanation:
Agouti related protein and Neuropeptide Y are the neuropeptides in the brain that are released by the arcuate nuclease to stimulate feeding, appetite and weight gain. 

 

Grehlin is the only hormone which stimulates this. 

 

Orexin also stimulates appetite but this is a neuropeptide itself and is released from the latera hypothalamus. 

 

Leptin, CCK and cytokines inhibit the release of AGRP and NYP and stimulate the release of alpha MSH which inhibits appetite.

Question: 57 year old, Michael Davis, is about to be discharged from hospital following a myocardial infarction. You, as his doctor, inform Michael that you will be adding aspirin to his repeat prescriptions. Michael tells you he is a retired pharmacist and would like a reminder of the mechanism of action of aspirin, to which you reply..
OptionA: Aspirin is an antiplatelet drug which irreversibly inhibits COX therefore inhibiting prostaglandin-I2 from platelets.
OptionB: Aspirin is an anticoagulant drug which irreversibly inhibits COX therefore inhibiting prostaglandin-I2 from platelets
OptionC: Aspirin is an antiplatelet drug which irreversibly inhibits COX therefore inhibiting thromboxane A2 synthesis from platelets
OptionD: Aspirin is an antiplatelet drug which reversibly inhibits COX therefore inhibiting thromboxane A2 synthesis from platelets
OptionE: Aspirin is an anticoagulant drug which irreversibly inhibits COX therefore inhibiting thromboxane A2 synthesis from platelets
Explanation:
Aspirin is an antiplatelet drug used as a preventative measure for arterial (white, platelet-rich) thrombi.

 

Risk factors for arterial thrombosis include:

  • Endothelial/endocardial damage:
  1. Atherosclerotic plaque/rupture
  2. MI
  3. Valve disease
  4. Atherosclerosis
  5. Hypertension
  6. Catheters

Aspirin is a unique drug in that it irreversibly inhibits COX, the first enzyme in sequence leading to formation of TXA2 and PGI2. (It is worth noting that aspirin irreversibly inhibits the COX-1 domain more specifically than the COX-2 domain). 

 

Thromboxane A2 is produced by platelets and is a key platelet activator, aggregator and vasoconstrictor. Whereas, PGI2 is endothelium derived, it promotes vasodilation, inhibits platelet activation and aggregation by increase cAMP.

 

Due to aspirin's irreversible inhibition, production of TXA2 can only recommence once a NEW COX enzyme has been made. This is because platelets have no nuclei and therefore cannot generate their own COX enzyme, therefore the levels of TXA2 remain low until new platelets are formed (takes about 2-3 days). However, as PGI2 is endothelium derived, these cells have nuclei and are able to make new COX within hours, allowing the level of PGI2 to remain high.

 

Therefore aspirin = sustained ↑ in PGI2:TXA2 ratio BLOCKS platelet activation and aggregation.

Side effects of aspirin: GI problems (PGs protective effect of GI tract removed) and haemorrhage.

Under 16 + aspirin = Reye's syndrome

 

Perhaps to just briefly go through physiology of the arachidonic acid cascade:

 

Arachidonic acid is cleaved off the cell membrane by enzyme phospholipase A2. It can then undergo 2 major pathways:

  1. The first is the less important one, where the enzyme lipoxygenase converts the arachidonic acid into leukotrienes.
  • Leukotriene receptors have roles in bronchoconstriction, vascular permeability and chemotaxis. Montelukast, a treatment for asthma, is a leukotriene receptor antagonist.

     2.  The next, and more important pathway, involves an enzyme called cyclooxygenase (COX) (also known as PGHS enzyme).

  • There are two isoforms of this enzyme, COX-1 and COX-2.
  • COX-1 is constitutive, and synthesised at a constant rate, whereas COX-2 is induced and therefore not always there.
  • COX-1 = required for maintenance of healthy gastric tissues, renal homeostasis and platelet aggregation.
  • COX-2 = required for inflammation, pain, heat and swelling (PGD and PGE).
  • The COX enzymes convert arachidonic acid into endoperoxides, PGG2 which is formed on the COX demain, and PGH2 which is formed in the peroxidase domain. PGG2 and PGH2 can then be modified into prostanoids.

This reaction occurring in platelets can lead to the production of thromboxane A2.

This reaction occurring in the endothelium of blood vessels results in the production of prostacyclin PGI2.

 


The PGH2 can also be converted into prostaglandins which are more stable, such as PGD2, PGE2, and PGF2. 

  • PGE2 - histamine, bradykinin, eosinophil, chemotaxis, vasodilation, used to induce labour.
  • PGF2 - bronchoconstrictor, uterine contraction
  • PGD2 - bronchoconstrictor, anti-platelet aggregation.

A lot of this was in Coffey's lecture last year in case 1 :)

 

(Thank you to the person who pointed out I had the wrong answer selected!)

Question: The stages of Alcohol related liver disease start at hepatitis steatosis and end with liver cirrhosis. Which of the following is most true about ARLD?
OptionA: Cirrhosis and fibrosis are the only irreversible stages of ARLD
OptionB: Hepatic Steatosis is defined as fatty infiltration of the liver and hepatoceulluar injury and inflammation
OptionC: In ARLD, the AST to ALT ratio is less than 1 typically
OptionD: Pentoxifylline is the first line management of ARLD
OptionE: Typically most patients with the condition are drinking over 18 units a day of alcohol
Explanation:
A-True

B-hepatic steatosis is JUST fatty infiltration of the liver; steatohepatitis and fibrosis is the definition typed here 

C-The ratio is usually >2. This is a stand out feature as in most other liver conditions the ALT/AST ratio is greater 

D-This is 2nd line. Oral prednisolone is typically first line, at 40mg for 4 weeks. This steroid can increase infection risk, which is why a Lille score should be used to identify steroid non-responders

E-This is partly true; those considered at risk are actually those consuming over 12 units over alcohol a day

Question:
Ellie presents to you with kussmaul breathing. You suspect she has an acid-base disorder and consequently perform arterial blood gas analysis. 

 

The results are as follows: 

 

pH: 7.21 (7.35-7.45) 

PaCO2: 3.2kPa (4.7-6.0kPa) 

[HCO3-]: 9mmol/L (22-26mmol/L)

 

How would you best describe Ellie's condition? 

 

  (This is what her breathing looks like)
OptionA: Respiratory acidosis with partial compensation by metabolic alkalosis
OptionB: Respiratory alkalosis with partial compensation by metabolic acidosis
OptionD: Metabolic alkalosis with partial compensation by respiratory acidosis
OptionE: Metabolic alkalosis with full compensation by respiratory acidosis
Explanation:
The pH and HCO3- levels are both acidotic, so the primary mechanism is a metabolic acidosis. The respiratory alkalosis is compensation for the HCO3-, but the pH is not within normal limits, so it is only partially effective.

 

Here's how I worked it out:

 

Presentation is important: 

Kussmaul breathing is a deep and labored breathing pattern often associated with severe metabolic acidosis, particularly diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) but also kidney failure.

 

Start by determining pH: 

7.21 = Acidotic 

 

Then look to see whether PaCO2 or [HCO3-] are in the same direction:

[HCO3-]: 9mmol/L = low therefore contributing to acidosis. 

 

Look for compensation 

PaCO2: 3.2kPa low and in an alkalotic direction - compensatory. 

 

However pH still outside normal range (7.35-7.45) so compensation is only partial.

Question: Which of the following is not a feature of the plasmacytoid dendritic cell in comparison with the conventional dendritic cell?
Explanation: PDCs also contain interferon B. Unlike conventional dendritic cells they only contain MHC 2. CDCs contain both MHC 1 and 2.

Question: You are on call in A&E when an 84 year old woman comes in after suffering a stroke at home. Her breathing is abnormal with a long inspiration and short expiration. This type of breathing is suggestive of a stroke in what part of the CNS?
Explanation:
This patient has apneusis breathing. This breathing occurs when there is a lesion in the Pons. 

 

A lesion in...

The thalamus would cause Cheyne-Stokes breathing - tachypnoea then apnea then tachypnoea etc.

The midbrain would cause hyperventilation

The medulla would cause ataxic breathing (irregular)

 

 Sorry the picture is a bit blurry, but it can be found in Plenary 2 from Case 16; Assessment of the unconscious patient

Question:
A 17 year old male visits the GP with gynaecomastia. He is not on any medication and drinks a moderate amount of alcohol. After examination, the GP wants a cytogenetic test to view his karotype.

 

What feature might the GP have noticed on examination?
Explanation:
There are 2 X chromosomes therefore this patient has a karotype of 47XXY - Klinefelter Syndrome. It is the most common sex chromosome disease.

Features of Klinefelter Syndrome include:

  • Gynaecomastia
  • Small testes
  • Tall stature
  • Poor muscle tone
  • Infertility
  • Shy personality
  • Primary hypogonadism (decreased testosterone, increased FSH)
  • Low IQ

 

A- Gynaecomastia is a sign of alcoholic liver disease, but this patient is unlikely to have this
B- Small testes are charactersitic of 47XXY
C- Neck webbing is a feature of Turner's Syndrome 45X, seen only in females
D- Patients are characteristically tall. A short stature in a female is linked with Turner's Syndrome 45X

Question: Which of the following are not released by the placenta?

whilst pounding the treadmill you see a woman in the gym with huge boobs which gets you thinking about your case 8 anatomy. You remember that the breast is composed of 15-20 lobes which divide into lobules which end in alveoli. You are correct in thinking there is one lactiferous duct per lobe that open at the nipple. You are struggling to remember what hormones cause proliferation and hypertrophy of said lactiferous ducts in pregnancy. When you rush home to check your notes, you discover that the hormone responsible for this is mainly...
Explanation:
A =  hPL's role is in metabolism

↓ maternal insulin sensitivity leading to an increase in maternal blood glucose levels.
↓ maternal glucose utilisation, which helps ensure adequate fetal glucose

B = correct

C = progesterone is responsible for proliferation/hypertrophy of the alveoli

D = hormone key in maintenance of lactation/galactopoesis

E = oxytocin is released by the posterior pituitary and cause contraction of the myoepithelial cells surrounding the alveoli

 

other changes to the breast in pregnancy include:

-increased vascular supply, mammary veins dilate, stretch marks

-size and pigmentation of areola increase for babies poor vision

-montgomery's glands enlarge to lubricate and condition the lactating nipple

Question:
Picture this: you are a second year medical student who, after a top night of boozy antics in the lash, is running late for placement. You rush onto the gastroenterology ward to find your placment group and see that they are shadowing the consultant on the ward round. You manage to slip into the group without being noticed. Phew! looks like you're off the hook.

 

But wait! The consultant decides to ask you "Which drug should we give this patient to maintain their remission?" In a panic, you steal a quick glance at the patient's notes and manage to see that they are a non-smoker with a recent episode of diffuse mucosal inflammation of the rectum, but before you can see more the consultant quickly covers the notes to stop you cheating. "Well? What's your answer then?" he says.

 

Which of the following is your best bet to get in the consultants good books and avoid his impending wrath?
Explanation:
The patient is most likely suffering from ulcerative colitis, since they had diffuse mucosal inflammation of the rectum (CD would present with patchy transmural inflammation). Drugs used in maintenance of remission of UC are:

  • Mesalazine (an aminosalycylate)
  • Azathioprine (an immunosuppressant)

So therefore the correct answer was E

 

As for the other drugs:

  • Antibiotics are given for active CD
  • Anti-TNF drugs are given for severe active CD or UC and maintenance of remission in CD
  • Corticosteroids are given for active CD and severe active UC
  • Diuretics are not routinely given in cases of IBD
Tags: Pharmacology, Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11, Inflammatory Bowel Disease

Question: Caradog has started to become unwell 3 days ago. He has now developed a rash, so his mother decides to take him to the GP. The GP examines the rash to be a maculopapular rash. He diagnoses him with Measles. What other symptom does he most likely have?
Explanation:
Measles and Rubella present with maculopapular rashes. 

 

A- Complication of Rubella- seen in 70% of females who have had the virus

B- Symptom of Mumps

C- Description of Forcheimers Spots seen in 20% of patients with Rubella 

  • Not to be mistaken for Koplik's Spots seen in Measles- these are grey/white lesions on the mucosa of the buccal cavity

D- runny nose is a description of the word 'coryza' - one of the 3Cs symptoms of Measles

  • coryza
  • cough
  • conjunctivitis

E- One of the symptoms of SSPE- a complication of a Measles infection

 

 

moral of the story: learn what the terminology means

Question: You take a stroll to the concourse to buy a cheeky BMD to get you through the next few hours of revision. You see a lady breastfeeding discreetly and remember lactogenesis, which is the fancy word for synthesis and secretion from alveoli. You recall that it has 3 stages, the first being when there is an increase in mRNA mid pregnancy at 16-22 weeks for milk proteins/enzymes such as lactose, casein and alpha lactalbumin. Which of the following best summarises stage 2?
OptionB: under autocrine control, in that milk synthesis is stimulated by milk removal
OptionC: high oestrogen and progesterone prevent milk secretion
OptionD: 30-40 hours after birth, high prolactin stimulates mRNA synthesis for milk proteins
Explanation:
a= true but D is more correct

b= true about stage 3 of lactogenesis - for as long as milk is removed, it will be produced

c= true about stage 1 of lactogenesis

d= correct answer, just after birth levels of progesterone/oestrogen drop so milk secretion is no longer inhibited by these hormones, and prolactin is high which increases the synthesis of lactose, lactoferrin, IgA and oligosaccharides

Question: Whilst on placement during your endocrinology case, you meet Geoff, a 43 year old man who comes to see his GP complaining of a recent loss of appetite and growing feelings of weakness. He also tells the GP that he has had some unintended weight loss recently. Upon examination, the GP notices that Geoff has hyperpigmentation of his palmar creases. Which of the following sets of lab findings would you expect to see in Geoff's case?
Explanation:
Geoff has Addison's disease caused by primary adrenocortical insufficiency, typically characterised by:

  • Progressive weakness
  • Non-specific complaints (loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, weight loss)
  • Hyperpigmentation of palmar creases
  • Hyperkalaemia and hyponatraemia
  • Dehydration
  • Hypoglycaemia
  • Sexual dysfunction
  • Adrenal crisis (if severe)

In Addison's the typical lab finding is low cortisol with high ACTH (the high ACTH is what causes the hyperpigmentation, since ACTH and MSH are both produced fromthe same precursor molecule)

 

Therefore the answer is C

 

A represents Cushing's with a secondary pituitary cause

B represents Cushing's with a primary adrenal cause

D represents Secondary hypoadrenlism (would shown similar symptoms but no hyperpigmentation)

 

See lecture on the endocrine system in case 10 for more info

Question: Galactokinesis is the ejection of milk stimulated by mechanoreceptors in the nipple acting on the hypothalamus. In the neural pathway, what hormone is causes contraction of the myoepithelial cell surrounding the alveoli and where is it released from?
Explanation:
a = incorrect

b = correct 

c = incorrect (but prolactin is released from the anterior pituitary)

d = incorrect

Question: Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an autosomal recessive disease. In the US the disease affects 1 in 10 000. Roughly, what is the carrier frequency?
Explanation:
We can calculate this using the Hardy Weinberg Equilibrium: p2 + 2pq + q2 = 1

  • p is the frequency of the dominant allelle
  • q is the frequency of the recessive allelle
  • p + q =1

 

p2  = frequency of homozygous dominant (AA)

2pq = frequency of heterozygous (Aa)

q2 = frequency of homozygous recessive (aa)

Question: Which of these arteries is not related to the internal carotid artery?
Explanation:
The ophthalmic artery, posterior communicating artery and the anterior cerebral artery are all branches of the internal carotid artery. The internal carotid artery then continues as the middle cerebral artery

 

The branches of the vertebral arteries are the meningeal artery, anterior & posterior spinal arteries and the posterior inferior cerebellar artery

Question: Colostrum is produced for the first week of so of breastfeeding and milk is considered mature from approximately 3 weeks. What substance is found in high concentrations in colostrum but not in mature milk?
Explanation:
colostrum contains lots of protein, minerals, vitamins ADE&K and IgA

mature milk contains lots of fat, sugar (lactose) and calories

Question:
You are an F1 doctor in A and E when a 9 year old male child presents to you having had an asthma attack. The child has a known history of atopic asthma and he is visibly very distressed.

 

The diameter of the child's airway has decreased by half, this is due to the contraction of the smooth muscle surrounding the bronchiole of the child.

 

What degree of resistance increase will be seen in the child's airway?
Explanation:
Poiseuille's law states that resistance =1/radius^4

 

Radius is proportional to diameter.

 

A decrease in the diameter by 1/2 will result in a 1/2 decrease in radius.

 

This will result in a 16 fold increase in resistance because r^4

 

Conversely a 2 x increase in diameter will result in a 16x fold decrease in resistance.

 

In order to get a 32x increase in resistance the radius would have to be decreased by a factor of 4

Question:
"Cause I'm Yograj,

Yes I'm the real Yograj,

All you other forehead models are just imitating,

So won't the real Yograj please stand up"

 

At this point The Real Yograj wonders which myoterms allow him to extend his knees in order to stand up?
Explanation: L4/3=knee

Question: Diabetic Ketoacidosis is a medical emergency. So when a patient presents with it, what is the first action you would take, for treating the patient?
Explanation:
With diabetic ketoacidosis; in the first house the following MUST be done:

  • IV saline must be given with 1L going in the first hour
  • IV insulin at a rate of 0.1U/kg/hour

Treatment is targeting to ensure:

  • Blood sugar falls by 3mmol/l per hour
  • Ketone level falls by 0.3mmol/l per hour
  • HCO3 rises by 3mmol/l per hour
  • K+ is 4-5mmol/l

Hourly blood sugars and ketones should be measured. 2 hourly HCO3 and potassium levels measured. A clinical examination should be made, especially of the abdomen. An assessment of the cause should be made.

Priority goes to replacing the fluid loss and infusing insulin. Therefore C is correct.

Question: What is X?
Explanation: The macula is the central ‘high definition’ area of the retina with a high proportion of cone cells.The fovea centralis is essentially a pit at the centre of the macula, responsible for sharp, central vision.

Question: Which of the following areas of the brain is hyperactive in depression?
Explanation:
 Ventromedial PFC mediates pain, aggression, libido and appetite

 Lateralorbital PFC mediates maladaptive and perseverative mood states and behaviours

Hyperactive in depression → enhanced sensitivity to distress, anger, anxiety, negative ruminations

 

 Dorsolateral PFC maintains executive function, sustained attention and working memory

Hypoactive in depression → psychomotor retardation, apathy, attention and memory deficits
Tags: Depression, Psychiatry, Case 12, Mental Health, Neurology

Question: This is the embryo at day 9 of development. What is (i) in the diagram?
Explanation: The primary yolk sac is present around day 9 of development. The trophoblast and the inner cell mass have differentiated by this stage with formation of the amniotic cavity (day 8). The development of the extraembryonic cavity is seen around day 11-12. The secondary yolk sac is seen at day 13.

Question:
You are trying to feel for your femoral pulse but you are having difficulty finding it.

 

Where should you be palpating to find this pulse?
OptionB: Halfway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic tubercle
OptionD: Halfway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the umbilicus
OptionE: Halfway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis
Explanation:
Answer is E. This is the mid inguinal point where you should feel the femoral pulse.

B is incorrect - ASIS to pubic tubercle is the inguinal ligament. Halfway between would mark the deep inguinal canal.

Question: A patient comes in to see you, they have a very complicated past medical history and are on lots of drugs. One of them is simvastatin, he asks you how this drug works. You tell the patient it blocks an enzyme, whiich enzyme do statins block?
Explanation: Statins block HMG CoA reductase which required for cholestrol synthesis. This lowers serum LDL cholestrol.

Question: What are the main three components of Cognitive Based Therapy?
Explanation: From Case 12 wrap up
Tags: Depression, Psychiatry, Case 12, Mental Health, Neurology

Question: You encounter a patient diagnosed with atypical depression. Which of the following is correct about atypical depression?
OptionC: There arms feel as light as feathers
OptionD: They have a huge increase in appetite
OptionE: Unlike typical depression, they show no response to any external stimuli
Explanation:
All about from D are the opposite in atypical depression

They usually gain weight-thought to be due to CRF deficiency and downregulation of the HPA axis. This also explains the increase in appetite 

They are usually hypersomnia-so sleep a lot more than usual (you could argue that this suggests sleep deprivation but D is clearly the more correct answer)

Some sufferers usually feel as though they have extremely heavy arms

The opposite to E-in atypical depression their mood can  brighten in response to actual or potential positive events

 

Source 

DSM IV

Question:
You are watching the Simpsons, where Ralph Wiggum is picking his nose and Homer is eating a lot of Pink iced doughnuts (or should I say Doh-nuts), as well as drinking plenty of Duff beer. 

Seeing Homer eat so much reminds you, a panicked stressed out revising year 2 medical student, about Prader-Willi Syndrome.

 

What hormone is associated with making you feel hungry and is raised in Prader-Willi Syndrome?
Explanation:
Prader Willi Syndrome, resulting from mutations on chromosome 15q11-q13 (q being long arm, p being short arm). 
This causes, among other things, increased ghrelin

Ghrelin: usually released by an empty stomach, with key release sites being stomach and small intestine. It makes you more hungry

Question: Phil has been revising hard all day and doesn't feel like cooking. Instead, he treats himself to some chicken from one of the many fine establishments on City Road. His friends warned him it was risky after they heard about a nasty outbreak of a stomach bug. Fortunately, Phil is fine for a few days and finishes his exams. But before he can celebrate he comes down with terrible gastroenteritis. He is very ill for about 5 days. What is the most likely infectious agent?
Explanation:
• Campylobacter is the commonest bacterial cause of IID in the UK. Outbreaks are linked to contaminated food, usually CHICKEN. It had an incubation period of 1-7 days and symptoms last 2-7 days. It is self-limiting unless immunosuppressed.
  • Clostridium difficile is linked to antibiotics (co-amoxiclav) which destroy the natural gut bacteria, it is spread via the faecal-oral route and mostly likely to be seen in the elderly and hospitalised. Can be asymptomatic or have awful symptoms including toxic megacolon. 
  • Cholera is spread by faecally contaminated water and food and outbreaks are common in SE Asia. Symptoms are profuse painless watery stool (rice water stool), needs to be managed with aggressive rehydration. There is a vaccine for travellers. 
  • Norovirus accounts for most of non-bacterial IID in hospitals. Outbreaks are common crusies. The IP is only 24-48 hours and symptoms include vomiting and diarrhoea. 
  • Salmonella enteritis comes from food poisoning often poorly cooked meat and is often associated with travel. Phil could have been infected by this but the information in the question suggests campylobacter is more likely!

Question:
You are a medical student on GP placement in Endor and a former Death Star employee comes in. She tells you about how she used to work on the ultimate weapon in the galaxy but was transferred shortly before it was destroyed. She continues to tell you about how sad this made her, her lack of energy and how many of her fellow Stormtroopers were lost. She now tells you how she low she is all the time and takes little pleasure in activities she used to enjoy such as destroying rebel scum. Given her history, the GP prescribes her Fluoxetine and asks you what this drugs mechanism of action is

 

You tell the GP...

 

Bonus points for correctly identifying the class of drugs the incorrect answers are for
OptionA: It inhibits the re-uptake of both Serotonin and Noradrenaline
OptionC: It is a D1 and D2 antagonist
OptionD: Blocks mainly dopamine, serotonin and other monoamine receptors
OptionE: It selectively blocks the re-uptake of serotonin
Explanation:
The correct answer is E as Fluoxetine is a SSRI

 

A=Serotonin and Noradrenaline Re-uptake Inhibitors e.g. Venlafaxine
B=MAO Inhibitor

C=Conventional/Typical Anti-psychotic e.g. Chlorpromazine (Haloperidol has a higher affinity for D2 than D1 so doesn't worsen the negative symptoms as much)
D=Atypical Anti-psychotic e.g. Olanzapine

Question:
You are an ST3 psychiatrist working in the new unit in Llandough Hospital. You are asked to see a 21 year old man who has been referred to the unit by his GP, whom he was convinced to see by his friends. From taking a history, (and a collateral history provided by the one remaining friend he trusts), you ascertain that he has become withdrawn from his social circle, rarely engaging in social activities for fear that some of his friends are talking about him behind his back in a derogatory manner. He does, however, love a curry, and used to be a frequent patron of Kasturi, but switched to Mowgli's upon hearing a disembodied voice telling him that the chef in Katsuri was adding cyanide to dishes for customers he did not like. He does not know the origin of the voice, but believes what it says as he believes it is of supernatural origin. You also discover that he was a heavy cannabis user in his early teenage years. He does not appear dejected or tearful.

 

There are no significant findings on any physical examination, and blood tests show nothing abnormal. He takes no regular medication and ECG shows no abnormalities. He is calm, and despite the fact the he does not believe himself to be ill, he does agree to engage with the treatment plan you suggest. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacological therapy?
Explanation: Of the drugs suggested, Quetiapine is the most appropriate. As he is presenting with both positive (auditory hallucination, persecutory delusion) and negative symptoms of schizophrenia (social withdrawal), an atypical would be the best initial treatment as they have superior efficacy over typical antipsychotics in the treatment of negative symptoms. He is calm, and so treatment with a benzodiazepine may not be necessary. SSRIs can be a useful adjunct but as his primary presentation is psychotic, not affective, it also may not be necessary. Clozapine is a more effective antipsychotic drug than Quetiapine or Chlorpromazine, but its potential for life-threatening ADRs rules it out as a first line therapy, and it should only be considered after failure to attain adequate symptom control by separate therapeutic trials of a typical and an atypical antipsychotic drug.
Tags: Pharmacology, Psychiatry, Schizophrenia, Case 12, Mental Health

Question: A pregnant woman is going on a hen do spa weekend. This is her first pregnancy and is extra precautious about everything. So, much to the dismay of the bridesmaid and the bride-to-be, she has written a (fun) list of "10 things you shouldn't do on a spa weekend when preggers". What is not included in this list?
OptionE: Pop some thalidomide pills that Ketty-Katie always bangs on about
Explanation:
• Having a Dead Sea Clay Full Body Wrap is always ok
  • Thalidomide is a known teratogen which was used for morning sickness initially but was discovered to cause phocomelia (missing limb segments) in babies
  • Never take anything from anyone called Ketty-Katie
  • Alcohol is not advised during pregnancy. It may cause foetal alcohol syndrome
  • Saunas may cause hyperthermia which might raise the mother's core temperature which is dangerous
  • Smoking is linked with in-uterine growth retardation

Question: A patient comes in to see you with xanthelasma, corneal arcus and tendon xanthoma. They tell you that their grandfather died of a heart attack aged 50 and their mother has had angina since she was 30. You think this all sounds very worrying and this she might have familial hypercholestraemia. What is the mechanism behind this condiiton?
OptionB: Decreased production of HDL, so less LDL removed
Explanation: Familial hypercholestroleamia is caused by a mutation in the gene that codes for the LDL receptor so LDL isn't removed from the system as efficiently. People with FH develop atherosclerosis on average 20 years earlier. The condition is autsomal dominant.

Question:
Jeff is thinking of a neurotransmitter but is struggling to remember it's proper name. 

He gets confused with neurochemistry and all the long words involved. 

He knows the neurotransmitter is derived from an essential amino acid. 

He also knows that low levels are associated with depression. 

What neurotransmitter is Jeff most likely thinking of?
Explanation:
Careful! 

 

Serotonin (5-HT) is 5-hydroxytryptamine

this is not the same as 5-hydroxytryptophan (5HT) which is a previous step in the synthesis pathway: 

 

Tryptophan --> 5-hydroxytryptophan --> 5-hydroxytryptamine (serotonin)

I know. It's totally ridiculous. But it caught me out so hopefully helpful! 

 

Dopamine is a NT and is also associated with depression as it is another mono amine (the MOA hypothesis states that these are low in depressive disorders) however serotonin is more specific to Depression. Dopamine has been linked to Schizophrenia (hypersecretion) and Parkinson's (hypo secretion)

 

5-hydroxy-tyrosine isn't a thing.. I don't think.

but Tyrosine is the essential amino acid from which catecholamines (NA, ADR, DA) are derived 

 

glutamate derived from glucose and is not associated with depression. It is the main excitatory neuro transmitter in the CNS

Question: The active metabolite of Carbimazole is an inhibitor of which enzyme?
Explanation: It just is

Question: Which pathogen causes Pott's paraplegia?
Explanation:
Option C: Tuberculosis

Pott's Disease or Pott's paraplegia is caused by tuberculosis infection occurring outside the lungs : the disease presents in the vertebrae (haematogenous spread).

Staph aureus is responsible for 60% of the spinal infections (also can cause surgical site infections-30%);

Enterobacter accounts for 30%, and rest all also cause spinal infections but not Pott's.

Question: A woman comes in with her 3 month old daughter who is due her 5-in-1 vaccination. The mother is concerned about the vaccines as she is afraid her daughter will become infected. You explain to her how this is not possible as none of the vaccinations are live and therefore cannot cause infection. What sort of vaccine are the tetanus and diphtheria portions of the 5-in-1 vaccine?
Explanation:
Correct answer = D. Diphtheria and tetanus vaccines are bacterial toxins which have been inactivated.

-----------------------------------------

A - Killed vaccines are intact organisms which have been killed. Examples include: IM polio, pertussis, influenza

B - Subunit vaccines are purified antigenic components. Examples include non-conjugated pneumococcal, haemophilus 

C - Recombinant vaccines are prokaryotic or eukaryotic cells with the genes encoding epitopes inserted into them. Examples include hepatitis B

D - Conjugate vaccines are a polysaccharide antigen linked to protein carrier to enhance immunogenicity. Examples include Hib, meningococcal, pneumococcal

Question: Aspirin exerts its effects through acetylation of which amino acid residue in the cyclooxygenase domain of PGHS?
Explanation: Aspirin acetylates a serine residue in the COX domain, leading to irreversible inhibition of PGHS. This was in Dr. Coffey's case 1 lecture on NSAIDS and paracetamol.

Question:
Mrs Jones is admitted to hospital with pneumonia. Shortly after she is admitted, Mrs Jones becomes very short of breath and splutters that she feels like she is drowning. Mrs Jones is known to have mild heart failure but it is usually well compensated as she takes ACE-Inhibitor, Beta-blocker and a mild thiazide diuretic. Due to her past medical history, you think that Mrs Jones is experiencing an acute pulmonary oedema due to decompensation.

What drug would you give to Mrs Jones to relieve her symptoms?
Explanation:
Mrs Jones’s pneumonia has caused her heart failure to become acutely decompensated. This would cause an acute pulmonary oedema (sometimes called ‘flash oedema’), which would result in Mrs Jones becoming acutely short of breath as the fluid would reduce perfusion of oxygen into and out of the blood. Furosemide is a strong loop diuretic. This should be used along with high flow oxygen as first line of care. The furosemide would cause Mrs Jones to excrete the excess fluid.

 

Ivabradine is a vasodilator and so not that useful in acute pulmonary oedema.

Ramipril is an ACE-Inhibitor. Mrs. Jones is already taking an ACE-I but it is important to check her concordance as when people become ill, they tend to become less concordant with their medication.

Spironolactone is an aldosterone antagonist. Although a diuretic it is not used in acute situations.

Warfarin is an anticoagulant. Anticoagulation of patients is advised but with Heparin not Warfarin.

Question: Which of the following conditions is linked to having large numbers of Copy Number Variants?
Explanation:
Studies have robustly demonstrated that large and rare copy number variants (CNVs) at several loci increase risk for schizophrenia.

See Case 12 genetics lecture

Question: You are a fifth year medical student on your elective in Thailand. Liam Marsh, a soon-to-be medic finding himself on his gap-yah, is brought into your hospital by his concerned friend and travelling companion, Adam Brown. Liam became acutely unwell shortly after the start of a full-moon party, becoming flushed and vomiting profusely after only a few drinks. Adam reveals that Liam's dentist had prescribed an antibiotic for a dental abscess just before they left, but Liam did not wish to miss out on the fun of the party so ignored his dentist's advice not to drink alcohol. Which drug was most likely prescribed?
Explanation: Metronidazole can cause severe toxic reactions to alcohol. This was thought to be due to competitive inhibition of liver alcohol dehydrogenase, though recently this mechanism has been disputed. Fluclox and Erythromycin may be used for this indication, but the toxic alcohol reaction is most suggestive of Metronidazole.

Question:
Jerry, a 55-year-old man, came to his GP complaining of symptoms of episodic diarrhoea with blood, crampy abdominal pain and during the attacks he felt generally unwell and had a low-grade fever. 

He was sent to the hospital to carry out further tests including histological studies of the bowel, what is a key feature from this test most likely to be seen under the microscope, that would indicate the disease Jerry has?
Explanation:
Jerry is suffering from an attack of ulcerative colitis

  • answers a, b and c are seen in Crohn's disease
  • D=pseudopolyps are seen in UC but generally in later stages of the disease
  • E is the correct answer as continuous, muscsal and submucosal inflammation is a key feature of UC
Tags: Histology, Case 11, Inflammatory Bowel Disease, Lower GI

Question: which of the following does human milk contain that is missing from formula milk?
Explanation:
lysozyme is involved in bacterial cell wall lysis, binding endotoxins, increasing IgA production and contributes to macrophage activation

formula also doesn't contain any lactoferrin (iron chelation) or IgA (adapted to survive in GI/resp tracts)

it only contains alpha lactalbumin and casein

Question: Nancy is adamant that she doesn't want to breastfeed as she thinks it will be painful and inconvenient. You tell her by not breastfeeding she is at increased risk of a few things. Which of the following is not in your list?
Explanation:
a, b, c and e were all mentioned in a lecture

d - i made up (quick google and a few sites say that prolonged breastfeeding has an increased risk of osteoporosis)

Question: On placement in Barry you see Nessa who is 34 weeks pregnant. She presents at the GP with a swollen painful and tender leg. You remember from case 8 that pregnant ladies are at a higher risk (x5-10) of venous thromboembolism which can go on to cause a PE which is a leading cause of maternal mortality/morbidity. Which of the following is not a reason that pregnancy increases their risk?
Explanation:
soz for negative question

 

as far as I know, folate deficiency doesn't contribute to the development of DVT/PE

A/B/D/E were all given in a lecture

 

risk factors include previous thromboembolism, family history and pregnancy. Within pregnancy your risk is higher if you are dehydrated, if you have hyper stimulative ovaries or you have a parity of over 4.

Question: RBC's obtained by blood donation must be used within 35 days and must be stored at 4 degrees celsius. What temperature must FFP be stored at and how long can it be stored for?
We all know that a raised C- reactive protein indicated the presence of infection, but what does it actually do in terms of the innate immunological response?
Explanation:
This is just to help with understanding > in Parham's it says the following

 

IL-6 changes the spectrum of soluble plasma proteins made and secreted in the liver, some concentrations go down and some concentration of proteins go up, one of them being c reactive protein as well as serum amyloid aA. These clearly stand out because the concentration increase by several hundred fold. That's why c reactive protein is used clinically as a diagnostic test for infection, inflammation and tissue damage. 

 

C reactive protein is an acute phase protein that activates compliment (calassical in absence of an antibody) and acts as an opsonin. See page 63 

 

:)

Question: the 3rd stage of labour is the afterbirth. Which of the following is not considered part of the afterbirth?
Explanation: a, b & c are considered the three components of the afterbirth. If the placenta is not fully delivered then this can result in post part haemorrhage.

Question: A 60-year old woman presents to her GP with rectal bleeding, diarrhoea and anal pain. On examination she has a palpable rectal mass. Her blood tests show iron deficiency anaemia. What should the GP do next?
Explanation:
Correct answer = D.

Patient should be referred for urgent colonoscopy as rectal cancer is suspected. Rectal bleeding, rectal mass and iron deficiency anaemia are all red flags for rectal cancer and investigations should be carried out to either confirm or eliminate this diagnosis as soon as possible.

Question: Anaemia is usually defined as a decrease in the amount of red blood cells (RBCs) or haemoglobin in the blood. Therefore, from this we can say that anaemia decreases the viscosity of blood. What effect will this then have on the resistance of the vessel and the flow of blood respectively?
OptionA: Decreases resistance and increases the flow of blood
OptionB: Increases resistance and increases the flow of blood
OptionC: Decreases resistance and has no effect on the flow of blood
OptionD: No effect on resistance and increases the flow of blood
OptionE: Increases resistance and decreases the flow of blood
Explanation:
(Apologies for making a haemodynamics question!)

 

Poiseuille's Law states that there is a relationship between flow, pressure and resistance. The equation can be applied to a single vessel, organ or an entire circuit.

 

Q = △P/R 

Where;

Q = flow

△P = change in pressure/pressure difference

R = resistance

 

Therefore, if △P remained constant, we could say that Q is inversely proportional to R. So, any increase in flow would DECREASE resistance of a vessel.

 

Resistance of a vessel is determined by 3 major variables

 

R = vL/r^4

Where;

v = viscosity (higher the viscosity, thicker the liquid i.e. honey has a higher viscosity than water)

L = length of vessel

r = radius of vessel

 

Using this equation, and assuming all other variables remain constant, we can say that

  • Resistance is proportional to velocity
  • Resistance is proportional to length of vessel
  • Resistance is inversely proportional to radius^4

Therefore if we put all the equations together.. We said earlier that Q is inversely proportional to R. And we just said above that R is proportional to v.

 

(Let's pretend that this ∝ is the proportional to symbol)

 

So; Q 1/∝ R ∝ V

 

So therefore a decrease in viscosity, as is in anaemia would also decrease resistance of the blood vessel, but increase the flow of blood.

 

How do those with anaemia compensate? They increase their Cardiac Output.

 

CO = MAP / TPR .. Because their total peripheral resistance decreases, their CO increases to compensate (also increasing stroke volume and heart rate as          CO = SV x HR)

 

The opposite would be in polycythaemia where there is an abnormally high concentration of Hb in the blood, either through decreased plasma volume or increase in RBCs. This would increase the viscosity = increase in resistance = decrease in flow.

Question: Whilst on placement in a GP surgery, a patient asks you about the absorption of different ions in the GI tract. Which of the following is true of calcium absorption?
Explanation:
Correct answer = B. Calcium is actively absorbed in the duodenum transcellularly via TPRV receptors. It is also absorbed passively in the ileum and jejunum.

-----------------------------------------

C = How sodium is absorbed in the jejunum via SGLT-1 transporters

D = Chloride is counter-transported with bicarbonate in the jejunum

E = Potassium is subject to solvent drag

Question:
Your younger sister is studying the heart in A level biology. She knows the SAN controls the heart rate. 

 

You try to show off and tell her about the ridiculous number of channels involved in the this. 

 

Which potassium only channel is specific to this area of the heart?
Explanation:
K Ach is an inward rectifier in the SAN and it is the only channel which responds directly to Ach from parasympathetic nerves. Hence causes a reduced rate of depol in the pacemaker potential and therefore bradycardia. 

 

The If channel or the HCN (Hyperpolarisation activated cycle nucleotide) does involve K+ but it is an Na+ K+ exchanger. 

 

IKs and Ikr  are in phase 2/3 in SAN and phase 3 in the ventricles

 

Ito is specific to phase 1 of ventricular action potential. 

 

I know all these channels are annoying to learn but the KAch channel relates to bradycardia so its got some clinical relevance.

Question:
Oedipus, a young man, was travelling to the great city of Thebes. Before he could cross the wall into the city a great Sphinx blocked his path. The sphinx said "Tell me which of the below options act as an muscarinic Ach antagonist leading to dilation of the pupil? Answer incorrectly and I shall eat you." 

What should Oedipus say to avoid being eaten?
Explanation:
Dilators

Tropicamide - muscarinic Ach antagonist, stops Ach binding to M3 thus stopping contraction of the cillary muscles causing dilation. Used in eye exams and its effects last around 4-8 hours.

Phenlephrine - Activates Alpha 1 receptor leading to relaxation.

Cocaine - Stops the uptake of of Na. Na normally activates Beta 2 receptors leading to relaxation. Hence less uptake, cuaes more Na leading to more relaxation.

 

Contractors

Pilocarpine - Acts as a muscarinic Ach agonist on the M3 receptor. Causes pupil constriction. Used to treat dry mouth and glaucoma.

 

Anaesthetic

Tetracaine - prevents the release of IC Ca2+

Question:
You are a 2nd year medical student on placement at a GP surgery. One of the patients has kindly agreed to come in so you and the other students can practice an abdominal examination on him. When palpating the abdominal aorta, you are sure you can feel a large expansile pulsation rather than pulsatile. You tell the GP this, and she checks herself, and agrees that it is expansile. She auscultates the patients abdominal aorta and remarks that there is a bruit. She sends him to A&E immediately, suspected an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

 

Once everyone has recovered from the drama, the GP asks you why the aorta is predisposed to an aneurysm more than any other vessel in the body?
OptionA: Because the aorta is the longest artery in the body
OptionB: Because the aorta is the artery with the greatest wall tension
OptionC: Because the aorta is the most susceptible to damage from trauma
OptionD: Because coarctation of the aorta can lead to an aneurysm
OptionE: Because the aorta is the vessel with the greatest cross-sectional area
Explanation:
(Again, sorry for a haemodynamics question!)

 

LaPlace's Law states that in a cylindrical vessel

 

T is directly proportional to P r

Where T = wall tension, P = pressure, r = radius.

 

The aorta is the artery with the greatest wall tension (therefore greatest pressure and radius - in a person who is lying down). 

What is wall tension? Think of blowing up a balloon, as you increase the radius the wall tension also increases, and eventually it bursts.

 

Therefore if the radius, wall tension and pressure increase, eventually this will lead to an aneurysm.

Because the aneurysm has a great radius, its wall tension will be greater than that of surrounding normal vessel segments. 

 

If the vessel enlarges, wall tension increases and the vessel is more likely to burst, leading to a dissecting aneurysm which is a medical emergency.

 

Abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAAs) are more common than their thoracic counterpart. One reason for this is that elastin, the principal load-bearing protein present in the wall of the aorta, is reduced in the abdominal aorta as compared to the thoracic aorta. Another is that the abdominal aorta does not possess vasa vasorum, the nutrient-supplying blood vessels within the wall of the aorta. Most AAA are true aneurysms that involve all three layers (tunica intima, tunica media and tunica adventitia). The prevalence of AAAs increases with age, with an average age of 65–70 at the time of diagnosis. AAAs have been attributed to atherosclerosis, though other factors are involved in their formation.

 

Before rupture, an AAA may present as a large, expansile mass above the umbilicus. A bruit may be heard from the turbulent flow in the aneurysm. Unfortunately, however, rupture may be the first hint of AAA. Once an aneurysm has ruptured, it presents with classic symptoms of abdominal pain which is severe, constant, and radiating to the back.

What is the single best intervention to improve Mrs Thomas' frailty status?
OptionA: Contact her family and suggest that she needs to be in a care home
OptionB: Monitor her for another 3 months and then reassess frailty
OptionD: Assess her gait speed and grip strength
OptionE: Assess her situation at home and if she requires it, make modifications to her house
Explanation:
C is correct according to the frailty tutorial. This intervention could help to improve frailty status.

D and E would be part of C but you wouldn't do them by themselves.

Question: Young Yograj has been through it all, from abdominal pain to witnessing a miscarriage to being dropped by Gucci's modelling agency. However, Yograj was picked up by Calvin Klein, so all is well with the world. To his poor luck, Yograj recently started to feel chest pain. It is a dull ache at first and then it becomes a sharp, stabbing pain. The pain is worst with inspiration and lying down but is made better with leaning forward. From the history, the Abu Dhabian Cardiologist has an idea of what it might be, but performs a 12 lead ECG to confirm the diagnosis. What is most likely to be seen in the 12 Lead ECG of the forehead supermodel Yograj?

Question: What is the function of the anterior spinocerebellar tract that ends in the right sided cerebellum?
OptionE: Left Sided Upper and Lower limb proprioception
Explanation: The ventral (anterior) spinocerebellar tract starts from golgi tendon organs  and end in the Ipsilateral cerebellum. It provides proprioception to the ipsilateral Caudal Aspect of the body and legs. The posterior spinocerebellar tract does the same more or less but also involves muscle spindles.

Question:
You are observing a post mortem of a 19 year old male with the pathologist. The patient died a few days ago. His notes reveal that he suddenly collapsed whilst playing basketball and sadly, the paramedics were unable to save him.

 

When you get to the heart during the post mortem, it looks quite dilated and you can see yellow fatty deposits in and around the heart. On the inside of the heart there are lots of trabeculae, more than normal.

 

What is the most likely cause for this young persons death?
Explanation: E is correct - fibre fatty infiltration of the RV with hypertrabeculation.
