Question:
Yograj senior was diagnosed with Alzeimer's dementia 5 years ago, he cognitive function has declined steadily since then. She has recently been put on a new medication. The name of the medication is_______

 

Yograj looked up the mechanism of action of said drug (as an inquisitive fellow) and found that it is a NMDA receptor antagonist.

 

What is the name of the drug?
Explanation:
A - CORRECT These drugs are used in dementia as they slow down excitotoxicity in the brain. Damaged neurones in Alzheimer's can die, releasing their stores of glutamate which if the NMDA is not blocked, can lead to excitotoxity and even neuronal death

B - This is an anticholinesterase drug also used in Alzheimer's

C - This is an anticholinesterase drug also used in Alzheimer's

D - This is an atypical antipsychotic

E - This is a typical antipsychotic

Question: You're in Kasturi. You get talking to a husband and wife who are also regulars. You find out that the huspand takes medication for depression. A while later, after the husband has tucked into one of Kasturis delighttful Saag Paneers (a very cheesy dish), he starts to complain of a severe headache. You throw your Naga aside and assess his blood pressure which you find to be exceptionally high. Which anti-depressant is he likely to be on?
Explanation:
This presentation is characteristic of a hypertensive crisis.This is due to sympathetic overstimulation. In this case, Phenylzine is the most likely answer as it is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor. Monoamine oxidase is an intracelluar enzyme (associated to the mitochondrial outer membrane) responsible for regulating the concentrations of 5HT and NA in nerve terminals as well as the inactivation of certain amines. Tryamine is present in cheese. If Phenylzine is ihbibiting MAO (monoamine oxidase) then tryamine concentrations will rise. Tryamine will then act as a neurotransmitter to cause the headache and hypertension.

A- is a TCA used to treat neuropathic pain. Common side effects are drowsiness, dry mouth, blurred vision and constipation.

B, C and E- SSRI. Side effects are fever, N+V. Due to the risk of suicidal ideation in adolescents, fluoxetine is the only one licened for use in adolescents. Citalopram has a risk of Long QT.

Question: What type of abnormality is shown below?
Explanation:
This is the characteristic CT image of an Extradural haemorrhage – the bleed has a classic ‘lens’ shape.

See case 16 unconscious patient lecture

Question: What is the cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism?
Explanation:
Renal failure is the cause of secondary hyperparathyoroidism.

Primary hyperparathyoroidism most often occurs due to intrinsic pathology of the parathyroidgland, and the most common cause of this is benign adenoma.

Hyperplasia and malignant tumours would cause primary hyperparathyoroidism, but these are very rare.

Question: Orthostatic hypertension occurs when a person moves from lying to standing; causing blood to pool in the veins, and therefore less blood returns to the heart. This decreases cardiac output and so, blood pressure decreases also. How does the body respond to this situation?
OptionA:
↑ afferent activity to the medulla

↓ parasympathetic activity

↑ sympathetic activity

↓ heart rate
OptionB:
↓ afferent activity to the medulla

↑ parasympathetic activity

↓ sympathetic activity

↓ heart rate
OptionC:
↑ afferent activity to the medulla

↑ parasympathetic activity

↓ sympathetic activity

↑ heart rate
OptionD:
↑ afferent activity to the medulla

↑ parasympathetic activity

↓ sympathetic activity

↓ heart rate
OptionE:
↓ afferent activity to the medulla

↓ parasympathetic activity

↑ sympathetic activity

↑ heart rate
Explanation:
The correct answer is E.

 

Baroreceptor reflex is responsible for the short-term regulation of blood pressure. These receptors are constantly monitoring the blood pressure and sending messages to the medulla. There are baroreceptors located in the;

  • Carotid sinus; at the bifurcation of the external and internal carotid sinuses. Baroreceptors located here fire impulses via its afferent fibres of CN IX to the nucleus tractus solitarus (NTS) in the medulla. 
  • Aortic arch; the baroreceptors here fire impulses via its afferent fibres of CN X to the nucleus tractus solitarus in the medulla.

 

Firing to the medulla via these afferent fibres stimulates the parasympathetic activity of the medulla which acts to decrease heart rate.

 

If there is no firing to the medulla, then sympathetic activity takes over which increases heart rate, increases the total peripheral resistance of arterioles, and promotes venous constriction.

 

Therefore to put it simply;

Firing to medulla = decreases blood pressure

No firing to medulla = increases blood pressure

 

If unable to prevent a change in MABP within several hours, the reflex will reset to maintain pressure are the new level. 

 

Keeping these 2 equations in mind: MAP = CO x TPR and CO = SV x HR, we can see how the MAP is controlled in 2 ways:

  1. Autonomic Nervous System

Parasympathetic - via M2 receptors in the heart, will decrease the HR (↓ BP)

Sympathetic - B1 adrenoceptors increase heart rate, increase stroke volume (by its stimulation of renin), and A1 receptors increase TPR as it causes vasoconstriction (↑ BP)

 

     2. Hormones

 

Angiotensin II - increases TPR by constricting vessels, increases aldosterone which increases Na+ and H2O retention therefore increasing preload, and increasing stroke volume (↑ BP)

ADH - facilitates retention of water, therefore increases plasma volume, increases preload, increases stroke volume (↑ BP)

ANP - produced by the right atrium, causes Na+ loss therefore decreases stroke volume (↓ BP)

 

If MAP = CO x TPR , if a person has low blood pressure (as is in the scenario), what can the medulla do?

 

  •  ↑ CO by ↑ HR (via the sympathetic B1) and inhibiting parasympathetic (via m2 receptors)
  •  ↑ TPR by stimulating a1 receptors

Question: Give the name of structure 2
Explanation:
1.Hippocampus

2. Caudate nucleus

3. Corpus callosum

4. Lateral ventricle

5. Third ventricle

6. Fourth ventricle

Question: What is the blue part of the brain?
In which phases do Early After Depolarisation and Delayed After Depolarisation occur?
OptionA:
Early After Depolarisation: 2 or 3

Delayed After Depolarisation: 3 or 4
OptionB:
Early After Depolarisation: 1 or 2
Delayed After Depolarisation: 3 or 4
OptionC:
Early After Depolarisation: 1 or 2
Delayed After Depolarisation: 2 or 3
OptionD:
Early After Depolarisation: 2 or 3
Delayed After Depolarisation: 4 or 1
Explanation:
Option A

 

After depolarisations are like ectopic beats. Because Action Potentials are lengthened, membrane isn't repolarised, so membrane potential stays high. This allows another Action potential to be generated.

 

Early After Depolarisation: Occurs in late Phase 2 or 3. More likely to occur when the length of the Action potential is increased. Calcium channel blockers can fix this by reducing the action potential length.

 

 

Delayed After Depolarisation: Occurs in late Phase 3 or early Phase 4 when Action potential is almost repolarised. It is associated with high levels of Calcium causing rapid depolarisations.

 

Source: CV Physiology

Question:
Dan Tyson, a 35 year old man, visits your GP clinic complaining of shortness of breath and syncope. You look at his past medical history on the computer and see that 8 months ago, Dan suffered from acute viral myocarditis. You check the serology lab report, and it says:

 

Positive for +ssRNA Coxsackievirus 

 

You send Dan to A&E, where he has a echocardiogram performed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
First, let's go through systolic and diastolic dysfunction.

 

  • Systolic dysfunction is where there is an abnormal reduction in ventricular emptying due to impaired contractility or excessive afterload.                                      -    Pressure factors: if the heart has to work against increased pressure in the systemic arteries (aorta), TPR increases leading to an increase in afterload. The heart compensates by pumping harder to overcome the increased afterload, thus developing hypertrophy (concentric)

          -    Volume factors: if there is an increased end diastolic volume (such as in aortic insufficiencies - increased back flow into left ventricle OR mitral                                  insufficiencies - flow back into atrium), the heart will respond by working harder as volume increases, therefore afterload is normal, and this leads to hypertrophy (eccentric).

 

  • Diastolic dysfunction is where the is a decrease in ventricular compliance during the filling phase of the cardiac cycle due to changes in tissue stiffness or impaired ventricular relaxation; the consequence is a diminished Frank-Starling mechanism. (Frank-Starling states greater the force of the stretch, the greater the force of contraction).    

Cardiomyopathy is disease intrinsic to the myocardial fibres. There are three basic types:

  1. Dilated Cardiomyopathy
  • This is the most common form of cardiomyopathy, where there is ventricular dilation w/only a modest hypertrophy which is less than appropriate for the degree of dilation.
  • As the ventricle chamber is dilated, this forces the heart to work in an impaired manner.
  • The heart muscle weakens and becomes floppy.
  • It can be of idiopathic cause, alcohol-related, drug-related (such as adriamycin), viral myocarditis - coxsackie B, or pregnancy-related.
  • It can occur for the right side of the heart, or left, or both.
  • Systolic dysfunction, despite compensations via Frank-Starling and increased contractility.
  • The diastolic (filling) functions remain intact and helps compensate for the chamber dilation
  • Compensation also includes increased sympathetic stimulation to myocardium.
  • Further dilation over time and mitral and tricuspid failure enhances systolic dysfunction, which eventually leads to complete failure.

     2. Restrictive Cardiomyopathy

  • Uncommon, caused by diseases that produce restriction of cardiac filling during diastole.
  • There is decreased ventricular compliance with diastolic dysfunction and a decrease in ventricular cavity size
  • Increased filling pressures lead to left and right sided congestion
  • Ventricular hypertrophy may or may not be present
  • Systolic function maintained close to normal, therefore normal contractility.
  • Aetiology: sarcoidosis or amyloidosis, in which there is deposition of granulomatous material in the heart, thus decreasing compliance and affecting diastolic function

      3. Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy

  • Hereditary - autosomal domininant (>50% of the cases), or can be idiopathic
  • Septal (banana-shaped) or left ventricular hypertrophy is unrelated to pressure overload
  • Increased synthesis of actin and myosin can lead to asymmetrical hypertrophies and decreased compliance affecting diastolic function
  • Diastolic dysfunction is due to increased muscle stiffness and impaired relaxation
  • Asymmetric hypertrophy of the septum is most common, often resulting in a restriction of the ventricular outflow tract and pulmonary congestion.
  • May be related to septal fibre disarray.

Please correct me if I'm wrong on anything. I wasn't 100% sure whether dilated CM has systolic or diastolic dysfunction, my notes say systolic but could be wrong!

Question: You are on placement and the consultant asks you to interpret a chest x-ray of a 74 year old male. You notice at the base of the lung there are some horizontal lines, somewhere in the back of your mind you remember learning about these in second year. What would these lines most likely represent?
Explanation: These horizontal lines are known as 'Kerley Lines' and are an indicator of Interstitial Pulmonary Oedema

Question: Erythema nosodum is associated with ..........? and it will be .....  to the pattern of the activity of the disease?
Explanation: Answer is A, erythema nosodum associated with crohns and will have parallel pattern with the activity of the disease, the skin lesion more common in ulcerative colitis is pyoderma gangrenosum.

Question: You see a patients spirometry results and you see that they have a reduced FEV1:FVC ratio. Which diagnosis is most likely?
Explanation:
The FEV1:FVC ratio is reduced in obstructive diseases, because FEV1 is reduced but FVC is normal.

In restrictive lung diseases both FVC and FEV1 are both reduced so the ratio is normal. 

All the options except for COPD are examples of restrictive lung diseases.

Question: You are on placement in a GP with atopic asthma. Which of the following is not a trigger for atopic asthma?
Explanation:
Atopic asthma is asthma that is triggered by the environment, triggers include:

  • smoking
  • strong smells and odours
  • pollen
  • mould
  • animals
  • dust mites

Coughing is a symptom of asthma not a trigger
Tags: Public Health, First year, Respiratory Medicine, Case 5

Question:
You are working in a busy A&E ward and are one hour away from finishing your shift and are excited to rush home and watch the latest episode of Game of Thrones before other people on the ward spoil it for you.


Suddenly, a 63 year-old man is rushed in complaining of severe difficulty breathing. When taking a history, the patient complains of feeling exhausted, although he blames this on not being able to sleep very well for the past few months. He also mentions that he has had type 2 diabetes for 10 years but emphasises that he is well controlled on metformin. He is not asthmatic. On examination, you find severe peripheral oedema, an apex beat that is slightly shifted to the left, a murmur that radiates to the carotids, and bi-basal crackles on approximately 60% of the lung bases.

 

You run an urgent test for U+E's and get the following results:
Sodium - 160mmol/L (135-145mmol/L)
Pottasium - 3.8mmol/L (3.5 - 5mmol/L)
Chloride - 99mmol/L (95-110mmol/L)
Urea - 2.8mmol/L (2.5-6.5mmol/L)
Albumin - 40 (35-50)
Creatinine - 98 (60-120)
Calcium - 2.31 (2.12 - 2.65)
Protein - 73 (60-80)


What is the best choice for initial treatment?
Explanation:
This patient shows signs of left-sided heart failure.

 

1. NOT BISOPROLOL (BETA-BLOCKER) - Beta blockers are contraindicated in unstable heart failure and because of the patient's symptoms and oedema it is unstable. Use of beta-blockers can worsen unstable heart failure as they reduce the activity of a heart that is already not pumping enough. Beta-blockers are involved in first-line treatment in stable heart failure.

 

2. RAMIPRIL (ACE INHIBITOR) - ACE inhibitors are the mainstay of the first-line treatment of heart failure. The patient is not asthmatic so ACE inhibitors should be OK.

 

3. FUROSEMIDE & NOT SPIRONOLACTONE - Furosemide is used most often to get rid of severe peripheral oedema while spironolactone is used as the first-line diuretic in heart failure patients who are fairly stable but whose heart failure is slowly worsening. Furosemide may be given at a lower dose or even switched to a weaker diuretic such as spironolactone when the worst of the odemea is gone.

 

All diuretics can mask hypoglycaemia and so should be used with caution in diabetics but loop diuretics, like furosemide, are not as bad as thiazide diuretics, like spironolactone, at this and so furosemide will be preferred Furosemide is contraindicated in patients in renal failure but this patient doesn't show signs of renal failure. There is sodium retention which is normal in heart failure patients. The patient is not hypokalemic and so furosemide should be ok.

 

ACE inhibitors can increase the risk of hypoglycaemia and so a low dose should be used both to avoid this and the severe hypotension often seen with first dose of ACE inhibitors. The hyperglycaemic effect of furosemide should partly combat the risk of hypoglycaemia seen from ACE inhibitors.

 

4. NOT DIGOXIN - Digoxin is used as a third-line treatment in patients where initial treatment with ACE-inhibitors, beta-blockers and diuretics are ineffective or not tolerated.

 

Most information taken from BNF and NICE pathways for heart failure management.

Question: You are on GP placement and see a patient with a mild case of conjuctivitis. You know that one antibiotic is commonly used topically for eye infections, and it interferes with bacterial protein synthesis.What is this antibiotic?
Explanation:
Azithromycin is often used for chlamydia, mycoplsma (both don't have proper cell walls) and legionella (intracellular)

Doxycycline can also be used for bacteria without proper cell walls and as a penicillin replacement.

Gentamicin is used for gram negative bacteria: staph, pseudomonas, e coli, neisseria.

Penicillin isn't an inhibitor of protein synthesis, it inhibits cell wall formation.

 

This is a good resource: https://meducation.net/resources/31898-Antibiotic-therapy

Question: Despite what Geeky Medics has told you about the significance of the dimples (Love dimples of Venus) found on your back. What are you actually feeling for?
Explanation: Mr Mike McCarthy clarified this during the Back Masterclass.

Question: As Staph Aureus is the most common cause of infections in our spine, Which antibiotic of choice would we use for treating Staph Aureus?
Explanation: For Staph Aureus its always flucloxacillin. Unlike other penicillins, flucloxacillin has activity against beta-lactamase-producing organisms such as Staphylococcus aureus as it is beta-lactamase stable. However, it is ineffective against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).

Question: Which antibiotic do you use to treat Chlamydia?
Explanation: For chlamydia, you would always use either doxycycline or azithromycin.

You are watching a debate about Brexit. You don't really care that much and are only interested in Europe with regards to your Panini Euro 2016 sticker collection and the Channel Tunnel.

Question: Which receptor does an Angiotensin Receptor Blocker block?
Explanation: AT1R is blocked so AII can bind to AT2R, which has the opposing effects of AT1R

Question: Which of the following ionic currents is responsible for phase 0 of the SAN action potential?
Explanation: ICa-L current is responsible for SAN phase 0. This is a long acting Calcium channel that works via the CaV1.3 channels (activates at a slightly more negative potential compared to the CaV1.2 channel of the Ventricles) and is responsible for SAN action potential depolarisation. Note that there are no fast sodium channel active in the SAN AP.

Question:
Hannah Baker, a 31-year-old first time Mum, presents to her GP with her 1-year son, as she is concerned that he hasn't yet called her 'Mummy'. She explains that he hasn't once said a coherent word but continually 'babbles'.

 

The GP explains to Hannah that there may be some language delay but that this isn't uncommon.

 

Which of the following is NOT a risk factor for language delay in infants?
Explanation:
Female Sex is NOT a risk factor for language delay - Male Sex is in fact a risk factor.

 

Common Risk Factors for Language Delay:

  • Male Sex
  • Poverty
  • Family History of language delays
  • Maternal Depression
  • Low birth weight
  • Prematurity
  • Low parental education

The patient seems to stabilised, your fellow junior doctor asks hands you the blood results and asks whether you think you should give the patient a KCL saline infusion.

 

What is the value of K+ of which you would NOT decide to infuse the patient with KCL?
Explanation: Colin Daylan's lecture on Diabetic Emergencies

Question:
A 25 year old patient, recently diagnosed with celiac disease, has gone away and done some research on the histology of her small intestine (like you do).

 

She is particularly interested in the enzymes produced by cells in the small intestine that help to fight viruses (again, like you do) and asks whereabouts defensin is secreted.

 

You recall from your PCS, case 3 and case 11 anatomy notes that she is referring to a type of cell called....?
Explanation:
• Crypts of Lieberkuhn: Secret inactivated pepsin, hydrochloric acid (to lower pH and activate pepsin) & mucus (to protect epithelial cells)

- Note that Paneth cells are found in the Crypts of Lieberkuhn

  • Brunner's Glands: Secrete alkaline fluid to protect duodenum from acidic content of chyme, provide an alkaline condition for intestinal enzymes to be active & lubricate intestinal walls

-  Note that these are only found in the duodenum

  • Payer's Patches: These are a bit like lymph nodes, only they are the intestine's mini version. They initiate the immune response in intestinal mucosa & prevent pathogen adhesion by secreting IgA.
  • Vasa Recta: These are straight arteries found in the intestine
  • Paneth Cells: This is the right answer! Yay! They also secrete lysozyme & PLA

Question: Which of the following arteries is occluded in lateral medullary syndrome?
How fast do axons regenerate in the PNS?

On assessing the waveform of the JVP of Mr Tumnus you discover that there is a clear increase in the peak of the V wave. Which of the following conditions is most likely to have lead to this abnormality?
Explanation:
An increased V wave peak is due to tricuspid regurgitation- a Rheumatic fever infection can cause endocarditis and so damage to the tricuspid valve causing tricuspid regurgitation. 

 

A: Amiodarone is a potassium channel blocker that is known to have side effects causing complete heart block, a complete heart block is A-V dissociation and would cause a bifid alpha wave on the waveform.

 

B: A pulmonary Embolism is most likely to have caused massive pulmonary hypertension this would cause a peaked A wave. 

 

C:Influenza along with many other chest infection/pneumonia viruses are known to cause constrictive pericarditis- this leads to an increased decent of the x and y lines of the waveform.

 

D: Renal Artery Stenosis is most likely to cause renal hypertension and so would probably not effect the JVP waveform.

Question:
As an avid procrastinator, you decide to search the 'BBC Good Food' website (whilst you still can) for some recipes to rustle up. You come across some fantastic recipes from TV chefs.

Which of the following chefs is most likely to develop Type 2 diabetes?
Explanation:
Unfortunately, everyones favourite TV Chef, Ainsley, (who is famed for his spicy meat) is most likely to develop type 2 diabetes out of these.

Carribean people are three times more likely to develop Type 2 diabetes compared to a Caucasian population.

Men are also twice as likely to develop the condition as opposed to women, hence why Ainsley is correct and not Rusty.

 

Mary Berry could be correct as she does make some cakes which are packed with sugar (yet taste delicious).

Question: At which of the following dates will a pregnant lady having an anomaly scan?
Explanation: Fetal anomaly scan occurs usually from 18 weeks to 20 weeks and 6 days

Question: Which facial nerve branch provides sensory innervation to the anterior 2/3 of the tongue?
Explanation:
The chorda tympani is a nerve that arises from the mastoid segment of the facial nerve carrying afferent special sensation from the anterior two-thirds of tongue via the lingual nerve as well as efferent parasympathetic secretomotor innervation to the submandibular and sublingual glands. (the parotid gland is supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve)

 

(note- also coming of the mastoid segment is the facial nerve branch to the stapedius)

 

Also the facial nerve gives rise to five terminal branches within the parotid gland. These branches innervate the muscles of facial expression:

 (Two Zulu's Bought My Car)

 

Temporal

Zygomatic

Buccal

Marginal Mandibular

Cervical

 

 

l

Question: A 41 year old male appears in your clinic following a progressive mental decline and behavioural symptoms. They also display signs of neurodegeneration through symptoms of alterations in muscle coordination. Following a familial history of Huntington's disease you he may be displaying the same condition. Which of the following is the cause of Huntington's disease?
OptionA: A mutation in the CFTR gene on long arm of chromosome 7
OptionB: A repeated section of the HTT gene on the short arm of chromosome 4
OptionC: A deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5 (del 5p)
OptionE: A mutation of the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome
Explanation:
A - Cystic Fibrosis
B - CORRECT
C - Cri du Chat
D - Down's Syndrome
E - Fragile X syndrome

 

Huntington's Disease is one of several trinucleotide repeat disorders which are caused by the length of a repeated section of a gene exceeding a normal range. The HTT gene is located on the short arm of chromosome 4 at 4p16.3.

 

It is a neurodegenerative genetic disorder that affects muscle coordination and leads to mental decline and behavioral symptoms. It follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.

Question: For which of the following NSAIDs is this the mechanism: irreversibly inhibits the COX domain of PGHS 1 and 2?
Explanation:
Aspirin is a irreversible inhibitor of the cox domain of PGHS 1 and 2.

Ibuprofen is a competitive inhibitor.

Question: A patient comes in to see you at a GP surgery, they have painful blisters all over their skin and in their mouth. They tell you that these blisters come and go in bouts. You suspect they have pemphigus and remember that is it an autoimmune condition, which structure is attacked by the immune system?
Explanation: Pemphigus is an autoimmune condition in which the immune system attacks desmosomes. This causes painful blisters all over the skin and in the mouth and throat. These blisters come and come in flare ups.

Question: What is the rate limiting step of glycolysis?
Explanation:
All the answers are rate limiting steps of a biochemical pathway:

A=Glycogenolysis

B=Hluconeogenesis

C=Beta Oxidation

D=The TCA cycle

E=Glycolysis- yay right answer!
Tags: PCS, PCS 1, Biochemistry, First year, tutorials

Question: Which of the following is most sensitive to skin stretch?
Explanation:
A-Sensitive to light touch discrimination between different shapes and textures

B-Most sensitive to light touch 

C-Secretes motilin 

D-Sensitive to skin stretch 

E-Takes up and processes microbial antigens

Question: In the gross CNS response to injury, reactive gliosis and scar formation occurs following a breach in the blood brain barrier. Which cells may be responsible for forming a plug over the injury lesion cavity?
Which cells in the body may express NogoA to prevent CNS axonal regeneration?

Mr Johnson comes to the GP for his check-up, he's had hypertension for many years and recently had a bad episode leaving him with very high blood volume. Which of the following should Mr Johnson's body naturally produce to dilate the afferent arterioles and increase his GFR to reduce his blood volume?
Explanation:
Prostaglandins, ANP, NO and kinins all act to dilate the afferent arteriole and so to increase GFR, aiming to naturally reduce his blood volume.

 

A, B and C would all increase afferent vasoconstriction and so would reduce GFR.

 

Spironolactone is not naturally produced by the body but is a diuretic that would probably b given to Mr Johnson to try and improve his symptoms by reducing Na+ reabsorption in the CD and so reaching his blood volume.

Question: What channel is mainly involved in the inherited LQT syndrome 1?
Explanation:
Iks is the current affected in LQTS 1. It runs through the Kv7.1 channels 

LQTS 1 is usually associated with exertional syncope, often swimming

Question: Whilst on placement with a CMHT you meet a 24 year old schizophrenic patient. He is well controlled and has insight into his condition. He describes the hallucinations he experienced as a positive symptom. Which modality is he most likely to have experienced hallucinations in?
Explanation:
C. 

Auditory hallucinations are more common than the other modalities in schizophrenia. They are often complex hallucinations consisting of spoken phrases, sentences or dialogue. Patients may describe hearing their own thoughts spoken aloud as they think them or as an echo, or patients may hear voice(s) speaking directly to them, or hear voice(s) talking about them in the 3rd person

Question: Which of the following personality types is associated with increased likelihood of health promoting behaviours (e.g. exercise) and decreased likelihood of health damaging behaviours (e.g. alcohol)?
Explanation:
These are "the big five" personality traits from the five factor model introduced by Goldberg, Costa and McCrae

 

Conscientiousness is associated with increased likelihood of health promoting behaviours and decreased likelihood of health damaging behaviours

Neuroticism is associated with dysregulation of the HPA axis - thus increasing likeliness of stress, anxiety and emotional states

OptionA: He is unable to produce defensin and so has a weakened immune response to bacteria and fungi

Brunner's gland secretions are alkali and as a result they neutralise chyme from the stomach

Question: You take in an elderly HIV patient you suspect has meningitis. He was diagnosed with AIDS six months ago but you are told he has no known allergies. CSF analysis confirms meningitis. With ceftriaxome already prescribed-what drugs should you add to best improve the patient's outcome?
Explanation:
From CNS infections lecture

This patient has AIDS-as is such is likely immunocompromised and thus the infection is likely listeria. 

AB treatment for this is Ceftriaxome, which he should have been given already, and amoxicillin/ampicillin ONLY.

Dexamethasone is an adjunct used for pneumococcal meningitis but actually worsens outcomes in meningococcal cases. It doesn't tend to be used in listeria cases either 

Vanomycin  is used if allergic to penicillin initially and possibly in listeria or streptococcus pneumonia meningitis instead of ceftriaxome

Question:
David, an 18 year old avid motorcyclist, was involved in a high speed crash in which he was thrown clear of his bike, landing on his spine. On examination, he has reduced neurological functions. After accounting for the effects of spinal shock, he is diagnosed with a T5 spinal cord injury.

 

In terms of neurological functioning and the level of the injury, what does this diagnosis mean?
OptionA: He has useful partial neurological function >1/5 at the level of T5
OptionB: He has useful partial neurological function >2/5 at the level of T5
OptionC: He has useful partial neurological function >3/5 at the level of T5
OptionD: He has useful partial neurological function >4/5 at the level of T5
OptionE: He has useful partial neurological function of 5/5 at the level of T5
Explanation:
The answer is:

 

C) He has useful partial neurological function >3/5 at the level of T5

 

The level of spinal Injury is defined as the First level with useful partial neurological function >3/5.

Although both answers D) and E) are possible, (i.e he may have either 4/5 or 5/5 neurological function at T5 and above) this is not the diagnostic criteria of a spinal cord injury.

(Taken from Serious Spinal Pathology 1 lecture, Case 14)

 

Side note: Try not to crash whilst riding a bike: you may hurt yourself

Question: In which layer of large blood vessel walls are the vasa vasorum found?
Explanation:
In larger vessels the tunica adventitia contain small blood vessels – the vasa vasorum - which supply blood to the tunica media

In smaller vessels blood reaches the tunica media via diffusion

Question: Which of the following is one of Schneider's first rank symptoms of schizophrenia?
Explanation:
A reflex hallucination occurs when a true sensory stimulus causes an hallucination in another sensory modality.
Thought block is an experience of a sudden and unexpected interruption of the train of thought, often experienced by the patient as a 'snapping off'. It occurs in organic states, schizophrenia (as part of negative thought disorder) and depression. Thought blocking should be differentiated from 'losing one's train of thought' which often occurs when an individual is anxious or exhausted.
Flight of ideas describes the experience of one's stream of thought being faster than usual. Although there may be no direction or purpose of thinking, successive thoughts appear to be connected. It is often associated with mania.
Hypnopompic hallucinations occur as a person awakes. The hallucinatory experience continues once the individual's eyes open from sleep.

 

The first rank symptoms are:
1. Delusions:
2. Auditory hallucinations
3. Thought disorder

4. Passivity experienc
^ which means Passivity experiences – the patient believes that their movements, emotions or will is being altered in a similar way to the thought issues, for examples, they believe their movements are being controlled. -

See more at: http://almostadoctor.co.uk/content/systems/neurology-psychiatry/psychiatry/schizophrenia#sthash.S6oJCmcc.dpuf

Question:
A 59-year-old lady has developed a fear of public places such as markets, shops and pubs after breaking her hip during a fall while shopping with her husband. Her avoidance of these places has affected her social life and she now rarely leaves home.
Which of the following best describes her excessive fear and avoidance?
Explanation:
fear of aminals eg spiders --> agoraphobia

fear of being in a closed and confined space - claustrophobia.
Phobias can be associated with severe impairment in functioning, especially in agoraphobia and social phobia, when patients eventually end up confined to their homes and unable to leave anywhere.
Post-traumatic stress disorder occurs after an individual suffers from an event in which their life or safety (or that of someone else present) in placed in danger. This can result in intrusive memories and flashbacks of the event, on a background of emotional numbness.

Question:
James is a 22 year old student who has volunteered in a study about renal function. During this study. certain pressures in his kidney are recorded and are as follows:

 

Glomerular blood hydrostatic pressure: 55mmHg

Capsular hydrostatic pressure: 15mmHg

Blood colloid osmotic pressure: 30mmHg

 

Using these figures, what would James net filtration pressure be?
Explanation:
Net filtration pressure (NFP) = GBHP - (CHP +BLOP) therefore NFP = 55 - (30+15) = 10mmHg

 

Using this diagram to explain the basics behind filtration and reabsorption where;

Pc = hydrostatic pressure of capillary

Pif = hydrostatic pressure of the interstitial fluid

πc = osmotic pressure of the capillary

πif = osmotic pressure of the interstitial fluid

 

Any force that pushes fluid out of the capillary is forces FOR filtration, and any force that pushes fluid into the capillary is for reabsorption and OPPOSES filtration.

 

The hydrostatic pressure of the capillary, Pc, is the pressure of the fluid inside the capillary which PUSHED FLUID OUT and into the interstitial space. (PRO FILTRATION)

 

The osmotic pressure of the capillary, πc, is the pressure produced by the presence of proteins within the capillary which PULLS FLUID IN from the interstitial space into the capillary. (AGAINST FILTRATION)

 

The hydrostatic pressure of the interstitial fluid, Pif, is the pressure of the fluid in the interstitial space which PUSHES FLUID OUT and into the capillary (AGAINST FILTRATION)

 

The osmotic pressure of the interstitial fluid, πif, is the pressure produced by the presence of proteins within the interstitial space which PULLS FLUID IN from the capillary (PRO FILTRATION).

 

Therefore, the forces for filtration would be;

 

Hydrostatic pressure of the capillary + osmotic pressure of the interstitial fluid

And the forces for reabsorption would be;

 

Hydrostatic pressure of the interstitial fluid + osmotic pressure of the capillary

 

So if we apply this to the kidney;

 

  • Glomerular blood hydrostatic pressure is the pressure of the fluid in the glomerular capillaries which pushes fluid into the capsular space and is therefore PRO FILTRATION (roughly around 55mmHg/8kPa)
  • Capsular hydrostatic pressure is the pressure of the fluid already present in the capsular space which pushes fluid into the capillaries and opposes the filtration forces (roughly around 15mmHg/2.4kPa)
  • Blood colloid osmotic pressure is the pressure from the presence of proteins (such as albumins, globulins and fibrinogens in the blood plasma) within the glomerular capillaries which also opposes the filtration forces by pulling fluid from the capsular space (roughly around 30mmHg/4.3kPa)

(Note; because proteins are not filtered into the capsular space in normal kidney function, there will be no osmotic pressure of the capsule)

 

Therefore to calculate net filtration pressure: forces for filtration - forces opposing filtration = GBHP - (CHP + BCOP)

 

The answer, 10mmHg, is the pressure that causes a normal amount of blood plasma (minus plasma proteins) to filter from the glomerulus into capsular space.

 

In some kidney diseases, if the glomerular capillaries are damaged, they become so permeable that they leak plasma proteins into the glomerular filtrate. This this results in the glomerular filtrate exerting a colloid osmotic pressure that draws water out of the blood thus increasing net filtration pressure, so more fluid is filtered.

At the same time, the blood colloid osmotic pressure decreases because its plasma proteins are being leaked out into the filtrate and lost to urine. As more fluid is filtered out of the blood capillaries and into tissues throughout the body than returns via reabsorption, blood volume decreases and interstitial fluid volume increases, leading to oedema.

Question: John is 40 years old and has been diagnosed with a brain tumour. At his routine doctors appointment he feels fine and is asymptomatic. They measure his intracranial pressure at 12cmH2O. A few days later he gets a severe headache, starts vomiting and has diplopia. He goes to the doctor and they say that the tumour has now grown so much that his head cannot compensate anymore. What is his new intracranial pressure?
Explanation: According to the Monro kellie doctrine any increase in one of the components must be at the expense of the other two. this means that up until 20cmH2O the head can compensate by excluding CSF and venous blood (and to a lesser degree squashing the brain). However as as the ICP reaches 20cmH2O the Monro-Kelli doctrine can no longer compensate .

Question: You are on placement with an ophthalmologist and are about to see a patient who has been referred with a suspected complete right sided 3rd nerve palsy. Before the patient enters the room the ophthalmologist asks what signs this patient might present with?
OptionA:
Ptosis of the right eye

Eye turned out and down

Fixed and constricted pupil
OptionB:
Ptosis of the left eye

Eye turned out and down

Fixed and dilated pupil
OptionC:
Ptosis of the right eye

Eye turned in and down

Fixed and dilated pupil
OptionD:
Ptosis of the right eye
Eye turned out and down
Fixed and dilated pupil
OptionE:
Ptosis of the right eye

Eye turned out and down

Normal pupil reflexes
Explanation:
The oculomotor nerve supplies all the muscle in the eye except for the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Contraction of the lateral rectus pulls the eye outwards while contraction of the superior oblique muscle intorts the eye. Normally the muscles of the eye balance each other out and the eye remains central. However a 3rd nerve palsy would disrupt the balance and only the action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique would remain and the eye would look out and down.

 

The 3rd nerve also controls the muscles of the eyelid as well as the iris sphincter muscle - hence why there is ptosis and dilation of the pupil

 

 

 

Common causes of 3rd nerve palsies:


Aneurysm of posterior communicating artery

Infarction of 3rd nerve (diabetics)

Midbrain infarction or tumour

Question: You are reading some information about statins, it tells you the absolute risk difference is 0.02. What is the number needed to treat for statins?
Explanation:
Number needed to treat= 1/ absolute risk difference

The ARD for statins was 0.02.

So NNT was 1/0.02 which equals 50.

Question:
Cataplexy is a condition often associated with narcolepsy.  It is characterised by sudden, transient, weakness of muscles, and is often triggered by strong emotions, such as laughing.  

This condition is caused by the autoimmune destruction of which neurotransmitter?
Explanation:
Correct answer:

 

E - Orexin - Also known as hypocretin, this neurotransmitter regulates arousal and wakefulness.  The neurones that produce it extend from the lateral hypothalamus.  Whilst the destruction of the neurotransmitter is usually autoimmune, you can also get secondary cataplexy.  This can occur after a lesion in the brain, usually the lateral and posterior hypothalamus, causes a depletion in the production of orexin.
Tags: Sleep, Case 12, Mental Health, Neurochemistry, Neurotransmitters

Question: You may or may not recall that Yograj's sister had a miscarriage a few years ago. As you may already know, she managed to get pregnant again. Yograj's sister was fortunate to have a happy and healthy pregnancy. However, when baby Jragoy was born, he was found to have Hyaline Membrane Disease. URGH. What is the main implication of this illness on young Jragoy's respiratory system?
OptionA: Thickening of the airway's basement membrane which will lead to difficult expiration
OptionB: Lack of hyaline on trachea and bronchi which will lead to frequent bronchospasms
OptionC: Surfactant deficiency which will lead to reduced lung compliance
OptionD: Lack of hyaline on trachea and bronchi which will lead to reduce lung compliance
OptionE: Hyaline deposition in lung spaces  which will lead to a dangerous increase in lung compliance
Explanation:
Hyaline membrane disease is surfactant deficiency. If baby Jragoy doesn't have surfactant then his alveoli surface tension will increase. This means that a greater pressure is required to move a certain volume of air in(or out) of the lungs. This is a reduced compliance. 

 

Compliance = change in volume/change in pressure

Question:
You are the on-call doctor in A&E when you see Adam Reynolds, a 55 year old man, who presents with half and hour of "crushing" chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea and pain in his left arm. You suspect this man is having a myocardial infarction. You perform a 12 lead ECG on Adam, and it confirms that he has had an inferior myocardial infarction.

 

What is the most common vessel occluded in an inferior MI? And what leads would you see the ST elevation in?
OptionA:
Occlusion of RCA (right coronary artery)

STE in II, III & aVF
OptionB:
Occlusion of LAD (left anterior descending artery)

STE in V1 & V2
OptionC:
Occlusion of LAD (left anterior descending artery)

STE in V3 and V4
OptionD:
Occlusion of LCX (left circumflex artery)

STE in V1 & V2
OptionE:
Occlusion of RCA (right coronary artery)

STE in I, aVL, V5 & V6
Explanation:
• Inferior MIs account for 40-50% of all myocardial infarctions.
  • Generally have a more favourable prognosis than anterior myocardial infarction (in-hospital mortality only 2-9%), however certain factors indicate a worse outcome.

How to recognise an inferior MI on an ECG:

  • STE in lead II, III and aVF
  • STD in aVL

Which artery is the culprit?

  • The vast majority (~80%) of inferior STEMIs are due to occlusion of the dominant right coronary artery (RCA).
  • Less commonly (around 18% of the time), the culprit vessel is a dominant left circumflex artery (LCx).

An example of an ECG for an inferior MI (you can see the STE in II, III and aVF):

 

 

If you're like me and think how the bloody hell am I gonna learn leads and all that, i've found the combination of this table and (giant) picture quite helpful in understanding it!

 

 

 

B = septal MI

C = anterior MI

D = posterior MI (but should be STD in V1 and V2, not STE)

E = lateral MI (but should be occlusion of LAD not RCA)

Question:
Darcy is a 52 year old teacher who has been diagnosed with breast cancer 8 months ago. She presented to A&E with weakness in both her legs and sensory loss. She also had difficulty walking, and had not opened her bowels since the symptoms started. 

 

As a foundation doctor at A&E, what is the best thing to do for Darcy?

OptionD: Schedule an urgent MRI scan within 24 hours
OptionE: Assess her FBC, ESR, U&E, Ca and LFT

Darcy is showing symptoms of a Metastatic Spinal Cord Compression, which requires an urgent MRI scan of the whole spine within 24 hours

Question: One of your medic kids calls you just before their second case 8 group discussion to ask you for one reason a woman would be allowed to have a C-section on the NHS. You reply:
OptionA: Breech presentation prior to external cephalic version
OptionD: Mother has HIV- on HAART with a viral load 350 copies/ml
Explanation:
Breech may be an indication but only if external cephalic version is denied or fails

Hep C alone isnt an indication but co infection with Hep C AND HIV is an indication

HIV is an indication but only if the woman has a high viral load such as over 400 copies/ml

Multiple pregnancy is an indication only if one of the children is breech

Question: You are on placement in a GP surgery and are visited by Luke, an 18 year old man in between school and university. He is concerned as over the past few days he has pain on urination and an unpleasant greenish-yellow discharge from his urethra. He informs you that during the summer since leaving school he has had multiple sexual partners, most of whom he claims to have impressed with dates to Kasturi. What is your most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
B is correct, the most likely infection is gonorrhoea.

 

A - Primary syphilis would present with a syphilitic chancre

B - correct, dysuria and a greenish-yellow discharge are symptoms of gonorrhoea

C - is obviously wrong

D - Possible, though the colour of the discharge would suggest gonorrhoea. Co-infection is possible but the coloured discharge would be a consequence of gonorrhoea.

E - H. Simplex infection would present with systemic symptoms and painful, shallow ulcers.

Question:
You are on a case 9 placement with Joe, a boring American Football fan who rambles on about it a little too much and is a second year medic like yourself. In a break after a discussion about measles symptoms, Joe talks at you about American football except you don't care like everyone else. As you start to fall into a boredom coma, you realise he isn't talking about the Super Bowl but instead is talking about a classification system named after a place in America and how measles fits into this classification system.

 

What is the name of the virus classification system and what class is the measles virus?
Explanation:
It is the Baltimore Classification system that Joe is eluding to and is as follows:


Group I: double-stranded DNA viruses
Group II: single-stranded DNA viruses
Group III: double-stranded RNA viruses
Group IV: positive-sense single-stranded RNA viruses
Group V: negative-sense single-stranded RNA viruses
Group VI: reverse transcribing single-stranded RNA viruses
Group VII: reverse transcribing  double-stranded DNA viruses

 

The measles virus is a single-stranded, negative-sense, enveloped (non-segmented) RNA virus and would thus be a Group V

 

The groupings can be remembered that DNA comes before RNA, that double goes before single, and positive before negative. And you'll just have to remember the last two

 

Good luck in your exams and good luck to Joe in his quest to find someone to listen to him! :)

Question:
During your S3 exam, you have a brain fart and cant remember what ARVC stands for

ARVC stands for Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Cardiomyopathy and is described as 'a condition mainly affecting the right ventricle characterised by fibro-fatty infiltration, ventricular dilation and hypertrabeculation.
Woman get it more than men by a 3:1 ratio
ECG presents with T wave inversion in V1-3

Reason I put this is because I kept forgetting

Question: What sunderland classification of injury may require an internal neurolysis procedure?

Your medic parents organise a party for your medic family (if they liked you enough to do so) and make you drink lots. While taking one of your many trips to the bathroom, your medic brother tells you he had the weirdest thought pop into his head while we went for a pee! He says Penile Necrosis came into his mind and apart from being horrified, he cant remember what drugs cause this. You, having been on peerwise loads and revising so much you forgot what sunlight looked like, reply confidently saying the two drugs are...
Explanation:
Synergism between Warfarin and Heparin causes Penile necrosis as stated in Dr Coffeys lecture on Anti-Arrhythmic Drugs

 

Warfarin is a Vitamin K carboxylase Inhibitor with an antidote of giving Vit K itself (monitor using INR)
Heparin activates anti-thrombin III which inactivates thrombin and Factor Xa with an antidote of Protamine Sulphate (monitor using aPPT)
Apixaban and Rivaroxaban are NOACs and both are Factor Xa inhibitors--Another peerwise user suggested to remember their MOA by remembering both have Xa in their name thus inhibit Factor Xa which I thought was very useful!

 

Good luck in your exams
