Question: How long does it take for 1st degree neuropraxia to recover?
Which of the following adrenoreceptors uses Gq as their G-protein?
Explanation:
Activation of Gq proteins causes activation of Phospholipase C.

 

Phospholipase C catalyses the reaction which produces Diacyglycerol and IP3 from PIP2.

 

IP3 causes release of calcium from intracellular stores (endoplasmic reticulum)

 

DAG causes activation of protein kinase C. 

 

This is clinically relevant as this leads to smooth muscle contraction and hence most importantly vasoconstriction. 

 

Antagonism of this cascade is a mechanism of action of the anti-hypertensives Doxazosin and Prazosin.

Question:
There are rumours that in fact Tupac Shakur wasn't killed in his supposedly fatal drive by shooting and he is actually chilling out with Biggie on a beach somewhere. However, the shooting did cause Tupac a spinal cord injury. He has ipsilateral paralysis, ipsilateral loss of touch and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation.

 

What type of spinal cord syndrome does Tupac have?
Explanation:
Tupac has unfortunately got Brown-Sequard Syndrome and results in the symptoms mentioned above.

 

This is because the corticospinal tract is cut but as it has already crossed and is a descending pathway, results in a ipsilateral paralysis
As the lateral spinothalamic tract is cut and crosses immediately, it will result in CONTRALATERAL pain and temperature sensation loss. Imagine drawing the tract on yourself and you'll realise why this happens

 

More unfortunately, Tupac did actually die in his fatal shooting and Biggie was killed a year later. May they both rest in peace

Explanation: A is the most likely answer is this case. The BNF quote from the lecture is pretty self explanatory but keep in mind you shouldn't really prescribe anti depressants to children if it avoidable.

Question: Where is the hormone erythropoitin secreted from during pregnancy to increase red blood cell mass?
Explanation:
C- Kidney

EPO acts to prevent apoptosis of erythroid precursors in bone marrow increase RBC mass by up to 20%. Progesterone is thought to aid the precursor cells utilize EPO. The efficacy of EPO can be improved by iron supplementation. Its secretion begins to rise late in the first trimester to keep up with the increasing oxygen demand of the fetus

Question: Emily, a 26 year old lady is pregnant with her second child. She gave birth 3 years ago to a baby boy with Downs Syndrome. She is worried that her second baby may also have Downs Syndrome. She is only 8 weeks pregnant, and therefore is unable to have any screening tests done. She has gone in for genetic counselling and and brings a printed copy of her karyotype with her. The karyotype shows 21/21 Robertsonian translocation. What is the probability that her second child has Down's Syndrome?
Explanation: Emily only has 45 Chromosomes. Her two chromosome 21s have translocated, therefore her offsprings will inherit this translocated chromosome 21 and a normal one from the father. This means that her baby will have 3 portions of Chromosome 21. They will have Downs even though they only have 46 chromosomes

Question: You are in a histology practical and you see a slide from the small intestine, you can see peyers patches. Where is this sample most likely to be from?

Question: What direction and type of muscle fibres will you find in the subepicardial layer of the heart?
Explanation:
Both these sets of fibres are involved in the longitudinal function of the cardiac muscle. See the lecture but the heart basically acts in a twisting motion, like a towel, when it contracts and relaxes. Note in exercise, the rapid untwisting of the heart improves in response to training; so olympic athletes will have high, rapid untwisting of the longitudinal muscle.

 

The radial heart muscle is in-between these two layers per say and being radial means the fibres go across the heart. In heart failure, radial function may increase in HFPEF to counteract the decrease in longitudinal function that occurs in heart failure.

Question: Which of the following spinal pathologies are you most likely to treat with dexamethasone?
Explanation:
Spinal cord compression is an oncological emergency and affects up to 5% of cancer patients. Extradural compression accounts for the majority of cases, usually due to vertebral body metastases. It is more common in patients with lung, breast and prostate cancer

Features

  • back pain - the earliest and most common symptom - may be worse on lying down and coughing
  • lower limb weakness
  • sensory changes: sensory loss and numbness
  • neurological signs depend on the level of the lesion.
  • Lesions above L1 usually result in upper motor neuron signs in the legs and a sensory level. Lesions below L1 usually cause lower motor neuron signs in the legs and perianal numbness. Tendon reflexes tend to be increased below the level of the lesion and absent at the level of the lesion

Management

  • high-dose oral dexamethasone
  • urgent oncological assessment for consideration of radiotherapy or surgery

Question:
You are on placement in a genetic clinic, and you and the consultant see a couple with a baby, who all want to be tested as there has been a death in the family with possible genetic links. 

Later in the laboratory, you see the DNA testing being carried out. The technician reveals that the dad is not the real father of the baby (😲) because the light and dark bands of the chromosomes do not match.

What is the name of this feature?
Explanation:
G-banding is light and dark regions on chromosomes due to gienesa stain.

Dark regions have heterochromatin and are gene poor. Light regions have euchromatin and many genes.

Homologous chromosomes are a pair of sister chromosomes.

Karyotyping is revealing the whole chromosome complement.

Telomeres are regions on the end of chromosomes that degrade with replication.

 

Also- G-banding might not be tell if two people are related but it fitted in nicely

Explanation:

Question: Hypoparathyroidism is a lack of PTH which means there will be low Ca2+. It is usually iatrogenic and due to accident damage to the parathyroid glands in thyroid surgery. Which of the following is a symptom of hypocalcaemia?
Explanation:
A, C, D and E are all symptoms of HYPERparathyroidism, which results in hypercalcaemia. This is normally due to enlarged parathyroid glands, probs a benign adenoma so you get PTH hyper secretion.

 

Only B is a symptom of hypoparathyroidism. Muscle spasms are more commonly known as 'tetany'.

 

Hypocalcaemia also results in paraesthesia in the mouth and feet.

Question: The prognostic marker for heart failure is:
Explanation:
BNP and NT-proBNP are the diagnostic markers used for screening and diagnosis of heart failure.

 

BNP is more reliable than ANP

 

CRP- a product of inflammation produced by the liver : can be produced due to renal or hepatic injury in chronic heart failure. Similar reasons for cytokines.

From Diagnosis of Heart failure lecture, Case 15

Question:
A patient has come in to A+E complaining of right sided loss of vision.

Whilst in the waiting room the patient has developed lowered level of consciousness and on examination you observe right sided weakness, a fixed and dilated pupil in a 'down and out' motion in the left eye.

 

Following a MRI the consultant confirms a cerebral herniation.

Which of the following herniations is most likely to have caused the patients symptoms?
Explanation:
E is correct. 

The medial edge of the temporal lobe 'uncus' moves towards the tentorium and puts pressure on the midbrain. This affects the descending corticospinal and leads to CONTRAlateral hemiparesis (because the corticospinal tract decussates below at the midbrain). It also compresses CNIII - occulomotor nerve, affecting the parasympathetic supply (causing pupillary dilatation) and the muscles -losing innervation (except for the lateral rectus causing 'down and out').

Compression of the posterior cerebral artery by the herniation results in a CONTRAlateral homonymous hemianopsia (loss of vision)

 

 

A - INCORRECT symptoms would be small, dilated fixed pupils with paralysis of upward eye movement

B - INCORRECT cingulate herniation is the most common and is usually a precursor to other types. symptoms include abnormal posturing and coma

C - INCORRECT this is a CEREBELLAR herniation where the tonsils of the cerebellum squeeze downwards through the Foramen Magnum. symptoms include headache, head tilt, and neck stiffness

D- INCORRECT this is usually a result of a fracture in the skull or following a craniectomy.

Question: Which of the following are origins of the fasiculus gracilis pathway?
Explanation:
B is correct - Meissener's corpuscles (respond to light touch) and Pacinian corpuscles (respond to pressure) are sensory receptors in the skin which serve as origins of the dorsal column (fasciculus gracilis and cuneatus)

Vestibular nucleus is the origin of the vestibulospinal tract 

 

Red nucleus is the origin of the rubrospinal tract

Muscle spindles are another origin of the dorsal column tract but E is not correct as the Red nucleus is not

(As per a case 14 lecture)

Question:
Lloyd, a mature student, is feeling confident for his exams.

He decides to have a tattoo done on the day before his exam. He has to adhere to the dress code set by the university in his exam and he's worried the irritation of the beige chinos on the tattoo will probably cause pain.

The tattoo artist says he might feel deep, lasting pain for a few days. Lloyd tells the man "I know about this... I'm a medic" and he decides to tell him his understanding.

What is the name and description of this sensory fibre involved in the pain described?
Explanation:
A B & E are fictitious.

 

C- A Delta fibres send impulses a lot faster than C fibres.

They are thinly myelinated and have a larger diameter than C- both factors increase velocity. 

 

D - C fibres are non-myelinated. They have a smaller diameter than A Delta fibres.

 

aplologies on the units, I couldn't be bothered to find mu.
Tags: Case10, Pain, First year, Case 17, Year 1

Question:
A 10 year old boy presents in A&E with a two day history of diarrhoea, vomiting and crampy abdominal pain.

 

On taking a full history, you learn that he has sickle cell disease. 

 

His mother, who took him to A&E says that he went to a friends barbecue a couple of days ago and she is concerned that he may have eaten something dodgy.

 

You have a suspicion that this is food poisoning and you need to treat this patient quickly because you are aware of the complications that can occur from this in sickle cell patients.

 

What medication would you need to prescribe to this patient?
Explanation: D is correct - fluroquinolones should be used for Salmonella poisoning. Sickle cell patients are at risk of developing osteomyelitis.

Question: A 65 year old patient with colon cancer comes into see you in your oncology clinic. He asks you where the most likely place for a tumour to form is?

This characteristic eye movement is associated with damage in which specific area of the brain?
Explanation:
Ocular Bobbing is chacterised by rapid downward movements of both eyesfollowed by slow return of both eyes to the mid-line. It is usually seen in pontine lesions. 

 

NOTE: D is technically correct as the pons is part of the brainstem however the question does ask for which specific area so E is more correct

Question:
The Monro-Kellie hypothesis states that the volume within the skull is fixed so any increase in volume will be accompanied by a change in pressure. 

 

Mr Smith a single 35 year old male who has just been made redundant. He makes a failed attempt at suicide via paracetamol overdose and subsequently goes into acute liver failure.This results in general brain swelling and therefore increased intracranial pressure.

2) Increased Systolic Blood Pressure 

3) ????????????????
Explanation:
Cushing's Triad is a clinical triad seen as having 

1) Abnormal Respiratory Pattern
2) Bradycardia
3) Systolic hypertension 

 

Pressure on the brainstem or decreased perfusion of the brainstem

Question: A primagravida is having contractions every 20 minutes and her cervix is 5 cm effaced. What stage of labour is she most likely in?
Explanation:
This is a descripiton of a woman in stage 1/active stage of labour

 

  • Contractions are usually every 20 mins
  • Cervix is 4-10cm effaced 
  • C fibres responsible for pain

 

Latent phase/early phase

  • regular contractions
  • 3cm effaced

Stage 2/Delivery of baby

  • strong contractions every couple of minutes
  • Ad fibres responsible for pain

 

Stage 3/Delivery of placenta

 

Braxton Hicks contractions are experienced in late pregnancy due to the high progesteron concentration

Question: A 7-year old boy presents to A&E with extreme weakness, confusion and vomiting. He appears extremely drowsy and are difficult to arouse. His mother tells you he has been complaining of abdominal pain and muscle cramps. He is severely dehydrated and hypotensive. He has no significant history except a recent chest infection. What medical emergency is most likely?
Explanation:
Correct answer = B. Addisonian crisis is an acute onset of adrenocortical insufficiency. It is often precipitated by infection, surgery or myocardial infarction. It's symptoms include confusion, weakness, nausea/vomiting, abdominal pain and muscle cramps/pain. Patients become dehydrated and hypovolaemic and may slip into coma. 

------------------------------

A - HHS. Occurs in type 2 diabetics which would be very very unlikely at his age.

C - Internal bleeding. Unlikely as no history of trauma.

D - Thyroid storm. Would present with very high temperature, tachycardia, hypotension, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain and confusion

E - Appendicitis. Would present with periumbilical pain, high temperature and nausea

Question: During labour, a midwife says she can see the baby crowning. What does she mean by this?
OptionA: The baby has turned to occiput anterior position
OptionB: The baby has descended into the pelvis
OptionC: The baby's head cannot be palpated in the abdomen
OptionD: The baby's head is under the pubic arch
OptionE: The baby's chin is tucked to its chest
Explanation:
D is the definition of crowning. At this point the baby's head is visable at the vulva (as the midwife has commented)

 

Mechanism of labour movements:

  • The baby descends into the pelvis (B)
  • The baby flexes- tucking the chin to the chest (E)
  • The baby internally rotates to the occiput anterior position just before crowning (A)
  • The baby is crowning as its occiput is now under the pubic arch (D)
  • The baby's head is born by extension 
  • The baby restitues (goes back to former position by externally rotating)
  • The baby internally rotates again
  • The baby's anterior shoulder goes under the pubic arch
  • The baby's posterior shoulder goes under the pubic arch
  • The baby laterally flexes its body 

Do Frogs In Cardiff Ever Ride In A Pink Limo

 

The midwife may have previously commented that "the head's engaged". In foetal head engagement: 

  • The baby has descended into the pelvis (at its widest diameter) (B)
  • The baby's head cannot be palpated in the abdomen (C)

Question:
In females, the development of oogonia to primary oocytes occurs before birth (~5months). Therefore, when the baby is born there are no oogonia left, all becoming primary oocytes that are meiotically active and arrested in a state of meiosis until puberty. Once puberty is reached, every month one oocyte continues meiosis until it reaches another meiotic state, and stops there until fertilised.

 

(1) What is the state that a primary oocyte is arrested in before puberty hits? (2) And what is the next state it is arrested in every month after puberty?
Explanation:
In female, oogonia develop into meiotically active primary oocytes before birth (~5m), and so no oogonia are left by the time the baby is born. These primary oocytes get to prophase I and stay in that status until puberty.

 

Once at puberty, every month, once oocyte continues meiosis until it reaches metaphase II and stops. If the secondary oocyte is not fertilised, it never progresses through meiosis and dies as a secondary oocyte in metaphase II.

 

If it is fertilised, it gives off a second polar body, forming an ovum, which then forms a zygote.

Question: What type of non ischaemic cardiomyopathy is best defined as 'a condition characterised by cardiac enlargement with reduced systolic function, absence of primary valve disease, and non-significant coronary artery disease'?

Johnny is a 55yo fireman and has a rather stressful job, during his last healthcare visit he discussed with the doctors his risk of a rare inherited form of cancer that runs in his family. The doctor explain to Johnny that as well as the increased genetic risk of this cancer his stressful job may also increase his risk. Which of the following is a correct explanation of why his cancer risk may be increased due to stress?
OptionA: A chronic increase in cytokine production which inhibits NKC action and phagocytosis
OptionB: An increase in MHCII production that will enable cancer cells to proliferate more rapidly within the body
OptionC: Decreased cortisol levels allowing the cancer to reduce chemotaxis and detection
OptionD: Increased IL2 levels so that the cancer can evade the body's natural immune response
OptionE: Increased TNF alpha levels will inhibit tyrosine phosphatase and so decrease MHCI expression so cancers can avoid detection
Explanation:
Stress is linked to an increased cancer risk due to many factors these include:
- Chronic suppression of cytokine production therefore reduced NKC activity and phagocytosis

- Increased TNF alpha levels will inhibit tyrosine phosphatase and so decrease MHCI expression so cancers can avoid detection

- Reduced levels of IL2 and so reduced CTL proliferation and reduced NKCs for detection and removal of cancer cells

- Increased IL1, 6 and TNF alpha levels again reducing MHCI and MHCII presentation and so less likely to detect cancer cells

 

Of the options in the Question:

A: There is a chronic DECREASE in cytokine production

B: There is a DECREASE in MHCII presentation and production

C: There will be INCREASED cortisol levels but this shouldn't affect the chemotaxis and detection of cancer cells

D: There are DECREASED levels of IL2 which decreases CTL proliferation

E: Correct

Question: What embryonic germ layer is the nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral disc derived from?
Explanation:
I believe this was in Prof Dave Wilson's embryology lecture, but the notochord is an important director of what's happening in the embryo, it;

  • Forms the nucleus pulposus of the IV discs
  • Induces ectodermal cells over it to form the neural plate (which will later form the neural tube which forms the brain and spinal cord).

I'm going to write about gastrulation, just because it helps me remember it too, so if you don't want to read a long explanation then go to another question now lol.

 

Formation of the trilaminar embryo and body folding occurs in weeks 3-4 of embryonic development. 

 

So, in the picture on the left, is a view of the upper surface of the epiblast (remember the epiblast is above the hypoblast with space in between them, except at the prechordal plate where epiblast and hypoblast meet), the shape has changed from circular to an oval structure. So you can see the head end is considerably longer than the tail end. And forming in the midline of the epiblast is a groove called the primitive streak.

 

In week 3, the cells of the epiblast, from the right and left side, migrate towards the midline, primitive streak. When they get to the midline, they turn and go inwards and descend towards the hypoblast beneath it.

 

Some of the cells of the epiblast migrate through the primitive streak and all the way down to where the hypoblast cells are, they invaginate that layer and start to occupy it. As more and more of epiblastic cells do this, they displace the hypoblast cells which eventually die. This layer of epiblast cells forms the endoderm.

 

Other cells that migrate through the primitive streak migrate toward the hypoblast, but enter the space between the two layers, which forms the middle layer called the mesoderm.

 

Other cells from the epiblast migrate through the primitive streak, also become part of the middle layer but these cells stay right in the midline and form the notochord.

 

Lastly, we have cells of the epiblast that don't migrate through the primitive streak, but remain in the upper layer (epiblast) and form the ectoderm

 

Therefore, the trilaminar embryonic disc is formed with an outer ectoderm, inner mesoderm and notochord and innermost endoderm - all originally from the epiblast cells.

 

Different parts of the ectoderm will adopt different names depending on which part of the upper layer they occupy, for example;

  • Those that occupy the upper layer near the midline will form neural ectoderm cells
  • Cells that are right alongside that are called the neural crest cells
  • The remainder either become skin or surface ectodermal cells.

 

Neurulation

 

During development, the notochord releases substances into its surrounding area to direct the cells around it to differentiate in different ways. One such substance is  the Shh protein, which induces formation of the floor plate of the neural tube.

The notochord also induces ectodermal cells over it to form the neural plate. The lateral edges of the neural plate become more elevated and form a neural fold with a depressed midregion called the neural groove. The neural folds come together and fuse to form the neural tube, which later forms the brain and spinal cord.

 

Note that neural tube defects are caused by arrest of normal development and closure of the neural tube, resulting in conditions such as spina bifida or anencephaly.

 

----

 

So now that we have a flat 3 layered embryo, we need it to become 3D. Think of three papers all on top of each other, top paper is ectoderm, middle paper is mesoderm and the paper at the bottom is the endoderm. To make it a round 3 layered embryo, we need to fold it (4 weeks). Therefore, the edge on the left and right meet and fuse at the midline to form a tube. Once the tube is formed, the outer layer is ectoderm, middle layer is mesoderm and inner layer of endoderm, with the tube opened at front and back.

 

Therefore, we know the inner endoderm forms the lining of the gut tube, so one open end is for the mouth and the other is for the anus. The outer layer is the ectoderm, which we know forms the surface of the body, skin. And everything in between is mesoderm, which gives rise to cartilage, bone, muscle, connective tissue, blood etc. Which is in fact what we find between the surface of the body and the lining of the gut tube. 

 

What happens when the lateral body folds fail to fuse properly? You end up with a gap in the ventral body wall. This can allow structures that should be inside the embryo to escape and end up in the amniotic cavity. One such problem is gastroschisis, where abdominal viscera exits through a defect in the abdominal wall and is found in the amniotic cavity. Or omphalocele, a hernia in which abdominal structures move into the umbilical cord. 

 

Sorry for the super long explanation, but it just helps me to write it all out!

Question: Which of the following lipoprotein would you expect its size in terms of diameter to be the smallest?
Which of these statements regarding the male reproductive system is correct?
OptionA: At cold temperatures, the cremaster and dartos muscles relax, moving the testes away from the body
OptionB: Omphalocele occurs when serous fluid collects in the tunica vaginalis of the testes
OptionC: LH stimulates the sertoli cells in the seminiferous tubules secrete testosterone
OptionD: Via negative feedback, testosterone inhibits the secretion of LH and suppressed secretion of GnRH from the hypothalamus
OptionE: In the external genitals and prostate, enzyme 5-alpha hydroxlyase converts testosterone into dihydrotestosterone (DHT)
Explanation:
(A) Scrotum

  • Consists of loose skin and superficial fascia that hangs from the root of the penis
  • Single pouch of skin separated into lateral portions by a median ridge called the raphe (externally)
  • Internally scrotal septum divides the scrotum into two sacs, each containing a single testis.
  • The dartos muscle is composed of bundles of smooth muscle fibres, it is found in the subcutaneous tissue of the scrotum.
  • The cremaster muscle is associated with each testis, and is composed of a small band of skeletal muscle that is continuous with the internal oblique muscle.
  • Location of the scrotum and contraction of its muscle fibres regulate temperature of the testes.
  • In cold temperatures: cremaster and dartos muscle contract, moving the testes closer, and vice versa. (A)

(B) Testes

  • Develop near the kidneys, in the posterior portion of the abdomen and begin their descent into the scrotum through the inguinal canal in 7m of development.
  • Tunica vaginalis (derived from the peritoneum) partially covers the testes.
  • A collection of serous fluid in the tunica vaginalis is called a hydrocele, it can be caused by injury to the testes or inflammation of the epididymis. (B)

- Internal to the tunica vaginalis is the tunica albuginea, which is a dense fibrous capsule.

- The tunica albuginea extends inwards, forming septa that divide the testis into a series of internal compartments called lobules

- Each of the 200-300 lobules contains one to three tightly coiled tubules, the seminiferous tubules, where sperm are produced.

- The seminiferous tubules contain two types of cells: (1) spermatogenic cells and (2) sertoli cells

 

(C) - Large sertoli cells are embedded among the spermatogenic cells, and they join with other sertoli cells via tight junctions, forming a blood-testis barrier, as blood must first pass Sertoli cells before they can reach developing sperm.

- In the spaces between adjacent seminiferous tubules are clusters of cells called Leydig cells, which secrete testosterone (C).

 

(D) At puberty, certain hypothalamic neurosecretory cells increase their secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), which stimulates the anterior pituitary to produce LH and FSH.

  • LH stimulates the Leydig cells to secrete testosterone (which is synthesised from the cholesterol in the testes), which readily diffuses out of the Leydig cell and into the blood.
  • Via negative feedback, testosterone inhibits the secretion of LH and suppresses secretion of GnRH from hypothalamic neurosecretory cells.

(E) In some places, like the external genitals and prostate, enzyme 5-alpha reductase converts testosterone into dihydrotestosterone (DHT).

Question:
Jeremy Hunt is having back problems and goes to see his GP as he is struggling to stand up in lengthy debates in the House of Commons. He is also complaining of muscle twitching and numbness in his feet and around his mouth. The GP send him off for a lumbar/hip Xray which shows diffuse demineralisation. His blood test comes back with...

 

low Ca2+

low PO4-

high PTH

high ALP

 

What is wrong with Mr Hunt?
Explanation:
E is correct. Signs of hypocalcaemia and X-ray appearance and blood results. Caused as Hunt is Vitamin D deficient. He hides away from the public/press/junior doctors who all want his head on a stick, and subsequently does not receive enough sunlight to make Vit D. His wife also makes him follow a vegan diet in an attempt to stay healthy as to avoid interaction with healthcare professionals.

 

A= also correct

B= blood results would show normal Ca2+, PO4-, PTH but raised ALP due to increased turnover of bone (increased osteoclast activity with impaired compensatory osteoblast activity)

C= blood results would show raised Ca2+, PO4-, low PTH and high ALP

D= blood results show no abnormalities in osteoporosis

Question:
You are the on-call doctor in A&E, when the ambulance brings in 51 year old Sean Matthews who is suffering from angina, shortness of breath and syncope for the last half hour. He has a history of a myocardial infarction 3 years ago. You perform an ECG, and the results are below:

 

 

What do you think Sean Matthews has?
Explanation:
The correct answer is C, monomorphic ventricular tachycardia.

 

Ventricular Tachycardia (VT) is a broad complex tachycardia originating in the ventricles. There are several different varieties of VT — the most being Monomorphic VT. It is defined as a run of successive ventricular ectopic beats occurring at a rate of >100bpm (usually 12--200bpm). It is classified as non-sustained or sustained based on whether it lasts for >30s. 

 

Depending on the heart rate, VT can sometimes cause syncope, angina, SOB and if sustained can compromise cardiac pumping, leading to heart failure and death. 

 

Three mechanisms exist for initiation and propagation of ventricular tachycardia:

 

  1. Reentry: Commonest mechanism. Requires two distinct conduction pathways with a conduction block in one pathway, and a region of slow conduction in the other. Develops due to abnormal myocardial scarring usually due to prior ischemia or infarction.

2. Triggered activity: caused by an early after depolarisation (EAD) or late after depolarisation (LAD) (for example, Torsades or digitalis toxicity)

3. Abnormal automaticity: accelerated abnormal impulse generation by a region of ventricular cells.

 

ECG findings for VT:

  • broad complex tachycardia (i.e. QRS > 120ms).
  • bizarrrely shaped QRS complexes (abnormally broadened)

The QRS complex is used to classify VT into 2 broad categories:

 

Monomorphic VT:

  • Regular rhythm.
  • Originates from a single focus within the ventricles. Presence of a stable reentrant pathway, typically MI-related scar.
  • Produces uniform QRS complexes within each lead — each QRS is identical (except for fusion/capture beats).

 

Polymorphic VT:

  • Caused by multiple ectopic foci or reentry in which the circuit pathway is continually varying, occurs during/soon after an MI.
  • Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia has QRS complexes that very in shape and size.
  • If a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia has a long QT Interval, it could be Torsade de Pointes.

 

Torsades de Pointes, 'twisting of the points', is a type of polymorphic VT in which episodes of tachycardia, may give rise to fibrillation and sudden death, are superimposed upon intervals of bradycardia, during which QT interval is prolonged. ECG shows varying shapes and amplitudes of QRS complexes, waxes and wanes. (May be caused by drugs or conditions that delay ventricular repolarisation such as; class 1A & III antiarrhythmics, hypokalaemia and hypomagnesia).

Question: Whilst on placement in a neurology clinic, you see a 34-year old woman with personality changes, increased inhibition and headaches. You suspect a brain tumour, which type is most likely?

Astrocytomas are slow growing tumors presenting with epilepsy.

Ependyomas are benign but space occupying- there could be hydrocephalus and raised ICP.

Microgliomas occur mostly in immunocompromised patients and present as raised ICP.

Neuromas are rare- that is because glial cells vastly outnumber neurones and they also lack the capacity to replicate.

Question:
Yograj and his lover Lizzie are getting ready for a mad night out. Yograj suggests to Lizzie that they should make this night "extra special" and from under his long over coat whips out a bottle of white pills. They both giggle and then decide to take one each. Yograj then leaves the room to fix his comb over. Lizzie (being a greedy girl) grabs the bottle and swallows all 30 pills. Yograj walks in to find a grinning Lizzie and an empty bottle, his face falls and he exclaims "no Lizzie". Lizzie asks "whats the problem Yog? We iz gonna partA tonight!". Yograj replies "I was trying to be cool and impress you, those pills were actually paracetamol............"

 

What is the Toxic metabolite of paracetamol and what is the antidote?
Explanation: Paracetamol (also known as acetaminophen) is broken down into the toxic metabolite N-acetyl-p-benzoquinoneimine (NAPQI). This is usually de-detoxified by the bodys antioxidant glutathione. In an overdose glutathione is saturated leading to excess NAPQI which can damage liver cells. The antidote is acetylcysteine which is a precursor to glutathione, thus helps the body replenish its supply of glutathione.

Question: In a revision session with Dr Watson, he wants to test your neurology knowledge and so he asks you which glial cell is responsible for maintaining extracellular glutamate in the CNS?
Explanation:
Astrocytes have a few roles in the CNS: 

  • regulation of blood flow by secreting vasodilators/vasoconstrictor 
  • maintain extracellular K+ level by direct uptake or redistribution
  • maintain extracellular glutamate to prevent excitotoxicity 
  • provide metabolic support 

Ependymal cells line the CSF-filled ventricles in the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord

 

Oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells are responsible for myelination of the neurones. Oligodendrocytes are found in the CNS and Schwann cells are found in the PNS 

 

Microglia act as the first and main form of active immune defense in the central nervous system (CNS).

You are shadowing a junior doctor in a clinic when a 30-year old man comes into the room. On first appearance, he seems fit and well, if a little skinny. He had been referred to hospital by his GP after he had recently been noticing blood and mucus in his stools for the past three weeks. He also notes that he has been passing stools much more often than normal and with greater urgency.

 

The patient explains that he has not been in any pain in the last three weeks. He also explains that he was given a diagnosis of inflammatory bowel disease nine years ago and that when he last had a flare up around two years ago he was given a steroid cream that got rid of his problems very quickly.

 

On these findings, what is the doctor's most likely first choice of treatment?
Explanation:
The symptoms match that of a case of ulcerative colitis.

 

This is the patinet's first exacerbation in 12 months and since it does not seem severe (he isn't in any pain) aminosalicylates like mesalazine are the first choice.

 

Glucocorticoids would be second line if these fail of if the attack was severe e.g. the pateint was in severe pain. Hydrocortsione is used generally in UC while prednisolone is used more often in Chron's disease.

 

Cicosporin is used in UC if both aminosalicylates and glucocorticoids fail.

 

Budesonide is an unconventional glucocorticoid used mainly in CD treatment.

 

https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg166/chapter/Key-priorities-for-implementation

https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg152/chapter/1-Guidance

Question: Which transporter is upregulated during exercise?
Explanation:
GLUT4 is upregulated during exercise

 

GLUT2 transports glucose out of the enterocytes and into the blood

GLUT3 is the transporter involved with the placenta

SGLT1 absorbs glucose and galactose from the intestine 

GLUT5 absorbs fructose from the intestine

Question: What is the potential side effect of chloramphenicol? What class of antibiotics is it?
Explanation:
Chloramphenicol is a protein synthesis inhibitor.

 

It binds to 50s portion and inhibits formation of peptide bond.

 

Probaby the way to remember it is:

As Chlor refers to a colour (green) and the side effect has a colour in its name. Thus, Chlorampenicol may cause Grey Baby syndrome.

 

 

Other options:

A- Inhibits CYP450 is by Clarithcomycin (a Macrolide- protein synthesis inhibitor). However, it is a useful alternative to penicillin if allergic.

C- nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity caused by Gentamicin (an aminoglycoside - Protein synthesis inhibitor)

D- Superinfection (by Candida) can be caused by the usage of tetracyclines.

Also caused by Clindamycin usage (superinfection by C.diff)

E- Bone growth- by tetracyclines

 


If you have not noticed, all the Abx mentioned above are protein synthesis inhibitors

Question: What is the potential side effect of Clarithromycin?
Explanation:
Clarithromycin is a protein synthesis inhibitor.

It binds to 50s portion and prevents translocation movemement of ribosome along mRNA

.

Probaby the way to remember it is:
Clarithromycin. Claret = deep purplish red. As many of this CYP450 enzymes are in liver and liver is red. Thus, clarithromycin, liver, inhibits CYP450.

 

Other options:
A- Grey Baby syndrome by Chloramphenicol.


Nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity caused by Gentamicin (an aminoglycoside - Protein synthesis inhibitor)

 

Superinfection (by Candida) can be caused by the usage of tetracyclines.
Also caused by Clindamycin usage (superinfection by C.diff)

Bone growth- by tetracyclines

If you have not noticed, all the Abx mentioned above are protein synthesis inhibitors

Question: What is the potential side effect of Gentamicin?
Explanation:
Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside. It changes the shape of 30s portion of ribosome, mRNa read incorrectly.

It also causes nephrotoxicity.

 

Other options:
Inhibits CYP450 is by Clarithcomycin (a Macrolide- protein synthesis inhibitor). However, it is a useful alternative to penicillin if allergic.



Superinfection (by Candida) can be caused by the usage of tetracyclines.
Also caused by Clindamycin usage (superinfection by C.diff)


Bone growth- by tetracyclines

 

If you have not noticed, all the Abx mentioned above are protein synthesis inhibitors

Question: What is the potential side effect of tetracyclines?
Explanation:
Tetracyclines can also cause superinfection. For example, by Candida.

Tetracycline acts by binding to 50s portion of ribosome and prevents translocation of ribosome along mRNA.

 

 

 

Other options:
Inhibits CYP450 is by Clarithcomycin (a Macrolide- protein synthesis inhibitor). However, it is a useful alternative to penicillin if allergic.


nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity caused by Gentamicin (an aminoglycoside - Protein synthesis inhibitor)


Superinfection caused by Clindamycin usage (superinfection by C.diff)

 

Grey baby syndrome by CHloramphenicol.

 

If you have not noticed, all the Abx mentioned above are protein synthesis inhibitors

Question:
Mr John Dice is a 56 year old man who presents to his GP because he's noticed yellow discolouration of his skin. He's lost 6kg over the last few weeks and is feeling lethargic and low in mood. He has no past history of anything and on examination the only finding was that the fundus of his gallbladder is palpable.

 

What are your thoughts on the diagnosis at this stage?
Explanation:
Painless jaundice is assumed to be carcinoma until proven otherwise

 

Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas is more common in men between the ages of 50 -60. The common bile duct will be compressed as it runs posterior to or is embedded within the head of the pancreas

 

Next steps would be to arrange and urgent ERCP

Question:
A 78 year old type 2 diabetic comes for their annual retinopathy check up. They complain about there worsening vision. On examination they have diabetic maculopathy with >600 micrometers of retinal thickness and macular oedema. 

 

What is the best pharmacological recommended by nice for the treatment of this patient?
Explanation:
All treatments are options for Diabetic macular oedema, however, I think Ranibizumab is the most effective. This has to be weighed against cost so is only used as an option for treating visual impairment due to diabetic macular oedema if: 

the eye has a central retinal thickness of 400 micro metres or more at the start of treatment and the manufacturer provides ranibizumab with the discount agreed. 

 

This question was taken from the Diabetic retinopathy lecture in case 10. :)

Question:
Henry Baker, a 15-year old boy, suffers from aplastic anaemia (failure of bone marrow development) and, as a result, he has a reduced number of platelets in the blood. 

 

Whilst playing in the park with his mates the other day, he fell off the skateboard ramp and cracked his head open on the floor. There was blood everywhere and he was quickly rushed to hospital and given a platelet transfusion. Henry, being a kid, was naturally interested in where these platelets had come from and wanted to know who had donated them to him. 

 

The doctor explains to Henry that platelets are retrieved from donors by two methods: from whole blood and from aspheresis. Which of the following is the correct number of donors needed from each method to produce a platelet transfusion to one patient?
Explanation:
Whole blood: 4 donors are required to produce 1 transfusion of platelets. 

Aspheresis: 1 donor is required to produce 1 transfusion of platelets.

Question: You see a patient with clozapine prescription who has been recently bee complaining of tiredness, weight gain and not feeling the best. He has been on the medication for 7 weeks; you arrange the usual Full Blood Count. Which of the following findings would give you most concern given what medication the patient is on?
Explanation: Given the patient is on clozapine, the side effect you should be most concerned about is agranulocytosis, which displays as lowered neutrophils.

Question: Which of the following embryological origins of the heart forms the arch of aorta?
Explanation:
Truncus arteriosus 

Forms the ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk

The division of the truncus arteriosus is triggered by neural crest cell migration from the pharyngeal arches. Problems with the migration may lead to transposition of the great arteries or tetralogy of Fallot

Question: Which recepetor does Candesartan block?
Explanation: Cabdesartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker, it blocks angiotensin 1 receptor that angiotensin 2 normally binds to.

Question: Which phase of the cardiac action potential do beta blockers affect?
Explanation: Beta blockers reduce the slope of the phase 4 potential and reduce calcium entry to the myocytes.

Question: What helps to increase the LV filling rate upon excercise?
Explanation:
In diastole there is a pressure gradient between the right and the left ventricles which causes passive filling of the ventricles as atrial pressure is higher than ventricular pressure.

On exercise the atrial pressure remains the same but ventricular pressure falls slightly which increases this gradient so there is more early diastolic suction of blood from the atria into the ventricles. This is what is improved by training.

Question: Hypertension can lead to many complications. Which of the following complications is the most serious that involves hyalinisation?
Explanation:
Hyalinisation is the deposition of deposition of large proteins such as fibrinogen in the media layer and proliferation of small blood vessels. Hyaline (pink, amorphous, homogeneous material) accumulates in the wall of small arteries and arterioles, producing the thickening of their walls and the narrowing of the lumina —  this is a form of arteriolosclerosis.

So A and E are both correct but E is more correct as atherosclerosis is a normal process of ageing but is accelerated by hypertension and other risk factors.

Question: Liddle's syndrome is a type of hypertension associated with a defect in a Na+ channel. Where in the nephron is the Na+ channel found?
OptionC: Thick Ascending limb of loop of henle

Question:
Dr Brown develops a new drug that can treat ulcerative colitis. In order to test the efficacy of this drug Dr Brown wants to test the drug against the next best drug on the market.

 

Drugs are tested in clinical trials and each of the stages has a different purpose.

 

Given that Dr Brown is developing a new drug and is comparing it with the next best drug on the market in a randomised clinical trial on a large population what phase of drug testing is she at?
Explanation:
Phase 0 - testing on animals and tissue to determine whether the drug works.

Phase 1 - testing whether the drug is safe on healthy people.

Phase 2 - testing whether the drug works on ill people.

Phase 3 - testing whether the drug works compared to the next best thing or a placebo.

Phase 4 - drug is out for use.

 

Same format applies for manufacturing a vaccine, the vaccine will go through the same stages of clinical testing.

Question: A high salt diet can lead to fibrosis and thus worsen/lead to hypertension. Which of the following explanations shows why a high salt diet leads to fibrosis?
OptionC: Positive direct effect on myocardial cells to hypertrophy

Question: What is the name of the amino acid that starts of the serotonin synthesis pathway?

You are investigating a patient for hypokalaemia and want to confirm the case is most likely conn's syndrome given the symptoms. What hormone or electrolyte levels, other than aldosterone and potassium levels, will most help you confirm your diagnosis?
Explanation:
The renin levels will help you differentiate between primary and secondary hyperaldosteronism. Primary will only show elevated aldosterone as there is not excessive activation of RAA system. So Renin levels will be low as the aldosterone secretion will lead to high blood pressure due to the Na+ and H2O retention it causes (ANP levels may rise to try and deal with this).

 

Secondary hyperaldosteronism will be as a result of chronic RAAS activation to try and maintain the high blood pressure that the demands of Renal artery stenosis or CCF permit. Thus you will have a high renin and big aldosterone levels.

Question: You encounter a women 22 weeks gestation with a BP of 160/110 and proteinuria of 0.35g/24 hours.  Given the most likely diagnosis, what is a risk factor for this condition?
Explanation:
This is a classic scenario of pre-eclampsia 

Strong Risk factors include 

• > 40 years old

• nulliparity (or new partner)

• multiple pregnancy

• body mass index > 30 kg/m^2

•diabetes mellitus

• pregnancy interval of more than 10 years

• family history of pre-eclampsia

• previous history of pre-eclampsia

• pre-existing vascular disease such as hypertension or renal disease

Question: Which toll like receptor is responsible for mediating nucleic acids?
Explanation:
TLR3 is found on endosomal compartments along with TLR 7 8 and 9. These mediate nucleic acids

 

TLR 1 2 4 5 and 6 are found on the plasma membrane and recognise PAMPs (pathogen associated molecular pattern)

Question: How does a measles virus induce a CD8 response?
OptionA: Measles peptides bind with MHC Class 1 in the Endoplasmic Reticulum
OptionB: Measles peptides bind with MHC Class 1 in an endosome
OptionC: Measles peptides bind with MHC Class 1 in the Golgi Body
OptionD: Measles peptides bind with MHC Class 2 in the Endoplasmic Reticulum
OptionE: Measles peptides bind with MHC Class 2 in an endosome
Explanation:
Measles is a virus which is considered to be an pathogen that replicates intracellularly.

 

  • The virus is endocytosed into a nucleated cell and replicates in the cytosol.
  • The pathogen enters the proteasome and it is broken down into peptides.
  • The peptides enter the ER via a TAP transport channel.
  • In the ER, the peptides bind to an MHC Class 1 molecule.
  • This is transported in a vesicle via the Golgi Body to the cell membrane.
  • MHC Class 1 initiates a CD8 response. 

Peptides from extracellular pathogens (bacteria) bind to MHC class 2 in an endosome.

Question: In an intracellular infection, what is the function of MAVS protein?
OptionB: Expose binding site of MHC Class 1 in ER for pathogen to bind
OptionC: Act as a pattern recognition receptor in the cytosol
OptionE: Transcribe ISGs to block replicaton of pathogens
Explanation:
MAVS protein causes dimerisation of RIG 1 like receptors after they have binded to a pathogen's RNA. This allows signalling. 

 

RIG 1 like receptors:

  • Act as a pattern recognition receptor in the cytosol
  • Recognise intracellular pathogens

JAK1 and STAT proteins:

  • transcribe ISGs to block viral replication

Question: The 2014 Ebola virus (EBOV) outbreak in West Africa is the largest outbreak of the genus Ebolavirus to date. By 2016, there are Ebola virus infection are less reported. For the Ebola virus to die out, what does the reproduction number need to be?
Explanation:
The reproduction number (R0) is the average number of people that one infected person goes on to infect. The average reproduction number is 4. 

 

  • For an infection to die out the R0 must be < 1 
  • For the number of infected people to remain the same, the R0 must be = 1
  • For the infetion to spread the R0 must be > 1

Question: You are on placement in ITU and you see a patient who is unconscious following a severe head injury. Which part of the brain control consciousness?
Explanation:
The reticular activating system causes activation of the cerebral cortex and hieghtened arousal controlling consciousness. It is made up of:

  • reticular formation- diencephalon, midbrain and rostral pons
  • thalamus
  • cerebral hemispheres

A disorder to any of these can cause unconsciousness.

Question: Which of the following is NOT true for Klinefelter syndrome.
OptionA: They have an increased risk of Autoimmune disorders
OptionB: They have an increased risk of breast cancer
OptionC: They have an increased risk of osteoporosis
OptionD: They have an increased risk of X-linked disease.
OptionE: They have increased FSH and LH levels.
Explanation:
Klinefelter syndrome is when males have an extra X chromosome --> XXY

D is correct because men with Klinefelter syndrome have a DECREASED risk of X-linked disease, as they have an extra X chromosome as a back up if one is faulty.

Other features of Klinefelters not mentioned are

- Tall stature

- Infertile

- Small testes

- delayed development of secondary sexual characteristics

- developmental delays

- gynaecomastia

- low testosterone levels

 

The treatment for Klinefelter syndrome is Testosterone, surgery for gynaecomastia and fertility treatment.

 

This is all from the Chromosome abnormalities lecture in Case 7 :)

Question: To which of the following does RNA polymerase copy genetic information from?
Explanation:
A - the leading strand is the same as the coding strand which is the same as the mRNA produced by RNA polymerase

B - this is made up

C - the coding strand is the same as the leading strand

D - this is the correct answer because the non-coding strand is complementary to the coding strand. Therefore if you wanted to make proteins from the sequence AGC (coding strand) then the non-coding strand (TCG) would be transcribed by RNA polymerase to form mRNA strand (AGC) which would then code for  a specific amino acid. 

E - the TATA box is a promoter sequence which is UPSTREAM from the gene you want to transcribe but RNA polymerase copies DNA downstream from this sequence. 

 

Just a bit of year 1 revision because I forgot all of this!

Question:
Edward, a 65 year old male, presents to you in A&E with uncontrolled bleeding. The patient's history shows that they are on a prescription of Dabigatram following a stroke two years ago. 

What action can be taken to reverse the blood thinning effect of Dabigatram?
OptionC: Dabigatram is a NOAC - no antedote available
Explanation:
The correct answer is E - administer idarucizumab. 

Dabigatram is a monoclonal antibody fragment which has a highly specific binding affinity with dabigatran therefore reversing any anticoagulant activity of dabigatran and its metabolites. It is very new and was only launched in the UK in December 2015.

This was not mentioned in Dr Coffey's lecture however he did refer to it in the wrap up. 

 

The other answers:

A - antedote for warfarin 

B - antedote for heparin 

C - incorrect, only recently however! 

D - Under investigation as an antedote for factor Xa inhibitors (rivaroxaban, apixaban etc) however not approved.

Question: Which drug of abuse acts via inhibiting DAT (Dopamine reuptake)?
Explanation:
Amphetamine - displaces dopamine from presynaptic vesicles, causing increased dopamine and stimulating the reward system

Cannabis - THC acts via CB1 receptors to increase dopamine

Cocaine - Blocks DAT dopamine reuptake

Ecstasy - Psychostimulant by interfering with serotonin storage and inhibiting dopamine uptake. 

Opiates - Act on Mu receptos to decrease neurotransmitter release by causing K+ efflux and hyperpolarisation. By decreasing GABA release they stimulate an increase in dopamine.

Question:
The three core symptoms of depression are:

Low mood everyday for 2 weeks, anergia and..
Explanation: All others are associated symptoms

Question: Severe depression is defined as:
OptionE: 3 core, 4 associated symptoms and mood congruent delusions and perceptual abnormalities.
Explanation:
Mild = 2 core and 2 associated

Moderate = 2 core and 3 associated

Severe = 3 core and 4 associated

Severe with psychosis = 3 core and 4 associated and mood congruent delusions and perceptual abnormalities.

Question: What is the most commonly prescribed antidepressant in the UK?
Citalopram is an example of what kind of drug?
What is the first line pharmacological treatment in schizophrenia?
Explanation:
Risperidone = an atypical antipsychotic. first line

Then try chloropromazine/ haloperidol

and last line is clozapine

 

Due to side effects.

Question: Which of these in an example of an orexigenic?
Explanation:
Anorexigenics:

- Leptin (released from adipose to signal body has enough food to maintain body weight)

- CCK (secreted by I cells of duodenum in presence of partially digested fats)

- Peptide YY (secreted by L cells of duodenum proportional to the amount of calories in the digested food)

- Cytokines (inflammatory response reduced appetite)

 

Orexigenics:

- Grehlin (P/D1 cells in the fundus of the stomach when it is empty)

- Orexin (low energy levels stimulate secretion)

- Neuropeptide YY 

- Agouti-Related Peptide (signals food scarcity)

Question:
A patient suffers from osteomalacia. They have some blood tests.

Which of the following most likely represents their results?
OptionA:
High Ca2+

low Vitamin D

low Phosphate

high Parathyroid hormone
OptionB:
low Ca2+

low Vitamin D

low Phosphate

low Parathyroid hormone
OptionC:
low Ca2+

low Vitamin D

high Phosphate

low parathyroid hormone
OptionD:
low Ca2+

low Vitamin D

low Phospahte

high parathyroid hormone
OptionE:
low Ca2+

high Vitamin D

low phosphate

high parathyroid hormone
Explanation:
Osteomalacia (or Rickets if it occurs in childhood) is defective bone mineralisation due to Vitamin D deficiency

 

Therefore Vitamin D is low by default

Osteomalacia is characterised by its low mineral content, thus calcium and phosphate are low.

Low calcium promotes Parathyroid hormone release, causing:

  • Increased calcium retention by the kidneys
  • Increased calcium absorption from the small intestine
  • Increased osteoclast activity
  • Increased Vitamin D production in the kidneys

Due to continued lack of vitamin D, Ca2+ and PO42-, Parathyroid hormone will be high

Question: You see a patient on placement who has recently started taking beta-blockers. You know that these decrease contractility of the heart (as well as heart rate). By what mechanism does beta adrenergic stimulation normally increase contractility?
OptionA: Activate β1 receptors ->Gαs activated-> increased cAMP -> increased Ca2+ release
OptionB: Activate β1 receptors ->Gαi activated-> increased cAMP -> increased Ca2+ release
OptionC: Activate β1 receptors ->Gαq activated-> increased PLC -> increased Ca2+ release
OptionD: Activate β2 receptors ->Gαs activated-> increased cAMP -> increased Ca2+ release
OptionE: Activate β2 receptors ->Gαi activated-> increased cAMP -> increased Ca2+ release
Explanation:
This is the correct mechanism.

 

β2 receptors are found in the lungs.

Gαi inhibits cAMP formation.

Gαq does increase PLC but this is not used in the heart.
Tags: Cardiology, Cardiovascular System, PCS Unit 3, case 4, Pharmacology

Question:
You are called to A&E to examine Mr Smith, a 50 year old gentleman who fell in the garden earlier today. Mr Smith is able to open his eyes when you try speaking to him, but only responds with grunts. When you rub on his sternum his arm moves up as he tries to move your hand away.

 

What is Mr Smith's GCS score and considering this, would you intubate him?
Explanation:
Mr Smith is:

- opening eyes in response to speech: 3

- incomprehensible sounds: 2

- localising to pain: 5

 

Therefore his GCS is 10. You would NOT consider intubating someone unless they have a GCS less than 8 because then they are at risk of not being able to maintain their airway.
Tags: Acute Care, Airway Managment, Glasgow Coma Scale, Case 16

Question: Colin, a thirty eight year old male, attend an appointment at his local GP surgery. He complained of feeling fatigued and had lost some weight. He had noticed his skin had started to darken in areas. The GP suspects that Colin has Addison's disease but wants to take a blood cortisol level to confirm the diagnosis. What time of day is the best to carry out the blood test?
Explanation:
The correct answer is A - 9 am

 

The levels of cortisol in the bloodstream fluctuate throughout the day following a circadian rhythm. Cortisol levels are greatest in early morning approxiatly peeking at 9am and are lowest at late evening. 

As you are testing Colin for adrenal insufficiency it would be most accurate to test for this when his cortisol levels are supposedly highest. If the test was carried out late evening it is not certain if the adrenal insufficiency is due to the circadian rhythm

Question: Jackie, a 25 year old woman, is currently in stage 2 of labour and in line with her labour plan is asking for an epidural. What agent is her consultant anaesthetist most likely to use for this situation?
Explanation:
From Dr Coffey's lecture on anaesthetics given in the practical. 

 

Bupivicaine is used for an epidural whereas fentanyl is used for a spinal. Lidocaine and Morphine are not commonly used for either epidural or spinal and proprofol is a hypnotic agent used for GA.

Question: Jeanette is currently revising Case 14. Being cheeky, she asked Sheryl what other ions' imbalances would increase PTH secretion besides having hypocalcaemia. In order to prove that Sheryl has also done sufficient revision, she confidently replies..
Explanation: Sheryl was right! Its Hypomagnesium.

Question: The goldblatt experiment demonstrates the pathophysiology of what happens to two kidneys if one kidney is shown to have renal artery stenosis. In the contralateral kidney to the stenosed one, what is the main hormone/substance change  you expect in the long term, understanding the principles of this experiment?
Explanation:
In the Goldblatt experiment; 

  • One kidney is stenosed, resulting in a reduction in blood flow to this kidney.
  • In response, the Juxatoglomerular cells of the stenosed kidney secrete more renin to allow ACE to be activated in the lungs and thus ANG-II to be formed
  • ANG II will cause a whole host of effects, mainly increased Na+ and H2O reabsorption in the kidneys 
  • Initially BP rises and normalises at a higher level as increased absorption of Na+ by the stenosed kidney is in part compensated by increases in secretion of Na+ by non-stenosed kidney (to which blood pressure increases thereby inhibiting renin secretion by that kidney), ie., ECF volume does not initially undergo a major expansion.
  • Despite reduced renin secretion by non-stenosed kidney intrarenal AT2 in this kidney remains elevated and hypertension persists.
  • Sustained increased blood pressure to the left kidney leads to glomerular damage (hence proteinuria.) and therefore reduced salt and water secretion. In other words the initial ‘vasoconstriction-mediated’ hypertension is replaced by a volume-dependent pattern.

Question: One of the mechanisms for chromosomal aneuploidy is non-disjunction. This is the failure of chromosomes to separate during meiotic division. You are speaking to a geneticist while on placement and they ask you what will happen to the gametes if non-disjunction happens at the second meiotic division. You answer:
OptionA: 1 of the 4 gametes will be abnormal
OptionB: 2 of the 4 gametes will be abnormal
OptionC: 3 of the 4 gametes will be abnormal
OptionD: All of the gametes will be abnormal
OptionE: None of the gametes will be abnormal

Question: Which of the following does the bulbis cordis develop to form?
Explanation: Bulbis cordis goes on to develop into all of the right ventricle and the smooth parts of the left ventricle. Thus B is the best answer. The primitive ventricle develops into the rest of the left ventricle

Question: A women's results from a recent Quadruple Antenatal screening test have just come back. The results indicate that the child may have Edwards syndrome. Which biomarkers indicate Edwards Syndrome?
Explanation:
Quadruple test is performed from 14-20 weeks.

 

A) High hCG and Inhibin A = Downs Syndrome (Mnemonic = HIgh)

 

B) Very high hCG and Inhibin A = Turners Syndrome (Mnemonic = HIgh )

 

C) Low Estriol, very low hCG = Edwards Syndrome (Mnemonic = HE(hCG and Estriol) is low)

 

D) NT = >3.5mm, Low PAPP-A = Downs Syndrome  (Combined test results, Low PAPP-A indicates an abnormality)

 

E) High AFP = Patau Syndrome or High AFP is indicative of neural tube defects (Mnemonic = AFPatau (P for PAPP-A is high)
