Question: Whilst shadowing Dr Yousef you hear him talking passionately talking to Mrs Jones about an exciting new drug which is known to have dual hormone inhibition and has so far shown to be very effective in treating heart failure. Having thoroughly enjoyed your non-medical treatments to heart failure lecture you are quickly able to recount that this must be the new LCZ 696 drug. Later on the wards Mrs Jones asks you to explain what the drug does exactly, you respond with....
OptionA: It has an angiotensin II receptor blocking action (AT-1) as well as stopping the enzymatic breakdown of BNP
OptionB: It has an angiotensin II (AT1) receptor blocking action as well as stopping the enzymatic formation of BNP
OptionC: It is an ACE inhibitor and angiotensin II (AT-1) receptor blocker
OptionD: It is an ACE inhibitor as well as stopping the enzymatic breakdown of BNP
OptionE: It is an ACE inhibitor as well as stopping the enzymatic formation of BNP
Explanation:
• new drug
• comined drug with two agents
• valsartan; is an agiotensin II receptor blocker (preventing adosterone stimulation, Na+ and H2O retention, vasoconstriction and hormone stimulation)
• sacubitral; blocks neprilysin which is an enzyme responsible for the breakdown of BNP (means increased Na+ and H2O excretion, vasodilation and supression of growth factors and inflammatory hormones)
• this overall affect means that BNP is in greater concentration and angiotenin II in lower concentration
• huge reduction in mortality
Tags: Pharmacology, Cardiology, Cardiovascular System, Case 16, Group 62

Question: You are discussing the negative symptoms of schizophrenia with your friends. One of your friends decides to test you and asks the following question. which of the following best describes the symptom of Alogia?
Explanation:
No motivation- Avolition 

Flattening of mood- affective flattening

Inability to feel pleasure- anhedonia

Social disintrest- Asociality 

Poverty of speech- Alogia

Question: Excess iron is stored in the liver as _________ and in the bone marrow as _________.
OptionC: DNA-binding proteins from starved cells (DPS) and Haemosiderin
Explanation:
Liver : Ferritin

Bone Marrow:  Haemosiderin

 

Case 8 : Haematology in Pregnancy

Question: Yograj presents to you in A+E with severe chest pain. He appears cool and clammy. You take an ECG and diagnose...
Explanation:
There is relatively clear ST segment elevation in leads V4, V5, V6, aVL and 1

 

Inferior: aVF, 2 and 3

Septal: V1 and V2

Anterior: V1-V4

Lateral: 1, aVL, V5 and V6

Question: Mrs Pippapig, a 40 year old woman came into the GP clinic today complaining of recent weight loss, thinning of axillary and pubic hair and decreased libido and amenorrhea. She has also been experiencing nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain as well as feeling tired without any energy left. You noticed a hyperpigmentation on her skin. Which hormone is most likely to be playing the role in hyperpigmentation?
Explanation:
The patient has Addisons disease and is also called primary adrenal insufficiency. Overstimulation of ACTH but adrenal glands are not responding so produces too little cortisol ad often too little aldosterone.

 

Excess ACTH (high ACTH) in Addison patients cause hyper pigmentation of the skin, gums, mouth, from formation of a derivative of ACTH (Melanocyte stimulating hormone -MSH) that targets the skin.

Question: Whilst heroically trying to rescue the next door's cat from the cherry tree Bob accidentally drops the saw on his left thumb, it cuts the nerve that allows him to bend and abduct his thumb. The doctors allow the nerve to naturally heal as it is stage II. 3 months after his accident the Schwann cells have de-differentiated and started to migrate and grow in the basal lamina to reform the nerve. Which nerve is Bob re-growing and what is the name of the factor produced by macrophages that is allowing his Schwann cells to migrate and regrow in the basal lamina?
Explanation:
The LOAF muscles of the hand: lateral two lumbricals, opponens pollicis, abductor pollicis and flexor pollicis brevis are all supplied by the Median nerve. The rest of the intrinsic hand muscles are supplied by the ulnar nerve with the radial nerve only supplying sensation to the hand. 

 

Galectic-1 is the factor released by macrophages to allow Schwann cells to migrate and re-grow within the basal lamina so they reach the correct target. 

 

Caspian is the protease produced by calcium release both in PNS Wallerian degeneration and in glutamate toxicity. It causes breakdown of the cytoskeleton from the tail end of the neurone. 

 

Chondroitin Sulphate Proteoglycan (CSPG) is a substance produced by astrocytes to prevent CNS axonal regrowth, it is an inhibitory molecule preventing the CNS from regenerating.

Question: Sammy is being treated for a meningitis infection, you started him on the broad spectrum antibiotics whilst you sent a lumbar puncture sample to microbiology for a PMN and Lymphocyte count. The results come back showing that Sammy's CSF has 60% Lymphocytes. With this information what is the next best course of action?
OptionA: Assume that this is a Fungal infection due to the lymphocyte:PMN ratio and so prescribe anti-fungals
OptionB: Assume that this is a TB infection with the mixed lymphocyte percentage and so alter treatment accordingly
OptionC: Assume that this is a viral infection due to lymphocyte count and so stop antibiotics and give fluids
OptionD: Assume that the results from the lumbar puncture are due to a traumatic tap and so perform a WBC:RBC ratio count
OptionE: Assume that this may still be a bacterial infection and so continue treatment with broad spectrum antibiotics until more test results come back
Explanation:
To conclude a viral meningitis lymphocyte count must be >90%

 

To conclude a bacterial meningitis PMN count must be >90%

 

If the count is between 50-75% then assume that the infection is bacterial until more test confirm otherwise.

 

Always assume meningitis has bacterial cause and treat accordingly until you are sure from PCR test etc. that it is due to another cause.

 

A traumatic tap would give you a high number of White Blood Cells in total (leukocytes) but if ratio of RBC:WBC tested then would reveal a percentage of 1000:1 is there was no infection present.

Question: You perform an exercise stress test on a gentleman with angina-what ECG changes do you expect during the patient's exercise?
Explanation: Myocardial iscahemia is most likely to appear as ST depression in an exercise stress test. ST elevation is more suggestive of myocardial infarction,

Question: You are shadowing a doctor in a paediatric clinic and come across a baby with microcephaly, a 'happy' demeanour, jerky hand movements and difficulty in balancing itself. The doctor asks you what syndrome you believe the baby has. You say:
Explanation: Angelman syndrome is caused by paternal uniparental disomy. There is inactivation of genes in the maternal chromosome 15. Patients will normally present with the above symptoms plus developmental delay, speech impairment, intellectual disability, difficulty walking and hypo pigmentation.

Question: What factor most likely decreases afterload?
Explanation:
Afterload is the force the ventricles have to contract against. 

  • Afterload decreases
  • Less pressure to contract against
  • Increased ejection velocity
  • More blood ejected
  • Decreased ESV

 

 

Factors that decrease afterload:

  • Valvular regurgitation
  • Low total peripheral resistance
  • Ventricular hypertrophy

**Ventricular hypertrophy decreases the afterload because its thicker wall has more sarcomeres so the wall stress/tension is better distributed. This can be calculated by this equation:

 

Factors that increase afterload:

  • Hypertension- systemic or pulmonary (eg COPD)
  • Valvular stenosis
  • Atherosclerosis

Question: Which of the following statements regarding the catecholamine synthesis pathway is NOT true:
OptionA: Transport of tyrosine across the blood-brain-barrier is a rate limiting step that affects the treatment of Parkinson's.
OptionB: Vit B6 deficiency can result in a decreased production of noradrenaline.
OptionC: In times of chronic stress, in the neurones of the catecholamine synthesis pathway, there is an increased expression of tyrosine hydroxylase.
OptionD: PNMT is mainly found in the neurones located within the rostral pons.
OptionE: Cells in the ventral tegmental area do not contain dopamine-β-hydroxylase.
Explanation:
Correct answer: D.
A: "Transport of tyrosine across the blood-brain-barrier is a rate limiting step that affects the treatment of Parkinson's."
This is correct. With normal dietary intake, these transporters are fully saturated. This means that treatment of Parkinson's with tyrosine supplements are ineffective, L-DOPA is used instead.
B: "Vit B6 deficiency can result in a decreased production of noradrenaline." 
This is correct. A cofactor derived from vitamin B6 is required for the conversion of L-DOPA into dopamine by the enzyme L-aromatic amino acid decarboxylase. Dopamine is then converted into noradranline by the enzyme Dopamine-β-hydroxylase (with cofactors Cu2+and Vit C)
C: "In times of chronic stress, in the neurones of the catecholamine synthesis pathway, there is an increased expression of tyrosine hydroxylase."
This is correct. In times of chronic stress, there is increased release of catecholamines. This leads to increased expression of tyrosine hydroxylase.
D: "PNMT is mainly found in the neurones located within the rostral pons."
This is incorrect. The "rostral pons" is referring to the Locus Coeruleus, which contains the largest cluster of noradrenergic neurones. As these neurones produce noradrenaline, they do not express the enzyme PNMT. PNMT is found in neurons that produce adrenaline (few in the brainstem and the adrenal medulla.)
E: "Cells in the ventral tegmental area do not contain dopamine-β-hydroxylase."
This is correct. Neurones in the VTA are dopaminergic neurones. They do not contain dopamine-β-hydroxylase as this is expressed in noradrenergic neurones for the production of noradrenaline from dopamine. 

All of this information was taken from the Neuropharmacology 1 Lecture in Case 12!

Question:
Bolt presents with a thunderclap headache then vomits. You believe he has had some sort of intracranial bleed. 

 

What is the most likely cause of this bleed?
Explanation:
Thunderclap headache is a severe sudden onset headache indicative of a subarachnoid haemorrage where there is a bleed into the subarachnoid space. 

 

The two causes are:

1. Saccular berry aneurysm (70%)

2. Atriovenous malformation (10%)

Remaining 20% have a mixture of rare causes. 

 

Chronic hypertension usually causes a intracerebral hemorrhage which causes 15% of all strokes.

Shaken baby syndrome is linked to the acceleration deceleration injury and a subdural haemotoma.

Fractured skull my rupture a meningeal artery causing an extradural haemotoma.

Question:
A mother brings a 2 year old child into the Children's Emergency Department, concerned that the child has persistent bilious vomiting, struggled to pass stools and that any stools passed have a red current jelly-like feature. On examination the child has a fever and a right upper quadrant mass. An ultrasound is done:

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
A- this can also present with bilious vomiting but not usually blood in the stools

B- this is  what happens in malrotation (A)

C-correct, this is the most common childhood emergency and causes a triad of bilious vomiting, right upper quadrant mass and intermittent abdominal pain. Also seen is blood in the stools, diarrhoea or vomiting, and fever. The donut sign is seen on ultrasound.

D- congenital so usually presents at birth when the baby fails to pass merconium. Causes vomiting and a distended abdomen

E- asymptomatic unless the diverticulum becomes infected, in which case symptoms are similar to appendicites

Question:
A 58-year old gentleman is admitted to hospital after falling 10 feet from a ladder and landing on his head. He explains to the doctor that he feels like he has been 'kicked in the head' and the paramedic explains that he has vomited multiple times in the ambulance on the way to the hospital and has been in and out of consciousness three times.

 

An emergency CT shows dense material in the basal cisterns and fissures and confirms the doctors suspicions of a subarachnoid haemorrhage. 85% of subarachnoid haemorrhages are caused by rupture of a cerebral aneurysm. Many of these occur in the Circle of Willis and its branches. Where is the most common site of a cerebral aneurysm in the Circle of Willis?
Explanation:
The most common areas for intracranial aneurysm are:

  • Anterior Communicating Artery - 40%
  • Bifurcation of the Middle Cerebral Artery - 34%
  • Posterior Communicating Artery - 20%
  • Basilar Tip - 4%

Question:
Mrs Jones, who is 85 years old, comes to the GP practice complaining of dry feet with breaks (fissures) in the skin. On examination, her feet feel warm and you are able to feel both pulses. However on the plantar aspect of her right foot there is a large callus.

 

Mrs Jones suffers from Type 2 diabetes which she has struggled to control recently. Based on your examination, what option below best describes the pathology that is likely to be affecting Mrs Jones' feet?
Explanation:
A - Gangrene is necrosis due to prolonged ischaemia. Mrs Jones has a warm foot with pulses so this is unlikely to be an ischaemic problem.

 

B - The features of neuropathic feet are: warm, well perfused, palpable pulses, decreased sweating and dry skin prone to fissuring. Calluses are the most important pre-ulcerative lesion because if they become very thick they can press on the soft tissues underneath and cause ulceration. Moist tissue under the callus suggests an ulcer is about to form/has already formed and therefore when you remove the callus, you will be able to see the ulcer. Neuropathic ulcers usually affect the plantar aspect of the foot under the metatarsal heads/toes.

 

C - Neuroischaemic feet are cool, pulseless with shiny skin and atrophy of sub-cut tissue. Neuroischaemic ulcers are mainly found on the medial and lateral surfaces of the feet or on the tips of toes. A classic sign of pre-ulceration is a red mark precipitated by poorly fitting shoes. 

 

D - stocking polyneuropathy is common in poorly controlled diabetic patients and Mrs Jones may well be suffering with this. However, this answer does not explain the callus and dry feet as well as a neuropathic ulcer/foot does. 

 

E - Charcot Foot is caused by diabetic peripheral neuropathy associated with progressive degeneration of the foot leading to loss of the arch and joint disorganisation.

Question: Patients with atrial fibrillation are offered warfarin to reduce their risk of having a stroke. What is warfarin's mechanism of action?
Explanation:
Warfarin inhibits vitamin K reductase which prevents the formation of reduced vitamin K which is needed to synthesise gamma carboxyglutamic acid residues. These residues form factor 2, 7, 9 and 10. 

 

An antedote for warfarin would be a vitamin K injection. 

 

 

Inhibitors of factor 10a- fondaparinux, enoxaparin (low molecular weight heparins), rivoxaban (novel oral anticoagulant)

Activator of antithrombin 3- heparin

Question: A patient feels his heart racing and is feeling dizzy. He has been diagnosed with an arrhythmia previously by a consultant cardiologist. Under his treatment plan, he knows to visit A&E during an episode like this to be administered a certain drug via IV. Which drug is most likely to be administered to this patient?
Explanation:
This patient has been diagnosed with AVNRT where they might be referred to be administered with adenosine in A&E via IV. 

Adenosine's mechanism of action:

  • It activates a1 receptor which is a GPCR with a Gi subunit
  • This inhibits adenylyl cyclase from being activated which decreases cAMP
  • Low cAMP causes hyperpolarisation by allowing increased potassium efflux at the AV node which results in complete heart block
  • In effect, adenosine 'resets' the heart

 

Atropine and isoprenaline are administered in bradycardic arrhythmias. Bisoprolol wouldn't need to be administered by IV in A&E.

Question:
A patient presents with shortness of breath, a dry cough and a history of gradual weight loss. He is on rhythm control medication for an arrhythmia- atrial flutter. On examination this patient has clubbing of the nails and on auscultation of his chest, you can hear bibasal fine crackles. He has a CT scan.

t

What drug might cause his presentation?
Explanation:
This patient is likely to have pulmonary fibrosis characterised by a history of weight loss, cough, breathlessness, clubbing and fine crackles. His CT shows a honeycombing appearance which is a sign of a fibrotic lung.

 

Amiodarone:

  • is a Class 3 Vaughn Williams drug
  • potassium channel blocker
  • delays phase 3 of a cardiac action potential

Its only indicated to be used as a rhythm control drug only if the arrhythmia is serious due to the serious side-effects linked to it. It may be used in:

  • Ventricular tachycardia
  • Atrial fibrillation
  • Atrial flutter
  • WPW Syndrome

Side effects include:

  • Photosensitive skin rash
  • Slate grey pigmentation to the skin
  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Pro-arrhythmic effects

Question:
Elle is a 6 month old girl who has been brought to your GP practice with her mum who is 24 for a review after having recently had a scan that confirms she has renal cysts. Elle's mum has had similar kidney problems and now suffers with diabetes. Therefore, she wants to know whether Elle is also at risk of diabetes and if this is what is causing Elle's kidney problems.

 

What type of diabetes is both Elle and her mum most likely to have?
Explanation:
The answer is MODY5 because:

- It is likely to be one of the MODY options because of the fact that her mother also has diabetes and Elle is so young.

- MODY5 causes renal cysts which are usually detected in a foetus before birth. 

 

In MODY5 the diabetes usually develops later on and requires insulin treatment. 

 

Bit of a hard one but I think it's good to know that renal cysts is a complication of MODY5. The information comes from the genetics lecture of case 17.

Question: Drug treatment has failed to control the rhythm of a patient with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. What is most likely to be the next step in this patients management plan?
Explanation:
This patient has paroxysmal AF meaning they have episodes that last less than 48 hours.

  • Paroxysmal AF patients are not indicated to have electrical cardioversion.
  • (They are indicated pharmacological cardioversion (amiodarone). However, the question states that drug treatment has failed.)

 

The patient is now a candidate for ablative therapy.

  • Pulmonary vein ablation is indicated in paroxysmal AF
  • Target ablation (i.e. area around the AV node) is indicated in permanent or persistent AF. These would also need a pacemaker. (pace & ablate strategy)

Question:
Bob and Brenda have 3 children together. Bob has recently been diagnosed with mitochondrial diabetes, which he knows is caused by a mutation in his mitochondrial DNA. They would like to know what the risk of Bob passing on his mitochondrial diabetes is.

 

As the clued up medical student that you are, you are able to answer and tell them...
Explanation:
Mitochondiral inheritance follows a characteristic pattern where:

- a mother passes it to ALL of her offspring

- a father passes it to NONE of his offspring. 

 

Mitochondrial diabetes is caused by a mutation in the rTNA leu gene which affects protein synthesis. It presents with diabetes-associated symptoms, deafness, muscle weakness and seizures. 

 

Heritability depends on mutation load but because only Bob has the condition then he won't pass it on to his children.

Question: A patient has low cortisol levels and you establish that they have Addison's disease. On imaging, the adrenals are ENLARGED. What is the most likely cause for this patient's addison's disease?
Explanation:
Source Peter Taylor lecture

 

Metastatic- shows as enlarged adrenals with architecture obscured- CORRECT ANSWER

 

TB/sarcoidosis shows as granulomas seen

 

Autoimmune looks like irregularly shrunken glands

 

Secondary hypoadrenalism is due a problem with pituitary and the adrenals are small and flattened

Question: A patient reports episodes of a racing heart and light-headedness that happens once a week. What's the most appropriate method to aid diagnosis?
Explanation:
This patient has a frequent paroxysmal arrhythmia which would suit the method of having a 24 hour tape monitor that the patient can have for up to 2 weeks.

 

If the patient had a persistent arrhythmia, it would be producible on a 12 ECG there and then.

 

If the patient had an infrequent paroxysmal arrhythmia, it would be best to have an implantable loop recorder which could monitor the patient's ECG for years

Question: IFN-a and IFN-B are mediators released by virally infected cells in response to the presence of double-stranded viral RNA. Which of the following is mainly responsible for producing large amounts of these mediators?
Explanation:
Interferons are a family of eukaryotic cell proteins classified according to the cell of origin. IFN-a and IFN-B are produced by a variety of virally infected cells, but the plasmacytoid dendritic cells are responsible for producing the largest amount of IFN upon viral exposure. Any cell can produce IFN because any nucleated cell can be infected by a virus, but plasmacytoid dendritic cells have an increased capacity for producing IFN-a and B, and are have an abundance of TLR-7 and TLR-9.

 

A cell that is virally infected can take the heroic stand of saving its neighbouring uninfected cells. This infected cell makes interferon, which is released to the other cells, which if accepted, saves these cells from viral replication.

 

Cells that accept IFN can temporarily shut down protein synthesis, which stops the virus from replicating, as they need the host cell's machinery to do so. Therefore, the virus can still enter the cell but it cannot replicate. 

 

There are 2 mechanisms in which IFN inhibits viral protein synthesis:

  1. Through activation of an RNA endonuclease, which digests viral RNA
  2. By activation of protein kinase that inactivates eIF2 (initiation factors), thus inhibiting viral protein synthesis, this effectively interferes with translation.

IFN can also activate natural killer cells by increasing the expression of ligands for receptors for NK cells. 

 

Exogenous human IFN may be used in antiviral therapy for chronic, active Hep B and C infection.

 

Therapeutic Uses of IFNs

  • IFNs increase the expression of MHC I and II, augment NK cells, and increase the efficiency of presentation of antigens to cytotoxic lymphocytes and T helper cells.
  • IFN-a is an antiviral used in treatment for Hep B and C infections
  • IFN-b increases remission in multiple sclerosis

Note that conventional dendritic cells are responsible for the activate of naive T cell

Question:
A 23 year old female English student presents to you with a history of right lower quadrant abdominal pain, tenderness, mouth ulcers and diarrhoea. She tells you that this has been going on for 18 months and has been getting fevers at least one a month and experienced significant weight loss. 

 

After carrying out an endoscopy, you confirm your suspicions as to what condition might be. As well as prescribing Sulfasalazine and Budesonide, you provide her with some information about the risks and complications associated with her condition. 

 

One such complication is fistulas. Which of the following fistulas is MOST LIKELY to develop with this particular condition?
Explanation:
Based on the patient's gender, age and symptoms, her condition was Crohn's Disease. The trans mural inflammation associated with Crohn's can often lead to fistulization, of which Entero-Enteric fistulas are most likely. 

 

 

A. Entero-Cutaneous Fistulae (Gut-Skin)

Fistulas work through the skin following the paths of least resistance including:

-Surgical scars (follows surgical dissection)

-Along persistent urachal remnant to umbilicus (anatomical plane)

-Along psoas muscle to emerge near the groin (anatomical plane)

-Direct retroperitoneal extension to burst through the flank (anatomical plane)

-Direct extension anteriorly to point in the right lower quadrant of the anterior abdominal wall (abdominal plane)

 

B. ENTERO-ENTERIC FISTULA (Gut-Gut)

-The organ into which a Crohn's disease fistula is most likely to penetrate is an adjacent loop of bowel.

-Fistula from a segment of ileal Crohn's can extend into other ileal loops, caecum and sigmoid

 

C. Entero-Vesical (Gut- Bladder)

-The terminal ileum crosses the dome of the bladder as it traverses the pelvis

-The most common form of internal Crohn's disease fistula after Entero-Enteric 

-Dysuria is a frequent symptom and UTIs result 

-Pneumaturia is one of the earliest and most pathogomonic signs

 

D. Perianal Fistulae and Abscess

-Arises from crypts of Morgagni in the anus and spreads through the internal sphincter muscle

-Complications include intershinceric abscess, ischiorectal abscess, supralevator abscess and/or rectovaginal/perineal/buttock fistulae

-Entirely seperate from intra-abdominal Crohn's and from enteric fistulae

-BUT 1/3 Crohn's disease may have a history of anorectal fissures/fistulae/perianal abscesses

 

E. Retroperitoneal Disease

-Extension of ileal disease into surround mesentery so the inflammatory process extends to the retroperitoneum

-Entrapment of the ureter (usually to the right) against the psoas muscle reuslts in non-calculous hydroureter and hydronephrosis

-Extension of the inflammatory process further posteriorly may cause a psoas abscess (usually on the left when fistulization arises from the descending/sigmoid colon)

-Typical symptoms include pain referred to the hip, knee, or thigh accompanied by hip flexion (all on the opposing side) and a pronounced limp 

(All this information was from the notes provided with the IBD Lecture from Case 11)

Question:
A 32 year old male presents to your clinic with a 2 day history of vomiting, diarrhea and abdominal pain. He tells you that he recently tried to recreate a cheeky Nandos in the comfort of his own home but was unsure as to whether he had actually cooked his chicken properly.

 

After telling him to 'COOK YOUR GOD DAMN CHICKEN', you take a stool sample and you conclude that the infective agent was Campylobacter Jejuni. 

 

Which of the following profiles matches that of Campylobacter?
OptionD: Gram -ve, lots of species
Explanation:
A: Giardia

B: Clostridium Difficile

C: Escherichia Coli

D: Salmonella

E: Campylobacter

 

 

A few points:

  • Microaerophillic: means microorganism needs O2 to surive but needs a environment with lower levels than are present in the atmosphere (<21%)
  • Facultative anaerobe: an organism that makes ATP by aerobic respiration if O2 is present but is capable of switching to fermentation/anaerobic respiration if O2 is absent 
  • Leave Nandos-style chicken to people that know what they're doing

Question: Which protein found in breast milk is responsible for inhibiting bacterial cell adhesion and promoting the growth of natural flora?
Explanation:
Correct answer = Caesin

 

Alpha-lactalbumin = Promotes growth of natural flora

Lysozyme = Bacterial cell wall lysis and increases IgA production and macrophage activation

Lactoferrin = Binds Iron, blocks viruses and adhesion of bacteria, cell growth and repair

Prolactin = a hormone produced by the anterior pituitary gland which controls milk production (lactogenesis)

Question: You are a GP and a middle woman has come to see you. She says she has been very tired recently, gained weight and feels down. On examination you notice she has bradycardia, a hoarse voice and cool, dry skin. What is the likely cause of these symptoms?
Explanation:
Hypothyroidism is when the thyroid gland secretes inadequate amounts of the thyroid hormones. It is more common in women and common causes include autoimmune disease, ablative therapy, iodine deficiency or it can be idiopathic. Other symptoms include: 

- cold intolerance

- menstrual irregularities

- joint pain

- constipation

- muscle cramp. 

Other signs include: 

- periorbital puffiness

- loss of out eyebrow

- non-pitting oedema

- hypothermia

- delayed relaxation of ankle jerk

If this is primary cause her likely blood results would be high TSH and low T4. T3 is not used as it is usually normal. If it is of secondary cause then TSH will also be low. 

Conn's syndrome is when there is excess aldostrone secretion from the adrenal gland/s. It presents with hypertension and sometimes hypokalaemia. 

Cushing's disease is when there is excess cortisol and can be cause my excess ATCH (from pituitary or ectopic ATCH tumor), excessive adrenal secretion or exogenous glucocorticoids. 

3 major symptoms of depression are anhedonia, low mood and anergia. 

Whilst iodine deficiency is a cause of hypothyroidism in LDC's, it is unlikely this is the cause of the patient's symptoms.

Question: You are on placement and notice a patient. They have a very round face, swollen belly but stick thin legs and arms. They also have a tan, like they have been on an exotic holiday. Whilst observing the patient you hear them snap at their partner for not good reason. What is the cause of the patient's symptoms?
OptionE: Muscle wasting and fluid retention from being suck in a hospital bed for weeks, and irritated because of how bored they are.
Explanation:
Cushing's Disease is due to excessive cortisol, in this patient's case it is likely to be from exogenous corticosteriods given as part of treatment. Other symptoms include fatigue, amerorrhoea or erectile dysfunction, hypertension and diabetes. 

Addison's is primary adrenocortical insufficiency which leads to low aldosterone and cortisol. 

Chronic Liver and Heart disease can both cause ascities. 

Whilst E is possible it wouldn't cause moon face or hyperpigmentation, and there is more likely to be peripheral oedema then central.

Question: What's not a treatment for atrial tachycardia?
Explanation:
Atrial tachycardia can be treated by:

  • Performing the Vasalva Manoeuvre
  • IV Adenosine
  • Amiodarone
  • Decreasing the digoxin dose (may have pro-arrhythmic effects)
  • Cardioversion (if drugs fail)

Question: A 26 year old patient presents with palpitations,T-LOC and breathlessness. His ECG is as follows. What might be the cause of his condition?
Explanation:
The ECG shows Torsades de Pointes. 

 

Causes include:

  • QT lengthening drugs e.g. amiodarone
  • Long QT syndrome
  • hypocalcaemia
  • hypokalaemia
  • hypomagnesia
  • hypothyroidism

Question: Which of the following statements regarding virology is incorrect?
OptionA: DNA viruses travel into the nucleus of the host cell in order to replicate, whereas RNA viruses can replicate in the cytoplasm
OptionB: Herpes virus (an enveloped virus) exits the host cell through fusion, whereby it fuses one host cell membrane with the next, and so on, forming a synctia
OptionC: Antibodies are helpful for controlling the spread of naked viruses by binding to it and preventing its attachment to a host cell
OptionD: -ssRNA virus entering a cell must first form an intermediate replicative form of +ssRNA before producing more -ssRNA
OptionE: Naked viruses are inactivated by heat and detergents, whereas enveloped viruses are not
Explanation:
All the statements are correct aside from E.

 

A naked virus is stronger than an enveloped virus. Why? Because the envelope is derived from the host cell membrane, therefore it is sensitive to drying and detergents. In the same way, when you sneeze, the cells that are expelled will dry and shrink as soon as the air hits them, because cell host membrane is sensitive to heat and detergents. 

 

Whereas, a naked virus is simply a piece of nucleic acid, surrounded by a protein coat (a very sturdy icosahedron coating) - therefore, when exposed to drying/detergents, it is not inactivated.

 

The way this translates clinically is because it is important for understanding methods of transmission. For example, only non-enveloped viruses can use the GI tract as a portal of entry. If enveloped viruses were ingested and passed into the stomach, the acidity would digest the envelope, and the virion package that would be left over would not have the necessary protein receptors to bind onto the host cell, and thus the virus is eliminated.

 

With a naked virus, when ingested, its sturdy outer structure can withstand the GI tract as a point of entry.

 

Norovirus, rotavirus, polio and hepatitis A are all naked viruses, and therefore can use the faecal-oral route of transmission. Whereas enveloped viruses (most of the hepatitis infections) are much more sensitive and are spread by close contract, sexual contact or shared needles.

Question: Which of the following substances in breast milk is responsible for the promotion of growth of bifidobacterium?
Explanation:
Lactalbumin -Promotes growth of bifidobacterium

Caesin is a protein in breast milk that inhibits bacterial cell adhesion and promotes the growth of natural flora.

Lysozyme-causes bacterial cell wall lysis and increases IgA production and macrophage activation 

Lactoferrin binds to iron, blocks viruses and adhesion of bacteria cell growth and repair

Question: A patient with angina comes into her GP surgery, she needs a repeat prescription of one of her anti-anginals, but unfortunately all of her previous drug history has been lost and her normal doctor is not into today. You are asked to find out what particular drug she needs. She says she sprays it under her tongue and it can give her quite a headache, but it makes her angina go away quickly. What drug do you request a repeat prescription for?
Explanation:
All of these drugs apart from GTN are oral.

Question: Ella Davies visits your GP morning clinic with her 3 year old son Ollie. She explains that since yesterday, Ollie has had a fever and has been holding his forehead in his hands saying "head bad bad". You have a look at poor Ollie who appears unwell, and notice something unusual. You check Ollie's immunisation history, and find he has had no vaccinations since birth. When you ask Ella about this, she says that vaccinations are the governments scheme of making us all the same by injecting these foreign things into us. What do you diagnose Ollie with?
Explanation:
Mumps (as well as measles) is from the Paramyxoviridae family of viruses.

The family characteristics are:

- Enveloped, helical nucleocapsid virus

- -ssRNA

 

Mumps

  • Reservoir: human respiratory tract
  • Transmission: person to person via respiratory droplets
  • Pathogenesis: lytic infection
  • Clinical presentation: - bilateral or unilateral parotitis, major swollen parotid glands, making neck extremely painful to move and difficulty swallowing

                                            - fever, headache and malaise

  • Complications include: pancreatitis, orchitis (inflammation of one or both testicles, leading to sterility in males, most severe complication), and viral meningoencephalitis
  • Diagnosis: - clinically - serology
  • Treatment: supportive
  • Prevention: live, attentuated vaccine for MMR

(SIDE NOTE; GUYS PLEASE ALL GIVE ME AN EXCELLENT RATING I WANT A BADGE HAHAHA - THANKS GUYS XX)
Explanation:
Anterior spinal artery syndrome (also known as "anterior spinal cord syndrome") is a medical condition where the anterior spinal artery, the primary blood supply to the anterior portion of the spinal cord, is interrupted, causing ischemia or infarction of the spinal cord in the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord and medulla oblongata. It is characterized by loss of motor function below the level of injury, loss of sensations carried by the anterior columns of the spinal cord (pain and temperature), and preservation of sensations carried by the posterior columns (fine touch, vibration and proprioception). Anterior spinal artery syndrome is the most common form of spinal cord infarction.

Explanation:
Plasma volume begins to increase from the start of pregnancy this is down to oestrogen stimulating the renin- angiotensin- aldosterone system. However red cell mass only starts to increase once there are sufficient levels of erythropoietin

- EPO is secreted by the kidneys to stimulate erythropoiesis in the 1st trimester 

 

 

Although renin does stimulate the pathway, the best answer for this question would be oestrogen.

Question: Why does IgG have the highest affinity for antigens out of all the antibody isotypes?
OptionA: Because somatic hypermutation occurs at the same time as class switching also occurs
OptionB: Because the CD40/CD40L interaction enhances the affinity of IgG
OptionC: Because IgG is the only antibody to accept IL-4 and IL-5 attachment which enhances affinity
OptionD: Because it has a J chain which binds specifically to the poly Ig receptor on the submucosa
OptionE: Because it is the only antibody to pass across the placenta
Explanation:
A is the single best answer for this question.

 

B - The binding of CD40 on an antigen-presenting cell to the CD40L on the TH2 cell is essential for activation of the B cell, and allowing class-switching from IgM to the other antibody isotypes. IL-4 is responsible for class-switching to IgE, whereas IL-5 and TGF-B are responsible for class-switching to IgA. The interleukins for class-switching for IgG vary depending on which IgG you are producing (i.e. IgG1, IgG2, etc). This however, has no effect on the affinity of IgG.

 

C - I made this up completely

 

D - This actually refers to IgA and why it protects mucosal surfaces. Because it is a dimer with a J-chain connecting it, the J-chain binds specifically to the poly Ig receptor found on the basolateral side of the submucosa. The IgA dimer takes the secretory component of the poly Ig receptor and uses it to pass through the cell, therefore the secretory component protects IgA from degradation as the enzymes in the mucosa cannot attack it. (This means that IgM, which also has J chains, can get into the mucosa as well, but it doesn't do so too well because of it's large size)

 

E - This is true, however it does not increase the affinity of IgG.

 

I'm just gonna go through somatic hypermutation a bit now, which might be slightly long so apologies in advance, but you don't have to read it lol!

 

A dictionary definition of somatic hypermutation is: it enables our immune system to expand the limited diversity encoded within our genomes to the billions of antibody specificities required to defend ourselves against external pathogens.

 

How does it do this? 

 

Germinal centres are sites within secondary lymphoid organs where mature B lymphocytes proliferate, differentiate, and mutate their antibody genes (through somatic hypermutation), and switch the class of their antibody, during a normal immune response to an infection.

 

When dealing with an infection, the immune response is proliferating every 10-12 hours. That is a huge amount of proliferation for eukaryotes. Usually, when making the antibody molecule, DNA polymerase lays down the correct nucleotides, and if it makes a mistake, it will fix it. However, in an infected state, type A DNA polymerase is stressed out and begins to make mistakes (point mutations) in the already made VDJ region of the antibody. Therefore, in somatic hypermutation, there are point mutations in the already made VDJ region resulting in affinity maturation.

 

These point mutations can have 3 different outcomes on the end-product antibody:

  1. It can increase the affinity of the antibody molecule to the antigen
  2. It can decrease the affinity of the antibody molecule to the antigen
  3. No change

If the affinity increases, the antigen binds to the antibody, and this results in an increased proliferation of this antibody, therefore we produce an army of clonal bodies where the daughter cells have a higher affinity and are more specific to the antigen.

 

If the affinity decreases, the antibody cannot bind to the antigen as well, and eventually dies off. 

 

If there is no change, then nothing ventured and nothing gained. 

 

Now, to the crunch of this question, the reason why IgG has the highest affinity, is because at the time when hypermutation is occurring, class switching is also occurring, where IgM is class-switching to IgG, therefore the somatic hypermutation occurs in the IgG antibodies, giving them an increased affinity.

Question: The anterior pituitary gland produces a number of different hormones. There is one hormone in particular that is involved in the protection against hypoglycaemia. Give the name of this hormone.
Explanation:
Anterior pituitary gland hormones:

FSH, LH

Growth hormone

Thyroid stimulating hormone

Prolactin

 

Note: Somatostain is produced by the hypothalamus and inhibits the pituitary gland’s secretion of growth hormone and thyroid stimulating hormone.

 

Growth hormone is synthesised and stored in somatotrophs. 

Function= PROTECT AGAINST HYPOGLYCEMIA.

 

GH targets: 

Muscle--> decreases glucose uptake, stimulates protein synthesis, inhibits protein breakdown, therefore get increased muscle mass

 

Adipose tissue-->Decreases glucose uptake, increases lipolysis, herefore decreases fat deposits

 

Liver--> Increases gluconeogenesis, increases protein synthesis, Stimulates IGF production

 

Bone--> Growth hormone works via Insulin growth factor that is synthesised in the liver to increase chondrocyte production and increase bone length.

 

A decrease in GH in children: Dwarfism

A decrease in GH in adults: no major symptoms

 

An increase in GH in children: Gigantism

An increase in GH in adults: Acromegaly

 

Also note that IGF stimulates SOMATOSTATIN release and somatostatin INHIBITS GH.

Question: On a ward round, you meet a patient who is recovering from a left sided chest stabbing. On assessment, he cannot feel any pain or temperature in his right leg. He also cannot move his left leg, or feel any touch upon it. What is he most likely to be suffering from?
Explanation:
Brown sequard is usually resultant from a penetrating such as a stab, causing hemisection of the cord. Symptoms are ipsilateral paralysis, ipsilateral loss of touch, contralateral loss of pain and temperature. 

This has the best prognosis out of the spinal syndromes.

Question: What does the a wave correspond to in the JVP?
OptionA: The atrium contracting and the mitral valve opening
OptionB: The atrium contracting and the tricuspid valve opening
OptionC: The atrium contracting and the mitral valve closing
OptionD: The ventricles contracting and the aortic valve opening
OptionE: The ventricles contracting and the pulmonary valve opening
Explanation: The a wave corresponds to the atrium contracting. The JVP is a measure of the right heart's function, so therefore it is related to the tricuspid valve opening.

Question: What does a large a wave in a JVP waveform suggest?
Explanation:
A large a wave shows that there is increased resistance to ventricular filling. This can occur in pulmonary hypertension or tricuspid stenosis, among other things.

A won't show anything directly on JVP (JVP is a measure of the right heart).

B would show an absent a wave 

C would show a cannon a wave

E would show a large V wave

Question: You are a second year medical student practising for your ISCE in a few weeks (sorry for the reminder). You decide to practice the cardiovascular examination on your younger brother, who is 5 years old. As far as you know, he is healthy. When listening to his heart you hear a third heart sound "lub-dub-ta". What does this mean?
OptionE: He is probably fine, this is normal in the young
Explanation:
The correct answer is E. S3 can be heard in youth, some trained athletes and sometimes in pregnancy. It is thought to occur when rapidly rushing blood from the atria is suddenly decelerated by the ventricle when it reaches its elastic limit. In a normal ventricle, this can happen with excessive volume of incoming blood, as can happen in hyperdynamic states or volume-loaded conditions (pregnancy). 

In pathology (ie if he wasn't a healthy 5 year old) S3 can be heard with hypertrophy and diastolic dysfunction. 

S4 is heard with a hypertrophic left ventricle.

Mitral regurgitation produces a pansystolic murmur

Aortic regurgitation does not usually produce an audible murmur

Mitral stenosis produces soft, rumbling murmur

I've said "delayed puberty" in the question, but she will actually never grow through puberty unless hormones are given, because there are steak ovaries.

Question:
A 61-year-old female with a diagnosis of bronchial carcinoma presents with increasing tiredness and dizziness.
Investigations reveal the following:
Plasma sodium concentration 115 mmol/L (137-144)
Potassium 3.5 mmol/L (3.5-4.9)
Urea 3.2 mmol/L (2.5-7.5)
Creatinine 67 µmol/L (60-110)

Which of the following is the likely cause of her problems?
Explanation:
This patient has hyponatraemia and other biochemistry is also low.
The likely diagnosis is syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion.
ADH is a posterior pituitary hormone that is responsible for antidiuresis. It can be ectopically elaborated by tumours such as bronchial carcinoma and hence cause a dilutional hyponatraemia.
The diagnosis is one of exclusion but can be supported by a high urine sodium concentration with high urine osmolality (concentrated urine).
Hypoadrenalism would be less likely and although associated with a hyponatraemia you might also expect a hyperkalaemia and mild hyperuraemia.

Question: A patient presents with winging of the scapula whilst you on placement. The f1 asks you which nerve is damaged to cause it?
Explanation: The long thoracic nerve inervates serratus anterior. If it is damaged then serratus anterior is paralysed. The serratus anterior muscle normally holds the scapula in position whilst the upper limb is moving, so this means the scapula can protrude out the back.

Only IgG can cross the placenta

Question: Which two components comprise a conjugate vaccine?
OptionA: An inactivated virus and an inactivated bacteria
OptionB: Cytokine which encourages class-switching, and primed antibodies
OptionC: Highly purified form of bacteria and aluminium salts (e.g. Aluminium Phosphate/Aluminium Hydroxide)
OptionD: A polysaccharide epitope and a toxoid protein
Explanation:
D is correct. I'll try to explan why...

 

Conjugate vaccines are used to against bacteria (e.g. Hib, pneumococcal, meningococcal) which have a polysaccharide coat. Bacteria with a polysaccharide coat are harder for antibodies to bind to - usually B cells recognise bacteria by the proteins on their membrane.

 

B cells present peptide segments (derived from the protein) of the vaccine to T helper cells (via MHC II), in order for the T helper cell to activate the B cell to start producing the correct antibodies. Without this interaction, B cells would not be activated and would not be able to produce the correct antibodies when the host is re-infected.

 

A conjugate vaccine must therefore contain 

  • polysaccharides (to mimic the bacteria's polysaccharide coat) 
  • and protein (to be internalised then presented to T helper cells)

Reinfection

 

The causative bacteria's polysaccharide coat is recognised by antibodies, and the bacteria are opsonised (or destroyed by complement), thanks to a speedy response from Ig-secreting plasma cells.

 

Hope this hasn't confused anyone!

 

Taken from Dr Matthew's lecture in Case 9

Question:

I appreciate a question like this is unlikely to come up but the purpose was to test whether or not you knew that H.Pylori is the most common cause of gastric ulceration and that it is tested for using the Urea Breath Test

Question: James Barnes, a 30 year old Lidl worker, comes into the GP practise you are on placement on. James cant be given a H2 Receptor Antagonist. Given his history, the anti-coagulant in question is warfarin. H2RAs are a cytochrome p450 inhibitor and impair the metabolism of warfarin. Other side effects include impotence and gynaecomastia

Question: Sally is 13 weeks pregnant, her endocrine system has adapted to allow for the pregnancy. Which of the following hormonal changes does not occur during pregnancy?
Explanation:
During Pregnancy the main hormonal changes that occur are:

 

A: Increase in hPL production

 

B: Incorrect: there is an increase in MSH secretion, this is due to production of placental substances that are very similar to ATCH and so cause TSH and MSH release- leading the the darkened pigment on the abdomen of pregnant women (linea nigra)


B: Suppression of FSH and LH due to progesterone and oestrogen

 

C: Increase in progesterone secretion, this allows expansion (vasodilation) of the mothers circulation to increase cardiac output

 

D: Increase in thyroid binding globulin, this helps to counteract the effects of hyperthyroidism that may be caused by placental trophic factors which are structurally similar to TSH and so cause thyroid hormone release. 


E: Suppression of FSH and LH due to increased oestrogen and progesterone levels therefore prevents ovulation occurring again

Question:
"Severe drowsiness in which the patient can be aroused by moderate stimuli and then drift back to sleep."

 

Which of the following terms relating to consciousness corresponds to this description?
Explanation:
Conscious: fully aware and interacting with one's environment

Drowsy (somnolent): easily aroused by voice/touch; awakens and follows commands; requires stimulation to maintain arousal

Lethargic: severe drowsiness in which the patient can be aroused by moderate stimuli and then drifts back to sleep

Stupor: only vigorous and repeated stimuli will arouse individual and when left undisturbed, patient will immediately lapse back into unresponsive state

Coma: a state of prolonged unconsciousness, from which one cannot be aroused, and fails to respond to stimuli

Vegetative state: awake but non-responsive state

Question:

Complete spinal cord injury shows complete loss of function below injury

Question:
It's your first week as a Junior Doctor at your local hospital and you really want to give a good impression to your peers. Your Senior, who is a sly guy, sees you slightly nervous and comes up to you and asks to analyse the following ABG of a patient on his ward:

 

  • pH: 7.36 (7.35-7.45)
  • PaCO2: 31 mmHg (35-45 mmHg)
  • [HCO3-]: 17 mEq/L (22-26 mEq/L)

 

What is going on here?
OptionB: Metabolic Acidosis with Full Respiratory Alkalosis compensation
OptionD: Metabolic Acidosis with Partial Respiratory Alkalosis compensation
Explanation:
Answer: Metabolic Acidosis with Full Respiratory Alkalosis compensation

 

pH: 7.36 (7.35-7.45)

- pH is overall normal, but is towards the acidotic side of the normal range.

 

PaCO2: 31 mmHg (35-45 mmHg)

- CO2 tension is low → respiratory alkalosis.


[HCO3-]: 17 mEq/L (22-26 mEq/L)

- HCO3- concentration is low → metabolic acidosis.

 

The pH is at the low end of normal (toward the acidotic side), but the HCO3- and CO2 levels indicate something abnormal is happening.

The body generally doesn't overcompensate and so the key thing here is the acidotic pH.

 

Respiratory Alkalosis compensation (i.e. lowering CO2) - Kussmaul's breathing, as seen in DKA of T1DM.
