She wants to work out her estimated due date and rings you, her medical student friend for help. You tell her her EDD is...
Explanation: EDD= 1st day of last menstrual period + 7 days + 9 months

Question: You are shadowing a doctor in a genetics clinic. A mother comes in with her little boy and says that he has been gets lots of infections and doesn't seem to be able to hear her. He was recently diagnosed with Teratology of Fallot. What do you think is wrong with him?
Explanation:
Di George is a deletion of 22q 11.2

 

Symptoms-

cardiac abnormalities

immune deficiency due to problem with thymus gland

hypoparathyroidism --> hyponatraemia

cleft palate

conductive deafness

short

learning disabilities

renal abnormalities

 

t21= down syndrome

 

t13= patau syndrome

 

Maternal UPD 15q11-13 is prader willi- maternal UPD means that the deletion is inherited on the paternal chromosome and the symptoms show because the maternal chromosome has been silenced

Question: Which of these is a derivative of the mesodermal germ layer?

A mother has had genetic testing because she had a baby with T21. Turns out that her genotype is 45 XX t(14:21).

What is her recurrance risk of having another baby with T21?
Explanation:
She has a robertsonian translocation of the acrosomic chromosomes 14 and 21.

This can lead to T21. It is the case of around 3-4% cases of T21.

If the mother is the one that has it her recurrance risk is 10% if it is the father his risk of recurrance is <0.5% due to the 'selection of sperm'

 

95% Down syndrome cases are caused solely by 3 seperate copies of c21 in the kid, and the recurrance risk for the mum in this case is 1% or the age related risk if she is over 35.

 

A Robertsonian translocation between 21 and 21 can potentially have a 100% recurrance risk (remember you have 2 copies of T21 in your cells, so if you get 2 long arms of 21 sticking together, you are providing 2 copies of c21, which goes with your partner's 1 copy of c21 and hey presto you have 3 copies for your child.)

Question: Where is oxytocin released from and where is it made?
Explanation:
Oxytocin is released from the posterior pituitary and is made in the hypothalamus.

 

I always get this wrong that is why I made it a question, hope it helps!

Question: Marina is 37 weeks pregnant, she has some bloods done and you are going through her liver function tests with her. What might you expect to see?

Question: What is the most common type of Robertsonian translocation? What does it increase the risk of?
Explanation: c13 and c14 are acrocentric chromosomes (as are 15, 21 and 22) acrocentric means they have a very short p arm

Question: Which of the following is true about glycaemic index (GI)?
OptionA: Pure glucose has high GI but will not reach 100
OptionB: Food with high fats content will increase the GI
OptionC: Low GI will release glucose more slowly and steadily
OptionD: High GI food is not suitable for meal after an intense exercise
OptionE: Vegetables and fruits have a high GI
Explanation:
The glycemic index or glycaemic index (GI) is a number associated with a particular type of food that indicates the food's effect on a person's blood glucose (also called blood sugar) level. A value of 100 represents the standard, an equivalent amount of pure glucose

 

The GI is useful for understanding how the body breaks down carbohydrates and only takes into account the available carbohydrate (total carbohydrate minus fiber) in a food. Although the food may contain fats and other components that contribute to the total rise in blood sugar, these effects are not reflected in the GI.

 

A high-GI food causes a more rapid rise in blood glucose levels and is suitable for energy recovery after exercise or for a person experiencing hypoglycemia.

 

Fruits and vegetables tend to have a low glycemic index.

Question: What day does gastrulation occur
Explanation: day 16

Question: What pattern of inheritance is this
Explanation:
Only males affected. Females are carriers

An example is red green colour blindness

Question: Which of the following about the physiological changes in pregnancy is true?
OptionA: Heart rate increases by a greater % change compared to the stroke volume change
OptionB: There is a decrease in fibrinogen and Factors VII, VIII, X
OptionC: Plasma Volume decreases by 10-15% usually in the first trimester
OptionD: Platelet count can decrease by up to 5% by the 3rd trimester
OptionE: GFR initially decreases by up to 50% in the first trimester
Explanation:
D is correct

A, B, C and E are all opposites basically 

Stroke volume increases more than heart rate 

Increase in clotting factors is generally seen 

GFR usually increases in the first trimester by up to 50% 

Plasma volume usually increases by 10-15% in 1st trimester

Question: We fast forward 30 years into the future and the Great Yograj has had a fulfilling career as a model. From the fine Abu Dhabian chicks to the ultra fast toyota corollas, he has had it all. Due to the stress of being a super model, Yograj lived recklessly and was diagnosed with COPD at age 50. A few years after his COPD diagnosis (which is very poorly managed), Yograj started to complain of chest pain and feeling his heart skip beats. He was referred to the cardiologist, his son Sujan, who performed a 12 lead ECG which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis considering his history and the ECG?
Explanation:
Multifocal atrial tachy is a narrow complex tachycardia.

 

A rapid, irregular atrial rhythm arising from multiple ectopic foci within the atria.
Most commonly seen in patients with severe COPD or congestive heart failure.
It is typically a transitional rhythm between frequent premature atrial complexes (PACs) and atrial flutter / fibrillation.

Question: When is a baby considered a fetus?

Question: You are on your gap year in Guinea, Africa. You meet John a 10 year old boy. He is talking to you about why he gets laughed at when he is at school. He has clubfoot. He wants to know what caused this.
OptionA: His mother got a tropical disease when she was pregnant which caused him to get clubfoot
Explanation:
Clubfoot is a deformation. Deformation= due to mechanical factors that moult fetal parts over a prolonged period of time. Eg. clubfoot from compression in amniotic cavity.

 

The relevance to Guinea is that in the UK most kids with clubfoot have the operation to sort it out no problem so you hardly ever see a 10 year old with clubfoot but in Africa it is often too expensive for families to afford this.

Question: Kelly's husband is angry because their kid has just been born without a limb. He thinks Kelly got some thalidomide on the black market because her morning sickness was so bad and she would try anything. However the doctor reassures him that is is more likely that their kid has:

Question: Princess Charlotte becomes unwell with a runny nose, fever, cough, redness of the eyes and Koplik's spots in her mouth. Kate and Will think it's probably just a cold and get the nanny to give her some Calpol. A few days later, however, a strange, bumpy rash appears on her forehead, so they decide it's best if the nanny takes her to the doctor. The doctor gives a clinical diagnosis of Measles. Which antibody would have been tested for in order to confirm this diagnosis?
Explanation:
Most cases of measles are diagnosed clinically but detection of measles-specific IgM in blood or oral fluid, or genome or antigen detection from nasopharyngeal aspirates or throat swabs should be used to confirm the diagnosis.

 

(Taken from Kumar and Clark)

Question: Mrs. Evans brings her 10 year old son into clinic with fever, malaise, headache, anorexia and severe parotid gland pain and swelling. The GP makes a clinical diagnosis of Mumps, what is the most appropriate form of confirming this diagnosis?
OptionE: Test for IgM antibodies in oral fluid
Explanation:
Diagnosis of mumps is made by clinical features, as the symptoms presented here are very typical of mumps, there is no need for further investigation. 

 

In doubtful cases, serological demonstration of a mumps-specific IgM response in an acute blood or oral fluid sample is diagnostic. Virus can be isolated in cell culture, or identified by genome or antigen detection assays, from saliva, throat swab, urine and CSF.

Question: What is the most common reason for triploidy?

CORRECT is Diandry= 1 egg fertilised by 2 sperm. 60-80% of triploidies. Causes a LARGE PLACENTA and a small fetus

 

Digny=Diploid egg fertilised by 1 sperm. 20-40% cases of triploidy. Small placenta and LARGE FETUS

 

C,D,E can more likely cause trisomies. such as T21, Down syndrome :)

Question: Youre in the genetics clinic and a distraught mother comes to you telling you that her baby has been born with holoprosencephaly. Question:

Question: Which of these isn't true about Prader Willi syndrome caused by UPD

Question: Which of the following statements is true about genetic disease?
OptionA: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is caused by maternal UPD chromosome 11 (short arm: 11p15)

OptionC: Angelman syndrome is caused by maternal UPD chromosome 15 (long arm: 15q11-13)
OptionD: UPD is defined as the occurrence of two or more cell lines with different genetic or chromosomal constitutions within a single individual or tissue
OptionE: Germline mosaicism often presents with with affected individuals having no features of the disease itself but being able to transmit the disease to their children
Explanation:
A-Caused by Paternal UPD of chromosome 11p15 

B-PWS can be caused by Maternal UPD chromosome 15q11-13

C-AS can be caused by Paternal UPD chromosome 15q11-13

D-This defines mosaicism. UPD is when a child inherits both chromosomes from the same parent (so maternal UPD  means both chromosome are from the mother for example)

E is true.

Question: There are certain types of biological rhythms that show cyclical variation over time. Sleep is one of these. Which of the following best describes the cyclical variation of sleep?
What is the main hormone involved in ejection of milk through the lactiferous ducts?
Explanation:
After birth:

Prolactin and oxytocin increase

Oestrogen and progesterone levels decrease

 

Oxytocin causes contraction of the myoepithelial cells that surround the alveoli, on contraction the myoepithelial cells eject the milk into the lactiferous ducts. 

 

 Orexin is not involved in the lactation! It is a neuropeptide that regulates arousal, wakefulness, and appetite.

Question: Mrs Lawrence is wondering whether she is a carrier for Duchenne's Muscular Dystrophy. She knows that her brother had the condition and that her mum was definitely a carrier, but none of her 3 sons have been affected with the condition. Given this fact, what is the chance that Mrs Lawrence is a carrier?
Explanation:
This is the explanation given in the lecture-but personally I find this quite time consuming and confusing so I will show my method below. Please don't stress too much over this-if it comes up it will be one question 

 

So DMD is an X linked recessive condition (which you would be expected to know) thus the father (not stated he has DMD) is irrelevant in this question. However, you know that her brother had the condition, so therefore the mother must be carrier. Knowing this, Mrs Lawrence has ½ of being a carrier as she would of have either receive the DMD X chromosome from the mother or the healthy X chromosome from the mother. You know also that her 3 children that are boys are all unaffected. If she were a carrier, the chance of her passing the DMD X chromosome on would be ½. If she weren’t a carrier the chances of her passing this DMD X chromosome would be 0, as she doesn’t have the affected X chromosome gene (throughout this question, you are assuming that there are no de novo DMD mutations which occurs in 1/3 cases of the disease) . Thus to calculate the total probability you supply multiple all the accumulative probabilities for both possibilities. From this you basically get 1/16 she is a carrier and ½ she is not a carrier. After this you can do an Odds Ratio. Basically a ratio of each probability to each you get 1: 8. To finally get the answer however, you need to add up the two numbers of the ratio (1+8=9) and then put the OR of her being a carrier (1) over the total (1/9)

Thus we can do this table 

Therefore 1/1+8 =1/9=Correct answer :) 

If I have confused you more, please comment and I'll try and explain it better. If your method got the right answer, ignore my method as I am doing what I find the quickest and easiest for me.

 

Thanks

Question: Jeanette is about to start medical school. Being from Malaysia, she is required to be vaccinated against Hepatitis B. However, after 3 full courses (9 injections) worth of Booster doses, Jeanette unfortunately isn't reactive to the vaccinations. 3 years fast forward, its its the start of clinical years. Her GP recommends that she would be given Human Normal Immunoglobulin. 2 weeks later she goes for a blood test. Her antibody results shows positive for _____
Explanation:
**** Sorry for the confusion. The answer is IgG anti-HBsAg. I've emailed Dr James and this was his take on the question. 

 

Interesting and useful question. Some individuals (less than 5%) do not make an anti vaccine response (IgG) to HBsAg even after a second round of three boosts (six shots in aggregate total). In order to protect these individuals they are offered a passive administration of anti HBsAg IgG from selected donors (termed Hepatitis B immune globulin or HBIG) with high anti-HBsAg titres (of at least 1:100,000). Please note that it is only anti-HBsAg IgG that gives 'sterilising' protection because it is a high affinity neutralising antibody that prevents virus from entering hepatocytes. Option B is therefore the correct answer as most people have indicated. With this revision it makes for an excellent question. Well done for thinking it up.
RJM

 

Q I was just wondering if someone doesn't react to Hepatitis B vaccinations containing HBsAg, why would you give anti-HbsAg IgG?
In that case, wouldn't the antibodies administered to that person be anti-HBeAg?

 

Good points but remember that this is 'passive' and not 'active' immunisation in this scenario. Just because an individual fails to make an 'active' immune response to HBsAg that does not mean they will not still be protected by a 'passive' administration of anti-HBsAg IgG. There has to be anti-HBsAg IgG in the sera that is administered because it's the only anti-HB antibody that will give protection. There may well be anti-HBeAg antibodies present in sera but they will not provide the 'sterilising protection' that is needed.
RJM

Question:
Yograj has got Prader-Willi syndrome.

What is true of Prader-Willi?
OptionA: The maternal chromosome is imprinted, and the mutated paternal copy is non-functional.
OptionB: The paternal chromosome is imprinted, and the mutated maternal copy is non-functional.
OptionC: The maternal chromosome is imprinted, and the paternal copy is functional.
OptionD: The paternal chromosome is imprinted, and the maternal copy is functional.
Explanation:
This is something that confused me massively.

 

In Prader-Willi syndrome, the paternal copy of the genes are non-functional. The maternal copy of the genes are imprinted - that is, they are not expressed, and may as well be invisible. Therefore, the syndrome arises because people PWS have a non-working set (paternal) and imprinted set (maternal) - and therefore don't have a single working set.

 

The exact opposite is true for Angelman syndrome.

 

I'm not sure on whether a paternal UPD or maternal UPD would cause Prader-Willi, can anyone explain that?

Question: A woman, at 50% prior risk of carrying DMD, has four sons who are healthy. Assuming her next child is a son, what is the chance that her next son will be affected?
Explanation: Please see my other question on this topic for a more detailed explanation how to do this question. Remember the answer is for the probability that her next son will be affected-ten question DOES NOT ask the probability that she is a carrier but you still need this to work out the answer

Question: Which of the following is true about imprinting in genetics?
OptionA: Imprinting refers to a gene from the mother or father of a child being switched on
OptionB: Paternally Expressed means the maternal copy of the gene is switched off
OptionC: Maternally Expressed means the maternal copy of the gene is switched off
OptionD: Paternally Expressed means the paternal copy of the gene is switched off
OptionE: Complete imprinting means both paternal and maternal copies of the gene are switched on
Explanation: Imprinted gene refers to a gene being switched off

Question: Your friend is sleeping badly because he is stressed about his exams. His overall state is sleep deprived. How will his body compensate?
OptionD: He will have more stage 3 and 4 sleep
Explanation:
His body will compensate with more slow wave, non-REM sleep i.e. stage 3 and 4.

Sleep deprivation within a circadian cycle is followed by less sleep not more.

Stage 1 sleep - alpha waves, low amplitude, similar to drowsy wakefulness

Stage 2 sleep - slower frequency, higher amplitude, K complexes and sleep spindles.

Stage 3 sleep - delta waves appear, deep sleep, breathing, heart rate and body temp decrease.

Stage 4 sleep - very deep sleep, difficult to rouse

REM - skeletal muscle paralysed, dreaming sleep, alpha waves

Question:
Harry Potter has just been to McDonalds and had a double quarter pounder with cheese and an Oreo McFlurry, and has started to feel some pain in the right upper quadrant of his abdomen which radiates slightly into his right shoulder. Harry had a gallstone in the bit which nobody talks about, between the chamber of secrets and the prisoner of Azkaban. He has the occasional butterbeer but he never gets wasted. 

His inflammatory markers are not raised and he is not pyrexic. 

Harry tried doing some of his spells on it, but he's actually a pretty rubbish wizard, so they didn't do anything.  

What disease does Mr Potter most likely have?
Explanation:
A- acute cholecystitis --> is in the right upper quadrant, but this shows signs of fever (pyrexia) and raised inflammatory markers. It is  Inflammation/infection of the gallbladder secondary to impacted gallstones.

Murphy's sign positive (arrest of inspiration on palpation of the RUQ)

 

B- Acute Pancreatitis --> This pain does radiate to the back, but is usually in the epigastrium. Usually due to alcohol or gallstones, so the history with Harry sort of fits, but the pain is often very severe and there is a low grade fever present so it is not the best answer. 

 

C- Appendicitis --> The pain is initially in the central abdomen before localising to the right iliac fossa (RIF).

Anorexia is common. Tachycardia, low-grade pyrexia, tenderness in RIF

also shows Rovsing's sign: more pain in RIF than LIF when palpating LIF, which i found RATHER INTERESTING. 

 

D- Biliary Colic. this is CORRECT! WELL DONE. this is made worse by eating a fatty meal and presents in the RUQ. Caused by a gallstone getting lodged in the bile duct.

In contrast to acute cholecystitis no fever and inflammatory markers are normal. 

It is more likely with a history of gall stones aand the pain can radiate to the back. 

 

E- Renal Colic --> this presents with loin pain radiating to the groin so this isn't what Harry's got. Pain is often severe but intermittent. Patient's are characteristically restless.

Visible or non-visible haematuria may be present.

 

THE END.
Tags: Pain, Renal system, Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11, Lower GI

Question: Which of the following is true about genetic conditions?
OptionA: Autosomal aneuploidy is generally milder than sex chromosome aneuploidy
OptionB: 47 XYY Patients are usually treated with testosterone treatment
OptionC: Robertsonian Translocations are between acrocentric chromosomes with the most common being between chromosome 21 and chromosome 14
OptionD: The most common pattern of Down's syndrome is robertsonian translocation between chromosomes 14 and 21
OptionE: There is a 100% recurrence risk for a parental chromosome 21 to chromosome 21 robertsonian translocation
Explanation:
A-the opposite is true as the y chromosome is small and because the x chromosome, if more than two, can be inactivated 

B-47 XYY patients usually have no treatment-see the lecture for more details, 47 XXY receive testosterone 

C-First part true but most common robertsonian is 13/14 translocation

D-Trisomy 21 is the most common pattern of DS with 95% of cases occurring by this method 

E correct; usually lower if different translocation (about 10-15%) but 100% if 21/21 translocation

Question: Which of the following drugs would not be prescribed routinely to treat depression in adolescents?
Explanation: SSRIs are not commonly prescribed, for very good reason, to people under the age of 18. They have massive inducing of anger, and high suicide risk.

Question: You are a 2nd year medical student shadowing a GP in their surgery. The next patient you see is 6 year old, Yograj Junior, with his mother, Mabli. Yograj has had diarrhoea and vomiting and has also been refusing to eat. The mother explains these symptoms started 2 nights ago after Yograj Jnr's father came home from Abu Dhabi. To celebrate his massive earnings from his forehead modelling career, he decided to have a hog roast and invite all the nieghbours as well (who, Mabli satys have also come down with D+V). The GP checks Yograj Jnr's temperature and records a reading of 38C. The GP now has an idea what is causing poor Yograj Jnr. to feel this way and asks you what the most likely causative agent is and how to treat it. You are taken aback by the question because you were focused solely on the fact that this is the son of the great Yograj and have been wondering whether you can ask for an autograph instead of listening to the GP. The GP is waiting patiently for an answer so you quickly reply..
OptionA: OMG can I pls have Yograj's autograph??!
OptionC: Campylobacter Coli and no treatment will be needed in this case
Explanation:
A - as much as you want to it's very unprofessional, you'll have to get that signature another time

B - c. jejuni although more common, it comes from poultry and isn't the BEST answer, also only if the infection is severe would you give erythromycin

C - CORRECT c.coli comes from pigs and as the whole neighbourhood came down with similar symptoms you presume it's the same causative agent and they all ate the same thing. You don't need to treat this as it's usually self limiting unless the pt is immunocompromised in which case it would be persistent or recurrent

D - also could be correct but again not the best answer and you again only treat salmonella if the infection is severe enough (i.e. to cause bacteraemia in immunocompromised pts) 

E - Not very likely as it is an e.coil strain which has a human reservoir but the treatment is right, you only treat if it's severe in which case you give Ciprofloxacin

Question: What part of the brain is illuminated here?
Explanation:
From the Case 16 lecture on Radiological Neuroanatomy

 

The corona radiata is an extension of the internal capsule superiorly, carrying the same ascending and descending tracts.

Question: Which of the following are highlighted in this brain scan?
Explanation:
From the Case 16 lecture on Radiological Neuroanatomy; all of the white matter tracts are highlighted in the brain scan.

 

The external capusle (outer aqua line on diagram) is a series of white matter tracts that run lateral to the lentiform nucleus and connect different areas of cortex to each other.

 

The interior capsule (inner curvy aqua line on diagram) is a series of white matter tracts split anatomically into the anterior and posterior limb connected by a bend called the genu (latin for knee). It runs medial to the lentiform nucleus and contains fibres running to and from coming from the cerebral cortex (the largest of which is the corticospinal tract).

Question: You're looking at an ECG and you noticed that the P waves look a little odd to you, instead of the usual P wave you have seen, this one has got two pointy bits (bifid wave). Which of the following is most likely the cause of this abnormal P wave?
Explanation:
Mitral stenosis can cause a bifid wave because there is left atrium enlargement. In left atrial enlargement, left atrial depolarisation lasts longer than normal but its amplitude remains unchanged. A common cause of mitral stenosis is rheumatic fever.

 

Therefore, the height of the resultant P wave remains within normal limits but its duration is longer than 120 ms.

A notch (broken line) near its peak may or may not be present (“P mitrale”).

 

In right atrial enlargement, right atrial depolarisation lasts longer than normal and its waveform extends to the end of left atrial depolarisation.
Although the amplitude of the right atrial depolarisation current remains unchanged, its peak now falls on top of that of the left atrial depolarisation wave.
The combination of these two waveforms produces a P waves that is taller than normal (> 2.5 mm), although the width remains unchanged (< 120 ms).

 

Source: http://lifeinthefastlane.com/ecg-library/basics/p-wave/

Question: Fracture of the area circled below is common as it is an area of weakness and can lead to an extradural haematoma due to the artery that lies below this structure... What is the name of this artery?
Explanation: An injured middle meningeal artery is the most common cause of an epidural hematoma. A head injury with a traumatic blow to the side of the head can lead to the fracture of the pterion, where the cranium is thin due to the fusion of the frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones. This area may also be fractured indirectly by blows to the top or back of the head that place sufficient force on the skull to fracture the pterion.

Question: You see a 1 year old child who has a cleft palate, abnormal facies, ventricular septal defect and who keeps getting infections. Blood results show a low calcium level, while  Believing this patient has a genetic condition, what test would you do to confirm your most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
From Case 7 lecture 

You would suspect the patient to have DiGeorge's syndrome as they have recurrent infections (Immune deficiencies (77%)), Hypocalcaemia (50%), Heart anomalies (74%)  and Characteristic facies

Question: A 32 week year old pregnant women presents with pre-eclampsia (proteinuria and elevated blood pressure). She needs 1mg/mL dilution with 0.9% NaCl solution (0.9g per 100ml) and an ampoule of hydrazaline (20mg/2ml). How many ml of NaCl solution do you need to mix with the hydralazine ampoule to get the desired dilution?

You are on a ward round with a paediatric surgeon when you come across a young patient with appendicitis, she is about to go into surgery and the surgeon asks you to insert a cannula into the patients hand. You tell the surgeon you are worried you may hurt the patient but the surgeon reassures you that they have had a topical, local anaesthetic cream (lidocaine) applied and has been given time to work. After you successfully place the cannula you think about how the cream worked to anaesthetise the patient. You remember that it does this by...
OptionA: Blocking ACh release so the sensory nerves cannot transmit the pain signal
OptionB: Antagonises the a-subunit of Na channels on the cystolic side to stabilise the membrane to stop sensory conduction
OptionC: It is an agonist to the a-subunit of the Na channels on the cystolic side to stabilise the membrane to stop sensory conduction
OptionD: Causes an influx of anions into the nerve cell membrane to hyperpolarise the cell so it needs a stronger action potential to cause the cells the depolarise
OptionE: It is an agonist to the beta-subunit of the Na channels on the cystolic side to stabilise the membrane
Explanation:
A = Botulinum - this is a neuromuscular blockade which is a paralysing agent and is either an anti-spasm agent or needs to be used with a general anaesthetic to prevent spasms and movements in surgery

 

B = CORRECT - by stabilising the membrane this prevents the sensory nerves depolarising so prevents pain, uses of local anaesthetics are:

  • topical
  • local infiltration
  • field, nerve, and spinal block
  • epidural

C & E = nearly correct but it is an antagonist and effects the alpha subunit

 

D = this is an example of ISPS which decreases the resting potential and makes exceeding the threshold for an action potential less likely

Question:
In a less economically developed country, an outbreak of a virus has occurred. Microbiologists have determined that antigenic shift has occurred.

 

What could be a possible repercussion?
OptionA: Many people in the population of the country are going to become infected
OptionB: Many people will become infected across the world
OptionC: A small number of people will suffer from the virus and it may be fatal
OptionD: The virus will stay in the already infected individuals and will not replicate
OptionE: No change has occurred to the virus
Explanation:
B is correct

 

Antigenic DRIFT=Progressive small changes in envelope proteins through mutation =Epidemic possible=A (Epidemics limited to one population which in this example, is the popular of the said country.
Antigenic SHIFT=Sudden massive changes in the envelope protein through Reassortment= Pandemic possible=B (Pandemics being across multiple populations, so it could be cross-continents)

 

Population=a group of living organism in a given area

Question: You are on a ward round with a cardiothoracic surgeon when you reach a patient who is about to have a coronary artery bypass. The surgeon knows that although you love the heart, the rotation is actually focused on anaesthetics. He decides to tell you that this patient will be given Atracurium along with a general anaesthetic for this surgery and asks how this neuromuscular blockade works and whether is will produce fasiculations. You reply saying...
OptionA: It blocks ACh release from the pre-synaptic membrane, this means ACh can't be released and induce depolarised in the motor end-plate and won't produce fasicualations
OptionB: It is a post-synaptic ACh receptor antagonist and classed as non depolarising so will produce fasiculations
OptionC: It is a post-synaptic ACh receptor antagonist and classed as non depolarising so will not produce fasiculations
OptionD: It is a post synaptic ACh agonist and classed as depolarising  so will not produce fasiculations
OptionE: It is a post synaptic ACh agonist and classed as depolarising so will produce fasiculations
Explanation:
A = this is how Botulinum works

B = almost correct but because it doesn't depolarise the the motor end-plate it wouldn't produce fasiculations

C = CORRECT

D = This is how Suxamethonium works but it will produce fasiculations because it is an agonist therefore will depolarise and cause fasiculations

E = Again how Suxamethonium works

 

Suxamethonium is a competitive agonist so blocks ACh from depolarising the end plate and is broken down much more slowly than ACh but when it first attaches it will cause a DP

Question:
In a less economically developed country, an outbreak of a virus has occurred. Microbiologists have determined that antigenic shift has occurred.

 

Which of the following best describes the process of antigenic shift?
OptionA: A virus enters the host cell and progressive mutations lead to small differences in the envelope proteins
OptionB: One strain of the virus enters a cell and exchanges genetic material with the host, causing a new resorted virus
OptionC: Two different strains of the virus enters a cell, where they exchange genetic material and create a new resorted virus
OptionD: Two different strains of the virus enter a cell, and through wide spread mutations create two new resorted virus strains
OptionE: Two strains of the virus enters a cell and exchanges genetic material with the host, causing a new resorted virus
Explanation:
C is correct

A explains antigenic drift

I made up the other explanations and are wrong given my level of knowledge!

Question: Give the name of structure 6
Explanation:
1. transverse process

2. pedicle

3. superior bony endplate

4. vertebral body

Question:
Sarah Parker, a 29 year old lady, attends a GP with her 3 year old son. She is concerned that her son can't hear her when she calls his names and that he cant hear music as well as seemingly having eye sight issues.

It is calculated the child was conceived on the 1st January of the year of her sons birth.

Sarah developed a rash that started behind the ears before spreading around the head and neck. It then spread to the chest and tummy. She also had flu like symptoms.

 

What virus did Sarah have and when did she have it?
OptionA: Sarah had the measles virus on February 13th
OptionB: Sarah had the measles virus on April 20th
OptionD: Sarah had the rubella virus on April 3rd
OptionE: Sarah had the mumps virus on July 31st
Explanation:
Given her presentation she had rubella. This, if contracted while being pregnant, can have profound effects on the child.
Given her sons presentation, it is likely she had rubella while at 13-16 weeks gestation as this would cause deafness and retinopathy.

Given that he was conceived on the 1st January and that would be deemed week 2 of gestation, it would place her rubella infection at around beginning of April/End of March

I appreciate the numbers may slightly vary but given the other options, D is the only date that is in the correct rough range and the correct virus.

Question: Give the name of structure 1
Explanation:
1. spinous process

2. superior articular process

3. vertebral body

4. intervertebral foramen

5. intervertebral disc space

6. inferior articular process

Question:
You are on a ward round in the orthopaedic ward with the doctor when you see a patient that has had a serious femur fracture that required surgery. The patient, Mrs Dorris, is 83 years old, is a non smoker and walks everyday to keep health although has been finding it harder because of a deep, boring pain in her bones. She tells you that the fracture happened when she was in the garden when she fell over a stone path and into the grass on her knees. Your doctor says this is definitely a pathological fracture and her blood work came back with:

 

Serum calcium -  9.6 (range 8.5 to 10.2 mg/dL)

 

ALP - 350 (range 20-140 IU/L)

 

Serum phosphate - 3.4 (range 2.5 to 4.5 mg/dL)

 

PTH -  12 (range 10 to 55 pg/mL)

 

From the history and bloods you determine that the most likely cause of this fracture was...
Explanation:
These are all causes of pathological fractures the other major one is renal osteaodystrophy

 

A = this is a possibliity because she has a couple of risks factors such as her age, female gender and that she's in menopause, however the fact that she complained of a deep boring pain is not indicative of osteoporosis and the blood tests will have come back normal, to diagnose this you would need to perform a DEXA scan

 

B = CORRECT it is the 2nd most common bone disorder in elderly but not all will present with symptoms as 70-90% will be asymptomatic. This is cause by disordered bone metabolism marked by an increase in osteoclast activity followed by and compensatory increase in osteoblast activity. So this results in disordered 'woven' mosaic bone that is weaker than normal. In a blood test, everything will be normal except for an increase in ALP.

 

C = unlikely because she has no major red flags for cancer such as unexplained weight loss, although the femur is a common place for metastases (along with humerus, spine, hip, ribs and skull) the blood test would show an increase in Calcium, Phosphate and ALP and and decrease in PTH

 

D = Again possible but with the clinical picture and because she exercises and works in the garden so must get some sun it is less likely, also she would have low levels of Calcium and Phosphate and high levels of PTH and ALP

 

E = presents with the classic, stones, bones, abdominal groans, psychiatitric moans so doesn't really fit in with the clinical pictures and she would have high levels of PTH with possible high levels of ALP and Ca but normal or low levels of phosphate

Question:
There is absolute pandemonium within the School of Medicine when news spreads that Ainsley Harriott will be attending Walkabout on June 9th. To try and impress the Lord, you decide to rustle up a delicious yet healthy meal (which follows the EatWell plate guidance). All your cookbooks are unfortunately at home, apart from the well-used C21 cookbook which you find under the bed.

After considering 'Andy's Meaty Balls' and Dr Keith Hart's 'Facili-Tater', you shortlist 5 possible recipes. Keeping in mind the EatWell plate, which of the following recipes would be most appropriate to cook for Ainsley?
OptionA:
Dr Tim Johnson's Six Minute Noodles

- 75% carbohydrate

- 15% vegetables

- 10% oils and spreads (fats)
OptionB:
Dr TJ Allen's Cheese and Tuna Medley

- 65% carbohydrate

- 10% vegetables

- 10% protein

- 15% oils and spreads (fats)
OptionC:
Dr Zarabeth Newton's Roast Dinner

- 35% carbohydrates

- 35% vegetables

- 15% protein

- 13% dairy

- 2% fat
OptionD:
Prof Dave Wilson's Stew

- 30% carbohydrates

- 20% vegetables

- 35% protein

- 15% fat
OptionE:
Ronnie's Red Lentil Soup

- 5% carbohydrates

- 20% vegetables

- 70% protein

- 5% fat
Explanation:
Zarabeth's Roast Dinner is the SBA in this question. The eatwell plate suggests that you eat roughly the following proportions per meal:

 

- 1/3 veg/fruit (5 a day) Fruit juice can only make up 1 of your 5 a day regardless how much you drink.

- 1/3 carbs

- 1/6 protein

- 1/6 dairy

- A small amount of fat from butters/spreads/oil.

 

Other notable points are that you should aim for at least 18g of fibre per day, and 6-8 glasses of water. Sugar free drinks (eg squash, tea/coffee) count towards this as well as low-fat milk.

 

The NHS is moving towards an EatWell guide which is in principle the same as above, but is thinking about getting the balance right over a day or a week. I've kept to the Plate as it's what came up in plenaries.

 

Good luck everyone!

Question: You are a 2nd year medical student observing a GP during surgery when she tells you that the next patient you are about to see is a 78 year old women with a history of osteoporosis. She tells you that she went to A&E a week ago after fracturing her wrist pushing herself off a bench. Your doctor says that they took her bloods in the hospital and they all came back normal. She suspects that the medication she is on currently isn't working so after the consultation she gives her a new prescription. What is was Mrs Dorris on before and what is her new treatment likely to be?
Explanation:
Treatment of osteoporosis, this is given if the patient is getting adequate calcium intake and  are vit. D deplete (NICE guidelines)

 

1st line = Alendronate or Risedronate

 

2nd line = Strontuim Ranelate or Raloxifene

 

3rd line = PTH agonist - e.g. Denosumab, PTH 1-84, Teriparatide

Question:
You are a 5th year medical student on placement in the A&E department when a patient comes in by ambulance after being in a car accident. After performing advanced trauma life support you take his heart rate, blood pressure and respiratory rate. These are the findings:

 

- Heart rate = 45bpm

- BP = 90/50mmHg

- Respiratory rate = normal but diaphragmatic breathing

 

The patient survives and along with treatment of his injuries has to remain on vasopressin for his stay to keep his heart rate and blood pressure up. From this, you determine that the patient was in shock, what is type of shock do you suspect?
Explanation:
Shock is defined as inadequate organ perfusion and tissue oxygenation resulting in cellular hypoxia 

 

Spinal shock, no treatment is needed and usually resolves after 24hrs. Main sign is areflexia and loss of sensation. Doesn't fit in with the clinical picture but could correct

 

Cardiogenic shock is due to reduced cardiac output usually after an MI

 

Anaphylacitc shock is IgE mediated and does cause hypotension but also tachycardia and a wheeze, also not likely with the clinical picture

 

Neurogenic shock is correct it is distinguished by bradycardia and can last 1-3 weeks. It is due to the disruption of the autonomic pathways so causes vagal tone to be unopposed resulting in bradycardia, low blood pressure occurs due to decreased systemic vascular resistance resulting in pooling of blood within the extremities lacking sympathetic tone. Neurogenic shock can be a potentially devastating complication, leading to organ dysfunction and death if not promptly recognized and treated. It is not to be confused with spinal shock, which is not circulatory in nature.

 

Tension pneumothorax is a build up of air in the pleural cavity which compresses the atria and could be caused by the car accident and would present with chest pain and respiratory distress, often with an increased heart rate (tachycardia) and rapid breathing (tachypnea) in the initial stages.

Question: You are currently shadowing a spinal surgeon, one of his patients is about to go into surgery, the surgeon explains that there are four main general cases that spinal surgery is used to treat, which one of the answers is he not likely to mention
Explanation:
In some polytrauma patients you treat conservatively all the other four are indicated for surgery. Sorry that it's a bit tricky because some you would treat with surgery but it was mentioned in a lecture so I thought I'd do a question on it.

 

You use conservative treatment in cases of:

- stable fractures

- some polytrauma patients

- unfit for surgery

- osteoporotic bone

The principles of conservative treatment are:

- anatomic reduction

- stable internal fixxation

- atraumatic technique

- early active mobilisation and rehab

The aims of conservative treatments are:

- decompress (directly or indirectly)

- realign/stabilise

-prevent late pain or deformity

 

Surgical treatment is used for:

- fractures

- dislocations

- instability

- acute compression

Complications for this are multiple such as renal failure, DVT/PE, hypotension, autonomic dysrefelxia, pneumonia

Question: You are working in the A&E department as an F1 when you get told about an incoming 19 year old male patient from a road traffic collision. You are told the patient is unconscious having been in a head on collision but before losing consciousness he was complaining about massive pain in his neck, the patient then arrives and the paramedic tells you that he has lost a lot of blood and has multiple injuries. When the patient is stabilised you perform a safe neurological examination and note that he has no reflexes. From this scenario what wasn't a factor that made you suspect a spinal cord injury.
OptionA: The fact that it was a head-on collison
Explanation: All but C are things that would make you suspect a spinal cord injury. A is an example of the mechanism of action a head on collision is very likely to have resulted in whiplash or sever damage to his neck making you suspect a spinal cord injury.

Question:
A new drug has been discovered to help treat rheumatoid arthritis. However, it has been found to have a few side effects. The new drug affects proteasomes and makes them ineffective.

In a patient receiving this new drug, which out of the following are they most likely to experience as a result of this?
OptionA: The patient is at an increased risk of not producing an adaptive response to TB
OptionB: The patients NK cells are less likely to bind to antibodies, resulting in a decreased antibody-dependant cell mediated cytotoxicity response.
OptionC: The patient is at an increased risk of not producing an adaptive response to Norovirus
OptionD: A reduction in the amount of Interferons
OptionE: TRL 3 is less likely to recognise PAMPs
Explanation: Proteasomes are key in adaptive immune response because they break down intracellular antigens into peptides. This is key to antigen presenting in MHC Class I. As this is only done to intracellular antigens, it is far more likely to affect the processing of a virus than a bacteria. Therefore it would affect whether or not peptides from a virus could be presented on a cell surface thus leading us to the answer C.

Question: You are shadowing a GP during surgery when a mother, Katy Adames, walks in with her 5 year old son, Monty Jnr. Poor Monty is complaining of lower back pain, you being to drift off and stop listening to the rest of the history but the GP then asks you some of the causes of lower back pain in children. What are you least likely to respond with only knowing lower back pain as a symptom and no other known history (because you weren't listening)
Explanation:
From one of the spinal lectures all are causes of lower back pain in children except for rickets

The 8 causes mentioned are:

1. Spondylolthesis and spondylolsis = disorders of the L5 vertebrae (pars interarticularis facet joints at the back of the spine)

2. Disc prolapse = nucleus pulposus breaching the annulus 

3. Trauma, such as apophyseal ring fracture

4. Scheurmann's disease or Kyphosis = uneven vertebral growth

5. Infections, such as meningitis

6. Non-accidental injury = child abuse

7. Scoliosis, but doesn't usually cause pain

Question: You are an F1 doctors working with the oncology department when you receive a patient who was urgently referred to you from a GP. Before you see him you have a quick look over his medical notes. You take the most important details from this and see that the patient is 52 year old Matt Baker who went to his GP with the presenting complaint of back pain. You see that the GP then took a much more detailed history to find out that has is HIV positive and that he has recently lost a lot of weight  and can't explain it. The pain in his back is in the thoracic region but it hurts only when he twists his back. You can now see that this urgent referral was because the doctor suspects metastatic spinal disease. Looking at this patient what is isn't a red flag for spinal metastases?
OptionB: The fact that he is HIV positive
Explanation:
The red flags for spinal metastases are:

1. <16yrs or >50yrs old

2. Unexplained weight loss

3. Previous cancer, serious infection or illness

4. HIV/AIDS

5. Non-mechanical pain (when lying down or sitting)

6. Thoracic pain

7. Spinal deformity

8. History of sig. trauma

9. Widespread neurological deficit

10. Failure to improve with treatmen

Also, longstanding steroid use, drug/alcohol abuse, Paget's and oseatoporosis

Question: How much of the Cardiac output does the kidney receive?

You see a patient in ITU who has been in a coma for 12 days. Your consultant asks you to perform some neurological tests on the patient to try and determine the site of damage within the brain.
Whilst examining the patient, you note they are taking deep gasping inspirations followed by short, insufficient expirations.
When rolling their head from side to side, you note their eyes are rolling to face the side you are turning them towards.
When lying normally, their eyes are "bobbing" from top to bottom. When tested, their corneal reflex is absent.
You return to your consultant and say that based on the information you have gained, the lesion is most likely to be located...
Explanation:
Apneustic breathing (gasping inspiration followed by insufficient expiration) is caused by upper medulla lesions, or lower pons. This therefore locates the site of pathology to the pons or medulla.
Occular bobbing is seen in bilateral pontine lesions.
Corneal reflex is carried on the afferent CN V1 nerve, mediated in the pons, and carried on efferent CN VII. 

Doll's head reflex is absent in brainstem injuries.
NB: Apneustic breathing alone does not define the lesion to the pons, nor does loss of corneal reflex (damage to CN V1/pons/ CN VII) or absence of Doll's head reflex. However in the presence of all three with occular bobbing (specific to bilateral pontine lesions) you can suggest with some confidence that the lesion is located in the pons.

Question: In what direction is disc herniation most likely to occur and why?
OptionA: Posteriorly because the posterior longitudinal ligament provides less support than the anterior longitudinal ligament.
OptionB: Anteriorly because the anterior longitudinal ligament provides less support than the posterior longitudinal ligament.
OptionC: Posteriorly because the ligamentum flavum is relatively weak.
OptionD: Anterolaterally because the anterior longitudinal ligament provides less support than the posterior longitudinal ligament and the annulus fibrosis is weaker at the front.
OptionE: Posterolaterally because the posterior longitudinal ligament provides less support than the anterior longitudinal ligament and the annulus fibrosis is weaker at the back.
Explanation:
Disc herniation is most likely to occur posterolateral because the posterior longitudinal ligament provides less support (only takes 20% of the weight and is thinner) AND the annulus fibrosis is weaker posteriorly. 

 

Furthermore, herniations in the posterolateral direction are more likely to produce symptoms because it is more likely to compress the nerve roots.

Question: What does cyanide inhibit in the electron transport chain to stop ATP production?
Explanation:
Cyanide acts as an electron transport inhibitor that inhibits complex 4 of the ETC

Complex IV, also known as cytochrome c oxidase, contains the hemeproteins known as cytochrome a and cytochrome a3, as well as copper-containing proteins in which the copper undergoes a transition from Cu+ to Cu2+ during the transfer of electrons through the complex to molecular oxygen. Complex IV is composed of a total of 13 protein subunits. Oxygen is the final electron acceptor, with water being the final product of oxygen reduction.

Question:
You are a keen bean that wants to find know what all the fuss is about in terms of vaccinating against MMR, looking particularly at mumps.

 

You know that one infected individual with mumps will infect 4 other individuals and that the vaccine is 88% effective. 

 

What is the critical vaccination coverage needed to achieve herd immunity (i.e. what percentage of the population needs to be vaccinated so that the disease is not passed on)?
Explanation:
Vc = (1 - 1/Ro) / E 

 

Vc = the vaccination level needed to eliminate the disease 

Ro = basic reproduction number > i.e. no. of people 1 infected person would infect = 4 in this case

E = Vaccine effectiveness = 88% or 0.88 in this case 

 

Vc = (1-1/4)/0.88

     = 0.85

 

Therefore 85% coverage is required - so that's why the UK gov. are pushing parents to vaccinate their children, because that's a lot of people that need to get vaccinated!

 

* Notes *

Ro - if less than 1 infection won't be able to be passed on and a lower vaccination threshold is needed 

Ro - if more than 1, the infection will spread and  a higher vaccination threshold is needed

 

** immunology tut.

Question: A 68-year old woman comes to you in clinic for a bone scan. Her bone mineral density is 1.5 standard deviations (-1.5 SD) below the mean value for a healthy 30-year-old. Her blood tests show normal alkaline phosphatase, calcium, and phosphate levels. What do you diagnose her with?
Explanation:
Hypoparathyroidism is can be caused by damage to the parathyroid gland during surgery. The symptoms are muscle spasms and parasthesia around the mouth.

Osteopenia is defined as bone mineral density -1.0 to -2.5 SD below the mean bone density for a healthy 30-year-old.

Osteoporosis is less than -2.5 SD below the mean bone density for a healthy 30-year-old

Paget's disease is where there is overactivity of both osteoclasts and osteoblasts leading to disordered, out of control bone formation. The bone is weaker than normal bone, but not as weakened as in osteoporosis. A marker is of high alkaline phosphatase.

Rickets is the manifestation of severe vitamin D deficiency in children.

Question: Among other treatment, you a prescribing a patient bisphosphonates for a bone disorder that they have. Which of the following do NOT require treatment with bisphophonates?
Explanation: Osteomalacia is the only one which doesn't require treatment with bisphosphonates. This is because it is caused by vitamin D deficiency. Therefore treat with vitamin D supplements. Bisphosphonates act to reduce bone breakdown but inhibiting osteoclast function and inducing their apopotosis, which is why they are helpful in all the other conditions.

Question:
Shock is a state of inadequate organ perfusion and tissue oxygenation. 

 

Which of the following statements regarding different types of shock is TRUE?
OptionA: Cardiogenic shock is a rare cause of death in acute myocardial infarctions.
OptionB: Neurogenic shocks occurs when there is a reduced sympathetic outflow causing unopposed vagal tone which leads to signs of tachycardia and hypotension
OptionC: Hypovolaemic shock is most commonly caused by loss of plasma and blood from severe burns.
OptionD: Cardiac tamponade causes shock because of increased fluid in the pericardial sac which compresses the heart and reduces cardiac output.
OptionE: Tension pneumothorax causes shock by compressing the left ventricle and reducing cardiac output.
Explanation:
A - Cardiogenic shock is the leading cause of death in acute MIs. It is caused by extensive damage to the heart leading to reduced cardiac output despite normal intravascular volume. 

 

B - Neurogenic shock is caused by a loss of sympathetic outflow and therefore unnopposed vagal tone, however the parasympathetic stimulation causes hypotension and bradycardia (this is the distinguishing feature of neurogenic shock) due to loss of vessel tone and venous pooling. 

 

C - Hypovolaemic shock is most commonly caused by haemorrhage e.g. from trauma, although loss of plasma and blood from extensive burns is also a cause. 

 

D - correct 

 

E - Tension pneumothorax causes compression of the right atrium which reduces cardiac output.

Question:
You are shadowing the spine dragon on the wards when you are called to see Mr jones, a 80 year old man who is an in-patient being treated for severe UTI. Before today Mr Jones was expecting to be discharged after recovering well from his infection.

 

However, over the past 24 hours he has been experiencing severe back pain in the thoracic region. The nurses tell you that he has developed a fever and that during the month and a half he has been in hospital, he has lost a lot of weight. Mr Jones has a history of lung cancer for which he has been in remission for 12 months. 

 

What is most likely to be the causing Mr Jones' signs and symptoms?
Explanation:
Mr Jones is showing many of the red flag signs for a spine tumour:

  • Over 50 with new onset pain
  • Unexplained fever (although a UTI can cause fever, the question states that Mr Jones has recovered from his infection, so this is unlikely to be causing it)
  • Recent serious infection or illness
  • Thoracic vertebral pain
  • Unexplained weight loss
  • History of cancer

 

Therefore, the most likely reason for his symptoms is a metastatic cancer, as these are the most common cause of bone cancers. Because of his history of lung cancer and the fact that his pain is in the thoracic region it is possible that his lung cancer has reappeared and metastasised to the thoracic vertebrae via the segmental arteries. 

 

A - Myelomas are the most common primary tumours of bone 

B - Tumours of the bone are most likely to be secondary from other tissues for example, breast, lung, thyroid, kidney and prostate

C - Osteosarcoma is the second most common primary tumour of the bone

D - A benign tumour of bone. 

E - This is the most common pathogen causing serious back pain however, with all the red flags present it is more likely that Mr Jones has cancer.

Question:
A new genetic condition is found called the FLW syndrome. It is found that people with this syndrome are not able to have mutations within their light and heavy chains of their immunoglobulins.

 

Which of the following statements therefore affects vaccination the most?
OptionB: They can not have vaccines that are for viruses
OptionC: They can not have vaccines that are for bacteria
OptionD: Booster vaccines they have are of little use
Explanation:
If an individual where to have this syndrome, they would not be able to perform mutations to change the affinity of an antibody.
This means it would be of little use to give a booster because their B cells would not be able to increase the affinity of the antibody they have on their surface. This means it cant undergo somatic hyper mutation. (The idea of B cell antibodies mutating and then the ones with an antibody with a higher affinity for the antigen outcompeting other B cells with antibodies with a lower affinity. Thus increasing the amount of the higher affinity B cell).

Question: What happens to the composition of pancreatic juice as its rate of secretion increases?
Explanation:
In pancreatic secretions

Acinar cells secrete enzyme, protein and chloride rich fluid-stimulated by CCK and acetylcholine

Question: What is the physiological change that causes a positive dromotropic effect on the heart?
OptionA: Under parasympathetic control, when the beta-1 adrenergic receptors are stimulated the cell depolarise more rapidly
OptionB: Under sympathetic control, when the muscarinic receptors are stimulation the cells depolarise more rapidly
OptionC: Under sympathetic control when when the beta-2 adrenergic receptors are stimulated the cells depolarise more slowly
OptionD: Under parasympathetic control, when the muscarinic recpetors are stimulated the cells depolarise more slowly
OptionE: Under sympathetic control, when the beta-1 adrenergic receptors are stimulated, the cells depolarise more rapidly
Explanation:
Dromotropy is the rate of conduction changes in the heart. The rate of conduction increases under sympathetic control with beta-1 adrenergic recepetor stimulation which causes the cells to depolarise more rapidly

 

The rate of conduction decreases in parasympathetic control with muscarinic receptor stimulation which causes the cells to depolarise more slowly.

 

Calcium channel blockers such as verapamil block the slow inward calcium current in cardiac tissues, thereby having a negatively dromotropic, chronotropic and inotropic effect.

 

Beta-adrenoceptors are coupled to Gs-proteins, which activate adenylyl cyclase to form cAMP from ATP.

Increased cAMP activates a cAMP-dependent protein kinase (PK-A) that phosphorylates L-type calcium channels, which causes increased calcium entry into the cells.

Increased calcium entry during action potentials leads to enhanced release of calcium by the sarcoplasmic reticulum in the heart; these actions increase inotropy (contractility).

Gs-protein activation also increases heart rate by opening ion channels responsible for pacemaker currents in the sinoatrial node.

PK-A phosphorylates sites on the sarcoplasmic reticulum, which enhances the release of calcium through the ryanodine receptors in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. This provides more calcium for binding the troponin-C, which enhances inotropy.

PK-A can phosphorylate myosin light chains, which may also contribute to the positive inotropic effect of beta-adrenoceptor stimulation.

In summary, the cardiac effects of a β-agonist are increased heart rate, contractility, conduction velocity, and relaxation rate.

Question: In the liver there is phase 1 and phase 2 metabolism-which of the following is the most about phase 1?
OptionD: Phase 1 involves oxidation, reduction, desterification and isomerization reactions

Question: What is the physiological mechanism that causes the rate of the relaxation to increase in the cardiac myocytes?
OptionA: PKA and calmodium kinase (activated by and increase in Ca2+) phosphorylates phospholamban which forms a pentamer which is more active allowing more SERCA Ca2+ uptake
OptionB: Phospholamban (activated by and increase in Ca2+) phosphorylates PKA and calmodium kinase which forms a pentamer which less active allowing more SERCA Ca2+ uptake
OptionC: PKA and calmodium kinase (activated by and increase in Ca2+) phosphorylates phospholamban which forms a pentamer which less active allowing more SERCA Ca2+ uptake
OptionD: PKA and calmodium kinase (activated by and increase in Ca2+) phosphorylates phospholamban which forms a pentamer which is less active allowing less SERCA Ca2+ uptake
OptionE: Phospholamban (activated by and increase in Ca2+) phosphorylates PKA and calmodium kinase which forms a dimer which more active allowing more SERCA Ca2+ uptake
Explanation:
Positive lusiptropy increases the rate of cardiac myocyte relaxation. It occurs when there is an increase in Ca2+ which activates PKA and Calmodium Kinase which phosphorylates phospholamban.

This results in it forming a pentamer which is less active which causes disinhibition which increases the Ca2+ uptake by SERCA

In other words, a quicker reduction in cytosolic calcium levels (because the calcium enters the sarcoplasmic reticulum) causes an increased rate of relaxation 

 

PKA also phosphorylates troponin - I to decrease myofilament sensitivity to Ca and increase cross-bridge cycling kinetics.
