Question: You are watching a patient perform an exercise stress test. You can see from the monitors that his heart is pumping a lot fasting, you assume that (as long as he is healthy enough) his heart will actually be pumping harder (increasing the force of contraction) You think back to year 1 and remember that positive inotropy is as a result of...
OptionA: Beta-adrenergic stimulation increasing cAMP which in turn activates protein kinase to increase in calcium entry into the cell through L-type calcium channels (prolonged opening of the L-type channels)
OptionB: Muscarinic receptor stimulation increasing cAMP which in turn activates protein kinase to increase in calcium entry into the cell through L-type calcium channels (prolonged opening of the L-type channels)
OptionC: Beta-adrenergic stimulation decreasing cAMP which in turn activates protein kinase to decrease in calcium entry into the cell through L-type calcium channels (shortened opening of the L-type channels)
OptionD: Beta-adrenergic stimulation increasing cAMP which in turn activates protein kinase to decrease in calcium entry into the cell through L-type calcium channels (shortened opening of the L-type channels)
OptionE: It just happens, the fact that we probably don't need to know this after this year is infuriating
Explanation:
If you put E I honestly don't blame you, after the 1st of June this is all leaving my brain forever.

 

Unfortunately we might need to know some sort of this in regards to drug functions and things

 

A is correct 

 

Calcium induced calcium release is the main source of calcium for excitation contraction coupling. The ryanodine receptor on the SERCA is opened by Ca and prolonged opening of the L-type channels has a positive inotropic effect (activated by b1 adrenergic receptor activation)

Activation of the IP3 signal transduction pathway also can stimulate the release of calcium by the SR through IP3 receptors located on the SR

 

Calsequestin = a protein in the SR

It inhibits the channel when Ca2+ isn't bound to it

This allows Ca2+ out when the concentration in the SR gets too high

 

PKFB ( not sure if this is the correct name always get letters mixed up and has some other name I can't remember if some could comment that would be great)

This stabilises the channel

B1 adrenergic stimulation causes PKFB to dissociate and removes its inhibition of SERCA

 

When phospholamban is phosphorylated by PKA its ability to inhibit the sarcoplasmic reticulum calcium pump (SERCA) is lost.

So activators of PKA, such as the beta-adrenergic agonist Adrenaline (released by sympathetic stimulation) increases the rate of relaxation.

Also as SERCA is more active, the next action potential will cause an increased release of calcium, resulting in increased contraction (positive inotropic effect). When phospholamban is not phosphorylated, such as when PKA is inactive, it can interact with and inhibit SERCA.

The overall effect of phospholamban is to decrease contractility and the rate of muscle relaxation, decreasing stroke volume and heart rate

Question: A GP is outlining her intended management for a patient with heliobacter pylori infection. The patient is allergic to penicillin-what is the best drug plan for this patient?
Explanation:
Triple therapy is used to treat H pylori. This consists of clarithromycin, amoxicillin (metronidazole if allergic to penicillin) and a PPI.

The drugs are taken twice a day, for one week and that is reasonably successful in clearing the infection

Question: Which of the following is not a cause of peripheral oedema?
Explanation:
Increased Pelvic pressure contributes to Oedema. Blood cannot be returned if the IVC is compressed, leading to peripheral oedema. (Pregnancy, Uterine tumours)

 

All of the rest contribute to oedema.

Another obvious cause that leads to oedema is increased Central Venous Pressure.

Question: It's June 1st and you've woken up from a lovely dream about Yograj and him sweeping you off your feet and taking you the Abu Dhabi. You then look at clock at realise it's 8:47 and you're going to be late for the exam! As you rush to get ready and get to the exam you can feel your heart pumping fast (along with dripping with sweat and swearing profusely). For some reason as you run to Taly you think what caused your heart to race.
OptionA: Muscarinic receptor stimulation activate PKB which causes an influx of K+ more than the efflux of Ca2+ shortening the AP
OptionB: Muscarinic receptor stimulation activate PKB which causes an influx of K+ the overcomes the efflux of Ca2+ lengthening the AP
OptionC: Beta adrenergic receptor stimulation activate PKB which causes an influx of K+ more than the efflux of Ca2+ shortening the AP
OptionD: Beta adrenergic receptor stimulation activate PKA which causes an influx of K+ more than the efflux of Ca2+ shortening the AP
OptionE: Beta adrenergic receptor stimulation activate PKA which causes an efflux of K+ more than the influx of Ca2+ shortening the AP
Explanation:
This is a genuine fear of mine so sorry if it set any of you on edge.

 

Essentially the levels of adrenaline will stimulate the beta adrenergic receptor which will activate PKA 

The effect of this is to activate K+ outwards more than Ca2+ inward which shortens the action potential allowing the heart to pump quicker

Question: Which of these is more true of ulcerative colitis (UC) compared to crohn's disease (CD)?
OptionA: UC causes more cases of erythema nodosum than CD
OptionB: UC usually has skip lesions and granulomas
OptionC: Bloody diarrhoea is more common in UC
OptionD: UC can effect any part of the GI tract
OptionE: UC more commonly causes fistulas than CD
Explanation: C is the only one true of UC. All the other are true for CD

Question: Daenerys Stormborn Targaryen, Queen of Andals and First Men, Khaleesi, Breaker of Chains, Mother of Dragons is a 19 year old female who also has Type 1 Diabetes (#PlotTwist). Owing to recent stressful events, you decide to measure her blood pressure using a 24 hour ambulatory blood pressure monitor. It is currently at 150/110 but what is the recommended blood pressure aim for Type 1 diabetics?
Explanation: From Professor Dayan's Lecture in Case 10 on 'Insulin Therapy in Type 1 DM'

Question: Which of these is most true in respect to Crohn's Disease (CD) compared to Ulcerative colitis (UC)?
OptionA: CD more commonly causes primary sclerosing cholangitis compared to UC
OptionB: CD increases your risk of colorectal cancer more compared to UC
OptionC: Episcleritis is more common in CD compared to UC
OptionD: Pyoderma Gangrenosum is common in CD compared to UC
Explanation: Only C is true while all others are true of UC compared to CD. Inflammation in CD is through all layers from mucosa to serosa with increased goblet cells and granulomas

Question: You are an F1 working in A&E when the next patient you see is Martha Hall. Martha is a 34 year old women who came in worried because she felt her heart "skip a beat" and then after her heart began thudding. Martha works as an investment banker which she finds very stressful so she tends to drink a lot of coffee and also admits to smoking a pack a day since she was 20 years old. What investigation did perform and how was she treated
OptionE: Implantable Loop recorder and lifestyle advice and reassurance
Explanation: This clincial picture is one of the patient suffering from ectopic beats. They actually occur in 75% of people on a 24 hour monitor and are usually asymptomatic. If they are symptomatic the correct test to perform is an implantable loop recorder and in this case you would advice the patient to quit smoking and reduce her caffiene intake (both exacerbating factors of ectopic beats along with alcohol and MSG) and possibly limit easting chinese food. You would also reassure that patient that it is normal but there are no medical treatments for ectopic beats.

Question:
Diane Nguyen, a 30 year old women, attend a GP clinic. She has been recently going through a very difficult time in her life and is questioning her direct in life after writing a novel and having issues with her long term partner. She is also feels dehydrated, has been having recent sexual dysfunction. On examination she has darkened skin as if she was tanned

 

Upon doing some blood tests, it is revealed she has high potassium levels and low sodium levels.

Given Diane's presentation, what is the biggest concern going forward if she is not treated correctly?
OptionA: She becomes increasing withdrawn, lethargic, sleepy and confused. Following this she falls into a coma.
OptionB: She will suffer further fatigue, cold intolerance and depression
OptionC: She may suffer from a tumour causing increased production of cortisol
OptionD: She may go into a state of intractable vomiting, abdominal pain with vascular collaspe
OptionE: Little of note to be concerned about going forward
Explanation:
Diane has Addison's Disease, which is Chronic Adrenocortical Insufficiency.

 

D is correct as it correctly outlines Adrenal crisis. This is as explained with hypotension too and may result in death

A=Myxoedema Coma seen in untreated Hypothyroidism
B=Some of Hypothyroidism symptoms
C=a cause of Cushings Syndrome

Question: Which of these is most true in respect to ulcerative colitis over crohn's disease?
OptionA: Smoking has been shown to be protective of CD but worsens UC
OptionB: A Leadpipe/drainpipe colon on  is more indicative of CD compared to UC on abdominal X-ray
OptionC: UC more commonly presents with tenesmus and urgency compared to CD
OptionD: Toxic megacolon is a complication more associated with CD compared to UC
OptionE: Gallstones are more common in UC compared to CD
Explanation:
C is true while the others are all reversed/opposite.

Gallstones are common in CD as secondary to reduced bile acid reabsorption

Question:
Sarah Harding, a 35 year old women, has been diagnosed with schizophrenia. Sarah actually has little issues with the negative symptoms, but suffers horrible from 'voices in her ears' and delusions that people want to use her DNA to make dinosaurs. She is currently pregnant.

 

She has been prescribed a new antipsychotic drug that works by suppressing the neurotransmitter found in the mesolimbic pathway. However, this new drug has the opposite effects it would in the mesolimbic pathway as it would in the hypothalamus.

 

What effect would this new drug have with regards to Sarah and breastfeeding her child once it is born?
OptionA: Sarah would produce too much breast milk for her child
OptionB: Sarah would have issues breast feeding correctly so would have to bottle feed the child
OptionC: The breast milk produced will be low in vitamin D
OptionD: The colostrum will be high in fat
Explanation:
The question was designed to combine a few things learnt in separate cases and see if they could be applied.

Positive symptoms in schizophrenia are caused by Hyperactivity in the mesolimbic pathway.
The made up drug works by suppressing dopamine in this pathway, thus would treat her positive symptoms (for the purpose of this question)
If it had the opposite effect in the hypothalamus, it would increase the amount of dopamine. Dopamine is key as it is the inhibitor of Prolactin. Less prolactin means less lactogenesis and therefore Sarah could have issues breastfeeding

Question: You are 2nd year medical student shadowing a cardiologist on their ward rounds. The next patient you see is Harry Turnell who was recently diagnosed with atrial fibrillation. He is is 78 years old a BP of 175/100 and has T2D, there is no other past medical history. The consultant wonders whether this patient needs to be put an anticoagulant so asks you to work out his CHADSVASC score. What is his score?
Explanation:
Hypertensive - 1pt

Age >75 yrs - 2pts

Diabetic - 1pt

= 4 points

Question: You are on the ward rounds with a cardiologist who is talking to a patient about their anticoagulant risk. The patient is 76 year old Matt Duct. Matt has AF which was discovered when he suffered from a stroke, measures have been taken to reduce his blood pressure and is now at 140/80mmHg. He had his bloods taken recently which showed an increase in his serum creatinine level of 1.6 (normal - 1.4), and his GFR was shown to be 48 (normal >60), his INR was measured at 5 seconds. Matt is a non-smoker and rarely drinks what is his HASBLED score?
Explanation:
No longer hypertensive = none

Abnormal kidney function = 1pt

Stroke = 1pt

Bleeding = none

Labile INRs = 1pt

Elderly = 1pt

Drugs/alcohol= none

Question:
Ian Malcolm, a 52 year old man, presents to his GP with uncontrolled diabetes. It has been uncontrolled for 10 years.

What is the most likely macrovascular complication of diabetes?
Explanation:
Only A is MACROVASCULAR

The rest are microvascular. This caught me out on the SBAs on Case 10 so thought I'd share this again to remind all

Question:
Pfizer have designed a new drug to assist in moving food along the Gastrointestinal tract. The drug has passed all the preclinical testing and has entered the first clinical trial phase where they test the safety of the drug, documenting any side effects using the yellow card scheme.The scientists involved in creating the drug note one of the common side effects noted is dyspepsia.

 

The drug works by increasing excitability in the large colon and promoting the movement of food substances along the large intestine.

 

Which hormone is the drug most likely to mimic?
Explanation:
The Large Colon is generally utilised for storing, mixing and propelling food. It is capable of absorbing and secreting Ions in response to the presence of certain hormones, but the question does not concern this.

 

2 hormones mentioned in our lecture on motility of the gastrointestinal tract are related to the large colon specifically. These hormones are CCK and Gastrin. Both hormones work by increasing the excitability of the muscles of the large colon and allow the generation of greater propulsion by the inner circular and outer longitudinal muscles of the muscularis proria.

 

Physiologically this makes sense as the presence of food in the stomach stimulates gastrin release by G cells. Gastrin either stimulates Parietal cells or ECL, or enters the blood. Upon entering the blood it may reach the large colon where it results in the increased excitability of the colon and moves the food in the colon towards the rectum making more space for the incoming food.

 

Based on the fact that excess Gastrin also causes excess HCL secretion by Parietal cells which would cause dyspepsia (Heart burn) it can be inferred that this drug is most likely similar to Gastrin.

Question: Ulcerative colitis can be measured by a number of features. Which of the following is most indicative of a severe attack of UC?
Tags: Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11, Inflammatory Bowel Disease

Question: Which of these is true in regards to management of Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis?
OptionA: Methotrexate is recommended only for use in UC, not in CD
OptionB: Surgery can cure CD but not UC
OptionC: 5-aminosalicylate/mesalazine can be used for both forms of IBD, but has been shown to be more effective in treating UC
OptionD: Diet therapy has shown to be very effective in UC but less effective in CD
OptionE: Remission of CD is usually with mesalazine and azathioprine, and remission of UC is usually azathioprine or mercaptopurine and methotrexate
Explanation:
C is correct while all the others are opposites

Note that though our IBD lecture says Mesalazine should be used for UC, it is not completely contraindicated in CD but is less effective

Methotrexate is effective in CD but not in UC
Tags: Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11, Inflammatory Bowel Disease

Question:
After spending what feels like your entire life in the library you look up and see that only 2 hours have passed since you woke up and had breakfast, but that is long enough for you to start to feel hungry.

 

Your Ghrelin levels are high and your Leptin levels and moral are low.

 

Your stomach begins to rumble and your mate asks you "do we need to know about how food passes through the GI tract?"

To which you reply " I don't know what we need to know, just like everyone else"

 

During the phase of starvation which mechanism of Food propulsion is dominant in the Small intestines.
Explanation:
When the small intestines are full, the mechanism of food propulsion is Peristaltic, Pendular, Segmented and via the individual Villi.

 

During starvation it is the MMC that is responsible for food movement. There are 3 phases of the MMC including a phase of no contraction at all, rhythmic contraction then random erratic contraction (Responsible for the sounds your stomach makes when you are hungry).

 

All movement along the gastrointestinal tract is governed by the SIP syncytium and the Myenteric Plexus.

Question: What chromosome is the adenomatous polyposis coli gene (APC) found on?
Explanation:
FAP is a rare autosomal dominant condition which leads to the formation of hundreds of polyps by the age of 30-40 years. Patients inevitably develop carcinoma. It is due to a mutation in a tumour suppressor gene called adenomatous polyposis coli gene (APC), located on chromosome 5. Genetic testing can be done by analysing DNA from a patients white blood cells.

Patients generally have a total colectomy with ileo-anal pouch formation in their twenties.

Question: Which condition would you treat with carbimazole and then thyroxine is a 'block and replace' treatment plan?
Explanation:
Block-and-replace is a strategy sometimes used with grave's diseases which is the commonest cause of hyperthyroidism

• Carbimazole is started at 40mg

• Thyroxine is added when the patient is euthyroid

• Treatment typically lasts for 6-9 months

The major complication of carbimazole therapy that can often occur agranulocytosis

Question: Which out of the following bacteria will have an outer peptidoglycan layer in their cell wall?
Explanation: All others are gram -positive=lipopolysaccharide cell wall  with peptidoglycan outer cell wall layer

Question:
A 23 year old female patient comes into your surgery complaining of stomach pain, constipation and lots of blood in her stools. On investigation superficial inflammation of the rectum only and pseudopolyps. The patient is also pANCA +. 

 

You decide to prescribe her medications that will induce remission of this disease. Out of the options below, which would not be an option for remission induction in this patient?
Explanation:
The patient has Ulcerative Colitis, more specifically proctitis which is the only case of UC where there is constipation as opposed to diarrhoea. 

 

E) Infliximab is an Anti-TNF drug. Although it works to induce remission in UC, it isn't currently approved by NICE (Plenary 4 Lecture Notes).

 

A) Sulfasalazine is an example of an oral aminosalicylate and is effective in inducing remission for pts with mild to moderate UC.

 

B) Mesalamine is more commonly used in distal colitis and proctitis and can serve as an adjunct to oral ASA's.

 

C) Budesonide is an oral steroid that can be used for more severely ill pts and those not responding to ASA's.

 

D) Azathioprine may be effective in remission induction for patients that are still unresponsive after the above treatments.

 

 

Crohn's Disease Therapy:

 

Treatment uses all the above drugs as in UC. However, anti-TNF, which are used in CD have the most rapid response. Liquid diets can induce remission, although responses tend to be short lived and seem to be more useful in children. ASA's such as sulfasalazine are used in CD but the results are not as good as in UC.

 

Surgery:

UC - Surgical treatment is required for patients with fulminant colitis (>10 stools/day) failing to respond to medical therapy, chronic intractable colitis unresponsive to drugs or from complications e.g bowel perforation, dysplasia or malignancy. surgery can be curative.

 

All notes taken from the IBD lecture, however please correct me if I have made a mistake as I wrote this because I can never remember this stuff! :)
Tags: Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11, Inflammatory Bowel Disease

Question: A 12-year-old boy with lymphoma is treated with Anthracycline. After 2 years of chemotherapy, he is in remission. 20 years later he presents  with shortness of breath, fatigue, and he constantly feels faint. What is the most likely reason for this presentation?
Explanation:
Anthracyclines and Trastuzumab are drugs used in chemotherapy which can cause dilated cardiomyopathies 

 

Other cancer drugs and their cardiac side effects: 

Cyclophosphamide - Arrhythmias, haemorrhagic pericarditis, Congestive Heart Failure (CHF) 

Paclitaxel - Heart block, Ischaemic Heart disease (IHD) 

Cisplatin - Coronary artery spasm, IHD 

VEGF inhibitors (Bevacizumab) - hypertension 

TK inhibitors (Sunitimab) - hypertension, CHF, IHD

 

From the Non- Ischaemic Cardiomyopathy Lecture, Slide 36

Question: Which of these is not a sign of pneumoperitoneum?
Explanation:
Rigler's/ Double wall sign - air is present on both sides of the intestine.

 

 

 

Falciform Sign - "The falciform ligament connects the anterior abdominal wall to the liver. The ligament continues to extend inferiorly beyond the liver where it becomes the round ligament (white arrow). Given that the falciform ligament is situated against the anterior abdominal wall, it is not surprising that it becomes outlined with air in a supine patient with free abdominal gas."

 

 

Football Sign -The football sign is seen in cases of massive pneumoperitoneum, where the abdominal cavity is outlined by gas from a perforated viscus. The median umbilical ligament and falciform ligament are sometimes included in the description of this sign, as representing the sutures. 

 

 

Thumbprinting is a radiographic sign of large bowel wall thickening, usually caused by oedema, related to an infective or inflammatory process (colitis). The normal haustra become thickened at regular intervals appearing like thumbprints projecting into the aerated lumen. It is not a sign of extra-luminal gas.

 

 

 

Crescent Sign - Presence of free subdiaphragmatic gas (erect CXR) 

 

 

 

 

References: http://radiopaedia.org/ . Small and Large Bowel Imaging Lecture.

Question: Which of these statements is not true regarding imaging of the small and large bowel?
OptionA: Fat is white and water is black on T1 type MRI.
OptionB: The small bowel is <3cm and contains folds called plicae circulares
OptionC: A hernia can cause both small bowel and large bowel obstruction
OptionD: Pneumatosis intestinalis is a highly suggestive sign of necrotizing enterocolitis.
OptionE: The majority of pathological calcification is due to renal calculi
Explanation:
C) According to the lecture, hernia is only a cause of SBO. Other causes include: adhesions, intussception, IBD and tumour. Causes of LBO: colorectal cancer, volvulus, toxic mega colon, ischaemia and intussception.

 

A) On T1 MRI - Fat is bright and water is black, which makes it good for looking at anatomy. On T2 - Fat is still bright and water is too - good for pathology.

 

B) This is correct. The large bowel is <5cm and caecum <9cm. It also has haustrae.

 

D)Pneumatosis Intestinalis is the presence of gas within the bowel wall

 

E) Calcification can be normal (lymph nodes or vascular) or pathological. Pathological causes include: renal calculi (80-90%), gallstones (15-20%), appendicolith?!, aneurysm, pancreatic, hydatid cyst.

Question: Brain Natriuretic Peptide  is a substance secreted in response to changes in pressure that occur when heart failure develops and worsens. Where is the primary release site of BNP?
Explanation: BNP was discovered in the brain but it's primary release site is the ventricles.

Question: During your 'hospital front-door' placement in third year (can't wait), a patient is rushed into A&E with a severe abdominal trauma and he appears to have to gone into hypovolaemic shock. The doctor in charge not so politely (but understandably) asks you to take a step back whilst they do their thing. You can't really see what's going on and your mind begins to wander back to year 2 physiology... which of these most accurately represents the bodies reaction to the fall in blood pressure following a substantial haemorrhage?
OptionA: ADH is released by the anterior pituitary gland which causes vasoconstriction in the peripheral tissues, vasodilation in the coronary and cerebral blood vessels, and increased water reabsorption in the collecting ducts.
OptionB: ADH is released by the anterior pituitary gland which causes vasodilation in the peripheral tissues, vasoconstriction in the coronary and cerebral blood vessels, and decreased water reabsorption in the collecting ducts.
OptionC: ADH is released by the posterior pituitary gland which causes vasoconstriction in the peripheral tissues, vasodilation in the coronary and cerebral blood vessels, and decreased water reabsorption in the collecting ducts.
OptionD: ADH is released by the posterior pituitary gland which causes vasoconstriction in the peripheral tissues, vasodilation in the coronary and cerebral blood vessels, and increased water reabsorption in the collecting ducts.
OptionE: ADH is released by the posterior pituitary gland which causes vasodilation in the peripheral tissues, vasoconstriction in the coronary and cerebral blood vessels, and increased water reabsorption in the collecting ducts.
Explanation:
A is almost correct except ADH (antidiuretic hormone/vasopressin) is secreted by the posterior pituitary gland in response to hypovolaemia, so D is the correct option. All the rest are incorrect as ADH causes a powerful vasoconstrictor in many tissues to help maintain arterial blood pressure, but vasodilatator in the cerebral and coronary vessels → the effect being a redistribution of blood to the essential organs.

 

Sodium uptake would also be important in this situation. Vasoconstriction by sympathetic stimulation and ADH would lead to constriction of the afferent arterioles supplying the glomeruli, which would decrease GFR and therefore decreases the concentration of Na+ in the distal tubule. This would activate the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system which would promote sodium reabsorption.
Tags: Physiology, Renal system, Biochemistry, Kidneys, Case 15

Question:
Sleepy, the 5th dwarf from Snow White and the 7 dwarves, has grown increasingly tired recently. 

He has been feeling very down and withdrawn, but put it to the fact that he misses Happy and Dopey (who have gone to visit Snow White and the Prince at the palace). 

His skin has taken on an orangey tint (even brighter than Bashful's) and has sneezed even more than Sneezy (which Is really rather an achievement). 

 

As Doc, you think you have successfully come to a diagnosis. To confirm this, you whack out a syringe and take some bloods just to be sure. Grumpy is now complaining because there's blood on the table and Snow White would be well pissed. What are your most likely results?
Explanation:
Mirror Mirror on the wall, which is the SBA of them all? 

 

So B is correct: 

These symptoms (tiredness, hyper pigmentation, depression, cold intolerance) are all characteristic of Addison's - which is hypo secretion of the adrenal cortex, so low aldosterone (zona glomerulosa), low cortisol (zona fasciculatis) and low sex steroids. Because of this, you have positive feedback to the anterior pituitary causing increase release of ACTH. Aldosterone normally unregulates activity of the Na+/K+-ATPase in the kidney to raise blood pressure by retaining Na+, therefore, low aldosterone will mean this occurs less, causing less Na+ to be reabsorbed (I.e. Na+ is low) and less K+ to be excreted, (I.e. K+ is high) 

 

Note: the hyperkalaemia associated with Addisons is the most serious aspect (more serious than the witch outside with a shiny green apple) 

p.s. Sorry if you got wound up by the Disney jargon but I'm bored and fed up of revision and idc.

Question: What is the most common cause of secondary hypertension?
Explanation: All of the options above can very well cause secondary hypertension, but renal parenchymal disease is the most common cause. Renal parenchymal disease includes things such as glomerulonephritis, tubulointerstitial disease etc.

Question: Which of these statements regarding colorectal cancer is correct?
OptionA: Patients with FAP have fewer polyps but a faster progression compared to those with Lynch Syndrome.
OptionB: The adenoma carcinoma sequence is: APC, K-ras, p53, SMAD4.
OptionC: Protective factors against colorectal cancer include eating fruit and vegetables, being a female and having a high BMI, exercise and eating wheat bran.
OptionD: Having 1 First Degree Relative with colorectal adenoma means your relative risk of developing it is 1.8.
OptionE: A patient with T4, N2 means they have colorectal cancer that has spread through the adventitia, and into at least 5 lymph nodes.
Explanation:
A) Incorrect - Patients with Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) have inherited an APC gene mutation. Typically, they present with 100-1000's of polyps around the age of 16, and go on to develop colorectal cancer at 42. Due to this they tend to have prophylactic surgery such as rectal polypectomy and ileostomy. Patients with Lynch Syndrome tend to develop fewer polyps around the age of 40 and quickly develop into cancer.

 

B) Incorrect - The adenoma-carcinoma sequence is: APC, K-ras, SMAD4 and p53. Knudsen's 2 hit hypothesis states that, a person who has inherited a mutant allele (such as APC gene) must experience a second somatic mutation to initiate tumorigenesis.

 

C) Incorrect - although most of this statement is accurate, consuming wheat bran is a risk factor for colorectal cancer. Other risk factors include: being male with a high BMI, eating red meat, smoking (duh!), increasing age and having chronic IBD.

 

D) CORRECT - If you have no 1st DR with colorectal cancer your RR is 0.8. If you have 1FDR with adenoma - 1.8. 1FDR with carcinoma - 2.8. Finally, IFDR <45 y/o - RR is 3.7.

 

E) Incorrect - The TNM staging of colorectal cancer is:

  • T1 - spread into the inner layer (submucosa)
  • T2 - spread into the muscle layer (muscularis propia)
  • T3 - spread into the outer lining (subserosa)
  • T4 - spread through the outer lining (adventitia)
  • N0 - no lymph node involvement
  • N1 - spread to 1-3 lymph nodes
  • N2 - spread to 4+ lymph nodes
  • M0 - no metastases
  • M1 - metastases.

Question: Which of these statements is correct regarding diabetic neuropathy?
OptionA: Polyradiculopathy often presents with severe pain in one or more nerve roots and may have muscle weakness
OptionB: In "glove and stocking" neuropathy pain, temperature and vibration sensation is lost in a superficial then deep manner.
OptionC: Damage to the peripheral nervous system is due to occlusion of the vasa nervorum and the accumulation of mannitol in Schwann cells.
OptionD: Bradycardia at rest is a sign of autonomic neuropathy.
Explanation:
A) Correct- not much more to say on that, except it was in the lecture.

 

B) Incorrect - In symmetrical polyneuropathy sensation is lost deep then superficial.

 

C) Incorrect - Damage to the nerve is caused by increase in sorbitol. Hyperglycaemia leads to increased glucose entering the polyol pathway where it is converted to sorbitol by the enzyme aldose reductase. Reactive Oxygen Species is produced by mitochondria. Another consequence of excess glucose is glycation reaction where a glucose is combined to a protein without the presence of an enzyme. This leads to generation of Advanced Glycation End Products (AGE's). AGE's bind to receptors on endothelial cells to generate oxidative stress. It is worth noting that AGE concentration normally increases with age, however in diabetes the accumulation is faster. AGE's are also found in tobacco leaves, and in some foods such as meat and butter.

 

D) Incorrect - Autonomic neuropathy presents as tachycardia at rest due to loss of vagal tone.Postural hypotension can occur due to loss of sympathetic tone on peripheral arterioles. Other symptoms include: gastroparesis (delayed stomach emptying), erectile dysfunction and hypoglycamia unawareness.

Question: ACE inhibitors work by competitively inhibiting the Angiotensin Converting enzyme active site that is normally taken by which amino acid of angiotensin I?
What 2 signals are required for the activation of a T lymphocyte?
Explanation:
The two signals required for activation of a T lymphocyte are:
T Cell receptor- on cytotoxic T cells this is CD8 receptor and MHC class I. On Helper T cells, this is CD4 receptor and MHC class II.
B7 and CD28 interaction. B7 expression on the APC is increased in inflammation and activation of pattern recognition receptors.

CD40 and CD40L is one of the signals required for activation of a B cell by a TH2 cell.

The AID enzyme is the enzyme activated in TH2- B lymphocyte interactions and leads to somatic hypermutation, affinity maturation and class switching! This is why you use conjugate vaccines- to induce this response, as a polysaccharide alone does not stimulate this reaction.

Question: All of the statements below are direct consequences of PTH activation, apart from one. Please select the option which is not a direct consequence of PTH secretion.
OptionA: Increased osteoclast activity, increasing bone resorption hence increasing plasma Ca2+.
OptionB: Increased Ca2+ reabsorption from the distal tubules of the kidney.
OptionC: Decreased phosphate reabsorption from the proximal tubules of the kidney.
OptionD: Increased absorption of Ca2+ from the duodenum.
OptionE: Increased synthesis of 1,25 (OH)2 cholecalciferol from the kidney.
Explanation:
PTH indirectly increases calcium absorption from the small intestine by activating 1,25(OH)2cholecalciferol (calcitriol) from the kidneys. The calcitriol then increases Ca absorption from the gut. It leads to increased expression of luminal calcium channels, calbindins and Ca also moves across the cell membrane via TRPV5/6 channels.

 

PTH is released by the chief cells of the parathyroid glands in response to low Ca2+. 

 

Excess PTH: Primary hyperparathyroidism can be caused by a tumour in the parathyroid glands. Symptoms include: renal stones, abdominal groans, psychiatric moans and weak bones.

 

Depleted PTH: This can cause hypocalcaemia which can manifest as tetany.

Question:
A patient comes into see you in your surgery.

 

He is complaining of feeling tired, a lack of energy, muscle pain and bleeding from his gums.

 

On observation and examination you see inflammation and bleeding of gums, he has lost a tooth, has foul smelling breath and has oedema.

 

When asking about his diet, he says to you that he is severely allergic to oranges. He has also been complaining of depression.

 

Hypothetically, what neurotransmitter/s is most likely causing his depression?
Explanation:
The answer is most likely D, Noradrenaline and adrenaline.

 

The patient seems to presenting with SCURVY - which is a deficiency of vitamin C characterised by:

  • feeling very tired and weak all the time (fatigue)
  • a general sense of feeling "out of sorts" – such as feeling irritable and miserable all the time
  • pain in your limbs – particularly your legs
  • inflammation of the gums – which become soft and vulnerable to bleeding (your teeth may feel loose or fall out)
  • severe joint pain, caused by bleeding inside the joints
  • shortness of breath – particularly after periods of physical activity
  • redness and swelling in recently healed wounds (new wounds may also fail to heal)
  • easily bruised skin

A lack of Vitamin C could be due to his allergy to ORANGES - he is not eating enough citrus fruits - vitamin C is found in Citrus fruits.

 

So moving on to his Depression (I don't know if a symptom of Scurvy is depression, so this could be a separate issue),

 

Depression is characterised by reduced levels of serotonin, noradrenaline and dopamine - known as the Monoamine theory of depression.

(Treatment would be to raise levels of 5-HT and NA – brain can form new connections and improve mood)

 

In the synthesis of Noradrenaline and adrenaline in the CNS: 

1. Tyrosine from food (milk is a major source) is actively transported into the brain through the BBB – it is fully saturated with typical daily intake – rate limiting step of the pathway.

2. Hydroxylated by tyrosine hydroxylase to form dihydroxyphenylalanine – requires Fe2+ , O2 and a H+ donor (tetrahydrobiopterin) to form L-DOPA – increased release of catecholamines → increase in TH activity – also rate limiting.

3. In NORADRENERGIC neurones in synaptic vesicles that store NA , DOPAMINE → converted via DBH (Dopamine-B-Hydroxylase) → NORADRENALINE. DBH requires Cu2+ and Vit C as co factors

4. In ADRENERGIC NEURONES in brainstem and ADRENAL MEDULLA, NA → converted via PNMT (Phenylethanolamine-N-methyltransferase) → ADRENALINE .A methyl donor is required as a co factor.

 

So hypothetically, reduced vitamin C , could reduce the amount of DBH, which could reduce the amount of both Noradrenaline and Adrenaline.

 

The SINGLE BEST answer here is D, A and E are also depleted in depression however he has no signs of reduced enzymes for conversion and production of these neurotransmitters. 

Glutamate and GABA are both derived from glucose from the Krebs cycle: GLUTAMATE from a-ketoglutarate via GABA-T • GABA from GLUTAMATE via GAD.

Glutamate is involved with Psychosis and GABA with anxiety.

Question:
Mr Adam Jones, a 69 year old man, has been brought into resus by an ambulance. The paramedics hand-over Mr Jones with the following summary;

 

"20 minutes ago, Mr Jones experienced severe chest pain, fatigue, syncope and confusion. He has a past medical history of atrial fibrillation since 2011, which he takes bisoprolol and diltiazem for. He has a heart rate of 50bpm, BP of 93/50mmHg. He has been a smoker for 40 pack years, and has a BMI of 32.1."

 

You immediately perform an ECG on Mr Jones, the results are shown below:

 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis of Mr Jones?
Explanation:
Mr Jones is presenting with complete heart block (3rd degree).

 

Overview: In complete heart block, there is complete absence of AV conduction, and so there are no impulses conducted from the atria and ventricles, causing them to each beat independently. As the atria and ventricles beat out of sync, when the atria tries to push blood into the ventricles, it meets with the AV valves instead, and thus the blood pushes back into the circulation, causing filling of the jugular veins. This explains why cannon A waves are found on the JVP of a pt with complete heart block.

 

Perfusing rhythm is maintained by a junctional or ventricular escape rhythm. Alternatively, the patient may suffer ventricular standstill leading to syncope (if self-terminating) or sudden cardiac death (if prolonged).

 

Mechanism: Complete heart block is essentially the end point of either Mobitz I or Mobitz II AV block:

  • It may be due to progressive fatigue of AV nodal cells as per Mobitz I (e.g. secondary to increased vagal tone in the acute phase of an inferior MI).
  • Alternatively, it may be due to sudden onset of complete conduction failure throughout the His-Purkinje system, as per Mobitz II (e.g. secondary to septal infarction in acute anterior MI)

Presentation: The patient typically presents with bradycardia, hypotension, fatigue, dizziness, syncope and severe chest pain. The low HR is associated with a lower than normal cardiac output, and syncope.

 

ECG: The ECG is characterised as having no correlation between P and QRS. Because of differences in intrinsic rates of pacemaker tissue, the frequency of P waves is greater than that of the QRS complex.

 

 

In the example ECG above, the atrial rate is 100bpm whereas the ventricular rate is 40bpm.

 

The ventricular rate depends on the location of alternate pacemaker; ventricular origination is slowest and least reliable.

 

Risk factors: The most common cause of heart block is age-related degeneration of tissue.

 

Because an acute myocardial infarction (MI) can cause complete heart block (usually an inferior MI), patients who concurrently experience an MI can have associated symptoms from the MI, including chest pain, dyspnoea, nausea or vomiting, and diaphoresis. Third-degree AV block may be an underlying condition in patients who present with sudden cardiac death.

 

Patients who have a history of cardiac disease may be on medications that affect the conduction system through the atrioventricular node (AVN), including the following:

  • Beta-blockers
  • Calcium channel blockers
  • Digitalis cardioglycosides

Treatment: Patients with third degree heart block are at high risk of ventricular standstill and sudden cardiac death.

  • They require urgent admission for cardiac monitoring, backup temporary pacing and usually insertion of a permanent pacemaker.
  • The best initial therapy is to give the patient atropine, as it is the fastest way to increase the heart rate, and is anti-cholinergic, therefore blocking vagal stimulation (which is why outcome of treatment is better with those with heart block secondary to Mobitz type I). Then, an implantation of a pacemaker would be a more permanent form of treatment.

What does somatostatin stop being released in their respective areas?

Explanation:
The basal bolus regime is a four dose regime recommended for busy life styles as it keeps insulin levels relatively constant. It is composed of 

3 x short acting insulins before meal times and one long acting insulin before bed time

Question: You encounter an elderly frail patient with heart failure and severe type II diabetes. His family do not believe he has long left to live. Given which insulin regime you would most likely recommend to this patient, what type of insulin would you give to this patient just before breakfast?
Explanation: The patient is elderly and nearing the end of life. From Colin's lecture from case 10, a lifestyle where good long term control may not be priority would be once daily insulin regime. From reading around, you can do this in one of two ways. Just before bed you can give an intermediate insulin such as NPH insulin or before breakfast/same time everyday you can give a long acting insulin such as insulin detemir or insulin glargine

Question: You are a doctor working in A and E. A 56 year old woman has been brought in by her son who is very concerned because he was round for Sunday lunch and she fainted. On questioning, the woman says she has been experiencing nausea and vomiting, palpitations and seems a little confused. She is talking about yellow/green discolouration too. You do an ECG, what would you expect to find?
Explanation:
Digoxin toxicity is what her symptoms describe. On an ECG, someone talking digoxin would have:

SHORTENED QT interval (not long in answer A)

PROMINENT u waves

Reversed tick appearance

PROLONGED PR interval due to increased vagal tone at AVN.

 

You can see these changes sometimes without the patient having digoxin toxicity, it just means they are taking it!

Question: You do an ECG on a woman in the GP surgery and notice that she has T wave flattening and a prominent U wave. What drug is she likely taking?
Explanation: Bendroflumethiazide can cause hypOkalaemia. This shows on ECG as flattening of the T wave, a prominent U wave
Tags: ECGs, Cardiology, Cardiovascular System, Case 13, Case 15

Question: A family friend is taking an antihypertensive and is worried she is getting one of the listed side effects. You practice doing a cheeky ECG on her while visiting her over revision period. You notice a tall T wave. What is she most likely to be taking?
Explanation:
Amlodipine= vasular smooth muscle relaxant used in hypertension

Bendroflumethiazide can be used in hypertension but tends to cause hypOkalaemia, not hypERkalaemia as question states (tall T wave)

ACE inhibitors (ramipril) CAN cause hyperkalaemia

Doxasosin is an alpha blocker also occassionally used in hypertension

 

Spironolactone isnt really used in hypertension

Question: You are helping a mother through the third stage of labour and your supervising consultant recommends that you should use syntometrine. Which of the following is the strongest contraindication for not using this drug in this management plan?
OptionB: The mother has a Blood pressure currently of 146/94
OptionC: The mother is has a BMI of 32 kg/m2
OptionD: The mother has a history of miscarriage
OptionE: The mother has had a caesarian section.
Explanation:
Syntometrine  is a mixture of Syntocinon (5U) with ergometrine (500 mcg).

It is used to induce uterine contraction.

Syntometrine is contraindicated in hypertensive patients due to the vasoconstriction action as the ergometrine may cause a dangerous increase in blood pressure in those who are already hypertensive.

Question: You encounter a patient with an adenohypophysis adenoma that is secreting excess growth hormone. The patient is a 11 year old boy. What is the most likely condition this child has?
Explanation: Acromegaly and gigantism are conditions that are related to excess growth hormone. Gigantism- if the condition occurs before the fusion of the epiphysis. Acromegaly- if it occurs after skeletal epiphyseal closure

Question: A 29 year old woman with poorly controlled type 1 diabetes and partial visual loss a presents to the the midwifery service pregnant with her first child. She is currently on a combination of insulin to manage her diabetes. Which of the following  drug additions will the diabetes specialist be required to make once the patient is referred?
Explanation: Pregnant women with diabetes should be not be any oral hypoglycaemics-except metformin. Insulin is the preferred management of a pregnant diabetic woman

Question: A 77-year-old man presents with back pain that comes on when he walks-this is the only symptom he complains of. After taking a full history and completing a neurological and vascular examination which is normal a diagnosis of spinal stenosis is suspected. After prescribing analgesia, what is the most appropriate next step to rule out a metastatic?
OptionB: Physiotherapy and exercise programme enlistment for the patient
OptionC: No management needed-not enough evidence to suggest spinal metastasis
Explanation:
This presentation requires a MRI to confirm the diagnosis and exclude other causes

• Suspected MSCC with neurological signs and symptoms = urgent MRI of whole spine within 24 hours

• Suspected Spinal Mets (no neurology) =MRI whole spine within a week of suspected diagnosis

Question: An 19-year-old Caucasian female presents to your clinic because of a recent increase in thirst and hunger. Urinalysis demonstrates elevated glucose. The patient's BMI is 20kg/m2. Which of the following is the most common cause of death in persons suffering from this patient's illness?
Explanation:
This patient's presentation is consistent with diabetes mellitus, type I. Myocardial infarction is the most common cause of death in diabetic patients (both type 1 and 2).

Diabetic patients have increased formation of atherosclerosis and arteriosclerosis. These changes impair blood flow to various organs and tissues (via vessel occlusion) which can lead to possible cardiac (MI), renal (nephropathy), CNS (neuropathy), PNS (peripheral neuropathy), and ocular (retinopathy) complications.

Question:
You are a medical student on placement in a GP surgery, shadowing the diabetic nurse. She is seeing patients for their 6 month diabetic review. During this review, the nurse reviews the oral hypoglycaemic drugs each patient is taking. One patient, Mrs Nkem Obande, a 65 year old lady, complains that her medication is causing her to have headaches. You ask the nurse about this drug and she tells you that it works by inhibiting dipeptidyl peptidase (DPP-4), thus inhibiting the inactivation of GLP-1. 

 

What drug is the patient most likely taking?
Explanation:
The mechanism of the drug described in the question correlates with sitagliptin.

 

Sitaglipin is one of two agents which affect GLP-1. GLP-1 and GIP are incretin hormones, both secreted by endocrine cells that are located in the epithelium of the small intestine. An increase of substances in the lumen of the GI tract (like glucose) triggers the secretion of these hormones. Incretins are carried through the circulation to target tissues: pancreatic beta cells. The incretin stimulation of beta cells causes them to secrete more insulin in response to the same amount of glucose. 

 

GLP-1 is inactivated by an enzyme called dipeptidyl peptidase (DPP-4). This enzyme breaks down the incretin. Sitagliptin works by inhibiting DPP-4 and thus preventing GLP-1 from being inactivated, so more GLP-1 in the circulation allows for an increase in insulin release, decrease in glucagon release and thus an overall decrease in blood glucose.

 

The main side effect of DPP-4 inhibitors is headaches.

 

Exenatide is the other drug that works on GLP-1. It is a long-acting GLP-1 receptor full agonist used in type 2 DM in a combination with other agents. It is therefore a GLP-1 mimetic.

 

Side effects of exenatide are nausea (therefore not given to patient with gastroparesis) and hypoglycaemia when used with oral sulfonylureas.

 

 

In regards to the other drugs:

 

Metformin is a biguanide which works by decreasing hepatic gluconeogenesis and may involve an increase in tissue sensitivity to insulin. Its mechanism of action:

  1. It increases cytosolic AMP
  2. This leads to an activation of AMP activated protein kinase (AMPK)
  3. This causes a decreased expression of phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK) and glucose-6-phosphatase
  4. This ultimately leads to a decrease in hepatic gluconeogenesis, increased insulin sensitivity and increased GLUT 4 activity
  5. All in all lowering plasma glucose levels

It is referred to as "euglycaemic", meaning it decreases postprandial glucose levels, but does not cause hypoglycaemia or weight gain.

 

Its side effects are lactic acidosis (as it forces tissues to pick up lots of glucose) and GI distress is common (diarrhoea).

 

 

Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinediones (i will never ever be able to say that). Its mechanism of action is:

  1. It binds to nuclear PPARs (peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors) involved in the transcription of insulin-responsive genes.
  2. It acts on them to increase the sensitisation of tissue to insulin
  3. It also decreases hepatic gluconeogenesis and triglycerides
  4. It increases the insulin receptor numbers

Its side effects are: hypoglycaemia (but less than sulfonylureas), weight gain, oedema, and in severe cases an increased risk of pancreatic cancer. 

 

 

Gliplizide is a sulfonylurea, which mimics the release of ATP in the beta cell of the pancreas, causing K+ channels to close. 

 

In normal beta cell physiology, glucose enters the cell via GLUT2 transporters and through glycolysis produces ATP. The rise in ATP is detected by the sulfonylurea receptor subunit (SUR-1) of the K+ATPase channel and causes it to close. This increases the K+ inside the cell which depolarises the membrane, leading to opening of Ca2+ channels. Calcium influx into the cell causes insulin to be released from granules. Sulfonylureas bypass all of this and and bind to SUR-1 thus blocking the K+ channels, causing insulin release. 

 

A common side effect of sulfonylureas is hypoglycaemia, and a more severe side effect is cholestasis (where bile cannot flow from the liver to the duodenum).

 

 

Lastly, acarbose (not one of the options, but i've gotten this far explaining them all so might as well carry on!) works by inhibiting a-glucosidase in the brush borders of the small intestine. This enzyme usually breaks down complex sugars into small absorbable sugars. Therefore, by inhibiting it, there is a decrease in the formation of absorbable carbs, thus decreasing postprandial glucose, and hence decreasing the demand for insulin.

 

Its use should be restricted to those who have failed to respond to diet alone and cannot tolerate the conventional oral hypoglycaemics.

 

Its side effects are: GI discomfort, flatulence (bloating), diarrhoea (keeping sugars in the gut causes osmotic pull of water), and recent concern over potential hepatotoxicity.

 

 

That's all folks, sorry for the length of this, but gotta love some pictures in there! Hang on guys, almost done now!

Question:
You are a medical student shadowing an endocrinologist, when this patient walks in for his appointment:

 

The endocrinologist tells you that this patient has a rare and severe genetic disorder which is autosomal recessive. The disorder is associated with insulin receptor mutations, which causes insulin resistance. You notice the patient has an aged face, thick lips, low-set ears, acanthosis nigricans and you are told he also has hyperandrogenism. 

 

What does the patient most likely have?
Explanation:
Donahue syndrome (aka leprechaunism) is an extremely rare and severe genetic disorder. Leprechaunism derives its name from the fact that those afflicted with the disease often have elfin features and are smaller than usual.

 

It is autosomal recessive and is associated with insulin resistance due to insulin receptor mutations.

 

Facial features indicative of Donohue syndrome include protuberant and low-set ears, flaring nostrils, aged face, acanthosis nigricans and thick lips. Physical features include stunted growth (including during gestation), an enlarged clitoris and breasts in affected females, and an enlarged penis in affected males.

 

In the Journal of Paediatric Medicine, Donohue and Uchida described affected sisters whose growth appeared to have ended in the seventh month of gestation, both born alive but dying before four months of age. Very early death (or spontaneous abortion) is the norm, although sufferers sometimes live longer than a decade.

 

Sadly, the patients usually appear like this:

 

 

The other insulin receptor syndromes are known as Rabson-Mendenhall and Type A Insulin Resistance.

Question: Katie, a beautiful 3 years and 4 months old girl has recently had her MMR booster. She is crying a lot and is at home when her mum notices that she has developed some parotid swelling. How long ago did she most likely have the jab?
Explanation:
18 days

 

Mumps incubation period average is 17 or 18 days (and mumps is what causes parotid swelling.)

 

The MMR booster is given here at 3 years and 4 months. The first dose would have been at about 1 year old.

 

Average incubation period for measles is 10-12 days (prodromal) and 14 days for onset of rash.

 

Average incubation for rubella is 14 days.

 

MMR vaccine is a live vaccine which is why it is possible to get some of the symptoms, mildly.

Question:
Whilst on placement in the emergency department you see a patient, Becky, come in with loss of sensation and motor paralysis in her lower limbs following a fall from a stepladder onto her back. While the doctors are assessing her reflexes (which were all absent) you think back to case 14 and try to recall the electrolyte changes occurring in Becky.

 

Which of the following is correct?
Explanation: Becky is suffering from spinal shock, an electrochemical disturbance which occurs from any impact to the spine. It is characterised by the initial loss of reflexes and sensory/motor deficits (which will gradually recover). During spinal shock there is migration of K+ ions into the extracellular space. Spinal shock begins within 30-60 minutes of an injury and can continue for up to 6 weeks, though it can resolve within 24 hours.

Question:
65 year old, Robert Baratheon, presents to A&E with episodic chest pain. He tells you that 2 months ago, he had the same pain which lasted for several weeks, but went away until early this morning, roughly around 6am. He says this pain can happen even when he is resting. He tells you he is under a lot of emotional stress at the moment as he found his darling wife Cersei sleeping with her own brother! 

 

You perform an ECG on Robert, and the results are below:

 

 

You give Robert nitroglycerin, which subsequently relieves his symptoms. You then perform another ECG, and he is now in sinus rhythm.

 

What did Robert most likely present with?
Explanation:
Robert is presenting with Prinzmental variant angina, a form of angina pectoris. Angina pectoria is a transient cardiac ischaemia without cell death, resulting in substernal chest pain.

 

Prinzmetal’s angina is a form of chest pain, pressure, or tightness caused by coronary artery vasospasms. It is a form of unstable angina, meaning that it occurs at rest, often without a predictable pattern. This is in contrast to stable angina, in which chest pain occurs in a predictable pattern during exertion or exercise.

 

Episodes of chest pain caused by Prinzmetal's angina usually occur in clusters, with periods of frequent episodes lasting for a few months followed by weeks or months with no chest pain episodes. The pain usually occurs between midnight and approximately 8:00 AM. Prinzmetal's angina may be brought on by hyperventilation, exposure to cold, or extreme emotional stress. 

 

ECG results show transient ST segment elevation due to transmural ischaemia.

 

It is relieved by nitroglycerine (vasodilatation), which also brings the ECG back to sinus rhythm.

 

Stable angina is the most common type of angina. It is caused by coronary artery atherosclerosis with luminal narrowing >75%. The chest pain is brought on by increase in cardiac demand, such as during exercise. The ECG will show ST segment depression due to subendocardial ischaemia. It is usually relieved by rest or nitroglycerin.

 

Unstable angina or crescendo angina is caused by formation of a non-occlusive thrombus in an area of coronary atherosclerosis. There can be a rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque in a coronary vessel, resulting in thrombosis of an already narrowed vessel.

The chest pain associated usually occurs with increasing frequency, intensity and duration. And the pain occurs at rest. Usually a precursor for an MI.

Sheryl is a 21 year old university student who has came to the GP complaining of having problems dressing herself, as she was unable to abduct her shoulder for more than 90 degrees. 

 

Which shoulder muscle is most likely to be damaged, and what is the nerve innervating it?
Explanation:
Supraspinatus abducts to 15 degrees 

Deltoid continues to abduct to 90 degrees 

Trapezuis does the rest 

 

She can't go beyond 90 degrees so trapezius is the problem

Question: What is the last stage of the exiting of a fetus from a mother during pregnancy delivery?
Explanation:
Mechanism of labour movements:

• The baby descends into the pelvis

• The baby flexes- tucking the chin to the chest

• The baby internally rotates to the occiput anterior position just before crowning

• The baby is crowning as its occiput is now under the pubic arch

• The baby's head is born by extension

• The baby restitues (goes back to former position by externally rotating)

• The baby internally rotates again

• The baby's anterior shoulder goes under the pubic arch

• The baby's posterior shoulder goes under the pubic arch

• The baby laterally flexes its body

Do Frogs In Cardiff Ever Ride In A Pink Limo

Question:
(November 2014)

 

You're sitting in the sports hall in the Heath sports and social centre.

 

You're participating in the drugs in the eye practical and are observing your partner who kindly volunteered to be the one receiving the eye drops. 

 

After about 20 minutes, you see that your partner's eye begins to constrict and the eye has a 'blood shot' appearance

 

As this experiment was a trial, neither you or your partner know what drugs was administered. From the information above, what drug can you conclude had these affects? (You're super keen so did the pre-reading and therefore know what drug causes what reaction)
Explanation:
So the correct answer is pilocarpine as it's a mACh receptor agonist.

A bit of info on the rest of the drugs:

 

Phenylephrine

  • Adrenoceptor agonist
  • Causes myadriasis (dilation of the pupil)
  • Peripheral vasoconstriction
  • Whitening of the sclera

 

Tetracaine

  • Local anaesthetic blocking voltage gated Na+ channels
  • Loss of corneal reflex

 

Cocaine

  • Local anaesthetic - loss of corneal reflex
  • Myadriasis (dilation of the pupil)
  • Peripheral vasoconstriction

 

Tropicamide

  • mACh receptor antagonist
  • Paralyses pupil constrictor response and cilliary muscle --> pupil dilation

Pilocarpine

  • mACh receptor agonist
  • Marked by pupil contraction (miosis)
  • Bloodshot eye

Question: A patient is suspected oh having diabetes. He has a fasting plasma glucose of 5.7mmol/l  and an 2 hour oral glucose tolerance test or 8.4mmol/l. What is the best description of this man's condition, given these results?
Explanation:
IGT is where a fasting glucose is below 7mmol/L but the 2 hour glucose test is between 7.8 and 11.1 mmol/L

Impaired fasting glycaemia is where the fasting glucose is 6.0-7.0 mmol/L

Diabetes is diagnosed as: If symptomatic, test on one occasion. If non-symptomatic, test on two occasions.

You need one of the following:

1.Fasting plasma glucose > 7.0mmol/L

2.Random plasma glucose > 11.1mmol/L

3. 2hr glucose post 75G GTT > 11.1

4.HbA1c > 6.5%

 


Prediabetes is a term which is increasingly used where there is impaired glucose levels which are above the normal range but not high enough for a diagnosis of diabetes mellitus. The term includes patients who have been labelled as having either impaired fasting glucose (IFG) or impaired glucose tolerance (IGT). So E is partly correct but C is more correct

Question: Which of the following features is only present in stage 2 of sleep?
Explanation:
• Alpha activity: regular medium frequency waves, produced when someone is resting
  • Beta activity: irregular, low amplitude waves, shows that many different neural networks are actively processing information
  • Theta activity: types of theta activity include sleep spindles and K complexes, occurs during stage 2 of sleep
  • K complexes: sudden sharp waveforms only found in stage 2 sleep, show the consolidation of memory but can also be caused by loud noises
  • Slleep spindles: short bursts of waves, present during stages 1-4, increased number of sleep spindles is associated with higher scores on intelligence tests

Question: Which antibiotic(s) stops dihydrofolate reductase converting folic acid into tetrahydrofolic acid?
Explanation:
Folate synthesis inhibitors include Sulfonamides and Trimethoprim

Sulfonamides prevent folic acid synthesis, so that amino acids and nucleic acids are not produced.

For our exam, we need to know that Trimethoprim stops dihydrofolate reductase converting folic acid into tetrahydrofolic acid, so that amino acids and nucleic acids aren't synthesised

Sulfonamides stop dihydropteroate synthase enzyme

What is 2?
Explanation:

2. Caudate nucleus

3. Corpus callosum

4. Lateral ventricle

5. Third ventricle

6. Fourth ventricle

Question: In the fetal circulation in utero, which of the following vessels will carry the highest oxygen content?
Explanation: The blood from the umbilical vein comes directly from the placenta so has the highest oxygen content. The umbilical artery will contain mixed blood due to the fact that blood has mixed before in the heart from the LV mixes with shunted blood from ductus arteriosus.

Question: Which of the following back muscles is highlighted in this picture?
Explanation: Spinalis, longissimus and iliocostalis are the 3 intermediate extrinsic muscles of the back

Question: What inheritance pattern does lynch syndrome show?
Explanation:
Autosomal dominant is the correct answer-patients can develop colonic cancer and endometrial cancer at young age
80% of affected individuals with get colonic and or endometrial cancer

Question: Which wave is the slowest and has the highest amplitude?
Explanation:
Alpha activity: Regular, medium frequency: Stage 1

Beta activity: Irregular: active during information processing

Theta activity: Sleep spindles and K complexes: Stage 2

Delta waves: Highest amplitude but slowest: Slow wave sleep: Stage 3 and 4

K-Complexes are sudden, sharp waves (consolidation of memory; can also occur due to loud noises)

Question: A 68-year old gentleman presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of heart palpitations and associated syncope. An ECG is ordered and examination of the jugular venous pulsation shows cannon 'A' waves. Based on the JVP waveform, what would you expect the ECG recording to show?
Explanation:
Cannon A waves are characteristic of complete atrial-ventricular dissociation as is seen in third degree (complete) heart block. Normally, the 'A' wave increases, reflecting the rise in pressure during atrial systole before peaking and then decreasing as the atria enter diastole. The 'C' wave marks the closure of the tricuspid valve, this causes a transient rise in pressure as the valve pushes back up towards the right atrium. 

 

Cannon A waves are seen when the atria contract against a closed tricuspid valve, hence the pressure in the right atrium will fluctuate giving it the characteristic 'cannon' waveform. In complete heart block, the atria and ventricles are contracting at different rates hence why the tricuspid valve may be closed during atrial systole.

Question: 85 year old Terrence Baker presents to the GP with profuse diarrhoea. He was treated a week ago for otitis media with an antibiotic. A stool sample was sent off, and came back positive for C. difficile toxins. What was the most likely antibiotic the patient was taking that led to this infectious agent in the large intestine?
Explanation:
Before I explain, just want to say this is a difficult question, and I don't think anything like this would come up in the exam, I just wanted an excuse to write out about the classes of antibiotics because I can't remember them to save my life!

 

Clindamycin is one of the many antibiotics that work as a protein synthesis inhibitor. So, I'm going to go through the protein synthesis inhibitors:

 

Protein Synthesis Inhibitors

 

1. Tetracyclines: - tetracycline and doxycycline

                             - works by interfering with the attachment of tRNA to mRNA-ribosome complex on 30s portion

                             - potential side effects: bone growth and superinfection with candida

 

2. Chloramphenicol: - works by binding to 50s portion and inhibits the formation of peptide bonds

                                   - potential side effects: grey baby syndrome

 

3. Aminoglycosides: - gentamycin and streptomycin

                                    - works by changing the shape of the 30s portion, causing the code on mRNA to be read incorrectly

                                    - gentamycin potential side effects: nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity

 

4. Macrolides: - erythromycin, azithromycin and clarithromycin

                         - works by binding to 50s portion, preventing translocation movement of ribosome along mRNA

                         - erythromycin useful for patients who are allergic to penicillins

                         - clarithromycin potential side effects: inhibits CYP450 enzymes, therefore decreased metabolism of drugs, and increased drug toxicity

 

5. Lincosamides: - clindamycin

                              - same mechanism of action as macrolides, works by binding to 50s portion, preventing translocation movement of ribosome along mRNA

                              - potential side effects: superinfection with C. difficile leading to pseudomembranous colitis.

Question: Which class of antibiotics does trimethoprim come under?
Explanation:
The correct answer is C.

 

Bacteria cannot take up folate from the environment, and so have to make it themselves. Folate is an important building block for synthesis of amino acids and nucleotides. 

 

The three antibiotics that work by inhibiting folate synthesis are:

  1. Sulfonamides
  2. Trimethoprim
  3. Methotrexate

Sulfonamides work by inhibiting the synthesis of folic acid, whereas trimethoprim inhibits the next step where folic acid is converted into tetrahydrofolic acid.

 

Sulfonamides and Trimethoprim are combined together to form co-trimoxazole, therefore, the drugs act synergistically. The advantage of using two drugs this way is not just that you get an enhanced effect but that you can use the drugs at a lower dose and thus have less chance of toxicity.

Question:
Lesley Barnes, an 18 year old girl, has attended the sexual health clinic. She says a week ago she had unprotected sex and has since noticed a white, clear discharge on her underwear, she has also recently felt some discomfort when urinating. 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis of Lesley?
Explanation:
Chlamydia is the best answer, UTI could be correct, however it does not explain the discharge, and there are no symptoms of urgency.

 

Chlamydia is a gram negative bacteria, spread through sexual contact. The patient can present with dysuria, a white-ish, clear, and non-purulent discharge, and also abdominal pain. It is the most common STI in the UK and is treated with azithromycin or doxycycline.

 

Gonorrhoea is a gram negative bacteria. Males infected usually present with burning on urination, a green/yellow purulent discharge from the tip of the penis, and inflammation of the foreskin. Women infected usually present with an unusual discharge which may be thin/water and green in colour, dysuria, and possibly discomfort in the abdomen. The bacteria can also grow in the mouth and anus. Babies that are born from mothers infected with gonorrhoea may have ophthalmia which can rapidly leave to blindness if untreated. Gonorrhoea is treated with cefixime or azithromycin.

 

Trichomoniasis is caused by a tiny parasite called Trichomonas vaginalis. Symptoms include vaginal discharge which is offensive smelling and of yellow/green colour. Discharge can also be frothy. Patient may also have vulvovaginitis which is referred to as a "strawberry cervix". It is usually treated with metronidazole.

 

Vulvovaginal Candidiasis is caused by an infection from candida albicans associated with dermatitis of the vulva. Symptoms include cottage cheese-like discharge. Patients taking tetracyclines are at risk of developing this infection. Usually treated with clotrimazole cream or oral fluconazole.

 

Herpes simplex is a dsDNA virus. Resulting in inflamed papules and vesicles on the outer surface of the genitals resembling cold sores. Usually treated with aciclovir or valaciclovir (anti-viral meds).

 

Syphilis is caused by gram negative Treponema pallidum. Patients present with small painless ulcers, typically appearing on the penis, vagina or around the mouth/anus. A non-itchy blotchy body rash that often affects palms of hands or soles of the feet. May also have white patches in the mouth. Usually treated with penicillin.

 

Urinary Tract Infection, most commonly caused by E.coli. Patients present with dysuria, urgency and lower back pain or pubic pain. Elderly patients may also present with delirium. Usually treated with a short course of antibiotics, most commonly trimethoprim.

Question: Which reaction(s) prevent polyspermy from occurring in fertilisation?
Explanation: Polyspermy prevention is via the Cortical reaction. This induces formation of a ‘fertilisation membrane’

Question:
A 35-year-old woman visits her GP complaining of a wide variety of symptoms that have become steadily worse over the past 5 months. She has put on over 3 stone of weight despite no change in her diet and she feels that this has concentrated on her face and neck. She also has noticed stretch marks on her abdomen and excessive hair growth over her body and face.

After referral to an endocrinologist she is found to have an increased secretion of adrenocorticotropic hormone due to a pituitary adenoma.

Which of the following best describes this condition?
Explanation:
This patient is suffering from Cushing's disease which results from increased secretion of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) from the anterior pituitary, often caused as a result of a pituitary adenoma. The symptoms should allow you to remove both Addison's disease and Conn's as answers, 

Cushing's triad is a set of three clinical signs irregular respirations, bradycardia and systolic hypertension resulting from raised intracranial pressure.

Cushing's syndrome is a collection of signs and symptoms due to prolonged exposure to cortisol and Cushing's disease is a specific type of Cushing's syndrome characterised by increased ACTH production of because of a pituitary adenoma (or sometimes due to excess production of hypothalamus CRH).

Question: A family has a child affected by sickle cell disease. Neither the father nor the mother have sickle cell disease; they have a 2nd unaffected child-what is the probability that he is a carrier of the sickle cell gene?
Explanation:
According to your punnet square, there are four possibilities for offspring. There is a 25% chance the offspring is normal, 2 out of 4 chances they are a carrier and a quarter chance they are affected.The previous affected child has no bearing on probabilities for this new offspring.

However, according to the question, the new offspring is not affected. There are now only two possibities for the offspring- carrier or healthy. Probabilites are now 2/3 that they are a carrier and 1/3 non-carrier. Sickle cell anaemia is an autosomal recessive condition, inherited via chromosome 11.

Question: When is the best time for a expecting mother to have her first booking visit during her pregnancy?

Question: Pre eclampisa in pregnancy can often lead to one developing eclampsia. Which of the following separates the two conditions?

Pre-clampisa =a condition seen after 20 weeks gestation characterised by pregnancy-induced hypertension in association with proteinuria (> 0.3g / 24 hours)

Eclampsia =defined as the development of seizures in association pre-eclampsia

 

In pre-eclampsia-Consensus guidelines recommend treating blood pressure > 160/110 mmHg although many clinicians have a lower threshold

 

Haemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets=HELLP syndrome and is a severe complication of  pre-eclampsia

It might be worth noting that smoking decreases your risk

Question: A patient presents to A&E complaining of headache and feeling nauseous. They remember that they banged their head falling down some stairs a few days ago so you run a CT. It shows a crescent shape collection of blood with effaced sulci on the same side. Explanation: CT description matches that of a subdural which is caused by Cortical atrophy that causes tension on bridging veins pulling them away from the dura leading to a venous bleed (In picture). Seen in the elderly,alcoholics and in shaken baby syndrome. (Hypertension is more associated with sub arachnoid bleeds)

Question: You are seeing a women who is pregnant who has been found to be rhesus negative. Not knowing the fetus' blood group; under NICE guidance, at what times would you  give this women anti D prophylaxis?
OptionB: After each potentially sensitising event during the pregnancy and within 72h of childbirth (if the baby is RhD-positive)
OptionC: Only within 72h of childbirth (if the baby is RhD-positive)
OptionD: Administration of anti-D antenatally (at 28 weeks and again at 34 weeks)
Explanation:
o To prevent sensitisation of RhD-negative women during pregnancy, anti-D is given:

  • After each potentially sensitising event during the pregnancy
  • Within 72h of childbirth (if the baby is RhD-positive)
  • NICE has also approved the routine administration of anti-D antenatally (at 28 weeks and again at 34 weeks) in addition to the usual postnatal administration

The administered anti-D would destroy any RhD-positive foetal cells in the maternal circulation before the mother has had the opportunity to make anti-D in response.

Correct answer is A

Question: From how many months gestation does lactogenesis occur?
Explanation:
Lactogenesis occurs from 4 months 

The first part of lactogenesis is hormone mediated 

 Stage 1 lactogenesis (from 4 months)

 Fat droplets increase in size

 Production of lactose, casein and α-lactalbumin

 Re-absorbed into the blood

 Full milk secretion prevented by high levels of progesterone and oestrogen

 Birth: sudden drop in oestrogen, progesterone & hPL

 High prolactin

 Cue for Lactogenesis II

 

 Stage 2 Lactogenesis

 30-40 hours after birth

 Increase in lactose, IgA and lactoferrin

 Increase in milk volume

 High oligosaccharide levels (protective against pathogens)

 Hormonally driven

 Milk removal necessary by day 3 to continue lactation

 After lactogenesis II: a switch from endocrine to autocrine control

 Milk removal primary control mechanism for milk synthesis Galactopoiesis or Lactogenesis III

 

Maintenance of Lactation (Galactopoiesis)

 Prolactin appears to be the single most important galactopoietic hormone.

 Continuous suckling is essential for removal of milk from glands: prolactin release.

 Feedback inhibitor of lactation; FIL (whey protein) regulates milk secretion

 Milk production slows when milk accumulates in the breast & speeds up when breast is emptier

 Fat content determined by how empty the breast is

 Emptier breast = higher fat milk

Question:
Martin O'Neill works in an office situated above Greggs bakery.

He frequents there on average 3 times a day Monday to Friday.

His favorite deal is the 5 sausage rolls for a quid.

Each sausage roll contains 349 kcal and 25g of fat 

If he has the 5 sausage rolls for lunch, how many calories is he allowed for the rest of the day? (His RDA is 2500 kcal).

What is the RDA of total fat (grams) in one day?
Explanation:
349 x 5 = 1745

2500 - 1745 = 755

NHS recommends that total fat = 70g.

 

This diet is not balanced and does not meed the recommendations by the NHS. This is an example of a bad diet. Eating 125g of fat daily is not advisable.
