Question: A caloric test is being carried out on Yograj. 20ml of cold water is poured into his left ear. There is no nystagmus and his eyes deviate to the left side immediately. What is the absence of nystagmus indicative of?
A 74-year-old man has just done a gait speed test. A gait speed of less than 0.8m/sec indicates frailty. This test is very sensitive, which means ...
OptionA: Many people with a positive test will not be frail
OptionB: Some people who take the test may be slow for reasons NOT to do with frailty, for example, an arthritic leg
OptionC: The test has a high number of false positives
OptionD: The test has lots of false negatives
OptionE: The test picks up the majority of people who are frail
Explanation:
A B and C are all to do with a high level of false positives, which would suggest a low SPECIFICITY, rather than a high sensitivity. Having lots of false negatives would make the test have LOW sensitivity. 

 

High sensitivity - lots of true positives (i.e. picked up nearly everyone who is frail) and few false negatives (ie - frail people with a high gait speed)

Specificity is a measure of the number of false positives (ie how many people were slow but actually not frail).

 

The gait speed test is very sensitive but not very specific.

Question: Your next door neighbour Max is a 79 year old gentleman who suffers from AF and is taking warfarin. You see him over the hedge when you are just about to get into your car, and give him a jolly wave. He's so excited to see you he stumbles down his front porch stairs falls. You run over to see if he is okay, and he is bleeding profusely from his leg, as he has cut himself on some jagged stone. In hospital, what treatment does he receive?

Question: You've watched so many episodes of House, M.D on your revision breaks that when you develop a right sided limp you decide to buy a snazzy cane. People start thinking you're bit weird so you visit the GP. You describe your symptoms as a sharp shooting pain in your right foot radiating up your leg, which worsens after long periods of standing and relieves on rest. You also have pins and needles and a burning sensation in your foot. What condition do your symptoms most likely fit?
OptionA: Foot drop due to posterior tibial nerve compression
OptionB: Tarsal tunnel syndrome due to common fibular nerve damage
OptionC: Foot drop due to common fibular nerve damage
OptionD: Tarsal tunnel syndrome due to posterior tibial nerve compression
OptionE: You had an infarction in your thigh muscle and had the dead tissue amputated when you were in a coma because your girlfriend betrayed you
Explanation: Tarsal tunnel syndrome is due to compression of the posterior tibial nerve usually within the tarsal tunnel. Pain (occasionally burning and tingling) is usually retromalleolar and sometimes in the plantar medial heel and may extend along the plantar surface as far as the toes. Although the pain is worse during standing and walking, pain at rest may occur as the disorder progresses, which helps to distinguish it from plantar fasciosis.

Question: A young later has recently gotten pregnant despite being on the COCP. You review her list of medications and social history and find that the drug responsible is most likely....
Explanation:
Not an exhaustive list but 

Inducers of the P450 system include

◦ Antiepileptics: phenytoin, carbamazepine

◦ Barbiturates: phenobarbitone

◦ Rifampicin

◦ St John's Wort

◦ Chronic alcohol intake

◦ Griseofulvin

◦ Smoking (affects CYP1A2, reason why smokers require more aminophylline)

 

Inhibitors of the P450 system include

• Antibiotics: ciprofloxacin, erythromycin

• Isoniazid • Cimetidine, omeprazole

• Amiodarone

• Allopurinol

• Imidazoles: ketoconazole, fluconazole

• SSRIs: fluoxetine, sertraline

• Ritonavir

• Sodium valproate

• Acute alcohol intake

• quinupristin

 

As an enzyme inducer, COCP will be processed more quickly by St John's Wort where as an enzyme inhibitor would increase the occurrence of ADRs

• Rolling (paraoesophageal): the gastroesophageal junctions remains below the diaphragm but a separate part of the stomach herniates through the oesophageal hiatus

Question: A man is exposed to hepatitis A on his travels, but luckily recovers soon. This was partly due to production of antibodies. Antibodies are produced as part of the adaptive immune response when dendritic cells migrate to the lymph nodes and present antigens. However in hepatitis, dendritic cells aren't directly infected, so how can they present antigens in lymph nodes?
Explanation: Cross presentation is when exogenous peptides are pinocytosed, associate with MHC 1 in the ER of DC's, which then migrate to lymph nodes and activatate CD8 cells.

Question: What type of general sensory receptor in the skin detects pressure and light touch and where in the skin is it found?
Explanation:
Superficial:

  • Merkel endings are found in the stratum basale (superficially) and detect fine touch and pressure
  • Free nerve endings are the branching tips of sensory neurons and respond to tactile, pain and temperature stimuli
  • Meisseners corpuscle provide sensations of fine touch and pressure and low frequency vibration - Located in dermal papillae of hairless skin
    (Nipples, external genitalia, fingertips, soles of feet, eyelids)

Deep:

  • Pacinian corpuscle detect vibrations and deep pressure - Located in the subcutaneous layer of skin (Mesentary, tendons, ligaments, joint capsules, fingertips, soles of feet, external genitalia, nipples) 
  • Ruffini endings detect distortion and pressure in the deep dermis - Located deep in the dermis, hypodermis and found in joint capsules

Layers of the skin:

 

The epidermis = a thin outer portion, that is the keratinised stratified squamous epithelium of skin. The epidermis is important for the protective function of skin. The basal layers of this epithelium are folded to form dermal papillae. Thin skin contains four types of cellular layers, and thick skin contains five. 

 

  1. Stratum corneum - The keratinised squames layer
  2. Stratum lucidum - Identified in thick skin
  3. Stratum granulosum - As the cells move up into this layer, they start to lose their nuclei and cytoplasmic organelles, and turn inot the keratinised squames of the next layer. The granules contain a lipid rich secretion, which acts as a water sealant.
  4. Stratum spongiosum - The cells in these layers have lots of desmosomes, which anchor the cells to each other, and contain thick tufts of intermediate filaments (keratin)
  5. Stratum basale - The basal cell layer (stratum basale, or stratum germinosum), is a single layer of cells, closest to the dermis. It is usually only in this layer that cells divide. Some of the dividing cells move up to the next layer.

 

The dermis = a thicker inner portion. This is the connective tissue layer of skin. It is important for sensation, protection and thermoregulation. It contains nerves, the blood supply, fibroblasts, etc, as well as sweat glands, which open out onto the surface of the skin, and in some regions, hair. The apical layers of the dermis are folded, to form dermal papillae, which are particularly prominent in thick skin.

 

The hypodermis = This layer is underneath the dermis, and merges with it. It mainly contains adipose tissue and sweat glands. The adipose tissue has metabolic functions: it is resonsible for production of vitamin D, and triglycerides.

Question:
Jeanette is on her post-op ward rounds, and came across this particular not to happy patient. On observation, Jeanette noticed that the patient has just had to amputate his toes.

Question: Familial adenomatous polyposis is caused by mutation of APC gene in most cases,  and is autosomal dominant. If one is found to have the adenomas that come with the condition what is the closest chance that one of the adenomas will turn cancerous?
Explanation:
From case 11 genetics lecture 

http://www.cancer.net/cancer-types/familial-adenomatous-polyposis 

FAP is a rare autosomal dominant condition which leads to the formation of hundreds of polyps by the age of 30-40 years. Patients inevitably develop carcinoma. It is due to a mutation in a tumour suppressor gene called adenomatous polyposis coli gene (APC), located on chromosome 5. Genetic testing can be done by analysing DNA from a patients white blood cells. Patients generally have a total colectomy with ileo-anal pouch formation in their twenties.

 

Typically over 100 colonic adenomas. Patients typically have a cancer risk of at almost 100%

It is notable that having a high BMI and female lowers you risk if normal population and raises your risk if LS.

Question: Which of the following statements is true with regard to the aging process of the intervertebral disc along the endplate?
OptionE: There is a conversion to fibrocartilage with regards to the nucleus pulposus
Explanation:
Disc aging leads to an overall loss of water content and conversion to fibrocartilage.

The intervertebral disc allows spinal motion and provides stability.

In addition, it is responsible for 25% of spinal column height. It consists of an outer annulus, with a high concentration of Type I collagen, and an inner nucleus pulposus, with a high concentration in Type II collagen. With aging there is degeneration of the disc that may alter the function as well.

Question: You are seeing a patient in A&E with cramps abdominal pain, vomiting and severe hyperventilation. Ketones are ++ in the urine and she has pH of 7.28. What Arterial blood gas result interpretation would you most expect and what is the cause of this finding?
Explanation:
D is correct as this person likely has DKA. Tim's lecture explains in ENOUGH detail for S3 but I will outline the basics here

 

The normal range = 10-18 mmol/L. Raised Anion gap relates to the fact there is H+ A- gain in the system; in general, a raised anion gap indicates an added acid load from within with an increase in negative anions. Lactic acidosis is another key example.

Normal anion gap can mean a high H+and Cl- level ( = hyperchloraemic metabolic acidosis) meaning often there may be H+ Cl- gain but also Hco3- loss.

So close to the exam I would stress too much if you cannot get your head around this but just learn to spot the common pattern of DKA. Clues to diagnosis are the low pH (<7.3), ++ Ketonuria (or 3mmol/l or greater), Bicarbonate less than 15 mmol/l, hyperglycaemia of 11.0mmol/l (note than RPG/2hr-OGTT requires 11.1mmol/l and above for diabetes diagnosis).

Question: You are seeing a patient with type II diabetes, who is morbidly obese and has literally just been diagnosed with  severe irreversible renal failure, following many years of uncontrolled hypertension. Following this, as your GP you decide that his new BP target is ......
Explanation:
Blood pressure management is a likely scenario in a lot of T2DM patients especially as they get older 

Normally Blood pressure target is < 140/80 mmHg in diabetics but is raised  < 130/80 mmHg if end-organ damage is present
ACE inhibitors are first-line regardless of the patients age or ethnicity for diabetes patients

Question: Where in the GI tract would you found a histological sample like this?
Explanation: From jejunum-signs are extensive plica circulares and really tall villi (in comparison to ileum)

Question: Where would a histological sample such as this be found in the GI tract?
Explanation: This is a slide from the Ileum-signs are plicae circulares that are smaller than the jejunum ones, peyer's patches in the submucosa

Question: Where would a histological sample such as this be found in the GI tract?
Explanation:
Key differences between the large and small intestine histologically

  • Crypts present
  • No plicae circulares 
  • Few/no villi 
  • Less dramatic folds

Question: A young female patient is admitted to the hospital with frequent diarrhoea, abdominal pain, marked weight loss over 6 weeks and evidence of perianal disease. On examination, there is an abdominal mass palpable in the right iliac fossa. Steroids are unsuccessful in treating this patient, so she has an ileum resection. Given this information and small of the ileum shown above, what is the most likely condition this lady has?
Explanation:
There are many tell tail signs of the CD over UC in the question-they include

  • The fact it is the lieum affected-UC only affects colon and rectum, where as CD can affect the whole tract 
  • The cobblestone appearance of the ileum 
  • The diarrhoea with no blood 
  • The RIF mass; LIF mass is more indicative of UC
  • The weight loss; though common in both, it is more common in CD 
  • Perianal disease-more common in CD
Tags: Gastrointestinal tract, Case 12, Inflammatory Bowel Disease

Question: A diabetic patient has been diagnosed with stage 2 nephropathy - what should his GFR be in mls/min/1.73m2?
Explanation: Basically, a=stage 1, b=    stage 2, c=stage 3, d=stage 4, e=not one of the stages (ie beyond stage 4). See case 17, complications of diabetes

Question: How does glibenclamide effect the pancreatic beta cell?
OptionA: Causes K+ ATP effluxer to depolarise via SUR1 receptors
OptionB: Causes K+ ATP effluxer to hyperpolarise via SUR1 receptors
OptionC: Causes Ca2+ influx into the cell via activating the Voltage gated Calcium channel
OptionD: Causes Ca2+ efflux out of the cell via activating the Voltage gated Calcium channel
OptionE: Causes insulin granules to be realised via direct activation of the tyrosine kinase receptor

Question: In a desperate attempt to cram from your exams, you are reviewing abdominal x-rays. You see an x-ray with calcification, but you can't tell which structure it is in exactly. You try to remember normal and abnormal sites of calcification. Which of these is NOT a pathological site of calcification?
Explanation:
Normal calcification= lymph nodes and vascular areas.

Abnormal= gall stones, renal stones, appendicolith, aneurysm,pancreatic, tape worm.

Question: You come across a diabetic patient with 'mononeuritis', ie a single nerve is being affected by her neuropathy; she complains of double vision. You decide to do a full cranial nerves exam to practice for your ISCE and don't notice much, although one of her eyes seems to be pointing inwards - what cause of double vision are you most likely to find, based on her symptoms and mononeuritis?
Explanation:
Abducens innervates lateral rectus, so damage to this causes the eye to deviate medially.

 

Retinopathy isn't a mononeuritis

Optic nerve mononeuritis - not sure if this happens at all but I imagine it would cause blind spots rather than double vision

Occulomotor mononeuritis would cause a down and out gaze because of the unopposed action of superior oblique (from the trochlear nerve)

Hypoglycaemia isn't a mononeuritis

Question: Teresa Hay, a 67 year old lady, recently had a fracture to the femoral neck. Her consultant suspected an underlying cause to her fracture. After several tests, he found that her T-score was -3.0. What is this most likely indicative of?
Explanation:
The T score scale allows an individual's bone mineral density to be compared to a "young, normal" adult (30 year old), who has peak bone density. Results are given as a T-scorem which indicates their divergence from the desirable density.

 

A score from -1 to 2 is regarded as normal bone density, and the person is at a low risk of poor bone health

A score from -1 to -2.5 is regarded as low bone density or osteopenia, and the person is at a moderate risk of poor bone health

A score of -2.5 to -4 is regarded as osteoporosis, and the person is at an increased risk of poor bone health

Question: Which of the following infections is most associated with a feature of clue cells and a fishy offensive vaginal discharge?
Explanation:
Bacteria vaginosis 

Caused by Gardnerella  vaginalis and mycoplasma hominis-  These two organisms are able to proliferate (e.g. due to antibiotic therapy) and replace the natural vaginal microflora leading to the following symptoms:

• Vaginal Discharge (grey/white)

• Fishy vaginal odour

• ‘Clue’ cells on microscopy

 

Diagnosis

High vaginal swab and microscopy and culture of discharge Amsel's criteria for diagnosis of BV

- 3 of the following 4 points should be present

• thin, white homogenous discharge

• clue cells on microscopy: stippled vaginal epithelial cells

• vaginal pH > 4.5

• positive whiff test (addition of potassium hydroxide results in fishy odour)

Question: In a myocardial infarction, usually one of the main coronary arteries is occluded. Which of the following is the most common coronary blood vessel blocked in MIs?
OptionA: The anterior IV (LAD) branch of the Left Coronary Artery
OptionC: The circumflex branch of the left coronary artery
OptionD: The posterior IV branch of the Right Coronary Artery
OptionE: The circumflex branch of the Right Coronary Artery
Explanation:
1. The anterior IV (LAD) branch of the LCA (40-50%)

2. the RCA (30-40%)

3. the circumflex branch of the LCA (15-20%)

4. the LCA

5. the posterior IV branch of the RCA

6. The circumflex branch of the RCA

Question: A 5 year old boy is playing in the garden with his grandma. The game consists of the boy giving an object for grandma to hold, and to try and guess what the object is with her eyes closed. The boy finds it funny because grandma can't seem to guess anything right, from a tennis ball, to a bucket, and even a sandwich, she has no clue! Taking this into consideration, in which functional area of the cerebral cortex would you expect to find a lesion?
Explanation:
Lesions in the somatosensory association cortex can lead to asterognosia (inability to recognise objects by touch). There is no loss of tactile of proprioceptive sensation (as there would be in a primary somatosensory lesion); but the integration of visual and somatosensory information is impaired. 

 

An individual with asterognosia is unable to identify an object by active touch of the hands without other sensory input, such as visual or sensory information. They are unable to identify objects by handling them, despite intact elementary tactile, proprioceptive, and thermal sensation. With the absence of vision (i.e. eyes closed), an individual with astereognosis is unable to identify what is placed in their hand based on cues such as texture, size, spatial properties, and temperature. As opposed to agnosia, when the object is observed visually, one should be able to successfully identify the object.

Question:
A 75 year old man is an in-patient on your ward. He has been taking antibiotics for an infection and this has now cleared up. He was being considered for discharge until he developed an infectious intestinal disease.

 

After considering the most likely causative organism in this situation, which part of the GI tract is primarily affected?
Explanation: The most likely causative organism in this situation is C. dif because this is a healthcare acquired infection and he has recently been on antibiotics. C. dif classically affects the large intestine primarily.

Question: A man has a stroke, with occlusion of his right anterior cerebral artery. Which is the most likely deficit he will show?
OptionA: Impaired sensation and hemiplagia in left lower limb
OptionB: Impaired sensation and hemiplagia in right lower limb
OptionC: Impaired sensation and hemiplagia in left face and left upper limb
OptionD: Impaired sensation and hemiplagia in right face and right upper limb
OptionE: Impaired sensation and hemiplagia in right face and left upper limb

Question: How is otosclerosis typically inherited?
Explanation:
o Otosclerosis – autosomal dominant inherited condition.

• Replacement of normal bone of ossicles (particularly the stapes) by vascular spongy bone.

• Impairs movement of stapes and therefore transmission of sound waves into inner ear.

• Features – conductive hearing loss, tinnitus (ringing sensation).

• Autosomal dominant, replacement of normal bone by vascular spongy bone.

Onset is usually at 20-40 years - features include:

• Conductive deafness

• Tinnitus

• Tympanic membrane - 10% of patients may have a 'flamingo tinge', caused by hyperaemia

• Positive family history

• Trigger post pregnancy

 

 Treatment is with stapedectomy and insertion of a prosthesis

Question:
You are a nurse working on a hospital ward. You have had to take some time off work due to a viral GI infection. 

 

How long should you wait after your last episode of diarrhoea before returning to work?
Explanation: If you work in a healthcare setting you should wait 2 days after your last episode of diarrhoea before returning to work. This is because there are big issues around transfer of infection from staff and visitors causing infection among patients.

Question: What is semantic memory best described as?
A 44-year-old man has just been diagnosed with a particular virus. This virus is a positive sense, ssRNA virus that uses DNA intermediates with reverse transcriptase. Which virus is it?
Explanation: HIV and hepatitis B are the only two which use reverse transcriptase activity, but hepatitis B is a double stranded DNA virus.

Question:
A patient has presented with bulky, pale and offensive smelling diarrhoea. They say that the have experienced a reduced appetite and nausea, which they think has caused them to lose weight. You notice that they also have some abdominal bloating.

 

You suspect that they may have a protozoal infection with Giardia and request a stool microscopy to confirm this.

 

What would you be most likely to see on stool microscopy in this infection?
OptionB: Oocysts may be seen using a modified ZN stain
OptionD: Trophozoites may be seen in fresh stool
OptionE: You would not perform stool microscopy for this infection
Explanation:
B - this is for Cryptosporidium

D - correct - would only see the trophozoites in fesh stool as they don't survive outside the host. A cyst is also passed in the stool and survives much longer but you would only see this with idodine staining.

E - you would not use stool microscopy for viral infections

Question: As part of Angela Rippon's new series on BBC "The Truth About Dementia", the brains of those with Alzheimer's dementia were compared with healthy brains. Which of the following statements is true in regards to a brain belonging to a patient with Alzheimer's dementia?
OptionC: There are no findings of senile plaques (from deposition of amyloid)
OptionD: The will be lifted sulci (i.e. not flattened)
Explanation:
I've worded this really confusingly, im sorry!

 

Alzheimers disease accounts for roughly 50-60% of patient's with dementia.

Risk factors:

  • female
  • family history
  • head trauma
  • down syndrome (associated with the APP gene on chromosome 21)

 

Neuroanatomic findings:

  • cortical atrophy (global atrophy of the whole brain)
  • flattened sulci
  • enlarged ventricles
  • shrinkage of the hippocampus 

Histopathology:

  • senile plaques (deposits of beta-amyloid)
  • neurofibrillary tangles
  • neuronal loss
  • synaptic loss
  • granulovascular degeneration of neurons

General points:

  • Decrease in ACh (which is linked to memory) and noradrenaline
  • Deterioration generally linear (i.e. slow deterioration) or progressive, with average duration of onset to death being about 8 years.
  • Focal neurological symptoms or deficits are rare (this is what differentiates vascular dementia from alzheimers)

End stage:

  • Bed-ridden
  • No sphincter control
  • Cannot walk
  • Cannot care for themselves - basically like a child again

Treatment:

  • Includes long acting cholinesterase inhibitors such as tacrine or donepezil
  • Risperidone (atypical antipsychotic) and other high potency antipsychotic meds ma be helpful in low doses to decrease agitation

On a side note, the Angela Rippon series is brilliant, I'd definitely recommend it! Although I doubt anyone will want to be watching/doing anything medical after June 9th!

Question:
A 23 year old female has been experiencing a number of symptoms, including abdominal pain, diarrhoea, weight loss and mouth ulcers. Her GP suspected Crohn's disease and referred her to the hospital for colonoscopy to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Which of the following combination of findings would most likely be seen if this diagnosis is correct?
OptionA: Continuous lesion in the jejunum, transmural lesions, cobblestoning
OptionB: Continuous lesion in the large intestine, lesions affecting only the mucosa
OptionC: Continuous lesion in the large intestine, transmural lesions, cobblestoning
OptionD: Skip lesions throughout the GI tract, lesions affecting only the mucosa, cobblestoning
OptionE: Skip lesions throughout the GI tract, transmural lesions, cobblestoning
Explanation:
B - Ulcerative colitis

The others are combinations of things seen in UC and Crohn's and aren't correct for either.

E is for Crohn's - any part of the GI tract can be affected, from mouth to anus, and the lesions seen are transmural meaning that they affect the full thickness of the intestinal wall. Cobblestoning is most commonly seen in Crohn's and looks like this:

Question: It is nearly lunchtime and you are feeling very hungry. You know that there are many neurotransmitters that increase appetite, which is the most potent?
Explanation:
Leptin is a peripheral long term SATIETY signalling molecule.

Grehlin is a peripheral orexigen from the GI tract.

 

MCH and orexin and the 2 main orexigens released from the satiety center (lateral hypothalamus) in response to NPY from the arcurate nucleus. They cause the release of AGRP, the terminal potent orexigen.

Question: Which of the following conditions has the most heritability?
Which of these is a positive symptom of schizophrenia?
Explanation:
Positive symptoms

Catatonia

Formal thought disorder 

Hallucinations-usually of an auditory nature

Delusions

 

Negative Symptoms 

Anhedonia 

Alogia

Affective flattening 

Asociality 

Avolition

Question: You are a doctor assessing an unconscious patient. You decide to see whether your patient's cerebral hemisphere is intact. You pour some cold water into his left ear. What would a normal response be?
OptionA: Eyes deviate away from the cold water, nystagmus away from the cold water
OptionB: Eyes deviate away from the cold water, nystagmus towards the cold water
OptionC: Eyes deviate towards the cold water, nystagmus away from the cold water
OptionD: Eyes deviate towards the cold water, nystagmus towards the cold water
Explanation:
A normal response when the ear is irrigated with cold water is for the eyes to deviate towards the cold water. This is because cold water effectively reduces the vestibular output from one side, creating an imbalance and causing eye drift towards the irrigated ear. Nystagmus is an attempt to restore the eyes to the middle. 

Neurology and neurosurgery illustrated - page 65

 

Here is a video - I recommend watching from 24 seconds!

 

 

(Hot water does the opposite, but I wouldn't bother learning both).

Question: What is the main component of the nucleus pulposus?
Explanation:
o Nucleus pulposus

• Central portion of the intervertebral disc that is surrounded by the annulus fibrosis

• Composed of type II collagen, water, and proteoglycans • Approximately 88% water

• Hydrophilic matrix is responsible for height of the intervertebral disc

• Characterized by compressibility

• a hydrated gel due to high polysaccharide content and high water content (88%)

 

o Proteoglycans interact with water and resist compression

• Aggrecan is a proteoglycan primarily responsible for maintaining water content of the disc

• Viscoelastic matrix distributes the forces smoothly to the annulus and the end plates

• Low collagen / high proteoglycan ratio (high % dry weight of proteoglycans)

 

• Chondrocyte-like cells • Responsible for producing type II collagen and proteoglycans • Survive in hypoxic conditions

Question: What is the resting potential of a normal neurone?
Explanation:
Normal Neurone=-70mV

Ventricular Myocyte=-90mV 

SAN=No resting potential as such but repolarisation is usually lower than -40mV as that is the threshold

Question: What is cardioversion?
Which of these is not an indication for induction?
Explanation: D is a contraindication for induction!

Question:
You are a GP having a consultation with a patient who frequently travels abroad for his work. He has come to you because he has been struggling due to lack of sleep and is unsure what is causing this. You attempt to explain to him about Circadian rhythms and how these are disrupted in jet lag. He is a very inquisitive gentleman and continues questioning you about how this works. You end up explaining to him about the region of the brain that is the main pacemaker for these endogenous rhythms.

 

What is the name of this brain area?
Explanation:
The suprachiasmatic nucleus is the main pacemaker for endogenous rhythms. It controls Circadian rhythms. 

It is a small group of cells located in the hypothalamus and lies just above the optic chiasm. It can receive information directly from the eye and the rhythm can be reset by the amount of light entering the eye.

The SCN sends projections to hypothalamic nuclei and the pineal gland to control body temperature and cortisol levels.

Question: What is the meningitis signs that displays severe neck stiffness which results in neck flexion causing a patient's hip and knees to flex in response?

A 55 year old woman presents with a recent history of increased thirst, polyuria and weight loss. A urine dipstick shows ++glucose ++ketones. She tests positive for Islet Cell antibodies and has a Random Plasma Glucose of 20.1mmol/L. What is her likely diagnosis?
Explanation: Don't rule out Type 1 diabetes because of her age. According to the 'Pathophysiology of Diabetes' lecture Type 1 can affect anyone aged 6 months - 70 years. The big clue in this question is the presence of Islet Cell Antibodies which suggests autoimmune islet cell destruction as seen in type 1. This question is taken from the end of case SBAs for case 10.

Question:
You are performing a mental state examination on a 23 year old male patient. You ask him about how his social life is at the moment. This is how he responds:

 

"I have some friends...Friends was a great TV show don't you think....my TV broke the other day I'm so bored... "

 

This is an example of what?
Explanation:
A - when speech production and requires a lot of effort, associated with damage to the anterior portion of the left hemisphere

B - problem with form of thought, long-winded way of talking, take a long time to answer questions because they keep getting side tracked by other information but eventually reach the point

C - accelerated flow, logical connections between thoughts, goal of thought not maintained

D - no association between one part of the sentence and the next

E - go off on tangents and never reach the point

Question:
You are a GP and a 21 year old male comes to see you. He has no history of any mental health problems.

 

He says that he has been feeling down recently, his mood has been pretty low. He previously loved to socialise with his friends but he is no longer interested in this and he doesn't find it fun. He has also found that he doesn't feel like eating much. As well as this, he has difficulty concentrating on his studies.

 

Based on the ICD-10 classification of depression, and the patient's description of his symptoms, which of the following is most correct?
OptionA: He fits the criteria for mild depression
OptionB: He fits the criteria for moderate depression
OptionC: He fits the criteria for severe depression
OptionD: He fits the criteria for somatic syndrome
Explanation:
Core symptoms - he has low mood and anhedonia

Associated symptoms - he has reduced concentration/attention and reduced appetite

Therefore he fits the criteria for mild depression - 2 core, 2 associated

B - 2 core, 3 associated

C - 3 core, 4 associated

D - when 4 or more of the following are present: anhedonia, decreased range of emotional reactivity, early morning waking, diurnal variation (worse in morning), psychomotor agitation/retardation, loss of appetite, weight loss >5% in the last month, loss of libido

Question: The umbilical vein forms what adult structure after birth?
Explanation:
The correct answer is B!

 

Also known as the ligamentum teres - or  ligamentum teres hepatis

Question: Hodor?
Explanation: Hodor
Tags: Bone, Cardiovascular System, Immunology, MSK, Mental Health

Question: Jeanette is back in the kitchen again. This time whipping up some fancy cupcakes. She reflected on all the Hypoglycaemic patients she could save with the sugar content in her gorgeous Crumbs and Dollies cupcakes. What is the minimal threshold of blood glucose before someone enters hypoglycaemia?
Explanation:
You'll be lucky if you managed to get a hand on those. They taste really good!!!

 

4.0 mmol/L is the answer. 

 

If you're wondering the flavours of the cupcakes are:

1) Pandan Gula Melaka Cupcakes (My favorite Malaysian-inspired flavor! Try it and you’ll thank me later)
2) Banoffee Pie Cupcakes and
3) Strawberries and Cream Cupcakes (cos it’s (almost) summer time!)

Question: You encounter a patient, who is an ex smoker of 15 pack years and has presented with severe breathlessness, lethargy and a chronic cough. Suspecting COPD, you perform spirometry and find that his FVC/FEV1 ratio is 0.5 and his predicted FEV1 % is 42%. What stage of COPD is this patient at?
Explanation:
FEV1 (of predicted) > 80%

Stage 1 - Mild**

 

50-79%

Stage 2 - Moderate

 

30-49%

Stage 3 - Severe

 

< 30%

Stage 4 - Very severe

 

FEV1/FVC (<0.7) is only used to determine that one has COPD. %FEV1 is used alone to determine severity

Question: You are performing an abdominal examination on a patient in your ISCE and notice a number of scars. One of the scars you notice is a mercedes benz scar in the upper abdomen. Which of the following procedures does this most likely suggest that the patient had?
Explanation:
http://oscestop.com/Scars.pdf

 

Recommend this page

Question: You are taking a sputum sample from a patient and see that there is a rusty red colour to the sputum. Which of the following is this most indicative of?
Explanation:
A rusty red colour is most indicative of pneumococcal pneumonia. Asthma can produce yellow sputum (as eosinophils) that is 'purulent' as can an acute bronchopulmonary infection (yellow as live neutrophils are passed in sputum). Asthma sputa can also be white and viscid

 

Chronic Bronchitis-often produces a mucoid-clear or grey appearance.

 

Acute pulmonary oedema typically produces clear and watery sputum

Question:
On one of those unexpected days, Jeanette thought she finally met the love of her life, Juliano. However, Juliano's parents disapproves of Jeanette's upbringing, family background and her Vitamin K deficiency heritage, and offered her £10,000 if she broke up with Juliano. After breaking up with Juliano, as to what seems is their last date, left her devastated inside. 

 

Upon returning to her flat, her heart had some funny rhythms and she soon found herself fallen down the stairs to her flat. She was found unconscious. Hearing this, Juliano rushes to the hospital, to be by Jeanette's side as soon as she wakes up. Unfortunately, Jeanette has lost too much blood from the fall and needed a bone marrow transplant. 

 

Knowing this, Juliano, offered his blood to be sent for crossmatching, which turns out that he was a perfect match. Upon receiving this wonderful news, Juliano thought this might be the perfect time to propose to Jeanette. With great excitement, he expresses his wishes to Jeanette's doctor.

 

"I'm going to marry her!"

"I'm sorry, but you're blood tests not only showed that you are the perfect match for Jeanette's bone marrow transplant, but you're also her cousin."

 

Which blood bottle was used to:

Question 1: crossmatch Juliano's and Jeanette's blood?

Question 2: measure Jeanette's INR?

Question 3: diagnose Jeanette's full blood count?

Question 4: identify the cause of Jeanette's fall?

Question 5: make sure that Jeanette was not suffering from a hypoglycaemic attack?
Explanation:
Pink -> Crossmatch

Blue -> INR values

Purple -> FBC

Yellow -> Troponin, LFTs, U&E, Calcium phosphate

Grey -> Glucose and lactate

Question: After healing from her bone marrow surgery, not long after Jeanette started turning yellow. She thought she was starting to see things, but Jeanette's mum insists it must be due to the medications she has been receiving after her injury. Which of these medications causes drug-induced jaundice?
Explanation:
Flucoxacillin is an antibiotic used to clear Staphylococcus and Streptococci infections. It is also commonly prescribed after surgery, and is also one of the common drugs that causes drug-induced jaundice. 

 

Other drugs that causes drug-induced jaundice are Co-amoxiclav, nitrofurantoin, paracetamol, TB drugs (isoniazid & rifampicin), Steroids, Oral contraceptive pill, and malarial drugs.

Question: Checking a patient's urea and electrolyte levels you see that they have hypernatraemia, but also notice that osmolarity and water volumes in this person are normal. You suspect an inappropriate response to hypovolaemia and commence a fluid deprivation test on the patient. What condition are you specifically testing for her in the patient?
Explanation:
Diabetes insipidus (DI) is a condition characterised by either a deficiency of antidiuretic hormone, ADH, (cranial DI) or an insensitivity to antidiuretic hormone (nephrogenic DI).

The main features of the condition are polyuria and polydipsia

Main investigations include-high plasma osmolality, low urine osmolality and a water deprivation test

 

Classically causes a hypernatraemia, hypercalcaemia and hypokalaemia

Question: You are seeing a lady diagnosed with osteoporosis who has been prescribed bisphosphonates, a drug that acts to reduce the activity of osteoclasts (bone resorption cells). Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities would you cautiously monitor this patient for while she is on her treatment?
Explanation: Hypocalcaemia has three essential main causes-increased renal excretion, some PTH problem or increase in deposition/decrease in uptake. By inhibiting osteoclast action, bisphosphonates promote increased deposition of bone and thus can lead to low calcium blood levels. This is why bisphosphonates can be used to treat hypercalcaemia

Question: You are in your ISCE and are given an ECG of a patient you took a history from-yet they had a respiratory viral infection a few weeks ago and you are confused why they have given you an ECG, even though he has presented with chest pain. All becomes clear when you see the classic ECG pattern and realise the connection. What ECG features is most specific to the condition this patient most likely has?
Explanation: The ECG changes characteristic of pericarditis include- widespread 'saddle-shaped' ST elevation and PR depression, with the latter being the most specific ECG marker for pericarditis. Pericarditis often presents in young people after a history of viral illness.

Question: A 54 year old man presents with collapse. He has been unwell recently with a chest infection for which he has been prescribed clarithromycin from his GP. He also takes medication for his hayfever at this time of year. What is the most likely diagnosis, given the ECG?
Explanation:
This patient has a prolonged QT interval. Medications are the likely culprits in this case: both clarithromycin and the antihistamine diphenhydramine can cause prolonged QT interval.

The normal length of the QT varies with heart rate and there is a formula that is applied to correct for this. ECG machines automatically provide you with this ‘corrected QT’ (QTc). Normal QTc is generally under 480ms. As a rule of thumb, if the end of the QT interval is over over half way to the next QRS then consider long QT.

Question: A 45 year old business man presents with a feeling that his heart is racing. He also has some shortness of breath. This is his ECG. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation: This is atrial flutter. The atria contract at 300 beats per minute causing a ‘seesaw’ baseline. Beats are transmitted with a 2:1, 3:1 or 4:1 block, leading to ventricular rates of 150, 100 and 75 BPM respectively. The rate in this rhythm is about 150 bpm.

Question:
Not too long now, Jeanette started preparing vigorously for her upcoming ISCE examinations. However, while she was running down the staircase, she forgotten that Sheryl just mopped the floor recently. Unfortunately, Jeanette slips and falls forward. Landing on a right flexed wrist and a left extended wrist. 

 

On examination, the doctor advises Jeanette to postpone her ISCE examinations as she suffered from two distinct wrist fractures. What fractures might the doctor be referring to?

 

1. Right wrist

2. Left wrist
Explanation:
Colles ’ fracture – this is a very common wrist fracture and is usually seen in elderly osteoporotic patients, following a fall onto an outstretched hand. The patient typically attends with a painful wrist, which has a ‘ dinner fork ’ deformity and radial deviation of the wrist and hand. The fracture is within 2.5 cm of the wrist joint and has dorsal angulation and displacement of the distal radial fragment. There is frequently an associated fracture of the ulnar styloid. Imaging includes AP and lateral views of the wrist but, if the diagnosis remains unclear, MR imaging may help. If good reduction can be achieved then immobilisation may be adequate management. Complications include damage to the median nerve and extensor pollicis longus which usually require surgical intervention.

 

Smith ’ s fracture – this is a distal radius fracture, where the distal fragment is palmar (volar) displaced and usually results from a fall onto the arm with the wrist in flexion. These fractures are unstable and will most often require open reduction and internal fixation.

 

Barton ’ s fracture – this is a distal radius fracture, which involves the articular surface of the distal radius and therefore predisposes to joint pain, stiffness and osteoarthritis.

 

 

These other typical bone fractures are not specific to the wrist.

Question: In your ISCE, you are given a patient who comes in with pleuritic chest pain and severe heavy breathing and tachycardia. She is pregnant and has recently come back from Australia over a week ago. On determining investigations, you suggest that the gold standard investigation for the likely diagnosis is....
Explanation:
Given the pregnancy and the long haul flight, Pulmonary embolism is the likely diagnosis

The consensus view from the British Thoracic Society and NICE guidelines is that

o Computed tomographic pulmonary angiography (CTPA) is now the recommended initial lung-imaging modality for non-massive PE.

o Advantages compared to V/Q scans include

• Speed

• Easier to perform out-of-hours

• A reduced need for further imaging

• The possibility of providing an alternative diagnosis if PE is excluded

 

o If the CTPA is negative then patients do not need further investigations or treatment for PE

Question: You take a history from a patient from a man presenting with a recurrent, severe headache which is usually unilateral and throbbing in nature. It is often associated with aura, nausea and photosensitivity. The headache attacks are often caused by exercise and routine activities of daily living. A typical attack lasts 5 hours and he has had 4 attacks so far. What Migraine diagnostic criteria does this history best fulfil?
Explanation:
The International Headache Society diagnostic criteria is as follows;

 

A

At least 5 attacks fulfilling criteria B-D

B

Headache attacks lasting 4-72 hours* (untreated or unsuccessfully treated)

 

C Headache has at least two of the following characteristics:

◦ 1. unilateral location

◦ 2. pulsating quality (i.e., varying with the heartbeat)

◦ 3. moderate or severe pain intensity

◦ 4. aggravation by or causing avoidance of routine physical activity (e.g., walking or climbing stairs)

 

D During headache at least one of the following:

• 1. nausea and/or vomiting*

• 2. photophobia and phonophobia

 

E Not attributed to another disorder (history and examination do not suggest a secondary headache disorder or, if they do, it is ruled out by appropriate investigations or headache attacks do not occur for the first time in close temporal relation to the other disorder)

Question: You encounter a patient with Blood pressure 164/100. At 54 years of age they are currently managed with ramipril and have shown no significant change in blood pressure reading in 8 weeks. He has no compliance issues with ramipril. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
Explanation:
Step 2 of NICE guidelines for a patient over 55 and not african american background. Add CCB but also keep ace inhibitor. 

Even if they were African American, your step 2 would be to use both an ACE inhibitor and CCB

Question: You are seeing a patient with COPD who has come with acute breathlessness with mild exertion and a worsening of cough. He wants antibiotics but as you are a strict GP, you tell the patient that according to NICE guidelines you can only give antibiotics if .....
OptionA: You present as you are now presenting, with a clear respiratory infection, as I shouldn't need to perform any investigations given your grave appearance
OptionB: Your FEV1 has reduced to less than 50% predicted
Explanation: It is common practice for all patients with an exacerbation of COPD to receive antibiotics. NICE do not support this approach. They recommend giving oral antibiotics 'if sputum is purulent or there are clinical signs of pneumonia. The most common cause of exacerbation in COPD is haemophilus influenza bacteria

Question: A young lawyer presents with tension headache. For treatment at the time, you prescribe aspirin for a week. However, the patient wants some prophylaxis advice. Which of the following is the recommended NICE prophylactic treatment for a tension headache?
OptionB: Combined Oral contraceptive pill for females, Propanolol for males
Explanation:
NICE currently recommend 'up to 10 sessions of acupuncture over 5-8 weeks' for tension headache prophylaxis.

 

Low-dose amitriptyline is widely used in the UK for prophylaxis against tension-type headache.

NICE guidelines do not however support this approach '...there was not enough evidence to recommend pharmacological prophylactic treatment for tension type headaches. The GDG considered that pure tension type headache requiring prophylaxis is rare. Assessment is likely to uncover coexisting migraine symptomatology with a possible diagnosis of chronic migraine.'

Question: Methotrexate is often used first line in patients with rheumatoid arthritis as a Disease Modifying Anti-Rheumatoid medication. What is the mechanism of action of the drug?
OptionC: Acts as a decoy receptor for TNF-α
OptionD: Anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody, results in B-cell depletion
OptionE: Triggers a fusion protein that modulates a key signal required for activation of T lymphocytes
Explanation:
A is correct; C to E describe the actions of various monoclonal antibodies 

 

Methotrexate is an antimetabolite which inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, an enzyme essential for the synthesis of purines and pyrimidines
